HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Declines Broadly On Fears of Lower Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar sank against all major foreign currencies yesterday in a slide prompted by widespread speculation that United States interest rates were headed lower. Trading volume was heavy. ''The dollar came under intense pressure,'' said John McCarthy, chief currency dealer at the Amsterdam-Rotterdam Bank's office in New York. ''We saw a pretty substantial selloff. Volume was very, very heavy. I would characterize it as brisk with a capital 'B.' '' 
The setback for the dollar came after the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, said that if a credible budget-deficit reduction accord was reached between White House and Congressional negotiators, then the central bank would be inclined to relax its monetary policy.
 
How Dollar Would Lose Appeal
An easing in Fed policy would lead to lower United States interest rates, a development that would be bearish for the dollar. A decline in United States rates - especially after Japan pushed up its rates - would make the dollar less appealing to investors because it would reduce returns on dollar-denominated holdings.
Many analysts have been urging the Fed to follow an easier monetary policy to reinvigorate the failing economy.
The dollar started its trading day in Tokyo by stumbling against the Japanese yen. It fell to a closing 137.65 yen, from 138.30 yen at Wednesday's close. It was the lowest closing level in Tokyo since Aug. 3, 1989, when the dollar finished at 136.40 yen.
In London, the dollar fell to 137.25 yen. And it continued to lose ground in later New York dealings, ending the session at 136.25 yen, down from 138.08 yen late Wednesday.
 
Sharp Drop Against Mark
The dollar did not fare any better against the German currency. It tumbled more than 2 pfennigs, to 1.5680 marks in late New York dealing, from 1.5915 marks late Wednesday.
The British pound benefited from the dollar's weakness. In London, the pound rose to $1.8770, from $1.8650 late Wednesday. A pound fetched $1.8825 late yesterday in New York, compared with $1.8590 a day earlier.
Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.3025 Swiss francs, down from 1.3290; 5.2520 French francs, down from 5.3303; 1,170.00 Italian lire, down from 1,187.75, and 1.16175 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16355.
 
Gains for Gold Prices
Gold prices posted modest gains on world markets.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, an ounce of gold for September delivery gained 80 cents to settle at $382.90. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $384.00 an ounce, $2.50 higher than Wednesday's late bid.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $384.00 an ounce, from $381.75 late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold rose to $383.40 an ounce, from $381.75 late Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.62 an ounce, to $381.82.
Silver had a mixed day. The metal rose on the Comex, with the contract for September delivery closing at $4.773 an ounce.

HEADLINE: In Combating Crime, Veterans Find a Home

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
In October 1967, when a United States Army patrol was pinned down by enemy fire at Loc Ninh, Pfc. Otis Caldwell volunteered to repel the attack, allowing the wounded to be evacuated and winning a Bronze Star in the process. Now he relies on some of the same instincts honed in distant jungles to try to reclaim the streets and subways that many New Yorkers think have become a war zone.
Each weeknight Mr. Caldwell, 43 years old, leads a platoon of ex-servicemen through the dimly lighted parks and rattling trains in and around Long Island City, Queens. While their forays may trigger memories of recon missions, the locales are vivid reminders of their onetime homes of last resort, because these men are also veterans of homelessness.
They are the Veterans Civilian Observation Patrol, a neighborhood group operating under the auspices of the 108th Precinct, and they are fighting to make streets safe amid a surge of conspicuous violent crimes in New York City that has left innocent people senselessly killed and the city outraged. 
The patrol members' efforts have earned them plaudits from the police and citizens, and one honor more prized than any medal - a place to call home. This weekend Mr. Caldwell and 22 other patrol members, or VCOPS, as they call themselves, will leave their cots at a shelter for homeless veterans and move into apartments in the Prospect Heights section of Brooklyn.
For these men, many of whom have waged protracted battles with drugs, the work has been a therapy that has let them tap newfound sources of strength and pride. ''Once you get back your self-esteem, you're on the road to recovery,'' said Mr. Caldwell, himself a recovering alcoholic.
The patrols leave each weeknight at 10 o'clock from the 108th Precinct station house in Long Island City and head east into the neighborhoods. One recent night pedestrians did quick double-takes as two dozen men wearing their trademark green T-shirts began their patrol through Sunnyside, Queens. In pairs they strode down both sides of the street, stretching from corner to corner. ''We walk with lots of space so people won't think we're a gang,'' said Bruce Weems, a Navy veteran whose broad, bulging biceps carried tatoos of a cobra and his initials.
Two point men led the way and cast darting glances into shadowy doorways, ready to alert others to any potential problem. Every few minutes they pivoted with arms raised to signal all clear, then waited until the entire squad responded in kind. Should any patrol member stand still with his arms at his side, it signals he has spotted something or someone suspicious.
 
Reassuring Sight
The sight of these men steadily advancing up the streets would appear to be enough to deter anyone with criminal intentions. As the patrol members slowly fanned out toward the perimeter of a local park recently, five youths emerged from the darkness and quickly crossed the street while glancing warily over their shoulders. Inside the park, the few remaining people appeared relieved to see the patrol.
''Sometimes a lot of things go down around here and it's nice to have these people watch out,'' said a 23-year-old woman who identified herself only as Kelly. ''They're here more than the cops are, and if something goes down they're here before the cops.''
The men routinely ride the No. 7 line to Sunnyside and walk through neighborhood streets back to Long Island City, although sometimes they will take the train back to the Hunters Point station and walk through the grimy, maze-like exits that lead to a desolate stretch of warehouses, factories and weed-covered lots.
Mr. Caldwell, who has been a patrol member since February and commander since May, left the Army in 1969 with two Bronze Stars, the Purple Heart and chronic pain from a bullet that ripped through his side and exited through his left leg. The citation for the Bronze Star he won at Loc Ninh described how, armed with only M-16's, he and others braved rocket and machine-gun fire to keep the enemy back.
 
Years of Alcohol
Eight years ago he abandoned his job as a maintenance man at a college to pass his days in an alcoholic haze that landed him first in a detoxification center and later at a homeless shelter. Sober for nine months now, he said that he held no bitterness toward others for his predicament and that all he is owed is a chance to make a fresh start. His patrol work, he said, is a way to do that.
''Compared to Vietnam, the subways are a picnic,'' he said. ''The difference is at least in Vietnam we had backup.''
Mr. Caldwell and the other VCOPS said they are a disciplined group that has rarely needed to use their fists. Their job is simply to observe suspicious activity and report it to the police. This summer they stopped two muggings and four times followed suspects to their hiding places, where the police made the arrests.
''These are guys who are willing to come out and put a little out for people who probably haven't put out themselves,'' said Sgt. John McCluskey, a narcotics officer at the 108th Precinct.
In 1988, residents of Long Island City were not willing to tolerate the Borden Avenue Veterans Residence, a city-financed shelter run by the Salvation Army. They complained that homeless men were drinking and urinating in the nearby vest-pocket parks and side streets. Officer Fran Kinkowski, the precinct's community affairs officer, decided to solve two problems by incorporating some of these veterans into the precinct's community patrol program. Since the original 13 recruits cleared the area of troublemakers and eased community opposition, 90 men have been patrol members.
More recently, the group spun off the Veterans Service Corps, a not-for-profit organization that seeks to provide housing, training and drug rehabilitation for the patrol members. Russell Hicks, formerly a social worker at the Borden Avenue shelter, started the service corps in response to what he thought was a paucity of services for homeless veterans.
Mr. Hicks persuaded a landlord in Brooklyn to allow the Veterans Service Corps to rent a refurbished building of 16 cozy studio and duplex apartments, complete with varnished wood floors, smooth white walls and spacious tile bathrooms. Rents will range from $595 for a studio to $695 for a two-person duplex. The men who have jobs will pay the rent from their wages; those who are unemployed, from public assistance. Mr. Hicks expects the rent to be partly offset by funds from a contract he is negotiating with the local office of the Department of Veterans Affairs.
 
Giddy as Short-Timers
In the days before the move into their new apartments, the patrol members had the nervous, giddy enthusiasm of short-timers, the military slang for men about to be discharged. On visits to the neighborhood - a section of Prospect Heights where robbery and drug-related crimes are above the city average, the police say - Mr. Caldwell and his men have already been welcomed by some residents.
While the area is fraught with many of the temptations and obstacles that caused their downfall, the veterans said they weren't going to dwell on the possibility of repeating mistakes.
''The VCOPS made me ready to step back into society and showed me that by following the rules I can make it,'' said Warren Kelley, 35, who has been a patrol member since June.
Before leaving his old command, Mr. Caldwell passed the mantle of leadership to Billy Reeves, a boyish-looking veteran who will continue to live at the shelter and recruit new VCOPS while the others begin a new patrol in Brooklyn. ''I'm sorry I can't carry all of you guys now,'' Mr. Caldwell said as he paced the room. ''But it'll happen to you the same as it happened to me.''

HEADLINE: SOUTER SEEMS SURE TO WIN APPROVAL, KEY SENATORS SAY

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
As Judge David H. Souter ended his second day of questioning by the Senate Judiciary Committee, some members and their top aides expressed agreement today that he was virtually assured of winning a positive vote from the committee barring some unforeseen development.
This was underscored publicly in discussions today, when several committee members spoke to him as if his winning confirmation from the full Senate and joining the Court were a foregone conclusion.
 
An Open-Minded Approach
Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, went so far as to suggest how Judge Souter might use his vacations from the Court to enrich his experience, like visiting an Indian reservation. The committee chairman, Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat who had been expected to be a tough and skeptical questioner, called him a ''soon-to-be Supreme Court Justice.''
For his part, Judge Souter sought to assure the committee that he would take an open-minded approach to sensitive issues like abortion and affirmative action, even as he continued his policy of avoiding comments on how he might rule on specific cases. 
Mr. Souter, who has spent most of his adult life as a state court judge and as Attorney General and Deputy Attorney General of New Hampshire, seemed to take care to address, in his two days of testimony, each of the issues that critics said make him ill-suited to serve on the Court. He was only recently named a Federal appeals court judge, Returns to Roe v. Wade Yesterday, Judge Souter politely but firmly cut short an effort by Senator Biden to explore his views of the rights of privacy on the ground that it would lead to a discussion of his views of Roe v. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court ruling that established a legal right to abortion. He said such a discussion would be inappropriate. [Excerpts from the hearing are on page 10.] Today, he returned to the issue in a more forthcoming but still ambiguous way, saying that he had no ''private agenda'' on how to vote on the issue of Roe v. Wade. ''I will listen to both sides of that case,'' he told Senator Herb Kohl, Democrat of Wisconsin. ''I have not made up my mind.''
He spoke expansively of the Supreme Court's role in furthering affirmative action programs to help minorities overcome past discrimination. He also offered deep praise for Justice William J. Brennan Jr., the longtime leader of the liberal wing on the Court, who retired this summer and whose seat Judge Souter would assume.
''Justice Brennan is going to be remembered as one of the most fearlessly principled guardians of the American Constitution that it has ever had and ever will have,'' he said in response to a question. Some members seemed moved by the remarks.
Several Senate aides said that Judge Souter's carefully balanced performance over the last two days virtually assured that he would avoid the rejection that befell Judge Robert H. Bork in 1987.
 
Testimony to End Monday
Judge Souter is expected to complete his testimony on Monday, his 51st birthday. After that, the committee will hear from a variety of witnesses, including some abortion rights groups that oppose him because they say he failed to assert that the right to an abortion recognized by the court in 1973 is fundamental and not open to debate. The hearings are expected to end next week, after which Senator Biden will schedule a committee vote.
In a private meeting with abortion rights advocates this morning, Senator Simon said Judge Souter had provided little in his first day of testimony on which to oppose him. Participants at the meeting said that Senator Simon, facing a re-election battle, also said that Judge Souter seemed to have come across well to the public, in marked contrast to Judge Bork's performance three years ago.
After today's session, Kate Michelman, the executive director of the National Abortion Rights Action League, said her group had no choice but to oppose Judge Souter's nomination. ''For the first time in history,'' she said, ''the Supreme Court is on the brink of taking away a fundamental right - the right to choose,'' and Judge Souter has not given assurance he recognizes that right.
At the hearing, as he questioned Judge Souter, Senator Simon remarked that he liked to spend time in places like Indian reservations to enrich his personal experience and he suggested that Judge Souter adopt a similar practice after he is on the Court.
 
'I Don't Believe That'
Judge Souter was asked by Senator Simon about having been quoted in a New Hampshire newspaper in 1976 as having equated affirmative action with ''affirmative discrimination'' before a college audience.
Judge Souter said that he hoped the quote was inaccurate ''because I don't believe that.''
He said that it should go without saying that ''there will be a need - and I am afraid for a longer time than we would like to say - a need for the affirmative action which seeks out qualified people who have been discouraged by generations of societal discrimination from taking their place in the mainstream and in all of America.''
He said that when discrimination was proved in the courts, the proper response was not to simply say ''stop doing it,'' adding, ''the appropriate response is to say ''undo it'.''
In response to a question from Senator Biden, Judge Souter said he was not talking simply about providing redress for an individual who experienced discrimination, but more broadly as in ''an identifiable class.'' His answers, nonetheless, leave questions about how far the government may go in fashioning remedies and he said the issue will be ''played out in constitutional litigation for some time ahead of us.''
The issue of abortion dominated the hearings again today. Senator Biden tried again with little success to have Judge Souter reveal his personal philosophy about the issues of privacy that underly the abortion ruling.
But in answering a question from Senator Kohl, Judge Souter said, ''I have not got any agenda on what should be done with Roe v. Wade if that case were brought before me.''
 
Criticism From Kennedy
While Judge Souter was treated gently by most committee members, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, portrayed the nominee as hard-hearted and overly legalistic. He said that one of Judge Souter's decisions while a State Supreme Court Justice was ''hostile and heartless.'' It involved a case in which the court upheld the denial of unemployment compensation benefits to two brothers, aged 76 and 78, both of whom were infirm and said they only wanted to work four hours each day, splitting a single job as they had done for years.
Judge Souter was also questioned closely today by Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont and others about his efforts to defend a proclamation Gov. Meldrim Thomson in 1978 that the flag be flown at half staff to commemorate Good Friday. In his brief as Attorney General, Mr. Souter said the state order did not violate the the Constitution's prohibition against the state furthering religion because Jesus was being honored as a historical, rather than religious, figure. Judge Souter agreed it was an unconstitutional proclamation.
Senator Leahy asked if it was proper for him to have taken a position so obviously unconstitutional. In response, Judge Souter said that he was representing the Governor and that he had an obligation to defend that position. ''I was hired on as a lawyer,'' he said.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: Ripples From the Gulf/A Special Report;
Crisis in the Gulf Hits Home: 'Everything is Different'

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TWENTYNINE PALMS, Calif.

 BODY:
Business is all but nonexistent at the three tattoo parlors in this desert town, which is home to the nation's largest Marine base. The dry-cleaner nearest the base has laid off 15 workers and cut its hours in half.
A note on the window of Ernie's weight lifting room announces that it will be closed on weekends and, ''In honor of our military, will remain closed until they return.''
In varying degrees, the military buildup in the Persian Gulf 8,500 miles away is affecting day-to-day life throughout the United States.
 
A Backdrop or Intrusion
In some places it is merely a backdrop - the yellow ribbons and American flags that line the main shopping street in Houston, for instance, or the videotaped messages from members of the armed services that are broadcast on television. 
Elsewhere, the mobilization is more of an intrusion, interrupting established routines in often unexpected ways. In Beaumont, Tex., Frances Foux has given up her lunch hour to bring cases of sodas to soldiers at the local port who are loading ships destined for the Persian Gulf. They remind her of her brother who was killed in Vietnam.
In still other places the mobilization has brought an unexpected boom in business for companies that make products useful for fighting a desert war. The Gatorade plant in Newport, Tenn., for example, is adding extra shifts to meet the growing orders from the military. So far, nearly 100,000 cases have been shipped to the Gulf.
 
Some Feel the Strain
And then there are the people and places for whom life has been turned upside down. People like Tracy Ross in places like Twentynine Palms.
At John's Hamburgers, which was nearly empty despite the noon hour, 5-month-old Derek Ross squealed with delight as Mrs. Ross, 23, dangled a set of Marine dog tags for her son's amusement. Derek's father, Danny, left for the Persian Gulf in mid-August, and Mrs. Ross said she was feeling the strain of life without her husband.
''Everything is different now,'' she said. ''Everything is harder.''
This Southern California town, 70 miles east of San Bernardino in the Mojave Desert, exists almost solely because of the Marine base. About 12,000 people live on the base and 13,000 others live around it. Although the Marine Corps refuses to say how many troops from which divisions have left this base and others around the the country, Karen Van Hout, a spokeswoman for the Chamber of Commerce, said it is fairly easy to figure out who is no longer in Twentynine Palms. The Seventh Marine Expeditionary Brigade, which has 4,000 men, was the first to leave, she said. It was followed by the First Force Service Support Group and the Third Light Armored Infantry Battallion.
''We don't know exactly how many have left,'' said Linda Jones, whose husband, Maurice, shipped out early in September. He left just two weeks after their hastily arranged wedding, which had originally been scheduled for next Valentine's Day. ''The better question is, 'Who's still here?' There are no men older than 18 and younger than 40.''
Mrs. Jones, who works as a visiting nurse, said the women have formed support groups. They ''help a little,'' she said, ''but they don't bring him home.''
 
The Better to Keep Busy
Some of the group meetings are structured and official, with information on emotional counseling and advice on balancing checkbooks. More often the gatherings are for pot-luck suppers or picnics with the children, the better to keep busy.
Suddenly, life in Twentynine Palms centers on the mail. Mrs. Jones said a trying day became a happy one recently when the Marine Corps relaxed rules that restricted the size of packages that could be sent to the troops in the Gulf. Now she is looking for the perfect tape recorder to send to her husband so she can replace her written letters with her voice and be able to hear him in return.
Mrs. Ross said she had written to her husband daily since he left, but is not certain how many letters have reached him. She has only received a handful from him so far, she said, and one was addressed to Derek.
''It said all the things a daddy wants to tell his son in case he doesn't come back,'' she said, jangling the dog tags faster and giving the baby a watery smile. ''I read it to him.''
 
An Unsettling Emptiness
There is the same unsettling emptiness at other military towns across the country, too. Nearly one-third of the 40,000 people in Hinesville, Ga., near Fort Stewart, has been sent to the Persian Gulf. In Killeen, Tex., near Fort Hood, pistol sales boomed, then dropped as soldiers bought weapons for their families before they departed.
At the courthouse in Bell County, where Fort Hood is situated, 325 marriage licenses were sold in the first two weeks of August; normally, the rate is 20 to 30 a week. Now it is back to normal.
In San Diego, local pizza restaurants are frantically advertising for drivers because pizza delivery was a popular side job for many marines from Camp Pendleton. Now most of them are gone.
In nearby Oceanside, Calif., Oscar Culp said he feels that the flow of the days is out of sync. Mr. Culp, who was a marine for 25 years, serving in World War II, Korea and Vietnam, now owns the CMC Furniture store in Oceanside.
Pay days at Camp Pendleton are on the 15th and 30th of the month, he said, and he could tell it was pay day without looking at his calendar. He would watch the buses filled to standing room with soldiers who came to town to have a a haircut, go shopping or retrieve items left in pawn shops between paychecks. In recent weeks, he said, the buses from the base are virtually empty.
 
At Guardsmen's Homes
 
Some Uncertainty But No Regrets
In smaller pockets around the country, far from military bases, equally dramatic disruptions of life are taking place.
In Detroit, Roger Wojtylko has lost the ability to plan his business. A staff sergeant in the Michigan National Guard, Mr. Wojtylko was called to active duty for two weeks. He was then released, but knows he might be called again at any time.
Mr. Wojtylko builds and remodels houses, and he has had to return deposits to 15 customers since the call-up began because he has no way of knowing whether he can complete a job. Since his National Guard pay is as sporadic as his call-up schedule, he and his two daughters, 6 and 15 years old, are living on his wife's salary as a bus driver.
Farther north, in Vienna Corners, Mich., Victor Briley is facing the same uncertainty. Mr. Briley, a first lieutenant in the Michigan National Guard, was called to active duty in mid-August. As a result he has postponed plans to double the size of his auto repair shop. While he is gone, his wife tackles the ledger books after she completes her regular job as a waitress, and one of his three employees runs the day-to-day business.
Neither Mr. Wojtylko nor Mr. Briley say they have any regrets about their decision to join the Guard, despite the disruption it is now causing them. They did not enlist for the money or on a whim, they said, but to serve their country and to challenge themselves.
''I'm a very patriotic person,'' Mr. Wojtylko said. ''I was in Vietnam. I don't want to leave home unless I have to, but if I have to, I have a commitment to supporting my Government.''
Mr. Briley agreed. ''I don't mind being called up,'' he said. ''It's a challenge. This is an opportunity for my unit to prove what it can accomplish.''
 
At the Workplace
 
Business Is Sweet And Bittersweet
For every place that has become unsettled since the partial mobilization, however, there is another that has been made more stable. The activity in the Persian Gulf is giddy news in some parts of the country, like the oil states of Texas and Oklahoma. With oil selling for more than $30 a barrel, there is optimism in those states on a level not seen in several years.
Engineered Support Systems in St. Louis has been laying off employees in the past year because of cuts in Government contracts for the water purification units that the company manufactures. In recent weeks the company has rehired 25 employees and might need to recall as many as 200 more.
At the Artesia bottled water company in San Antonio, bottling machines are working 20 percent longer each week now that Artesia has received a contract to supply water to parched troops in Saudi Arabia.
Beau Price is quenching thirst another way in thanks for his more modest increase in business. His T-shirt company has sold 2,000 shirts with a picture of an Iraqi soldier riding a camel and being attacked by American troops. The slogan: ''I'd fly 10,000 miles to smoke a camel.''
Many of the shirts were sold to soldiers working at the port, and in appreciation he is using some of the profits to buy cases of soft drinks for the troops in Saudi Arabia.
When business improves, so do hundreds of lives. Randy Hudson, for instance, is a 30-year-old welder in San Antonio who has a wife, two children and a mortgage. He had worked at Fairchild Aircraft for five years before he was laid off in January when the company filed for bankruptcy.
 
'Big Reunion' at Fairchild
The chapter 11 proceedings were almost complete when the mobilization began and Fairchild received a $3.86 million contract from the Air Force to manufacture special vests that are hooked up to air-conditioning units.
Now Mr. Hudson is one of 60 employees that the company has called back to work. It plans to hire 30 more.
Returning to Fairchild after nine months of sporadic jobs welding race cars and worrying that he would lose his house was ''like a big reunion,'' he said, adding, ''We're happy to be working up a sweat so the guys over there don't have to.''
Often, however, this jubilation has a bittersweet side. At Survival Technologies, also in St. Louis, Alice Jennings and Catherine Kinnard are among the 180 workers who produce 95 percent of the nerve gas antidote in the West.
Since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the company has rushed the delivery of an 85,000-piece order and has received a second order for $6 million. The company would not give specifics on the size of the order, but 40 people have been added to the staff so far and 25 more are needed.
But Mrs. Jennings and Mrs. Kinnard are not happy that business is going so well. Both have sons in the military, and as they fill the antidote canisters and ship them out both mothers realize that their sons might need the pen-sized applicators someday.
''Every day when we leave we feel like we've accomplished something,'' Mrs. Kinnard said. ''I think I'd feel the same if I didn't have a son.''
Mrs. Jennings said: ''I hope he never has to use what we make. I hope they leave it on a shelf and it gathers dust.''
 
'The Lucky Ones'
 
Other Things On Their Minds
At the businesses that are struggling, at the ones that are reborn and in the households that are praying for relatives and friends in the armed forces, it may seem impossible that there are people who have not been affected at all by the Gulf crisis.
But for some people - Mrs. Ross, waiting for her husband to return to the Marine base at Twentynine Palms, calls them ''the lucky ones'' - there are jobs to worry about, bills to pay, and concerns like crime that seem more personal and more urgent.
Two New York City police officers near Times Square looked slightly baffled recently when they were asked if the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait had altered their daily lives.
''We work in Times Square,'' said Officer Jeff NcNamee. ''That's what's on our minds.''
His partner, Officer Joe Guinn, said: ''It hasn't affected us. We got our job to do at home. The soldiers got their job to do over there.''
Fifty blocks uptown, at Broadway and 93d Street, sales at the Cunningham Newstand have not increased because of Saddam Hussein. But they did rise noticably last week when Time magazine ran a cover story about New York's social and economic problems, said Marc Salih, the newsstand manager.
 
Social Issues Take Precedence
''People here are concerned with social issues, not the Middle East,'' he said. ''My worry is to keep the business going. You can't worry about things on the outside.''
Sherri Baker, a 25-year-old Boston housewife, echoed this sentiment. ''I don't read about that stuff,'' she said as she flipped through the pages of The Boston Herald and waited for her husband to return from an errand.
When asked what she reads instead, Mrs. Baker took the pink hairbrush she was holding and pointed to an article about local prison releases. ''I read stories about convicted killers being released,'' she said, ''because I want to know where they are.''
Across the street, 15-year-old Carlos Caballo, a student at Boston High School, was standing outside the school board building. ''I didn't know anything was going on,'' he said when asked about the Persian Gulf. ''I don't read the news.''
What does occupy his thoughts? ''Jobs, girls, clothes,'' he replied. ''Stuff like that.''

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Saturday about the Persian Gulf confrontation's impact on America misstated the reasons for layoffs at Engineered Support Systems of St. Louis. It laid off workers earlier in the year because of delays receiving Government money and the prospect of reduced military spending.

PUB-DATE: September 15, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1207 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
AMERICAN WARSHIP FIRES A WARNING AT IRAQI TANKER

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
American and Australian warships fired warning shots before boarding an Iraqi tanker in the Gulf of Oman today in a coordinated action to enforce the trade embargo against Iraq, Administration officials said.
The Iraqi ship refused to stop and allow the Americans and Australians to board until the shots were fired. After the boarding party found that the tanker, the Al Fao, held no cargo, the ship was allowed to sail on to the southeastern Iraqi port of Basra.
While other ships have been boarded, the incident today was the first forcible boarding of a vessel in the Persian Gulf crisis. It was also the first time shots had been fired by Americans in the region since the United Nations Security Council adopted a tough resolution last month that Washington has interpreted as allowing the use of force to block shipping to and from Iraq. The resolution was long sought by the United States. 
 
Further Pressure on Embassies
As the boarding of the vessel was reported, Iraq put further pressure today on the 15 or more nations that have refused to close their embassies in Kuwait since Iraq invaded the country on Aug. 2. France announced that Iraqi soldiers stormed the French Ambassador's residence, seizing the military attache and three other French nationals. The attache was released later, but the other three were being held at an undisclosed location. [Page 4.] Pentagon officials also disclosed today that the United States had agreed to sell Saudi Arabia $20 billion in advanced weaponry, trucks, F-15 fighters, and surface-to-air missiles over the next several years. The purchase, which exceeds previous estimates of its value, will be the single largest foreign sale of arms in American history. [Page 5.] President Bush, discussing the boarding of the Iraqi tanker, said the naval action was taken ''in accordance with the United Nations resolutions, in accordance with the sanctions.'' He said the shots were fired because ''it required a bit of a warning before the captain pulled over and permitted the boarding party to have a look.''
Asked if the events today in the Gulf region put the United States any closer to war, Mr. Bush replied: ''I wouldn't put it closer to a war situation. I still hope that this matter can be peacefully resolved. And the way for that to happen is for Iraq to comply with the sanctions.''
 
'I'm Not Rattling Sabers'
But Mr. Bush added a warning.
''When an escalation is required of me, Saddam Hussein will know it,'' he said. ''I'm not rattling sabers. When I rattle a saber, the man will know it.''
The naval action today was unusual in that it demonstrated coordination between vessels of separate nations. The sailors in the boarding party came from two frigates, the American ship Brewton and the Australian ship Darwin.
Each of the navies of more than a dozen countries that have contributed ships to the armada normally have functioned independently. A Pentagon spokesman said there had been only a few joint boardings before this one. The Pentagon did not say how the joint action was organized, and whether the United States was in command.
Besides entering the French Ambassador's residence, Iraqi forces also broke into the Belgian diplomatic compound and the residence of the Canadian Ambassador, where the consuls of the United States, Canada, Ireland, Australia and Britain were seized and then quickly released. The American diplomat was accredited to Baghdad, and all of the others were accredited to Kuwait City.
 
'Hussein Against the World'
After the break-in, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada said: ''This is not a conflict between Arabs and the West, nor is it a conflict between Iraq and the United States. It is Saddam Hussein against the civilized world.''
About 10 American diplomats remained in the United States Embassy, where electricity and water have been cut off since Iraq annexed Kuwait nearly a month ago.
President Bush said he had not yet determined how long he would keep the embassy open. The diplomats remain to underline the point that the United States still recognizes Kuwait as a sovereign country, and to keep in touch with hundreds of Americans who remain trapped there.
At a brief news conference at the White House, President Bush said, ''These developments not only underscore the brutal behavior of Iraq, but also the international support that exists and is marshaled against Iraq's occupation of Kuwait.''
 
'Grateful to Japanese'
Reflecting the Administration's pleasure that Japan and West Germany have pledged billions of dollars in new aid to help the international buildup in the gulf, President Bush praised the two nations, which have been heavily criticized by members of Congress in recent days for what has been perceived as their modest support for the embargo and defense of Saudi Arabia.
Administration officials had expressed concern that the perception that the United States was ''going it alone'' in the gulf would diminish popular and Congressional support for the gulf operation in the weeks and months to come.
''We are grateful to the Japanese,'' said Mr. Bush, who said he had spoken by telephone with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu on Thursday night. ''Specifically, Japan will be providing significant economic assistance to key countries in the region that are most severely affected by the sanctions and higher energy prices.'' $4 Billion Pledged A substantial portion of Japanese aid, which currently amounts to pledges totaling $4 billion, will go to Jordan, Egypt and Turkey, countries that will lose billions of dollars worth of trade, service fees and worker remittances as a result of the crisis. Mr. Bush said another portion of the Japanese aid package will go to the forces ''in the collective defense effort.''
Britain, Italy and Canada also pledged to bolster their efforts in the gulf. London said it would send an additional armored brigade of more than 120 tanks and 6,000 combat troops. Canada committed 12 fighter jets and a total of 450 airmen to the effort. And Italy told the visiting Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, that it would send eight Tornado jets and an additional frigate to join the three Rome has already deployed to the gulf.
Despite Mr. Bush's enthusiasm for increasing signs of foreign support, Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, said today that the Germans and the Japanese would have to do more to help countries that have suffered economic setbacks because of the crisis in the Persian Gulf. Mr. Nunn, perhaps the most influential member of Congress on military matters, called on the Japanese to ''get off their wallet.''
The naval incident today also marked the first time that American forces had fired warning shots at an Iraqi ship and then boarded the ship. Last month, American ships fired warning shots twice at Iraqi vessels, but the ships did not stop and were not forced to do so. There have been about 35 other boardings of Iraqi ships, but none of those ships have been shot at.
The Iraqi ship boarded today had messaged the allied ships that it was on its way to Basra. A Pentagon spokesman said the allied commander grew suspicious about the ship's cargo because it would not obey orders to stop.

LENGTH: 805 words

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS Good News Takes Care

BYLINE: Flora Lewis

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
It's all done but the parades. D-day, ''Deutschland-day'' in Eurojargon, is Oct. 3. United Germany will elect its first postwar government Dec. 2. There will be no more occupation rights but certain obligations.
This has been settled without a peace treaty, not for the same reason that none was possible for 45 years; just the opposite. Before, the four powers that occupied Germany after World War II could not agree on its future. Now they have agreed among themselves not to bother assembling all the states that declared war on Germany, although the other European states will have a chance to endorse the settlement in the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe in November. 
When the conference's accords were signed in Helsinki in 1975, they were intended as a substitute for the unachievable German peace treaty. Seemingly it was a ratification of partition, but they also provided for human rights and military rules that gradually eased the division of Europe. For a number of years after, Helsinki was denounced by American conservatives as a giveaway to Moscow. It worked the other way around.
The new treaties (German-Soviet and German-Polish pacts will be added to the package) also have several anomalies that could have blocked final agreement. Though all of Germany will be part of NATO, covered by its guarantees from the date of unification, Soviet troops will remain in the eastern part until the end of 1994. Bonn will pay the cost of maintaining and repatriating them.
Other forces in Germany will not be allowed on eastern territory, or paid. Germany's Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the key architect of the settlement, was asked why the unequal treatment. ''They are our friends,'' he answered in surprise. ''We want them to stay.'' In the new climate after the cold war, sticking points can be brushed aside. When governments decide accord is more important than digging in, they reach it and that's that.
Late last November, President Francois Mitterrand of France was still saying German reunification ''is not on the agenda.'' But the ice thawed so fast that the flood of events carried away the hesitant. Like the end of all eras, it begins another, uncertain and problematic.
The dilapidation and economic decay of East Germany, supposedly the most successful of Communist states, and the coming cost of rehabilitating it have been a surprise. That means the rest of Eastern Europe, without benefit of a rich brother, is in for an even harder time than Flora Lewis's column will now appear on Wednesdays and Saturdays. current pessimists foresee. On their own, they could barely take stock of what is needed. They will have neither the expertise nor the solid social-political framework that the former Federal Republic will provide the former Democratic Republic.
Even many in Bonn share European worries that the vacuum will be filled by German enterprise and influence, establishing an unchallengeable power beyond constraint, though it be democratic and non-aggressive. Germany will emerge so flourishing that it has no reason to push, but its leaders are aware that if too much fear is provoked it could lead to new anti-German coalitions.
The antidote has to be greater effort by others - in Europe, the U.S. and Japan - to join in bringing in the East, so that inevitable dependence during the long transition years is spread. This is not just a matter of competing with Germany; it is in the interest of all concerned to keep a balance and an open Europe.
There are worrisome signs that the time lag between the European Community's economic and political consolidation and the new Germany's organization will undermine emergence of a larger union. It is pointless to argue that the Deutsche mark would dominate a single E.C. currency; it dominates anyway. The issue is whether its authorities operate alone or must listen to partners. The U.S. should urge Britain particularly to take the plunge, not stand aside.
This is no time for Americans to carp at German resistance to using its military. Bonn has been slow to respond to solidarity needs in the Persian Gulf crisis, but manpower should not be its contribution. It is ironic that the treaty ending World War II for Germany comes when it is so strong, but that is not cause to forget the reason for its self-limitations.
Though they come when a cruel new aggressor threatens tragedy in an area of strategic importance to the world, Europe's optimistic perspectives must be safeguarded and supported. It took a long, dangerous time to reach this watershed. Resolve and statesmanship brought success, and are still needed to assure peace and democracy in Europe.
Good news can come almost as suddenly as bad news. Making it hold and bear fruit requires almost as much care as facing down the foe.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

LENGTH: 335 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Details of Japanese Aid

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Government officials, offering new details about Japan's $4 billion Middle East initiative, said today that Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu would soon seek legislation to enable thousands of Japanese to serve in noncombat roles in the region.
But because of the time involved and difficulties in obtaining approval of the legislation, officials said it could take months for any Japanese personnel to arrive in the gulf.
Indeed, the Japan Socialist Party, the leading opposition group in Parliament, said tonight that it would oppose the idea of forming a ''peace cooperation team'' under Japanese or United Nations auspices. The Socialists lead an opposition coalition that controls the upper house of Parliament. 
Mr. Kaifu's Cabinet today formally adopted a $3 billion package of aid to the international effort in the Middle East, made in addition to the $1 billion package announced two weeks ago.
Of the total, half is intended to assist the military mobilization led by the United States, and the other half will go for economic assistance for Jordan, Turkey and Egypt.
Officials acknowledge that it could take months for the money to be spent, and that in the case of the economic assistance for Middle Eastern countries, it could take years because the bulk would go to build factories, roads and other projects.
Disclosure of the plan for Japanese personnel to go to the gulf was seen as another in a series of concessions this week intended to mute criticism in the United States that Japan was not doing enough to help the international effort after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. In particular, Japan has been assailed in Congress for pledging only money, without being willing to put its people at risk to insure a free flow of oil.
Japanese officials said that some of the teams to be sent to the region could be medical personnel or other noncombat specialists from the Japanese military forces who would take leaves of absence and be temporarily transferred to other agencies.

PUB-DATE: September 15, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Page 5, Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1206 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Assad Assures Baker of Support in Gulf

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. 14

 BODY:
President Hafez al-Assad assured Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today that Syria was prepared to keep sending forces to protect Saudi Arabia from Iraq. But he urged Washington to continue to seek a political rather than a military solution in the Persian Gulf.
Officials said that Mr. Baker asked President Assad, who is traveling to Teheran on Saturday, to use his influence to persuade the Iranians to abide by the United Nations sanctions against Iraq and to stifle their calls for a ''holy war'' against the American presence in the Gulf.
The Secretary of State and the Syrian President met for almost four and a half hours, two more than scheduled, in Mr. Assad's downtown office. Mr. Baker was accompanied only by Edward P. Djerejian, the United States Ambassador, and the State Department translator. President Assad was joined by his Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa. 
 
Baker Fills In Bush
Their meeting was the first between a senior American official and the Syrian President since the December 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, which United States intelligence agencies widely believe was carried out by a Syrian-sponsored Palestinian organization. Mr. Baker telephoned President Bush in Washington shortly after the meeting with Mr. Assad to brief him on the results.
Mr. Baker also made what was probably the toughest statement yet by a Bush Administration official on terrorism, which apparently occupied a significant portion of the Baker-Assad meeting. He asked Syria to expel terrorists; Mr. Sharaa said this would be done if there was sufficient evidence.
At a press briefing, Mr. Sharaa stressed that President Assad believed that ''it is very important for everyone to pursue a political solution to the gulf crisis. Not a military one. For the time being, we believe that the adherence to the Security Council resolution is very important to achieve a political solution.''
The fact that the Syrian leadership forcefully urged the United States to seek a diplomatic solution at this time probably reflects a concern that the Assad regime's opposition to the Iraqi invasion is not entirely popular at home.
 
Fear of Recolonization
Western diplomats here say that the Syrian public is largely ambivalent about the gulf situation - uncomfortable with Iraq's invasion, but having little sympathy for the Kuwaitis, who they consider arrogant and unresponsive to previous Syrian aid requests.
Moreover, the presence of so many Western troops in the gulf region has raised suspicions among many Syrians that the West is looking for an opportunity to re-colonize the Middle East.
The main purpose of Mr. Baker's visit, American officials insisted, was symbolic. By meeting with President Assad, Mr. Baker sought to draw attention, particularly in the Arab world, to the fact that one of the most hard-line Arab nationalist regimes is joining the American-led multinational coalition against Iraq.
Syria's participation legitimizes that coalition in Arab eyes in a way that no other country could, American officials say. The Administration has been worried from the start that President Saddam Hussein would break out of the boycott by convincing the Arab public that he is really fighting the Americans and just a few Arab ''lackeys.''
Mr. Baker used his news conference after the meeting with Mr. Sharaa to insure the symbolism of his visit was not lost. After Mr. Sharaa expressed his desire for a political solution, the Secretary interjected:
''We talked as well about the importance of this being an Arab solution. And one thing I think which is demonstrated, if I may say so, by the fact of my presence here today is that this is indeed a largely Arab solution that we are trying to implement.''
 
'Arabs at the Forefront'
Egypt is contributing forces, Mr. Baker noted, all of the Persian Gulf nations are contributing their forces, Morocco is contributing forces and Syria is contributing forces.
''There are Moslem nations that are non-Arab who are contributing forces,'' he added. ''So I think it is important for people, particularly in this part of the world, to realize that Arabs are at the forefront of the solution to this problem.''
The Syrians have already dispatched 3,000 men to Saudi Arabia and 1,000 to the United Arab Emirates, and today Mr. Sharaa declared that ''Saudi Arabia can ask for Syrian troops and we said that we will respond to any Saudi request.''
''There was no ceiling on the number of troops, which was very much the desire of the Saudis,'' he continued, ''and we will respond positively to any request.''
American officials say that for now the Syrians are prepared to send an armored division of up to 15,000 men and 300 tanks and armored vehicles. But so far the Syrian pledge has not been carried out, in part because of a lack of transportation ships and planes, and there was no prediction on when the Syrian troops might move. There were rumors in Damascus that the Soviets would provide the transport, but they could not be confirmed.
The Saudis and Kuwaitis have promised Damascus a multibillion-dollar aid package in return for the Syrian troop deployment, and the Syrians are also hoping for backing from the European Economic Community and Japan.
 
Baker Cites 'Terrorism'
After some muted comments earlier in the week about Syria's involvement with terrorism, Mr. Baker, with Mr. Sharaa standing by his side, told Syrian and Western reporters:
''We share a common purpose with respect to problems in the gulf. But we make no secret about the fact that there are still problems revolving around this question of terrorism. Our policy cannot and never will be amoral. We can have close relations only with countries that share our fundamental values.''
Mr. Baker renewed Washington's request that Mr. Assad expel from Syria the Damascus-based Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, headed by Ahmed Jabril.
The group is believed to have carried out the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 on a contract from Iran and with the knowledge of Syria.
He said that Syrian-American relations could not be normalized until such action takes place. Mr. Sharaa responded: ''We made it very clear that if there was hard evidence to link any person or group staying in Syria with any terrorist acts then those responsible will be placed on trial.''
The Central Intelligence Agency and West German intelligence have amassed more than circumstantial evidence linking the P.F.L.P.-G.C. with the Pan Am bombing. As Mr. Baker tersely put it, ''there is a disagreement between us on the sufficiency of the evidence.''
One of the surprises of the news conference was the ease with which the Syrians seemed to sign on, in public, to the Bush Administration's insistence that there be no linkage of a settlement of the gulf conflict and a settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict.
Otherwise, Washington argues, President Hussein would be able to claim that his invasion produced at least a diplomatic gain for the Arabs.
''Let me make it clear to you,'' Mr. Sharaa told reporters, ''that I don't believe there is a linkage between the two questions. We are not linking the gulf crisis with the Arab-Israeli crisis at all.''

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Safety Standards Being Tightened For Garage Doors

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
As deaths and injuries continue in accidents involving automatic garage doors, the Federal Government, states and manufacturers are moving to tighten safety standards. Forty-five children and 3 adults are known to have died in door accidents since 1982, and 27 children and 6 adults were hurt.
Most of the children who died, all of them 14 years old or younger, suffocated because garage doors failed to stop their descent and reverse when they touched the children. Automatic doors are operated by portable transmitters or buttons mounted on an inside wall of the garage. The doors can be opened and closed from inside or outside the garage. 
''This is a problem people don't know about,'' said Shawn M. Bartsh, a lawyer from St. Paul who has represented families of children who died after being trapped under garage doors. ''You don't consider your garage door as something that could kill your child.''
Here are some of the fatalites caused by automatic garage doors that were described in a July report by the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission:
* In 1982, a 4-year-old boy was crushed in Dayton, Ohio, by a door installed without an automatic reverse mechanism.
* In 1985, a boy, 2, in North Platte, Neb., suffocated when he became trapped under a door.
* And in 1989, a boy, 8, in Grand Rapids, Mich., was asphyxiated when he was caught between the door and the garage floor.
Minnesota, where garage-door openers are widely used, passed the first state law this year setting mandatory standards for door-opening systems. The California Legislature has approved a similar measure that is now awaiting the Governor's signature. And a Federal bill to provide mandatory standards has been introduced by Representative Gerry Sikorski, Democrat of Minnesota.
''We must protect children all over this country from the potential dangers of unsafe opener systems,'' Mr. Sikorski said. ''Without a fail-safe device, parents can be fooled into believing their garage-door opener is operating safely, when the reverse mechanism is actually defective.''
The Door Operator and Remote Controls Manufacturers Association says the automatic openers are ''one of the safest products in American homes.'' The group notes that about 40 million American homes are fitted with them and that they have been marketed for more than 40 years.
Safety experts say garage doors are the largest, heaviest piece of moving equipment in the home. About 1.5 million openers are sold each year, at prices ranging from $100 to $175, excluding installation.
 
Door-Opener Makers to Meet
Underwriters Laboratories has called a meeting with door-opener producers at its Northbrook, Ill., headquarters on Sept. 26 and 27 to discuss upgrading its voluntary standards to improve the safety reverse features. And the National Safety Council and the producers' group have declared October National Garage Door Safety Month.
The Consumer Product Safety Commission has never proposed mandatory safety requirements for garage-door openers. But it does issue news releases urging homeowners with children between the ages of 2 and 14 to be especially careful when automatic openers are connected to their doors.
Carl W. Blechschmidt, a program manager at the commmission, said the agency would not issue a regulation ''unless we think it is needed and can make the findings necessary to support it.''
Thus, until the Minnesota law, opener standards have been strictly voluntary and have largely been a result of the programs of Underwriters Laboratories. The first U.L. safety standard for door openers was established in 1973. Improvements were added in 1975 and again in 1982.
Manufacturers say that more than 95 percent of the openers produced today meet the 1982 standard, known as U.L. 325. But the Minnesota Safety Council says that as many as half of the systems in use may not comply.
 
Other Mechanisms
''It won't hurt to add another level of protection,'' said Don Grob, a U.L. engineer, who was referring to the discussions with manufacturers scheduled for later this month. ''We're looking to do anything we can that is technically possible and economically producible.''
Three kinds of additional reversing mechanisms are under consideration, he said: an electric eye at floor level, an infrared or ultrasonic motion detector and a switch that trips when the door hits something.
The Minnesota law requires all automatic garage-door openers sold or repaired in the state to conform to the U.L. standard by next Jan. 1. Two years later, openers sold in the state must be built in such a way that any failure of the reversing mechanism prevents the entire system from operating.
Manufacturers say they, too, are concerned about safety. ''Every death is a problem and a concern,'' said John E. Clark, the president of the manufacturers' group. ''We are all continuing to work toward quality, reliability and safety.''

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Early Gold Climb Trimmed; Corn and Wheat Fall Again

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The gold market remains sensitive to Mideast developments but to a lesser extent than in the early days of the conflict, analysts said yesterday after gold posted modest gains amid unsettling news from the region.
Gold futures settled $2.20 to $2.30 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange, with the contract for delivery in September at $385.10 a troy ounce. Silver was 2.3 cents to 3 cents lower, with September at $4.75 an ounce. 
Gold rallied strongly at midday on news that American sailors fired a warning shot at an Iraqi tanker and then boarded the vessel briefly. But the gains were quickly scaled back despite higher crude oil prices and lower stock prices, two factors that have tended to support gold during the six-week-old conflict.
Higher oil prices suggest the United States inflation level could rise, prompting investors to buy gold as an inflation hedge.
Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with Paine Webber Inc. in New York, said gold was near the top of its recent trading range, which ran from about $370 to $390 an ounce, and some traders were reluctant to buy until the market showed it had enough strength to go above $390.
He added that gold also might have been held back by the weakness in silver prices, because of abundant supplies, and by selling linked to the expiration of October gold options.
Corn and wheat futures, meanwhile, extended their losses on the Chicago Board of Trade while most soybean futures advanced, mostly in a continuing reaction to Wednesday's Government crop report. The Agriculture Department report contained higher than expected estimates of 1990 American corn and wheat production and predicted that the nation's soybean stockpile would continue to dwindle.
Joel Karlin, grains analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago, said wheat futures were also put under pressure by Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter's pledge to oppose an increase in crop set-aside acreage as a means of stemming a slide in wheat prices.
Mr. Yeutter told a farmers' group in Chicago that taking more crop acreage out of production would ultimately make the United States less competitive in the world market.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher After Middle East Flare-Up

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished modestly higher against most major foreign currencies in United States trading yesterday after news of a flare-up in the Middle East conflict abruptly reversed an earlier slide.
Initially, the dollar moved lower as trading opened in New York, continuing a trend based on a bearish United States economic outlook. Government reports released early in the session confirmed that deteriorating economic conditions are being accompanied by rising inflation. 
The Labor Department reported that the Producer Price Index jumped 1.3 percent in August, mostly as a result of steep oil price increases. Separately, the Commerce Department said retail sales dropped six-tenths of a percent.
The figures did not surprise financial markets but they added to pessimistic economic data.
It is widely expected that the Federal Reserve Board will modify its monetary policy to revive growth. If the central bank pushes down interest rates, demand for dollars and dollar-based investments will decline.
But currency traders put aside their economic concerns when news broke that United States and Australian Navy ships had fired warning shots, halted and then boarded an Iraqi tanker in the Gulf of Oman.
That news, plus earlier information about Iraqi troops breaking into the French Embassy residence in Kuwait City, spurred dollar purchases.
Robert Gruber, senior corporate trader at Chemical Bank, said United States trading was hectic and volatile before settling down, as it usually does on Fridays. He said once it became apparent that an actual shooting war was not breaking out in the Middle East, the dollar buying subsided.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 136.55 Japanese yen, from 137.65 yen at Thursday's close. It was the lowest closing level since Aug. 3, 1989, when it was 136.40 yen. Later, in London, the dollar fell to 136.65 yen. But in New York the dollar ended dealings at 136.45 yen, up from 136.25 yen late Thursday.
The British pound rose to $1.8980, from $1.8770 late Thursday. The pound climbed in New York also, ending the session at $1.8930, compared with $1.8825 late Thursday.
Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with late quotes on Thursday, included: 1.5695 German marks, up from 1.5680; 1.2990 Swiss francs, down from 1.3025; 5.2565 French francs, up from 5.2520; 1,171.75 Italian lire, up from 1,170.00, and 1.16505 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16175.

HEADLINE: Oil Nears Highest Price Since Invasion by Iraq

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Oil prices rose further yesterday, and now stand at their second-highest level since the Iraqi invasion. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude for October delivery ended the week at $31.76 a barrel, up 69 cents for the day and $1.72 for the week.
Since Aug. 1, the day before the invasion of Kuwait, the price is up by 43.7 percent. It reached its post-invasion peak of $31.93 on Aug. 23. 
The increase came despite a comment from President Bush at an impromptu news conference that oil supplies were adequate and prices were too high.
 
Gas Price Down
Product prices fell, with gasoline for October delivery off 3 cents, to 90.36 cents a gallon, and heating oil down 0.69 cent, to 82.79 cents a gallon.
The Energy Department estimated yesterday that higher oil prices and a sluggish economy could push domestic demand lower by 500,000 to 700,000 barrels a day in the fourth quarter. Gasoline consumption could fall by 140,000 barrels a day in the fourth quarter and the first quarter of next year, compared with periods a year ago, said the department. Those drops would represent a decline of about 2 percent.
International oil experts said supplies were rising from Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and elsewhere. But the Oil & Gas Journal, a trade publication, reported that further production declines were likely in this country.
Traders pointed yesterday to scattered unfavorable news. The United States Navy fired a warning shot across the bow of an Iraqi ship that American and Australian sailors then boarded, and Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait City broke into several embassies. Robert E. Martini, a trader at Cargill Investor Services, also cited an announcement by British Petroleum that a pipeline under the North Sea that normally carries 420,000 barrels a day from the Ninian field would be limited to 350,000 barrels a day for about a week, until mechanical problems could be corrected.
 
Orders to Sell
Mr. Martini said price rises were being limited by clients who had placed standing orders with their brokers to sell at prices in the current range. Many people, he said, have contracts that entitle them to buy more oil than they need, at prices below current ones. ''They are looking to take profits,'' he said.
The President, speaking at the news conference, said speculators were causing higher prices. ''The market should not be going for higher prices,'' he said. ''In other words, it's speculation; it's futures speculation.''
As for increasing supplies, Robert P. Boslego, a consultant in Winchester, Mass., said that short-term tanker charters from the Middle East and globally were up about 30 percent over early August. These charters represent only a fraction of the total tanker traffic, but accurately forecast the direction of the shipping trend, he said.
At Cambridge Energy Research Associates, Daniel Yergin, the president, said Venezuela had already increased its production by 200,000 to 250,000 barrels a day. ''It's not something that happens overnight,'' he said. ''It takes several months and a lot of effort.'' In Venezuela's case, this often means firing up equipment that injects steam into one end of an oilfield, pushing the oil toward wells at the opposite end.
 
Venezuela Sells Stored Oil
Vahan Zanoyan, an expert at the Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington consulting firm, said that Venezuela, in addition to sharply increasing production, had sold large amounts of oil from storage.
Additional supplies are dribbling in from elsewhere. The Petroleum Minister of Gabon, Jean Ping, said yesterday that his country had raised production to 80,000 barrels above its former OPEC quota, The Associated Press reported, and would raise it an additional 25,000 barrels.

HEADLINE: Stocks Drift Lower Again; Dow Falls 18.56

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices drifted lower again yesterday in continued slow trading as unsettling news from the Middle East drove up the price of oil another notch.
Although a new flood of economic data showed that the economy was moving deeper into recession, hardly anyone seemed to pay much attention to anything but the price of crude.
With many traders nervous about what the weekend will bring in the Persian Gulf, the Dow Jones average of 30 blue-chip stocks tumbled 18.56 points for the day, to 2,564.11, making the week's loss 55.44. 
While still sluggish, trading activity rose to 133.4 million shares, from 123.4 million on Thursday. Some 1,008 stocks declined and 171 hit 52-week lows while 472 advanced and 8 hit 52-week highs. Birinyi Associates said heavy program selling clipped nearly 31 points off the Dow for the day and 148 for the week.
 
Mideast News and Rumors
''There's so much conflicting news and rumors about what's happening in the Middle East, it's confusing to figure out what's going on,'' said Peter G. Grennan, head of stock index futures trading at Shearson Lehman Brothers.
He related that crude prices increased in Europe after unconfirmed reports that one of the Soviet Union's biggest pipelines had shut down for unscheduled maintenance. ''No one knows if it's a real rumor,'' he said.
''That stuff drives you nuts. The next day you sift through the news and find out where you stand. But during the day, it's difficult.''
Looking at the market from a purely technical stance, Joseph A. Feshbach, director of technical market analysis for Shearson Lehman Brothers, remarked, ''Oil's up and bonds are down, so we have a weak market.''
Noting that the Dow slid to a ''climactic low'' of 2,483 on Aug. 23, he said: ''You have to retest the lows. History teaches us that the first rally, of the last two weeks, always fails.''
 
Testing the Low
Typically, he went on, the market comes down to test the low. ''This usually leads to a more sustainable rally.''
This means that the market ''should come down some more,'' he said, ''maybe to around 2,500 or a tad under,'' which would mean a drop of an additional 64 points or so.
Mr. Feshbach argued that at that point the market ''should engage in a short-term bottoming process and then turn up - and give a better rally in the fourth quarter.''
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said the Fed might ease monetary policy if Congress produced a ''credible, enforceable'' budget package and long-term rates came down, but Mr. Feshbach maintained that his views for the moment were not moving the market.
''What he thinks about doing,'' he said, ''is not important at this point. All that matters is oil prices are up, which suggests that long-term interest rates will move higher. When oil prices stop going up, then long-term interest rates will stop going up -and that'll help the stock market.''
Digital Equipment, the computer giant, slid 2 7/8, to 56 3/8, after tumbling 2 3/8 on Thursday. It topped the Big Board's active stocks, trading 2.2 million shares and dropping to a 52-week low of 54 3/8. Furman Selz downgraded it Thursday and others followed.

HEADLINE: Industrial Production Declines 0.2%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Industrial production fell two-tenths of 1 percent in August, its worst performance in four months, the Government said today in a report that analysts characterized as another indication of continued lethargy in the manufacturing economy.
''The industrial side is clearly signaling a slumping economy,'' said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a New York government securities dealer.
It was the Government's first report on factory activity since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. But the manufacturing economy was sluggish long before that, growing a meager 1.5 percent during the last 12 months, the Federal Reserve Board said. August's decline was the worst since an equivalent decline of two-tenths of 1 percent in April. 
 
Capacity Usage Down
In a companion report, the central bank said the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities -which usually moves in tandem with industrial production - fell four-tenths of a percentage point, to 83.1 percent. The operating rate measures not only output but also changes in productivity levels.
''It's consistent with the other data,'' including the manufacturing employment figures and the National Association of Purchasing Management index, said Evalina Tainer, senior domestic economist with the First National Bank of Chicago. ''It continues to show the manufacturing sector is quite sluggish.''
The Labor Department reported last week that 45,000 factory jobs were lost in August. It was the 16th time in 17 months that manufacturing jobs declined.
The monthly survey by the purchasing executives last week showed the manufacturing sector had slowed in August for the second straight month. Their index was down to 47 percent. A reading below 50 percent is considered an indication that the economy is weakening.
In the production report today, only utilities posted a gain, up 1.2 percent. But Gordon Richards, an economist with the National Association of Manufacturers, said the advance came solely from electric power and ''may have been little more than a seasonal factor'' reflecting demand for air-conditioning.
None of the other major components showed a gain.
 
Durables and Nondurables
Manufacturing was off one-tenth of 1 percent, including a drop of two-tenths of 1 percent in the output of durable goods, items expected to last more than three years. Nondurable output was unchanged, and mining production fell 2.3 percent.
The Fed said its industrial production index in August stood at 109.8 percent of its 1987 base, down from 110 percent in July.
In its capacity-utilization report, the Fed said the operating rate at factories producing durable goods fell four-tenths of a percentage point, to 81.4 percent, while the rate at plants making nondurable goods slipped two-tenths of a percentage point, to 83.8 percent.
The operating rate at mines fell from 89.7 percent in July to 87.8 in August, while it gained a percentage point, to 86.9 percent, at utilities.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Up 1.3% in August

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
A surge in oil costs sent wholesale inflation soaring in August, the Government said today, providing the first hard look at how the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait damaged the already weak United States economy.
''If you are leaning toward a recessionary view of the economy, these numbers don't discourage you from that,'' said Nicholas Perna, chief economist at the Shawmut Corporation.
The Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, which measures the cost of goods at all stages of production before they reach consumers, jumped 1.3 percent last month, about as expected, reversing the July decline of one-tenth of 1 percent.
 
Biggest Since January
It was the sharpest climb since a 1.9 percent rise in January, after extremely cold weather caused energy and food costs to soar. 
The Middle East oil shock, the worst in a decade, also caused consumers to close their checkbooks. Retail sales slumped six-tenths of 1 percent last month, after a rise of four-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Commerce Department said.
Analysts had predicted a much smaller drop of about two-tenths of 1 percent. The August number aroused concern because consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of economic activity.
''People are filling up the gas tank, and they have no money left over for much else,'' said Davis Wyss, an economist at Data Resources Inc., a research firm.
Excluding gasoline, retail sales last month showed an even larger drop of 1.1 percent.
A 4.3 percent decline in automobile sales, the largest since January, was crucial in pulling down retail sales. In July, auto sales rose 1 percent.
 
Factory Output Falls
In another sign of a weakening economy, industrial production in August dipped two-tenths of 1 percent, after being unchanged in July, the Federal Reserve Board said. In the last 12 months, factories have increased production at an uninspiring 1.5 percent rate.
''The Fed has to lower interest rates'' to get the economy moving again, said Kathryn Kobe, an economist with Joel Popkin & Company.
But few Wall Street economists expect the central bank to loosen its grip on short-term credit before Congress and the Administration, now locked in budget talks, agree on how to cut the Federal deficit.
''If the only club the Fed has to hold over Congress is interest rates, why throw away the club before you've got something out of Congress?'' Mr. Perna asked.
The central bank is in a predicament: lower interest rates could add to inflation, but many people say the sluggish economy needs cheaper credit to avoid a recession.
''I don't think it can hold off much longer,'' said Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Assocation of Wholesaler-Distributers.
The core Producer Price Index, which excludes the volatile food and energy categories, matched expectations of a moderate climb of three-tenths of 1 percent, the rate it has maintained for much of the year.
 
Up 4.6% So Far This Year
For the first eight months of this year, producer prices have climbed 4.6 percent, slightly above the 4.5 percent rate for the period last year.
But the latest increases in oil prices will push wholesale inflation well above 5 percent for the year, analysts said, as the effects of higher energy prices work their way through costs at all stages of production.
''This is the first installment of bad news,'' Mr. Perna said.
Home heating oil prices at the wholesale level jumped a record 38.8 percent in August, and wholesale gasoline was up 16.9 percent, the Labor Department said.
Food prices also climbed, up eight-tenths of 1 percent. In one hopeful sign, unrefined food and feed prices fell nine-tenths of 1 percent and foods that require some processing fell one-tenth of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Digital's Stock Declines Sharply

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The stock of the Digital Equipment Corporation, the nation's No. 2 computer company, fell sharply yesterday as Wall Street grew increasingly skittish about the minicomputer maker's outlook.
Several analysts have slashed earnings estimates and Digital's shares have tumbled by about $10 a share since last Friday to their lowest level since 1985. Digital shares sank another $2.875 yesterday, to $56.375, and they were the most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange, with more than 2.2 million shares traded.
Some analysts linked the selloff to the fears about demand as the United States economy slows, but others cited deeper product questions about the Maynard, Mass., company. Analysts are worried that the mid-sized VAX 6000, an important minicomputer line for the company, may be squeezed by competitive products from rival computer makers and from Digital's own newly introduced high-end machine.

Bodine was purchased last December by the Toyota Motor Corporation's New York-based subsidiary, Toyota Motor Corporate Services of North America Inc.
