HEADLINE: Once Considered a Sure Thing, California's Environmental Package Falters

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 15

 BODY:
When first proposed, a sweeping California ballot measure that promised a ''bold and comprehensive'' plan to protect the environment seemed a sure winner that could deliver a powerful national message about the public's determination to fight pollution.
But seven weeks before the election, the initiative appears to be in trouble. And environmentalists fear it may prove that voters' willingness to convert noble, abstract notions about the environment into concrete actions may be limited by the potential cost.
''A recession is coming,'' one backer said. ''People get scared when they hear it's going to cost billions of dollars. Until recently I would have said it would pass handily. Now, it just might lose.'' 
The Nov. 6 vote may offer the first public test of the domestic political consequences of the turmoil in the Middle East, which has sharpened public awareness of the trade-offs between energy production and environmental protection, a balancing act that is nowhere more pointed than in automobile-dependent California.
While the initiative still leads in the polls, it has been battered in recent days by reports - vigorously disputed by its backers - that it would cost billions of dollars to local governments and the state and that it would depress agriculture and other industries. The legislative analyst for the City of Los Angeles, for example, estimated that the city's Department of Water and Power would have to spend more than $6 billion just to reduce carbon dioxide emissions.
 
Opponents Focus on Tom Hayden
An advertising campaign financed by chemical and allied agricultural interests has portrayed the initiative as an effort that tries to do too much and promotes the political ambitions of Assemblyman Tom Hayden, the chairman of the steering committee leading the effort to pass it. While Mr. Hayden, of Santa Monica, has long since moved into the Democratic liberal mainstream, the commercials attempt to exploit the public's lingering perception of him from his youthful days as an opponent of the Vietnam War. Those opposing the initiative call it the Hayden Initiative.
The environmental leadership, which calls the measure Big Green, is worried. ''We're on the line,'' said Robert K. Hattoy, regional representative of the Sierra Club here. ''If Big Green loses, it will look like the movement cannot translate the rhetoric of Earth Day into the reality of Election Day.''
Mr. Hayden says this will not happen. ''A tremendous amount of money is flowing from the chemical companies to create a fictional campaign, but we will win in the end,'' he said. But doubts are growing. The campaign is using the same Hollywood hoopla environmentalists used successfully four years ago to pass an initiative to label foods and products containing toxins. On Thursday night, celebrities, including Bette Midler, Robin Williams, Cher, Olivia Newton-John and Meryl Streep, sang, danced and preached for clean air and water, nearly filling the 6,166-seat outdoor Greek Theater in Hollywood and raising about $600,000.
 
'Other Side Is Much Smarter'
''They're blindly going through campaigns of the past,'' said one disaffected backer, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. ''The other side is much smarter. There is a feeling Big Green goes too far and voters do not want to pay a lot of money. There is no groundswell of support.'' A California Poll, an independent, nonpartisan statewide survey taken by the Field Institute Aug. 17-27, found voters favoring the measure by 58-26, but the margin was 49 percent to 35 percent among those who were familiar with it. The poll, with a margin of error of plus or minus five percentage points, also found that 16 percent were undecided. A recent Los Angeles Times poll found support had slipped to 44 percent in favor and 42 percent against; the poll's margin of error was three percentage points.
Political experts say this is ominous because the opposition has not begun its main television advertising assault. The measure is popular in the Los Angeles and San Francisco areas, but not in the politically pivotal San Joaquin Valley, the huge agricultural region, because of fears that curbs on pesticides could injure the economy.
 
Could Influence Governor's Race
For that reason, the measure could play a key role in the governor's race between Dianne Feinstein, the Democrat, and Senator Pete Wilson, the Republican. Ms. Feinstein has endorsed it, hurting her in agricultural areas; Mr. Wilson has not. Jim Costa of Fresno, chairman of the Democratic caucus in the state Assembly, said: ''I told her that if it's a close race and she loses, the reason will be that she did poorly in the San Joaquin Valley because she supported Big Green.''
On the ballot as Proposition 128 and formally known as the Environmental Protection Act of 1990, the measure runs 39 pages and nearly 16,000 words. It would substantially rewrite California environmental law, imposing standards far more stringent than Federal law, including these:
* All pesticides and herbicides known to cause cancer and reproductive harm would be phased out and the sale of imported produce containing residues of those substances would be banned unless they presented ''no significant risk'' to health.
* Emission of ''any gases which may contribute, directly or indirectly, to global warming,'' including carbon dioxide, would be reduced by 40 percent by the year 2010.
* Manufacture of chlorofluorocarbons would be phased out to protect the ozone layer.
* A $300 million bond fund would be created to buy ancient redwood forests, limit clear cutting of timber and require developers to plant trees.
* All oil and gas drilling in state-controlled coastal waters would be prohibited and a $500 million oil-spill response fund created.
* $40 million a year would be provided for ''applied research'' on alternatives to pesticides in agriculture and other topics.
It would also create an elected state Environmental Advocate, with authority to enforce environmental laws, independent of the governor and attorney general. Reportedly, Mr. Hayden wants this job, but he has not acknowledged that. Proponents say the new post is necessary because the Legislature, Governor and Federal Government have been unwilling to take adequate measures to protect the environment. The measure was originally mounted to bolster the gubernatorial campaign of Attorney General John K. Van de Kamp, who opposed Ms. Feinstein in the Democratic primary. It cobbles together several disparate approaches to environmental protection that backers said the Legislature and Governor were unwilling to pass.
 
'A Multipurpose Creature'
Critics call the initiative a poorly drawn law. John P. Dwyer, a professor of law at the University of California at Berkeley, likened it to ''a frenzied scientist's recombinant DNA experiment'' that had spliced unrelated changes into a ''multipurpose creature.''
Debate focuses mainly on the cost and Mr. Hayden's role.
Frederick Cannon, senior economist at the Bank of America in San Francisco, told a symposium at Berkeley's Graduate School of Public Policy about 10 days ago that while the measure would not cause a recession, its impact would be ''substantial'' with ''major dislocations'' for certain industries, particularly farming. He added that the costliest provisions would be the ''greenhouse'' gas reductions.
The nonpartisan Legislative Analyst's Office in Sacramento estimates direct costs to state and local governments at up to $2.6 billion over the next 20 years. An analysis commissioned by opponents of the initiative said it would increase energy prices by $10 billion to $15 billion a year, raise electric rates by at least 20 percent by the year 2000, and cause the loss of 500,000 to 2 million jobs in manufacturing and construction. The opponents have refused to release the details of how these conclusions were reached.
Backers angrily dismissed such figures as scare tactics and are preparing their own economic analysis. ''These are simple-minded economic assessments based on the notion that we are capped out on energy savings,'' said Ralph C. Cavanagh of the Natural Resources Defense Council. ''There are large opportunities to save more by saving rather than producing energy.'' He argued that renewable energy sources including geothermal, solar and wind power would get a substantial boost from the initiative.
The measure faces further political difficulties because the ballot will contain three other measures related to the environment. One of them, called Careful and mounted by the California Farm Bureau Federation and the Western Growers Association, would set less restrictive rules on pesticides. The two others offer competing plans on logging by environmentalists and timber companies.
''There's a lot of confusion. All four sound good. People don't know how to vote to be good environmentalists,'' said Mr. Hattoy of the Sierra Club.

HEADLINE: Democrats Straddle a Line in Policy Statement

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
The Democratic National Committee tried to accomplish a difficult task here today: express full support for the American troops in the Persian Gulf while criticizing the Republican Administration that put them there.
''We'll stand up to Saddam Hussein, but we won't stand by as the new Republican recession wreaks havoc with the economy,'' Ronald H. Brown, the party chairman, told the committee.
Today's meeting reflected a party scrambling to adjust to a political world made new by the events in the Middle East. Democratic leaders were still pressing the economic themes they hope will dominate this fall's campaigns, but they also carefully embraced the Bush Administration's gulf policy, which has overwhelming support in the public opinion polls. 
''The Democratic Party stands united behind our President as he acts to roll back Iraq's blatant aggression,'' Mr. Brown said. ''Saddam Hussein will get no mixed signals from America or from this party. But the perils and costs we face in the Persian Gulf cannot lead to paralysis at home.''
Committee members approved a resolution sounding similar themes, beginning with its title: ''Stop Aggression in the Persian Gulf and Start Fighting a Recession at Home.'' In that resolution, and in Mr. Brown's address, the Democrats sought to place the blame for the economic downturn on ''a decade of Republican disinvestment and debt'' and to lambaste the Bush Administration's domestic policies.
The members asserted that any spending reductions and tax increases necessary to ease the Federal deficit ''must not fall first on working Americans.'' And Mr. Brown assailed the President for calling again for a reduction in the tax rate on capital gains.
''It is long past time, my fellow Democrats, to abandon Republican economics,'' he said. ''We've got to stop them before they do it again.''
Democrats also took the Republicans to task on energy policy, passing a resolution that ''the 10-year failure of three successive Republican administrations to develop a national energy policy can no longer be tolerated.''
At the same time, the party rejected the notion of easing the United States' dependence on foreign oil primarily through expanded exploration in offshore areas. Instead, the committee embraced a much vaguer, and more politically palatable, solution: ''expanded U.S. energy conservation efforts and fuels development compatible with the global warming threat and our national public health.''
In their two-day meeting here, the Democrats also adopted the formal call for their 1992 nominating convention, including the rules that will govern the selection of about 4,200 delegates to the convention. Party leaders said this was remarkably early for Democrats to be approving their call to the convention, and cited it as a sign of new harmony.
''We needed to get this housekeeping business out of the way and get on with what our real mission is - that is, sweeping the elections this fall and winning the White House in 1992,'' Mr. Brown said.
Still, while the Democrats now have their rules and their convention city, New York, their Presidential candidates have yet to emerge. And today's meeting suggested they are still scrambling to cope with a popular President.

HEADLINE: Bill Would Again End Benefits to Census Workers

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
About $40 million in unemployment benefits that were stripped from temporary census workers in May and restored in August are threatened again by legislation approved this week by a Senate subcommittee.
A bill appropriating money for the Commerce Department, the parent agency of the Census Bureau, includes a provision saying no unemployment benefits should be paid to temporary census workers on the basis of work done after April 20.
The vast majority of the 250,000 temporary workers who went door to door to 35 million homes or processed the mailed-in forms from 65 million households would not have accumulated enough working time before April 20 to qualify for unemployment solely on the basis of their census work. 
The measure, which now goes before the full Senate Appropriations Committee, is the latest word in a tart legislative exchange between Senator Ernest F. Hollings, a South Carolina Democrat who opposes unemployment benefits for temporary census workers, and a variety of lawmakers, including Representative Thomas Downey, a New York Democrat who in August thwarted the attempt to strip those workers of benefits.
 
Conflict With Existing Law
An aide to Senator Hollings said the Senator opposed granting unemployment benefits to workers who took these jobs knowing how temporary they would be.
Congressional sources said Mr. Hollings was incensed by the reversal of a bill passed in May that prohibited the payments. They said he was further enraged by the manner in which it was reversed, by insertion of a provision into the Trade and Commerce Act, which was signed by President Bush last month. That act is still in force, and benefits will continue for census workers unless the new legislation becomes law in its current form.
Susan Howard, Associate Undersecretary of Commerce, said the department's lawyers are studying the legislation and believe that ''there are statutory conflicts,'' with existing laws. But, she said, the lawyers could not say immediately how those conflicts might be resolved if the measure became law.
 
'Playing Yo-Yo'
In the House, a staff member who spoke only on condition of anonymity said Democrats on the Ways and Means committee were concerned that the Federal Government would set a troubling precedent if it exempted itself from paying benefits to some of its own workers. ''It could open the door for abuses because it's hard to say who's temporary and who's not,'' the aide said.
Mr. Downey said of Mr. Hollings's action: ''Fritz is a friend of mine and I'm going to have to go see him. I don't think he understands that we're not going to let this happen. We're treating these people unfairly by playing yo-yo with their lives.
''If the rationale is that we can use this money to get a better count, let's find more money for the count. All of us feel that this is a bad and inaccurate count. But we don't improve it by not paying these workers benefits.''
Mr. Hollings left the capital Friday and could not be reached for comment.

HEADLINE: Massachusetts Journal;
State Borrows Trouble With New Library Law

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
The frantic call to the Plymouth Public Library came from a woman who had several overdue books and was frightened that she might be arrested.
''She was all nervous,'' said Kathleen L. Clegg, Plymouth's assistant librarian. But despite Ms. Clegg's assurances that she would not be arrested, the woman jumped into her car in Sandwich, on Cape Cod, and raced to Plymouth, a half hour drive away, to return the missing volumes.
Anxiety over overdue books has swept across Massachusetts in the past week since a law went into effect toughening the penalties for people who keep library books too long, steal books or deface library materials. 
The law has led to a flood of overdue books being returned, many through drop boxes at night and bearing notes of apology. But it has also brought protests by irate patrons who complain that Gov. Michael S. Dukakis - who, after all, could not keep Willie Horton, the convicted murderer, in jail - is using police state tactics on harmless library goers.
Radio talk shows, political cartoonists and newspaper columnists have poked fun at the new law, though some of them have distorted it, exacerbating the public fear about errant borrowers being dragged to jail.
The law does provide for fines of up to $25,000 and five years in jail for the theft of library materials valued at more than $250 or for the alteration or destruction of library catalogues, which might conceal a theft. But for overdue books, the penalty is only a maximum fine of $500, with no reference to a prison term.
But Mike Barnicle, The Boston Globe's most popular columnist, wrote of the law differently: ''The incredible shrinking governor - tough as nails on stuff like this - signed it a few weeks ago and if you are late getting 'Swiss Family Robinson' back to the library you could now be arrested and thrown in jail. It's about time.''
James C. Flaherty, the director of the Framingham Public Library, thinks the reaction to the law reflects the public's mood of anger at government in Massachusetts. It is a choler provoked by the state's sharp economic downturn after a decade of affluence, by the Governor's poor performance as the Democratic candidate for President in 1988 and by a state budget crisis, which has led to higher taxes and reduced services.
''The climate in Massachusetts is not good now for public sector employees,'' Mr. Flaherty said. ''People object to anything government does, even in this case where the libraries are really only trying to protect public property.''
Indeed, librarians here say they pressed for the law because communities were collectively losing an estimated $1.1 million a year in library materials, including books, video tapes and paintings, with some small towns like Shrewsbury, with a population of 23,000, losing $12,000 a year in missing books.
Gregor Trinkaus-Randall, the collection management consultant for the Massachusetts Board of Library Commissioners, a state agency, noted the old law covering overdue books dated from 1883 and provided for a fine of only $25. ''You can't buy a book for that today, when you include the costs for cataloguing and shelving.''
The new law does include a provision that the police can arrest an offender without a warrant. But that was already in the 19th-century law, Mr. Trinkaus-Randall said, and few librarians would ever use such an extreme step. ''We just want to get the books back,'' he said.
At the Reading Public Library, Susan M. Flannery, the director, said her staff has been besieged by patrons asking whether they would be sent to jail. ''We bend over backward to give people good service and the only image we have as librarians is as this rampaging group of people who will do anything to get a book back,'' Ms. Flannery said.
In one case, she lamented, a man in his late 60's who had heard about the new law on a radio talk show came in to the library, slammed his library card down on the counter and demanded that his name be taken off the membership rolls. Just to make sure, he watched while a librarian erased his name from the computer.
''He said he did it to protest the new legislation,'' Ms. Flannery recounted. ''It is very sad. The talk show host didn't lose anything. But the library lost a customer and a man lost access to millions of dollars worth of materials.''

HEADLINE: In Mississippi, They're Counted Out

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MAYERSVILLE, Miss., Sept. 12

 BODY:
The words are repeated, almost verbatim, from one front stoop to the next, as the residents of the Unita Blackwell housing project come out to answer a question from their Mayor, Unita Blackwell: ''No, ma'am, the census didn't come here.'' ''No, nobody talked to me.''
To the Census Bureau, these 3-year-old rows of small apartments did not exist. By extension, neither do their elderly or disabled residents: Alice Rash, Fronie McIntosh, Adline and Robert Jones, Essie Keys, Joe Shell, Jack Frankle, Anna May Dolly and 17 others.
That leaves the preliminary census count for Mayersville, a hiccup of humanity in the Mississippi Delta, at least 25 people short. There may not be 350 people here as there were 10 years ago. But there sure seemed to be more than 272, the figure issued last month in the preliminary census count. 
Out here, where the only things numbered in the millions are cotton plants, soybeans and cicadas, the Census Bureau this year has run into the same problems it faces in the inner-city neighborhoods of New York City or Detroit: poverty, illiteracy, suspicion.
 
'They Think You're Nosy'
''People are scared to tell you things,'' said Mayor Blackwell, a 57-year-old former civil rights advocate who in 1973 became Mississippi's first black Mayor. ''They think you're nosy. They think you're going to cut their checks off.''
Regional planners say about 20 percent of the county's total income is in the form of Government payments like welfare and food stamps. Many of the town's newer amenities like the apartments for the elderly were provided with Federal money obtained through Mayor Blackwell's efforts.
Ruby Crawford's experience in collecting census data did not entirely bear out Ms. Blackwell's prediction. ''I had one lady straight out refused me,'' said Ms. Crawford, who drives a school bus in neighboring Sharkey County and who worked as a census enumerator in Mayersville, the Issaquena County seat. But, she said, ''I didn't have a lot of problems with people not wanting to be counted.''
What she did have problems with, Ms. Crawford said, were the census maps, which had some houses miles out of place, and local streets, which were often unmarked.
Jewel Spencer, the enumerator for northern Issaquena County, said she ''only had about three refuse me.'' But she said many dwellings in the county are trailers, summer homes or weekend homes. Mrs. Crawford said she left a census form on the window of one empty trailer and when she returned a few days later, the trailer was gone.
 
Met Their Requirements
Both women said they completed the work they were given. ''I did the best I could,'' Mrs. Spencer said. ''People can make mistakes. I don't think I made any.''
Mrs. Crawford said, ''I filled out my lists.''
Kimball Brace of Election Data Services, a Washington consultant on Congressional redistricting, said Issaquena County, which dropped from 2,513 people in 1980 to 1,774 in this year's preliminary figures, was one of only a handful of counties in the country that apparently lost about 30 percent of its population in the decade.
Clearly, Issaquena County lost population. What is not clear is how many of those that remained were missed by the census because they did not understand the census form or did not want to. ''You want to talk about how many people in this town can read a form?'' Mayor Blackwell asked. ''If you classify me as illiterate, then give me a form and tell me to fill it out. That's ludicrous.''
How was the housing project overlooked?
Mrs. Crawford said she saw it, realized it was not on her address list, and told her crew leader, Linda Edwards. Mrs. Edwards said she told her superivisors about it and was told that it was not her worry, that it would be counted separately as group housing. It was not.
Anne Tolbert, who headed a census office in Greenville, said she considered census business confidential and would not discuss how the project was missed.
 
Chance to Gain Population
Mayor Blackwell has a chance to get those 25 residents back in the count before the numbers become final. Mayersville, like 3,128 sites around the country, has accepted the Census Bureau's invitation to challenge its housing figures. So far, no state has a higher percentage of challenges than Mississippi: one in three of the state's 378 local governments contends the Census Bureau counted incorrectly.
Still, despite months of warning, many of the country's 13,200 local governments were ill-equipped to mount effective challenges. Even if they were prepared, the Census Bureau is not committed to revisiting more than 2 percent of the housing in each jurisdiction, or 2.1 million homes nationwide. But if someone's house was counted and they were not, the chances that they will be included in the final count are now slim.
Local officials in Mississippii, however, are still trying, passing out the Census Bureau's ''Were You Counted?'' forms all over the state. They are being passed out in Pearl, just east of Jackson, where the Mayor says 1,000 housing units were missed. They are being passed out in Greenville, where a count of 4,000 more people will put the the city over the 50,000 mark, making it eligible for a range of Federal health and hospital grants.
 
More Jobs Added Than People
The forms are in the Statehouse, too, while Gov. Ray Mabus shuttles between the Census Bureau's headquarters in Suitland, Md., and the local courthouses trying to prove that a state cannot gain 130,000 jobs that economists say have been added in the last decade and only 13,000 people. The preliminary 1990 census count for Mississippi was 2,535,000, more than 4 percent below what the bureau had been estimating for the state. Nationwide, the count was 1.45 percent below estimates.
''Any time you've got a state with a large number of people that live at or below the poverty line, any time you've got a large number of rural people, there's a pretty big body of evidence that says you're systematically undercounted,'' Mr. Mabus said. ''Then there are the anecdotal things. I didn't get a form. The Secretary of State didn't get a form.''
There are also two unpleasant realities. One is that the rural areas of Mississippi, especially the Delta, with its double-digit unemployment rates, have been hemorrhaging people for decades. The other is that the state is perilously close to losing a Congressional district. Indeed, if Kentucky can find about 3,000 more people than Mississippi, Kentucky will keep its seventh seat and Mississippi will lose its fifth.
The Delta is represented by Mike Espy, Mississippi's first black member of Congress since Reconstruction. He took an interest in the census form the outset, requesting that his Delta district get its own census office. An office was opened in Greenville, but Mr. Espy, a Democrat, was displeased when Mrs. Tolbert, a former Republican county chairwoman, was named to head it.
''The Mississippi number is outrageous,'' Mr. Espy said. ''There is a question of accuracy and fairness.''
I'm not saying it was intentional or purposeful,'' he added.
 
'Everybody in a Dither'
Mel Jordan, who heads the main district office of the Census Bureau in Jackson, said, ''The perception of the count is what's got everybody in a dither.'' Mr. Jordan, like other census officials, said the local review process will mean that housing units will be revisited by enumerators.
Barbara Everitt Bryant, the census director, told Congress this week that ''millions'' would be added to the preliminary count.
Issaquena County needs a few of those millions. William Haney, executive director of the South Delta Planning and Development District Inc., said many of the improvements in the county, including the Unita Blackwell housing project, have been financed through community development block grants.
''It's competitive,'' he said. ''One of the determinants of how you rate is cost per beneficiary. The fewer the beneficiaries, the higher per-beneficiary cost.''
His associate, Julie Lindner, is drafting a $300,000 grant application for a welfare department building in Mayersville that would have a cold-storage unit. That way, when the Agriculture Department distributed surplus cheese, milk and eggs, the food would not spoil before residents received it. ''If it doesn't get funded this year and I have to do the same next year with those new population figures, I don't see how it can compete,'' she said.
In the Mayersville challenge, Mr. Haney is even asking the Census Bureau to count 16 units of low-income housing that were not even complete last spring when the count was taken. ''When you're at the bottom,'' he said, ''you need everything you can get.''

PUB-DATE: September 16, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 17, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 532 words

HEADLINE: U.S. TO POSTPONE DEBATE ON ZIONISM

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 15

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is postponing plans to seek repeal of a United Nations resolution equating Zionism with racism at this year's General Assembly so as not to imperil Arab support for trade sanctions against Iraq and for America's military buildup in the Persian Gulf, United Nations and American officials say.
The decision by the United States to avoid a confrontation with the Arabs on this issue is widely seen as illustrating the way the gulf crisis and the Security Council's tough response to Iraq's aggression against Kuwait are likely to dominate much of the discussion at this year's Assembly session.
 
Commitment From Quayle
Last December Vice President Dan Quayle, with strong support from American Jewish organizations, committed the Administration to the repeal of a much criticized 1975 resolution describing Zionism as a form of racism, arguing that repeal would increase the United Nations' ''moral authority'' and allow it to play a constructive role in the Middle East. 
But on Friday, Under Secretary General Ronald I. Spiers, the United Nations official in charge of the Assembly, said he did not expect the United States to attempt to press for repeal at this year's session.
State Department officials confirmed that while the Administration still favors repeal, it does not want to irritate Arab states at such a sensitive moment by pressing the Assembly to act this year.
Israeli diplomats also said they did not expect a push for repeal at the Assembly session, which opens Tuesday. ''We want repeal but we want an overwhelming majority in favor and this may not be the right moment to get it,'' said Israel's representative, Johanan Bein. New Stature for U.N. Although the international campaign to oust Iraq from Kuwait is directed by the United Nations' 15-member Security Council, many believe it will have a far-reaching effect on the General Assembly, promoting debate over many aspects of the organization's future and stimulating pressure for change.
Many believe that the gulf crisis has showed that the United Nations is finally capable of working as it was intended to, which will also encourage countries to look critically at the organization and its functions.
''There are a lot of issues burning under the surface which become important as countries take the United Nations more seriously,'' says Edward C. Luck, President of the United Nations Association of the United States.
 
Japan Seeking a Seat
Chief among these, many diplomats say, is the composition and authority of the Security Council now that it is starting to carry out its task of safeguarding international peace effectively.
In particular, the privileged position enjoyed by Britain and France as World War II victors with permanent seats and veto power is hard to justify when Germany and Japan are richer and pay more of the United Nations' costs.
Japan has informally suggested the creation of six permanent Council seats without a veto for itself, a united Germany, India, Egypt, Nigeria and Brazil. But this means amending the Charter which many fear would open a Pandora's box of demands, including abolition of the permanent members altogether.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Germany Pledges $1.87 Billion to Aid Gulf Effort

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUDWIGSHAFEN, West Germany, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today that his country would fulfill its responsibilities in the multinational effort to confront Iraq by providing military equipment and economic assistance worth $1.87 billion.
But the German Chancellor said that because of restrictions in the German Constitution, which prohibit West Germany from sending troops outside of the NATO theater, Bonn would not be sending any men to join the American and other European forces stationed in and around Saudi Arabia. The Chancellor promised that as soon as the two Germanys are unified and elect an all-German Parliament in December he will introduce an amendment to the Constitution so that Germany could dispatch troops to the Persian Gulf and similar crises.
Chancellor Kohl made his commitment in a 90-minute meeting with Mr. Baker in his Ludwigshafen country home, in south central Germany. The West German offer comes in the wake of mounting Congressional criticism of Bonn's reluctance to commit resources to the multinational effort to roll back the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. 
 
Baker Expresses Appreciation
Similar Congressional criticism of Japan was quieted somewhat this week when Tokyo promised a package worth $4 billion. It was unclear whether the West German announcement would mollify the critics.
Mr. Baker said he was ''very appreciative of these contributions, both economic and military.''
''We see them as very positive and very forthcoming,'' Mr. Baker said. ''They go beyond what we privately discussed in earlier communications and substantially so. The President will be pleased, and I know the American people will be pleased as well.''
Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who met with Mr. Baker in Petersberg, near Bonn, earlier in the day, said he was sure that in light of the West German contribution ''the critical voices will be silent.''
 
Kohl Regrets Restrictions
Although the German offer was valued at $2 billion by Mr. Baker, that figure includes West Germany's share of a European Community aid package. The assistance is actually made up of military equipment, transport and logistical aid and financial help totaling $835 million.
Speaking to reporters after meeting with Mr. Baker in Ludwigshafen, Mr. Kohl said: ''We would like to make it very clear that we would like to give full support within the limits available to us to our American friends and partners, who are active in the gulf and who are also defending our interest in the region.''
Regarding Germany's refusal to commit troops, Mr. Kohl explained: ''We very much regret that our Constitution does not allow us at the present to assume our full responsibility in the area, something that I regret very much. I hope that right after the elections we will be able to initiate a change in our Constitution and fully assume our share of responsibility.''
 
Little Enthusiasm from Germans
Until today, Bonn's contribution has been limited to warmly endorsing the multinational effort in public statements, sending five mine sweepers and two supply ships to the Mediterranean so that the American ships stationed there could be transferred to the gulf and granting Washington permission to use its bases in West Germany as way stations for transferring troops.
Opinion polls in Germany show little enthusiasm for any extensive involvement in the gulf crisis, which comes at a time when West and East Germany are preoccupied with their pending unification on Oct. 3. West German officials argue that they are going to have to pay billions of dollars in order to integrate East Germany into their economy. Also, West Germany gets virtually all of its oil from the North Sea and Norway, and 0.3 percent from Iraq.
The limited West German contribution up to now stood in stark contrast to that of other major Western industrialized countries. On Friday, Britain committed 8,000 combat troops to the gulf force. France has sent naval forces and promised 4,000 troops today, while Italian officials informed Mr. Baker in Rome Friday that they were dispatching a squadron of eight Tornado fighter aircraft and a frigate.
Mr. Baker said this evening that he had asked the Soviet Union to provide air and sea transport for the 10,000 troops and 300 tanks that the Syrians promised Saudi Arabia last week. Mr. Baker said the Soviets are considering the request.
Before arriving in Germany from Rome, American officials traveling with Mr. Baker made little effort to disguise their extreme disappointment with the behavior of the West Germans. They felt that Bonn, America's richest European ally, has been remarkably unforthcoming in the gulf crisis.
What made Bonn's unresponsiveness, up to now, even more galling, said Administration officials, was the fact that President Bush and Secretary Baker felt they had bent over backward in the last year to convince their European allies and Moscow that a united Germany would not be a threat.
Mr. Baker's stop in Germany ended a 12-day tour of Europe and the Persian Gulf, which raised more than $16 billion in financial support for the multinational coalition in the gulf as well as extensive commitments of military support.
In light of those commitments, the United States and its allies can sustain the quarantine of Iraq, Mr. Baker said, ''a lot longer than a lot of people thought when this thing first started.''

HEADLINE: What Makes The 2 Sexes So Vulnerable To Epidemic

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
A host of medical, cultural and economic factors make Africa especially vulnerable to the heterosexual spread of AIDS, which is believed to account for more than 80 percent of adult cases there.
The second major mode of spread in Africa, contaminated transfusions, is declining as hospitals adopt blood screening, and reused medical needles account for only a small share of cases. Homosexual intercourse and intravenous drug use, which account for most AIDS cases in the United States and Europe, are believed to be rare.
Studies in the United States show that transmission of the AIDS virus during vaginal intercourse is usually quite difficult, especially from female to male. But research in Africa has revealed conditions that multiply the danger. 
One is the rampant extent of sexually transmitted diseases. In particular, transmission appears to be boosted by those that cause genital sores such as syphilis and, above all, chancroid, which causes festering ulcers. These provide ready portals for the AIDS virus and brim with concentrations of cells it inhabits.
 
Higher Chance of Transmission
Studies in Kenya suggest an extraordinary impact. When a woman with the AIDS virus also has a genital ulcer, the chance of AIDS transmission to a man in a single act of intercourse may be as high as 5 percent to 10 percent, according to Dr. Allan R. Ronald, head of internal medicine at the University of Manitoba and an organizer of the studies. When partners do not have a sexually transmitted disease, the chance is only a fraction of 1 percent.
Other venereal diseases that do not cause ulcers but often cause inflammation, like gonorrhea and chlamydia, also appear to increase the risk of AIDS transmission, though not so powerfully as the ulcerative diseases.
A second major factor, evidence suggests, is the lack of male circumcision in much of Africa. Uncircumcised males are more likely to have infections or small breaks in the skin of the penis, and the foreskin traps virus-containing fluids in a hospitable environment. Across Africa the tribes that do not practice circumcision tend to have the highest AIDS rates. Dr. Ronald believes that lack of circumcision by itself doubles AIDS transmission risks. Combined with the presence of genital ulcers, he calculates, the risk from a single encounter may be 15 percent or higher.
Researchers are just now turning attention to little-known sexual practices that might also raise transmission odds.
In parts of Central Africa including Zambia, Zaire, Zimbabwe and Malawi some women engage in a practice known as ''dry sex.'' In variations of the practice, designed to increase friction during intercourse, women use herbs, chemical powders, stones or cloth in the vagina to reduce lubrication and cause swelling. Those kinds of agents are also sometimes used as medications.
In Zambia, Dr. Subhash K. Hira of the University of Lusaka found evidence suggesting that women who practiced dry sex had a greater chance of becoming infected with the AIDS virus, presumably because of an increased chance of abrasions.
 
Common Promiscuity a Factor
Studies in Malawi find that more than one in 10 women have used ''vaginal-tightening agents.'' But the studies find no evidence of a significant association between the practices and infection with the AIDS virus.
Promiscuity helps drive the epidemic. While data do not exist for comparing sexual behavior on different continents, surveys do show that extramarital sex is commonplace in Africa.
Prostitution, always an engine of sexually transmitted diseases, has played a major role in African AIDS. Typically, a small group of infected prostitutes passes the virus to large numbers of men, who take it to their wives and girlfriends.
Prostitution is encouraged by migratory labor patterns rooted in the colonial past and current poverty. Millions of couples are separated for months at a time as men work in mines or plantations or move to cities for any paying job. For many women, especially those with little education who have left the dreary cocoon of the village, selling sex may seem essential for economic survival.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard Dimba, who has AIDS, being examined by Dr.Clement Chela at a hospital in Chikankata, Zambia. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Poor Nations Get Unspecified Pledge of More Aid

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Rich industrial nations agreed to increase their aid to the world's poorest nations at a United Nations conference that ended here today, but their agreement fell short of the third world's goal of having the industrialized world double its aid.
Officials at the Second United Nations Conference on the Least Developed Countries had feared that the two-week session on helping the poor would end in disarray because of disagreements over what specific aid target the rich nations should adopt to help the world's 42 poorest nations. When the two-week conference began, representatives of the poorest nations called on the industrial world to raise its aid to 20 one-hundredths of 1 percent of their gross national product, more than double current aid levels. 
Principally because of opposition from the United States, the industrialized nations failed to agree to raise their aid to a single fixed target. Instead, the nations agreed to set their own goals, with the final declaration creating a menu of options, including one in which countries could pledge to contribute the amount the poorest nations were seeking.
''The outcome of this menu is a good meal,'' said Jan Pronk, development minister from the Netherlands. ''It has got meat.''
The conference aimed to study how to lift the 42 poorest nations, 28 of them African, out of their misery and how to reverse the economic decline those nations suffered in the 1980's. In those nations, which include Afghanistan, Chad, Haiti, Laos and Tanzania, per-capita income averages $227 a year, and one of seven children dies before the age of 2. Newly established Namibia was added to the group at the meeting.
In a departure from the first conference, held in 1981, the final declaration called for promoting private-sector initiative to help the poor nations.
Last year, the industrialized world -the United States, Canada, Japan, New Zealand, Australia and Western Europe - gave the poorest nations about $12 billion in aid. But third world officials say that by the year 2000, that aid needs to be raised to $36 billion, in current dollars, for these nations to raise economic growth to 5 percent a year, enough to make a tangible difference in living standards.
''Without outside support, these poor nations will have a hard time,'' said the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas. ''They will never escape from their vicious circle of misery.''
At the 1981 conference, the industrialized nations set a target of contributing 15 one hundredths of 1 percent of their economic output to the poorest nations, but the industrialized world has fallen far short of that level. The United States donates four one-hundredths of 1 percent of its output to the poorest nations, while Japan gives seven one-hundredths of 1 percent.
Under the options the conference agreed to this week, the loftiest is for nations to continue donating more than 20 one-hundredths of 1 percent. Scandinavian nations and the Netherlands are already in this category.
Another option - the one that African delegates said was the least lofty - was chosen by the United States and Japan, the two largest donor nations in absolute terms. That option calls for countries to promise to increase aid, without setting a specific target. American officials say they fear that if they pledge to raise aid to the poorest nations, then they might be forced to reduce aid to other deserving recipients.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Yale;
7 Athletic Teams Are Eliminated To Trim Budget

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
This summer, Jeffrey Wyshner spent three hours a day practicing for a tennis team that no longer exists.
A junior from North Canaan, Conn., Mr. Wyshner joined Yale's junior varsity team last year. During the summer, he practiced daily and played in eight local tournaments, hoping to improve enough to make the varsity squad. 
But when he returned to Yale in late August, Mr. Wyshner learned, to his astonishment, that the athletic department, because of a $150,000 budgetary cut, said it had been forced to eliminate seven junior varsity programs, including tennis.
''I think everyone should have the opportunity to come here and compete intercollegiately,'' said Mr. Wyshner, an economics major. ''The days of the walk-on athlete are disappearing.''
In addition to men's and women's tennis, the athletic department cut junior varsity programs for men's and women's lacrosse and men's basketball, baseball and wrestling. The department saved about $10,000 by eliminating these teams, which have a combined roster of about 70 students, said the associate director for varsity sports, Barbara Chesler. But team coaches are trying to keep the programs going through alumni donations.
 
'We Have to Make Choices'
Yale continues to sponsor 10 junior varsity teams and 35 varsity programs. But more junior varsity teams might be eliminated next year if the athletic department's budget continues to shrink, Ms. Chesler said.
''We have to make choices, reallocations and trade-offs,'' said Associate Provost Lloyd Suttle. ''Needs around a place like Yale inevitably grow faster than resources. Rebuilding Yale is the top priority of this administration, and you can't pour money into buildings without taking it out elsewhere.'' The university's president, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., has embarked on a capital-improvement plan to renovate campus buildings that Mr. Suttle said could take decades and cost up to a billion dollars.
The baseball, wrestling and men's lacrosse programs are among those that coaches hope to resurrect through alumni donations. Traditionally, these teams have not traveled, so the primary expense involves hiring referees for home games.
''We think having a 'B' squad is vital for our program and for the student athlete,'' said the lacrosse coach, Michael Waldvogel, who estimates that sponsoring a junior varsity program will cost $1,000.
 
'Goes Without Saying'
Five of the seven All-American players on Yale's nationally ranked lacrosse team, which reached the National Collegiate Athletic Association semifinals last year, spent at least one year in junior varsity play, Mr. Waldvogel said.
''There's no telling who will develop into an All-American,'' said Mark Horney, a senior history major from Baltimore who spent two years on the junior varsity lacrosse team before advancing to the varsity.
''You have to have J.V.; that goes without saying,'' agreed David Nicoll, a senior on the varsity wrestling team. Each week, junior varsity athletes can challenge their varsity counterparts, and ''without that competition, varsity wrestlers might get complacent,'' said Mr. Nicoll, an engineering major from Rochester.
Although coaches tend to see junior varsity teams as stepping stones to their varsity teams, many junior varsity athletes simply enjoy the chance to compete on the collegiate level.
''When I heard that they cut the J.V. program, I thought of all the people who play J.V. and just have a lot of fun,'' said Peter Ladig, a sophomore history major from Glen Mills, Pa., who hopes to make the varsity baseball team this year. ''Cutting the team ruins the chance for students to come out, put on the uniform and say they played J.V. baseball at Yale,'' he added.
Or, as Mr. Wyshner said, ''Playing Harvard is still playing Harvard, whether you're on J.V. or varsity.''

HEADLINE: ANTIQUES;
Mining the Greeks' Gold Standard

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
Wreaths of tissue-thin leaves, vase-shaped earrings encrusted with specks of glowing metal, and a hairnet of chains embellished with a bust of Athena are among the dazzling pieces of Greek gold jewelry on view at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum in Manhattan, through Jan. 13.
The 200 ancient, medieval, Byzantine and neoclassical artifacts exhibited in ''Gold of Greece: Jewelry and Ornaments from the Benaki Museum'' document virtually every metalworking technique used in crafting objects of adornment over 4,000 years of history. The Benaki Museum in Athens, which organized the show with the Dallas Museum of Art, is a little-known repository of one of the world's great collections of historical jewelry. The exhibit is the first presentation in this country of selections from the Benaki's collection. 
''On each of these earrings, you can barely see the woman playing the lyre,'' said David R. McFadden, the Cooper-Hewitt's curator of decorative arts, admiring a pair of Hellenistic earrings from the fourth century B.C. The delicacy and scale of these highly complex figural designs are rendered with such refinement, Mr. McFadden noted, that the women are almost invisible to the human eye.
Mr. McFadden said goldsmiths in ancient Greece achieved extraordinary results with far fewer tools than were available to 19th-century craftsmen, many of whom used machines when making their adaptations of the Greek jewelry.
''Ancient Greece is such a jumping-off point for all jewelry design,'' Mr. McFadden said. Beginning with the Mycenaeans in the second millennium, the vocabulary of decoration developed by the Greeks - images of gods and goddesses, mythological creatures, snakes, beasts and stylized flowers - has been revived in the Middle Ages, the Renaissance and the 18th and 19th centuries.
Animal motifs borrowed from antiquity also are common in today's jewelry. But the bracelets and earrings worn in the fifth century B.C., with their fierce-faced heads of rams, lions, lynxes, bulls, antelopes or griffins, were set off by more elaborate engraving, filigree, raised relief and beading.
This use of naturalistic detail may have stemmed from the ancient Greeks' belief in the talismanic power of jewelry bearing animal and plant forms to protect the wearer from an assortment of evils. Jewelry worn to show status, another Greek custom, remains intact today - although somewhat changed. In ancient times, jewelry revealed intellectual as well as financial power, and men in the fourth century B.C. wore as much jewelry as women. In fact, the men donned some of the most extravagant examples - including wreaths of gold ivy or oak leaves, worn when they marched in victory processions.
Beginning in the third century B.C., the subject matter of Greek jewelry became increasingly romantic and exuberant. On view at the show are necklaces and earrings depicting Aphrodite or pairs of doves, which convey the idea of love; Dionysian motifs suggest sensuous pleasures.
Serpents, a jewelry motif that has endured through the centuries, were used in the stunning pair of bracelets exhibited, which are from the third century A.D. The serpents probably depict the Greek myth of Zeus and his mother Rhea. Gold was combined with semi-precious stones like garnets or with bits of colored glass, a trend that intensified under the Romans and in the early Byzantine period as gold grew scarce.
The Greek mastery of gold disappeared when the taste for adornment declined. Medallions became weightier and less refined; pendants depicted crosses, madonnas or abstract motifs. Under Emperor Justinian in the fifth century, the taste for luxury returned briefly with an improved economy. But the sumptuous necklaces and belts, blazing with precious stones, were far from the fantasies created in ancient Greece.
The exhibition contains later examples of Greek jewelry, including enameled pectorals made in the 15th and 16th centuries in the form of four-masted ships, to celebrate the age of sailing the seas to discover new continents. The Ottomans' delight in boldly colored stones and the Venetian use of filigree influenced the design of Greek jewelry into the early 19th century, when its ancient forms were revived.
The Benaki Museum was founded in 1930 in Athens by Anthony Benaki, a member of a family prominent in politics and cultural affairs in the Greek colony in Alexandria, Egypt. As a young man, Benaki collected Greek art and artifacts of all periods. His collection eventually spanned the Bronze Age to the 20th century, and he decided to donate it to the Greek people, after he settled in Athens in 1926. He remained involved in the museum's operations until his death in 1954. Housed in the Doric-columned Benaki mansion on Queen Sofias Avenue, the museum was enlarged several times to accommodate the founder's holdings and other gifts.
The show's handsomely illustrated paperback catalogue ($24.95) offers a cursory history of the jewelry shown. (The Benaki is preparing a more scholarly study of the museum's gold collection that will document the history and pedigree of major pieces.) The exhibition, which is supported by the Federal Council on the Arts and the Humanities, will travel next year to the San Diego Museum of Art and the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Who's Afraid of Industrial Policy?

BYLINE: By CHALMERS JOHNSON; Chalmers Johnson, a professor at the University of California's Graduate School of International Relations and Pacific Studies at San Diego, is author of ''MITI and the Japanese Miracle.''

 BODY:
It is not news that the United States and Japan are on a collision course. In fact, a book entitled ''Nichi-bei Shototsu e no Michi,'' which is roughly translated as ''The Japanese-American Collision Course,'' is a best seller in Tokyo. What is news is that intellectual vested interests stand in the way of clearly recognizing the differences between the two countries and prevent either side from taking appropriate measures to change course.
On the one hand, professional neo-classical economists and an array of lobbyists, apologists, and public-relations specialists claim that the Japanese economy is just like any other capitalist economy. Although they usually do not read a word of Japanese and have made no empirical study of the Japanese economy, they claim that the Japanese just get up earlier, work harder, and save and invest more than their competitors. This school is often known as the ''chrysanthemum club.'' 
On the other hand, scholars of the Japanese state bureaucracy - myself included - some American trade negotiators and many American manufacturers who have competed successfully everywhere else except Japan argue that the Japanese economy is different from that described in American economic models. It is what what we term a ''capitalist developmental state.'' This school has been dubbed the ''revisionists'' because its members are attempting to revise orthodox American policy by calling for specific trade measures tailor-made for Japan.
This latter group is beginning to achieve a small measure of success, as seen, for example, in the Bush Administration's Structural Impediments Initiative to open the Japanese market. However, any success by this group is proving extremely painful to the devotees of Adam Smith.
Everyone agrees that many factors have contributed to the collision course between the United States and Japan and that to single out any one of them as central is a source of error. Both sides stipulate that the United States must soon resume financing its own government, provide incentives for its people to save instead of consume, reorient its engineering from military to commercial products and get serious about educating its labor force. But there is one cause of the trade deficit that the classical economists cannot acknowledge, because it tends to undercut everything they have stood for and might even require that some of them give back their Nobel prizes in economics. That is Japan's industrial policy. Industrial policy is to English-speaking economists something akin to sin. It means governmental affirmative action on behalf of domestic industry to foster the orderly retreat of declining industries and to build the high-value-added industries of the future. It works on the supply side and takes as its criterion the number of truly valuable jobs held by a nation's workers. It favors computer chips over potato chips.
The Japanese are past masters at industrial policy. The most important command post within their economic general staff, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, is called the Industrial Policy Bureau.
The prime tools of industrial policy are export incentives, trade barriers to protect the home market, low-cost credit, pro-business environmental and educational policies and unorthodox accounting practices. For private companies going into government-approved industries, there are other incentives, like foreign commercial intelligence services, nationalistic patent policies and a host of other forms of economic covert action. Public subsidies are not very important.
Western economists do not like industrial policy because it interferes with their mathematical models. And in Japan, economic policy is made not by economists but by highly nationalistic state bureaucrats trained at the University of Tokyo Law School.
American politicians do not like industrial policy because it draws attention to one of the most important asymmetries between Japan and the United States: the effectiveness of the Japanese Government in economic affairs as compared with the blundering of Washington. Needless to say, Japanese leaders are not about to draw attention to industrial policy; it is more effective if their competitors do not know what is going on. The Japanese government thus engages in extensive disinformation on this subject aimed especially at people who do not read Japanese.
Today's challenge goes well beyond the old shibboleths of level playing fields, competitiveness and protectionism. In fact, industrial policy is the antidote to protectionism of important but weak industries like machine tools and robotics.
The idea of a level playing field means that people should play by the same rules. But since the Japanese play by different rules, and since we seem to have had little success in agreeing on what a new set of common rules might look like, we must learn to match rather than imitate them.
The idea currently popular in some American business schools is that American companies lack ''competitiveness.'' Actually, American companies are merely the products of - and are responding to - the short-term incentives and signals sent out by the American political and financial systems. Until these are changed there is no such thing as a company-level solution to the problem of competitiveness.
Japan differs almost completely from the United States in its history of industrialization, the role of the state in it, and the place of economic affairs in national security. Japan is not, however, unique. It is similar to that other great late developer, Germany. Both began intentionally to catch up with the original beneficiaries of the industrial revolution at about the same time, 1868 for Japan and 1870 for Germany. Both have experimented for more than a century with corporate forms of social goal-setting, while retaining the efficiencies of the market. The challenge for American national and corporate economic policy is to recognize this country's differences from Japan and to begin to formulate strategies for managing them. It is also the indispensable first step toward avoiding another national collision.

HEADLINE: In Japan, the Private Sector Plays a Role in Foreign Aid

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While America's gunboat diplomacy builds swiftly in the Middle East, Victor H. Palmieri appropriately points out the growing influence of Japan's foreign-aid programs (''U.S. Takes Back Seat in Third World,'' Aug. 26). Indeed, in 1987, Japan was the largest donor of official bilateral assistance to 29 countries, among them China, India, Indonesia, Iraq, Syria, Nigeria, Kenya and Zambia. In its rapid rise to become the world's largest donor, Japan has received broad-based public support and assistance and encouragement from the powerful private sector, including Keidanren, the Japan Federation of Economic Organizations. This is in contrast to the aid fatigue and disillusionment that grip many wealthy nations of the West. 
The public-private cooperation in development aid and direct investment was clearly evident at the beginning of the year when Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, visiting Poland and Hungary, announced a $1 billion aid program for the two countries. The announcement was seconded by the Suzuki and Daihatsu Motor Company with plans for new automobile plants in the region. In Southeast Asia, Thailand has been a principal recipient of Japanese official assistance for 20 years. In 1988, this came to $360 million, which was dwarfed the following year by direct private investments from Japan of $3.5 billion. Such infusions have made Thailand the world's fastest-growing economy in 1988 and 1989. ''Japan Inc.'' is also moving strongly into Vietnam, while Washington maintains its moribund policy.
Chile - another booming economy - received $123 million in Japanese investments in 1988, considerably more than the total for the prior 10 years. The newly elected President of Peru, Alberto Fujimori, is also seeking aid and investments from his ancestral homeland. These developments are inexorably turning the yen into an international coin of the realm; meanwhile, the United States remains hamstrung by its massive budgetary deficits.
LESLIE S. HIRAOKA
Union, N.J., Aug. 30
 
The writer is a professor of management science at Kean College of New Jersey.

HEADLINE: WORLD MARKETS;
A Bond Strategy for Foreigners

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
With the economy slowing down, or possibly in a recession, and with a steadily weakening dollar, there is little to attract foreign investors to the American stock and bond markets From January through May, foreigners were net sellers of $6.7 billion in American stocks and $5.9 billion in Government securities, according to the most recent data from the Securities Industry Association. Analysts say the trend is likely to continue - especially if the dollar falls further, which would cut deeper into profits or widen losses for foreign investors who must convert assets back into their home currencies.
In the midst of this gloom, Michael R. Rosenberg, manager of international fixed income research at Merrill Lynch & Company, has found a bright spot: a bond investment that should be attractive to foreigners - and some Americans - and that makes a profit out of hedging against the falling dollar. He thinks the strategy could help slow the flight of foreigners from the American bond market, which some analysts say creates pressure for higher interest rates. 
The Japanese investor, for example, would do this: Take yen and buy dollars and then buy a 10-year American bond, which has a yield of around 8.85 percent. Then, to hedge against the risk of the dollar falling further, the investor sells the dollars forward; that is, he sells the dollars now but agrees to deliver them at a set later date - a week, month or maybe longer.
This strategy gives the investor a much higher yield than he could get in Japan. There, a 10-year bond (the longest maturity) is yielding just 7.70 percent based on the semiannual compound rate used in the United States. This means the interest rate on the American bond is 114 basis points higher. (A basis point is one one-hundredth of a percentage point.) In addition, whenthe investor sells hisdollars forward for yen,he will earn a premium of about 30 basis points, because short-term interest rates in Japan are now higher than those in the United States.
This leaves the investor with a bond yielding 9.14 percent, counting the premium for selling dollars forward, or an investment that yields 144 basis points more than hecould get in Tokyo. The nice extra is that the hedge against a further decline in the dollar, which would reduce the value of the investment, actually adds to the profit.
Americans can use this strategy, too, even though some foreign bonds have higher yields. For example, the British 10-year gilt yields 11.81 percent, more than the American counterpart. But three-month rates in Britain are 688 basis points higher, giving a net gain of 391 basis points when the investor sells the dollars forward for pounds. Doing the same with the Canadian dollar would give a net higher yield of 225 basis points.
Here's the real beauty in the strategy. What makes it attractive is the change in interest-rate differentials between the United States and the rest of the world, which is what weakened the dollar and made investment here less attractive in the first place.
The strategy could, of course, turn into a nightmare. Worries about inflation could depress bond prices in the United States, which would push yields higher. Mr. Rosenberg has calculated that if interest rates on the 10-year bond rise by 30 basis points, the drop in bond prices would, for example, wipe out the Japanese investor's gain from the 144 basis-point spread. Then the yield would be the same as if he had left his money in Japan. But if interest rates on Japanese bonds also rose about the same amount at the same time, the gain would be intact.
For Americans, hedging by buying pounds, yen or Canadian dollars is fine as long as the American dollar continues to decline or is stable. If it rises, then the investors will lose some of their gain when they turn the foreign currency back into dollars.
Mr. Rosenberg is not worried about these problems for now. He thinks that the differential in short-term interest rates will continue to widen. He expects the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates because of the threat of recession. And he believes the Bank of Japan will continue to push up interest rates to counter inflationary pressures.

LENGTH: 1695 words

HEADLINE: Car-Buying, 1990, Is a Matter of Multiple Choices and Pitfalls

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: SILVER SPRING, Md.

 BODY:
It doesn't take long to get a salesman's attention in an auto showroom these days - just seconds in the case of a solitary, pre-lunchtime shopper at Covington Buick, one of 20 franchises owned by six dealers in Auto Sales Park of Montgomery County, which in good times is a hotbed of automotive retailing.
''The economy finally caught up with us,'' said Barry Covington, the owner, lamenting the year-long dearth of customers.
The 1990 model year, ending Sept. 26, has been the softest since the recession of the early 1980's. Dealers have sold a total of 14.2 million vehicles - an estimated 9.5 million cars and 4.7 million trucks.
Things have been particularly tough for the Big Three domestic auto makers: in the face of weak demand they were forced to trim production and increase discounting. Moreover, the Japanese aggressively expanded their United States-based output, increasing the pressure for rebates. 
But the difficulty facing new-car buyers isn't just a question of the economy. There are a daunting number of choices - technological, ideological and financial.
Sedans, coupes and station wagons have been joined by minivans, utility vehicles and extended-cab pickups. Auto makers offer and rescind cash rebates at a dizzying pace; rebates may be replaced by low-interest financing plans or low-cost leasing. The safety-conscious must decide whether airbags are superior to automatic seatbelts. Should one choose a standard or multivalve engine, and who understands the issue?
And what of ideology in an age when the line between imported and domestic models has been blurred by foreign companies assembling cars in the United States?
''People have become scared to death of buying a car because there are so many gimmicks out there,'' said Mr. Covington.
The recent experiences of three typical suburban Maryland shoppers show some of the intricacies encountered in today's market.
 
 G.M. Keeps One
 Clifford Crawford, a 37-year-old pediatrician living in Silver Spring, is precisely the type of customer the General Motors Corporation looks for. Young, well-educated and affluent, he sees cars not just as a means of transportation, but as a means of expressing himself.
According to G.M.'s own marketing strategy, Dr. Crawford should have switched directly from the 1986 Pontiac Fiero GT he was leasing for $345 a month to a more expensive model, perhaps a Corvette or a Cadillac Seville. But two years ago he began to grow weary of the incessant mechanical problems with the Fiero. (The model finally was discontinued, partly because of such complaints.) ''It was a great little car,'' he said, ''but the bolts holding the alternator sheared three times, the cooling system failed three or four times, the engine didn't idle properly despite serial visits to dealerships.''
Having grown up in Flint, Mich., G.M.'s birthplace, Dr. Crawford resisted the idea of switching to an import. But in January, he leased a 1990 Nissan 300 ZX - it was $500 a month and $250 more for premium fuel, but it ''turned heads, especially where I work at the Quantico Marine Base in Virginia.'' In April, Dr. Crawford gave up his lease on the Fiero.
Keeping two cars for all those months had been a financial burden. Further complicating things, Dr. Crawford, having been convicted twice for speeding, was having trouble finding insurance coverage. One company quoted a price of $2,100 a year. Moreover, Dr. Crawford was not altogether confident of the safety of the 300 ZX. In May, he started shopping for a new car.
Dr. Crawford visited about 10 dealerships, test driving a variety of foreign and domestic sport models, including the Lexus M30, Acura Integra, Pontiac Grand Prix, Toyota Celica and Toyota Supra. ''I wanted something with style and power, but I also wanted an airbag and antilock brakes for safety,'' he said. ''Electronic goodies were important, too.''
Finally, he bought a $19,000, four-door Buick Regal at Covington Buick. It had antilock brakes but no airbag. He had decided the Japanese sporty models were either too expensive or couldn't offer the same equipment, such as a six-cylinder engine, that Buick offered for the same money.
Dr. Crawford ended up with a G.M. car, but just barely. He says that if the Buick doesn't work out, he won't hesitate to buy an import.
 
Ford's Financing
 When Don and Rose Money of Silver Spring came to Crystal Ford in the Auto Sales Park, they were looking for a vehicle that had the cargo capacity for the newspapers that Mr. Money, 38, distributes for The Washington Times. He was considering a Ford Econoline van.
''I had owned a Ford pickup and loved it,'' he said. ''I've never had much luck with Chevys.'' Ford and Chevrolet agree that one of the last bastions of brand loyalty in the automotive business is the truck market: Those who have owned Fords rarely migrate to Chevy, and vice versa.
The Moneys wanted to trade their tiny 1988 Hyundai Excel for the Econoline, but had a big problem. They still owed $6,900 to the Chrysler Credit Corporation, which had financed the Hyundai. The Hyundai had cost about $5,900 new two years earlier and now was worth only about $2,000. The Chrysler loan was larger than the purchase price because it covered not only the Hyundai, but the unpaid balance on a previous auto loan.
Thus, the Moneys had negative equity of almost $5,000. They had only $5,000 in cash, enough to cover the old loan but not a down payment on a new vehicle. One Ford dealer wouldn't consider selling to them. But Mr. Money met a Crystal salesman who was friendly ''without being pushy.''
''He was young, and you could talk to him,'' said Mr. Money. ''He wasn't one of these guys who had been in the business 15 or 20 years and talked down at you.'' At first, Ford Motor Credit turned down their application for a loan. Crystal Ford tried again.
''Sometimes you can point out something about an applicant that makes him or her a better credit risk than what appears on paper,'' said Howard Castleman, Crystal Ford's owner. ''As a creditor you're buying the person as much as you are buying the loan.'' The Moneys both have stable jobs and a good credit history.
Creative financing provided the solution. The Moneys paid off the loan on the Hyundai but agreed to the full retail price of almost $20,000 for an Econoline van that normally would have been discounted for less than $16,000. Ford Motor Credit loaned them more than $15,000 and the Moneys agreed to 60 payments of about $360 a month.
Though they have the new Econoline, the Moneys' negative equity problem may have grown worse. As soon as the van was driven away it turned into a used vehicle and its wholesale value dropped to about $12,000. That means the Moneys now are about $8,000 ''upside down.''
Ford's loan to the Moneys and hundreds of thousands of loans like it represent a potential time bomb even as recession looms. With almost $300 billion in automotive debt outstanding, a substantial proportion represents negative equity.
 
Playing the Prices
 A need for basic transportation wasn't the only motivation for Jonathan Sams, 23, to shop for a new car, but it was his No. 1 consideration.
Mr. Sams's 1982 Pontiac Trans Am had a case of ''the 50,000-mile blues,'' he said, and needed constant repairs. ''I wanted something that would hold up well since I have to move around quite a bit, and it had to be able to transport my bicycle,'' said Mr. Sams, a sailor stationed near Washington with the Navy.
The point was not so much price or rebate, but monthly payment - including insurance - which he wanted to keep at about $280. A sporty 1990 240 SX going for $13,200 had caught his eye at Gordon Nisson in the Auto Sales Park. The snazzy Nisson, on which insurance would have been $3,000 a year, flunked the test.
Then, while visiting home in Cincinnati, Mr. Sams found a 1990 Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme sedan deeply discounted from the retail price of $18,900 to $14,600. Insurance on this more sedate model: $1,900 a year.
Further sweetening the deal, Mr. Sams's father took his used Trans Am and in return promised to pay his son's car insurance for two years. Without any insurance costs, and after a $2,700 down payment, Mr. Sams met his $280 a month budget.
''I never thought this nice a car could be in my price range,'' he said, noting that it was equipped with a six-cylinder engine. Moreover, the back seat folded down, allowing him to carry his bicycle.
 
THE EQUITY SQUEEZE
The good news for dealers and lenders is that Americans, however confused or beset with financial problems, are still willing to borrow to buy cars and trucks.
But debt-burdened consumers are finding they have less wherewithal to make a deal than at any time since the last recession. Spurred by rebates and generous financing, shoppers went on a new-vehicle buying spree starting in late 1986, sometimes borrowing imprudently to do so. Today, as many contemplate trading in their three- and four-year-old vehicles, they are discovering that they owe huge amounts.
It's called the ''upside down'' phenomenon: The amount owed on the outstanding balance of the loan is more than the car is worth. Without any equity, it is difficult to buy a new vehicle before the old loan is paid off. Being out of equity, or ''upside down,'' normally is the case when a car is brand new. But the trend to loans of five years and more in order to make cars more affordable by reducing monthly payments - combined with the drop in value of used cars in recent years - means that a customer today often stays ''upside down'' for years.
To make matters worse, ''Now the finance companies are tightening credit, which knocks poorer buyers out of the box,'' said Lou Kairys, chairman of the Lustine organization, which owns several dealerships in the Washington area.
H. L. Davis, group vice president of marketing for the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, G.M.'s financing arm said, ''All of our efforts are aimed at shortening the term of loans in order to help customers get equity in their cars earlier.'' As a practical matter, shorter terms also mean higher monthly payments.
