SECTION: Section 3; Page 1, Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2827 words

HEADLINE: France's Industrial Shogun

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
Alain Gomez is an unlikely candidate to be the savior of America's consumer electronics industry.
Chairman of France's giant, state-owned Thomson Group, Mr. Gomez quotes Goethe and Nietzsche with ease, is the grandson of a Spanish anarchist and once helped establish a far-left faction within France's Socialist Party. He is also not quite a household name in the United States.
Yet after an unusual political and business evolution, this maverick 51-year-old manager finds himself at the helm of a company that is No. 1 in color television and video cassette recorder sales in the United States. Thomson acquired the consumer electronics businesses of the General Electric Company and its RCA subsidiary in 1987, and now Mr. Gomez talks like a warrior about safeguarding the industry in America and Europe from further Japanese encroachment. 
''The Japanese are waging a type of industrial war,'' said Mr. Gomez, whose company is France's leader in both consumer and military electronics. ''There comes a time when you have to draw the line, when you have to say we just won't accept the loss of 1 more percent of the market.''
A driven, hyperintense man, he contends that the Japanese have not played by the rules and that, as a result, Westerners should not have to, either. Protectionism should be used, he says, to offset the huge competitive advantages the Japanese have acquired by bending the rules.
''The Japanese strategy of conquest is made easier by the gullibility, naivete and weakness of the West,'' said Mr. Gomez.
Mr. Gomez's pronouncements command a lot of attention nowadays because he is one of the brightest stars in a new generation of European business leaders who have revived their tired companies and the Continent's economy. Other stars include Percy Barnevik, chief executive of Asea Brown Boveri, the Zurich-based electrical engineering giant; Jean-Louis Beffa, chairman of Saint-Gobain, the French glassmaker, and Mark Wossner, president of Bertelsmann, the German publishing conglomerate.
 
Single-Minded and Fierce
Mr. Gomez has distinguished himself by his single-minded implementation of his industrial vision and by his fierceness in combating Japanese competition. Thomson is one of just a handful of major Western electronics companies -the others are Philips N.V. of the Netherlands and the much smaller Zenith Electronics Corporation in the United States - that have not abandoned the struggle against total Japanese domination in consumer electronics.
But Mr. Gomez's fight has another aim: to save Thomson. He has built Thomson into the world's fourth-largest consumer electronics company - after Matsushita, Philips and Sony - by snatching up the operations of other Western manufacturers that quit the business.
It is not at all clear, however, that Thomson will still be standing at the end of its battle with the Japanese.
''The problem is that Thomson is fighting a moving target and the target is moving very fast,'' said Yves Doz, a professor at the Insead business school outside Paris. ''Thomson has made tremendous strides, but it still has some very difficult years ahead.''
For all of his complaints about unfair competition, Mr. Gomez nonetheless admits that Thomson long lagged behind the Japanese in innovation, quality and design. Thomson's televisions used to have a reputation for flimsiness and required four times as many working hours to produce as Japanese sets did.
But Mr. Gomez has been winning high marks for closing many of these gaps. Thomson now produces televisions with fewer hours of labor than the Japanese, some analysts say. And showing its increased technological proficiency, Thomson has reduced its reliance on Japanese manufacturers for VCR's.
Indeed, Thomson has made huge strides since 1982, when Mr. Gomez took charge of what was an inward-looking, nearly bankrupt company.
Under Mr. Gomez, Thomson has grown into Europe's second-largest consumer electronics maker (behind Philips) and its largest military electronics company, second in the world behind the General Motors Hughes Electronics Corporation. The year he took over, Thomson lost $142 million on sales of $7.5 billion; last year it earned $86 million on sales of $13.3 billion. (Last year's profits were down 59 percent from 1988, largely because of a drop in television and VCR prices and restructuring costs in military electronics.) Going Global As the European Community moves to create a barrier-free market in 1992, Mr. Gomez has helped lead the way in showing how to transform a company that relied on domestic sales into a global giant that ignores national boundaries. Thomson gets 72 percent of its sales from outside France, and 12,000 of its 100,000 employees are in the United States. Mr. Gomez often boasts how non-French Thomson has become: The headquarters of its television business is in Indianapolis; it has factories in Singapore; its television research center is in West Germany.
At the same time that Mr. Gomez tangles with the Japanese, he also has to keep alert at managing Thomson's $5.6 billion military division.
With Europe's arms industry consolidating, Mr. Gomez has worked hard to strengthen Thomson's already formidable position. In 1985, Thomson-CSF, the company's arms subsidiary, and the GTE Corporation, its American partner in the project, won the largest-ever Pentagon contract based on non-American technology, a $4.3 billion order to supply the Army with battlefield communications. Thomson-CSF also has a $6.5 billion contract to provide sophisticated equipment to Saudi Arabia. It was also a major supplier to Iraq.
On a continent where governments are less loathe than Washington to meddle in industrial matters, Mr. Gomez likes to make his views known to help sway policymakers.
He argues that the West's consumer electronics business must be saved. Without it, he says, the United States and Europe will lose thousands of engineering and factory jobs as well as their semiconductor industry, which relies heavily on orders from consumer electronics manufacturers. If the semiconductor business goes under, he adds, then the Japanese will steamroll over other industries that rely on semiconductors, including cars and computers.
''The Japanese have chosen consumer electronics as their field of battle, and if that domino falls, a lot of other industries will fall, too,'' said Mr. Gomez, a former paratrooper who often used to drive to work on his motorcycle.
Partly as a result of Mr. Gomez's prodding, France's Government is working hand in hand with business to check the Japanese. It has imposed quotas on Japanese-made cars and televisions and pushed the European Community to slap dumping penalties on Japanese products. France has also pledged $550 million to help Thomson develop high-definition television - in contrast to Washington, which declined to put up money.
''The French are the flagship of European protectionism,'' said Takao Negishi, European director of the Electronics Industry Association of Japan. ''They're not playing the game according to the rules.''
But the Japanese broke the rules first, Mr. Gomez counters. Although he admires Japan for its well-trained work force and the high savings rate that makes low-cost capital available to business, Mr. Gomez has called Japanese companies ''cheaters,'' part of an ''inexorable industrial machine that will not stop until it captures 100 percent of a market.''
 
$200 Million Edge
Japanese televisions sell for 10 to 20 percent more in Japan than outside Japan, he said, arguing that this unfairly subsidizes exports. ''That gives them $100 million extra a year in their pocket for research and investment,'' he said. He added that it was nearly impossible for Western companies to sell electronics goods in Japan because the Japanese dominate the distribution system.
But now, Mr. Gomez says, high-definition television could give Western manufacturers a rare chance to catch up to the Japanese.
Thomson is staking a lot of its future on HDTV, which provides far sharper images than current televisions. Mr. Gomez believes that HDTV, which he hopes will be introduced in the mid-1990's, could create a worldwide market worth hundreds of billions of dollars.
Through behind-the-scenes lobbying, Thomson and Philips succeeded in preventing Japanese specifications for HDTV from being adopted in the United States and Europe. The two companies are spending $3.8 billion on joint development ofan HDTV system that they hope will be embraced by European and American officials.
''This is a crucial product,'' said Mr. Gomez. ''If things go the way we think, there is no reason why we can't truly catch up to the Japanese.''
But some analysts say HDTV might not be the great boon and equalizer that Mr. Gomez envisions. The high cost of the new televisions might prevent a boom in sales. What is more, even if Thomson bursts out of the HDTV starting blocks alongside the Japanese, its success is not assured. For example, Thomson does not have as much expertise in developing large flat screens, an important part of HDTV.
Dennis Exton, a London-based analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company, sees another problem. ''Even if you catch up in image and design, you have to be at least equal to the Japanese in manufacturing,'' he said. ''The Japanese are still two generations ahead in manufacturing.'' In many ways, it is an accomplishment that Mr. Gomez can even talk about catching up to the Japanese. When France's Socialist Government nationalized Thomson in 1982 and placed him in charge, the company was in 23 disparate lines of business and teetering near bankruptcy.
Mr. Gomez quickly changed all that, citing Goethe's dictum that injustice is preferable to disorder. He streamlined Thomson, sold off its majestic 19th-century headquarters and broke up its many feudal baronies. He slashed headquarters staff and laid off thousands of office and factory workers. Many Socialist cohorts demonized him as a ruthless capitalist.
''In my political days, we were fighting to modernize the country and its economy,'' Mr. Gomez said. ''I decided to help do that in the field, in business. I have no regrets.''
 
Rising Troubleshooter
 Mr. Gomez graduated from France's elite Ecole Nationale d'Administration and then went to Harvard Business School. After working in the French Finance Ministry, he joined Saint-Gobain, the state-owned glass, packaging and construction products company. There, he was a troubleshooter who rose to head the company's glass operations.
When Mr. Gomez arrived at Thomson, he quickly began unloading money-losing businesses, including telecommunications, copper wire and medical equipment. He instead focused on two areas: consumer electronics and military electronics.
In consumer electronics, for example, Mr. Gomez bought Telefunken of West Germany; Thorn EMI's Ferguson division, Britain's No. 1 television maker, and finally the G.E.-RCA consumer electronics business. All told, he spun off businesses with $4.4 billion in sales and acquired ones with $5 billion in sales.
He also maintained Thomson's semiconductor operations, because he saw them as essential building blocks for the two core areas. Thomson has entered a 50-50 joint venture with SGS, the state-owned Italian chip maker, to form Europe's No. 2 semiconductor group after Philips.
Mr. Gomez has often been second-guessed for focusing on areas where Japanese competition is so fierce, but he said those were the cards he was dealt. ''None of the businesses that we had, except for the three we kept, had a chance of attaining global size or even European size,'' he said.
 
American Investments
 Much of Mr. Gomez's focus has been on modernizing production. Thomson is pouring more than $200 million into its American factories, including its picture tube plant in Marion, Ind., and a factory in Circleville, Ohio, that makes glass for the tubes. It is also expanding its factory in Bloomington, Ind., the world's largest television assembly plant.
Thomson is also greatly expanding its production in low-wage areas, including Singapore, Malaysia and Mexico. ''We have to have the same costs, if not lower costs, than the best Japanese manufacturer,'' he said.
France's Socialist officials and labor unions are not delighted that Mr. Gomez has transferred factory jobs from Europe to Asia. Neither are American unions happy about a new Thomson plant in Juarez, Mexico. But Mr. Gomez argues that only by having a low-cost manufacturing base can Thomson's consumer electronics business survive, making it possible for the company to keep its advanced factories and highly skilled research jobs in Europe and the United States.
And it is those factories and jobs that will make the difference for the future, he says. Thomson has already moved ahead of the Japanese in developing a wide television picture tube. The tube, which distorts movie broadcasts less than the more squared-off traditional models, will be introduced in Europe next month. Some Japanese competitors are even trying to buy Thomson tubes.
''For once the followers are leaders,'' Mr. Gomez said, taking a puff on his cigar.
 
BEYOND COLD WAR
Alain Gomez, chairman of the Thomson Group, has aggressively reshaped Thomson's $5.6 billion military electronics business to prepare for the post-cold-war era. Three years ago, he angered labor unions and French officials by cutting the military group's work force even though it was making record profits.
''He anticipated the downward trend in defense spending before most others in the industry,'' said Christophe Cherblanc, an analyst with Cholet Dupont in Paris.
At the same time, Mr. Gomez has expanded the arms operation in other ways, to give it the size and research muscle needed to stay in the business. Thomson is a leader in radar, mines, missile systems, electronic countermeasures and battlefield communications.
As Europe's arms industry has gone through a massive restructuring, Mr. Gomez has been busy maneuvering. Thomson has purchased most of Philips's arms business in Europe, acquired half of the sonar business of Ferranti of Britain and formed a joint venture in avionics with Aerospatiale, the French aerospace company.
In addition, Thomson and British Aerospace have agreed to form a joint venture to make missiles, Eurodynamics, which they say will have $2.8 billion in sales next year. Acquisitions have also made Thomson the European leader in civil air traffic control systems.
''When a market shrinks, and you are a leader, you have to work to increase your position,'' said Mr. Gomez, who foresees a 20 percent decline in military spending worldwide.
''Defense electronics should be the least affected,'' he said. ''New military doctrine will put a premium on mobility, reconnaissance, detection and communications. The fewer soldiers, the more you need strong individual technology.''
 
AMERICAN BRANDS FROM A FRENCH COMPANY
Not many Americans realize that when they buy color televisions that say General Electric or RCA, those sets are made by a French company: Thomson. Because those brands are so well-known, Thomson, which acquired the G.E.-RCA consumer electronic businesses in 1987, has no intention of putting its own name on the televisions and VCR's it sells in the United States.
Bernard Isautier, chief executive-designate of Thomson's consumer electronics division, said the United States is crucial to the division's future since America represents half of its sales. Thomson is market leader in color televisions, with 22 percent of the American market; it also leads in VCR's, camcorders and radios.
Thomson uses the G.E. label to cover the low end of the market and the RCA label for the middle and middle-to-high-end range. Later this month, Thomson plans to introduce a sleek product line, tentatively called Pro-scan, to capture more of the high-profit high end of the market. And it hopes to spruce up RCA's image with a $30 million advertising campaign, beginning today, that reintroduces RCA's most famous symbol, Nipper the dog.
''They are going after the Sony end of the market,'' said David Lachenbruch, director of Television Digest, an industry newsletter based in New York. ''But Sony will continue to be able to charge 10 to 15 percent more than RCA. RCA does not have the prestige of a Sony.''
Thomson hopes to change all that through investment, innovation and dedication. ''Consumer electronics wasn't considered strategic by G.E.,'' said Mr. Isautier. ''But for us it's very strategic.''
He said that whenever he watches television in the United States he tells himself, ''What a lousy picture.'' Thomson hopes to improve matters with high-definition television. It is working with Philips, the Dutch electronics firm, as well as with NBC and the David Sarnoff Research Center in Princeton, N.J., to develop an American HDTV system.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2, Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1404 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY/SEPTEMBER 9-14

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Preventing Another Banking Crisis
 
On one side of the tables sat lawmakers terrified that they would be blamed for another Federal bailout. On the other sat the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, afraid that Congress would hurt the banks more than help them. Mr. Greenspan urged House Banking Committee members on Thursday to limit their plans for higher deposit insurance premiums. The General Accounting Office had warned two days before that bank failures might deplete the Federal insurance fund. Better to cushion losses by having banks bolster their capital than by making them contribute more to the fund, Mr. Greenspan said. Some analysts agree, saying that as much as risky lending and a weak economy have buffeted the banks, they remain far more healthy than the savings and loans. Arthur P. Soter, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, said politicians risk compounding the banks' problems: ''You keep raising these insurance payments,'' he said, ''and ultimately you're going to undermine their safety and soundness.'' 
 
More Pressure on Oil Prices
 
Word that the Bush Administration might dip into strategic oil reserves failed to keep prices from rising last week. Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said on Thursday that shortages might require the release of some supplies. But on Friday came news that Iraqi troops stormed the French Embassy in Kuwait. Traders who saw an increasing threat of war bid oil up to $31.76 a barrel on Friday, for a gain of $1.72 on the week.
 
Inflation Protection
 
This time, some economists say, higher oil prices might not ignite rapid inflation. Last week's report that producer prices rose 1.3 percent in August was troubling, but no surprise. Higher energy prices were to blame; without food and energy, wholesale inflation rose just three-tenths of 1 percent. Declines in retail sales and industrial production had some economists wondering whether producers will be able to pass on their higher energy costs. In the 1970's, a roaring economy turned an oil crisis into high, persistent inflation. ''This time, you have a very, very weak level of economic activity,'' said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities. Others fear that several categories of services - health care, education - might keep consumer prices rising even if wholesale prices settle down. As Lawrence Krohn, an economist at Shearson Lehman Hutton, said, ''The overall inflation picture is not nearly so bright as the core P.P.I. picture alone.''
 
Philadelphia Finances
 
A statue of Benjamin Franklin still looks out on Philadelphia from a perch on City Hall, but his city has cast aside his thrifty ways. After running deficits since 1988, the city failed last week to arrange $375 million in temporary financing to stave off default. As city and state politicians feud, Philadelphia faces drastic cuts in most services, and insolvency by the end of the year.
 
In Brief
 
The New York Stock Exchange approved limited after-hours trading for the first time in its history, initiating a program intended to establish 24-hour activity by the year 2000.
 
The Senate plans to vote next week on a bill to require that auto makers achieve an average efficiency of 40 miles per gallon by the year 2001. The Administration says the bill would force the auto makers to sell smaller, less safe cars. But many lawmakers say the fuel savings are essential.
 
COMPANIES
 
Re-regulating Cable Television
 
The House of Representatives voted unanimously last week to restore some regulation and competition to cable television. During the Reagan era, viewers complained that cable companies rapidly raised their charges, exploiting their local monopolies and exclusive rights to popular programs. The legislation gives the Federal Communications Commission power to roll back rates, and bans programming contracts that prevent competition. Advisers to President Bush have threatened a veto.
 
S.& L. Deal Doesn't Pass Muster
 
Federal regulators blocked the $3 billion sale of the Columbia Savings and Loan Association's ''junk bond'' portfolio to a Canadian investment partnership that planned to have Columbia lend 90 percent of the price. The Office of Thrift Supervision said Columbia could get a better, preferably all-cash, deal.
 
In Brief
 
ARCO agreed to pay $287 million last week to settle a 13-year lawsuit over royalties on North Slope oil owned by the state of Alaska. Other oil companies face a trial next year.
 
New York City Council President Andrew Stein has proclaimed Sept. 26 Accountant Appreciation Day. ''New York City is composed of caring, giving people,'' he said, with accountants among them.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Yeltsin Seizes the Lead
 
He was at the vanguard of reform; now he is at the rear. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's endorsement on Tuesday of a plan for free markets in 500 days came so grudgingly and late that he can claim little credit or capacity to lead. He was pulled both ways. His own economic adviser, Stanislav S. Shatalin, led the group that drew up the plan. But Mr. Gorbachev's Prime Minister proposed a more cautious course, limiting private ownership and maintaining state control of prices. The same day that Mr. Gorbachev sided with Mr. Shatalin, Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian Republic, regained the initiative by rushing the program through his Parliament. The vote: 251 to 1. ''Yeltsin just forced the issue,'' said Joe Tragert, an economist at the Planecon consulting firm. And Mr. Gorbachev has little choice but to go along.
 
Cigarette Shortage
 
With cigarette shortages provoking riots and demonstrations, the Soviets are sending in RJR Nabisco and Philip Morris. The companies agreed on Thursday to ship 34 billion cigarettes, which represents more than a month's supply. The need is so urgent that both producers might transport some loads by air freight. Marlboro cigarettes, from Philip Morris, are virtually legal tender in the Soviet Union; just ask any cabby whether he wants American cigarettes or rubles.
 
The Soviet Share of the Pie
 
It took truckers from Finland, wine from Hungary and a contractor from London to bring American pizza to Moscow. Pizza Hut, a unit of Pepsico Inc., opened its first two restaurants in the Soviet Union on Tuesday with an investment of $10 million. The chain's executives say they actually receive 60 percent of their food and service supplies from Soviet sources. They also say they will be able to use this approach across the Soviet Union. The McDonald's Corporation spent more than $50 million to arrange the production of its own beef patties, milk and buns.
 
Building Trade Ties With Mexico
 
As economic alliances coalesce in Europe and Asia, President Bush is rushing to cement a regional trade agreement of his own. And what better time than an energy crisis to snuggle up to Mexico, which sells about 30 percent of its oil to the United States? Administration officials said last week that the President will ask Congress to let him negotiate a broad free-trade agreement with Mexico, like the one between the United States and Canada. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico has already cut some tariffs from 100 percent to 10 percent - effectively reversing his country's historic opposition to free trade. The Mexicans have pledged to produce more oil, and American companies expect to sell them more oil equipment.
 
Japanese Film Deficit
 
They might not buy American cars, but American movies are always welcome. The Japanese remain the largest overseas market for United States films. Fashions and fads in Japan tend to absorb everyone or no one, so movies already certified as hits in the United States do best there. Tom Cruise, and Indiana Jones, are national heroes, and the popularity of ''Gone With the Wind'' lingers, with many Japanese products adopting antebellum themes. American film producers say the Japanese market is still young. But they are confident that better promotion and more theaters and screens will attract far more viewers. Kyoko Hirano, director of the Japan Society film series in New York, says Japanese films in the United States have a much more limited audience: ''The Japanese import 100 Hollywood films and the Americans import just one.''

CORRECTION-DATE: September 23, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
A report on the Business Diary page last Sunday about Philadelphia's finances misidentified the statue on top of City Hall. It is of William Penn, the city's founder, not of Benjamin Franklin.

HEADLINE: Currency;
A Little Rally That Went Poof

 BODY:
The dollar put on a little rally last week against the German mark, inching up above 1.59 marks. But Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, ended the rally quickly on Thursday. He told the House Banking Committee that the Fed would ease interest rates if the White House and Congress came up with a credible agreement to cut the budget deficit. Although Mr. Greenspan had said such things before, it was enough to send the dollar reeling against all major currencies. With a boost from Mideast jitters on Friday, the dollar managed to finish a little up for the week against the mark. As for the yen, it continued its rally against the dollar and other major currencies. On Friday, the yen was at its highest level since August 1989.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Here Comes the S.E.C. on Fees

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
In late August, Richard C. Breeden, head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and members of his staff shared a birthday cake with members of the Investment Company Institute, the mutual fund industry trade group. The occasion: the golden anniversary of the Investment Company Act of 1940, the law that regulates mutual funds.
But the good cheer at the gathering belied the tensions that the anniversary has inspired. In March, the S.E.C. set up a blue-ribbon task force to take a fresh look at the 50-year-old law and recommend changes. 
Many industry executives say that the law still works well, by and large, and that simple tinkering can take care of any deficiencies. But some are worried by the task force's broadly defined mandate. Indeed, some view the study group as the swan song of Kathryn B. McGrath, the recently departed head of the agency's division of investment management. Ms. McGrath, who built a reputation as a tough regulator who worked hard to protect fund investors, handpicked Matthew A. Chambers, a rising star in the agency, to head the task force.
For their part, investors and consumer advocates say dramatic changes in the law are just what is needed, particularly when it comes to fund fees, sales charges and protecting investors from the shenanigans of some fund sponsors and managers.
Their worry is that too little may get done. Unlike savings and loan institutions, the funds have managed to steer clear of major disasters, leaving the industry with enough clout to defend the status quo, consumer groups fear.
With the desires and expectations of the two sides so far apart, it is far from clear how the work of the S.E.C. task force will come out. The group is accepting comments until Oct. 10 from both investors and the industry on what direction it should take; it hopes to issue its report to the commission by early next year. (Comments may be submitted in triplicate to Jonathan G. Katz, Secretary, S.E.C., 450 Fifth Street N.W., Washington D.C. 20549. Refer to file S7-11-90.) What is clear is that the task force will have to deal in some way with the sensitive issues of fees, sales charges and how funds should police themselves. Matthew P. Fink, counsel for the I.C.I., declined to give the industry group's views pending completion of the comment period. But in the past, the industry has been fiercely opposed to change.
What follows is an explanation of the issues and some suggestions for change.
First, 12b-1 fees. Named for the section of the Investment Company Act that authorizes them, these fees are assessed by funds annually to finance marketing costs.
Although most consumer advocates want the S.E.C. to abolish 12b-1 fees, John Markese, research director for the American Association of Individual Investors in Chicago, has a more modest proposal: keep 12b-1 fees, but eliminate all other sales charges and fees; cap the 12b-1 fee at five-tenths of 1 percent of an investor's holdings; drop the distinction between ''load'' funds, which impose upfront sales charges, and no-loads, and make sponsors pay marketing expenses with their own money.
Right now, investors must sort through a crazy quilt of upfront and back-end sales charges and 12b-1 fees to find out what they pay. Mr. Markese's proposal would include the 12b-1 fee in a fund's expense ratio - the ratio of expenses to average net assets - making comparisons between funds simple.
Most important, the fee would be figured into fund performance. So funds with high fees would have to perform that much better or risk having investors migrate elsewhere.
The second issue: If upfront sales charges are kept in place, how can they be handled better? Under the current rules, these charges are not subject to negotiation; the only way to lower them is to increase the size of the investment. That makes mutual funds the last bastion of fixed commissions in the securities industry, a distinction that must end, consumer advocates say.
Finally, what is the best way to protect investors? Right now, boards of directors oversee fund operations. But they are advised by fund officers, who are usually paid by fund sponsors. Can the officers give impartial advice to the directors? Some say no.
''When you wear two hats that are in conflict, the paymaster wins,'' said R. Bruce Oliver, former chairman of the John Hancock group of funds and a former member of the I.C.I.'s board of governors.
To prevent a repeat of the S.& L. debacle, Mr. Oliver wants three full-time independent fund officers to monitor a fund's daily operations and report directly to its board of directors. The independent officers would be paid by the fund; the money would come from reducing the fee paid to the sponsor for its investment management services.
 
THE DISMAL RECORD SINCE AUG. 2
How have mutual funds held up since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2? Not too well, according to indexes that serve as proxies for three types of funds: gold, growth and international.
International funds turned in a dismal performance largely because of the decline in the yen, prompted by Japan's heavy dependence on imported oil. Stock funds didn't fare much better. Even gold, the traditional haven for investors in times of international crisis, showed a decrease.
Indeed, ''there was nowhere to hide,'' said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services Inc. in Summit, N.J. And because the American economy had begun slipping even before the invasion, investors will have to tread carefully through the market for some time to come.

HEADLINE: Headliners;
Reagan Hailed for Taking the Evil Out Of The Empire?

BYLINE: By Carlyle C. Douglas

 BODY:
Historians may continue to debate exactly why Communism fell, but Eastern European leaders last week rained gratitude on Ronald Reagan for giving it a push.
In East Berlin, where preparations are under way for ceremonies next month marking the reunification of Germany, the former President met Sabine Bergmann-Pohl, the President of the East German Parliament, who said, ''Mr. President, we have much to thank you for.'' Later, near the site where in 1987 he had challenged Mikhail S. Gorbachev to ''tear down this wall,'' the 79-year-old Mr. Reagan himself took a few symbolic hammer swings at a remnant of the Berlin divider and said he found it ''damned hard.'' 
Continuing an 11-day trip that will take him to Moscow and Rome this week, the former President next stopped in Poland, where the Government newspaper Rzeczpospolita hailed him as ''the real father of perestroika,'' and called his European tour ''a symbolic harvest'' of his Presidency. (Mr. Reagan's aides hastened to make it clear that that was the only sort of harvest the former President and his wife Nancy would be receiving on this trip. Mr. Reagan, who was roundly criticized for accepting $2 million in honorariums during a trip to Japan earlier this year, would be getting no speaking fees this time around, they said.) In Warsaw, the Speaker of the Polish Parliament, Mikolaj Kozakiewicz, welcomed the former President with words reminiscent of some of Mr. Reagan's old speeches. ''You are the President who returned to America its sense of greatness,'' said Mr. Kozakiewicz. ''You raised the spirit of the American nation after a series of failures it endured.''
Later, Mr. Reagan paid a courtesy call on President Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Communist party leader whose efforts to crush the Solidarity union a decade ago prompted Mr. Reagan to impose economic sanctions on Poland. These days Solidarity, from whence sprang the Polish democracy movement, is split into factions that will oppose each other, perhaps bitterly, in coming elections. Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, has been at outs with some of his former comrades from the Gdansk shipyard strike days, and is mulling over a run for the presidency.
Doubtless mindful of this, Mr. Reagan, who is to meet over the weekend with Mr. Walesa, offered his hosts some tips on keeping family conflicts under control.
''To protect the liberty you have won at such a cost, you will need a full measure of the tolerance and openness that are Poland's tradtion,'' he said. ''For you, historic transition means that you must fight as opponents, not as enemies.''

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Behind the Census Numbers, Swirling Tides Of Movement

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO

 BODY:
As demographers study the preliminary results of the 1990 census, they are discovering that not everything is as it seems. There were great internal population shifts, but they did not always reflect Americans' preferences for one part of the country over another. And places where growth had seemed to be stagnant were actually alive with counterbalancing migrations.
For example, early estimates showed New York State holding its own with a slight population increase of 69,000 people, even though a million or more people apparently left the state in the 1980's. Similarly, California attracted some 5.6 million new inhabitants, but perhaps only 3.5 million, and maybe far fewer, moved to the state from elsewhere in the United States. 
Immigration is the complicating factor, and it may have subtle effects in areas such as the division of Federal funds and the reapportionment of congressional power.
Immigration kept New York from experiencing a net loss and contributed heavily to California's gains. And, when the final census numbers have been fully digested, immigration patterns may show remarkable similarities between these two seemingly opposite states.
At the same time, immigration kept a flow of new blood moving into the industrial heartland, replacing thousands of established residents who had pulled up stakes.
To some extent immigrants have always settled, at least initially, in cities where large immigrant communities already exist, such as New York, Chicago, and more recently Los Angeles. But there are different schools of thought about other factors contributing to the mass movement of immigrants into the old industrial states, an area of the country that others were leaving behind.
 
Economic Restructuring?
''One possibility is that this reflects a restructuring of the economy,'' said Frank D. Bean, a sociologist at the University of Texas at Austin. ''A decline in manufacturing jobs in industrial states could explain an out-migration, particularly by middle-income people. What remain are high-end jobs in professional services, finance and the like, and a growing number of low-end service jobs -janitors, waiters, housekeepers, for example - that are presumably being filled by immigrants.''
Anywhere from 7 million to 9 million immigrants entered the country during the 1980's, depending on how the number of new illegal aliens is calculated. All told, the newcomers accounted for 33 percent to 40 percent of the nation's overall population growth of 23 million people.
Scholars are now beginning to examine the overlapping effects of the two very distinct migrations of the 1980's: The internal movement of residents, mostly from north to south and from east to west; and the largest influx of people from other countries since the early 1900's.
More is at stake than the satisfying of academic curiosity. Federal funds are allocated on the basis of population. So too is political power at a time when congressional districts are about to be redrawn to take population shifts into account.
Immigrants are one of the population groups most vulnerable to undercounts, and the census does not distinguish illegal aliens from other residents. And in cases where population shifts have seen English-speaking residents replaced by people with another first language, education costs can be affected.
Jeffrey S. Passel, a demographer at the Urban Institute, a Washington-based research group, said that prelmiminary statistical analysis had yielded ''only a rough sense'' of how the distribution of immigrants interacted with domestic migration during the 1980's.
It will be late next year at the earliest before detailed census data on things like income and country of origin are available. Right now, estimates for the total number of illegals range from 1 million to 3 million people, and their geographic distribution can only be guessed at. Experts agree that the largest concentration of illegals is in California, where anywhere from 500,000 to 1 million reside.
Overall, about 1.8 million legal immigrants moved to the Pacific coast and Southwestern states, which also drew by far the largest share of domestic migration. But a nearly equal number of immigrants settled in the Northeastern and Midwestern states that have been generally losing population since the late 1960's.
''It appears these states are hanging in there with stable or slightly increasing populations, but in fact people are still moving out and they are being replaced by immigrants,'' Mr. Passel said.
New Jersey, for example, showed a modest gain of 252,000 people, bringing it to a total of 7,617,000 - 3.4 percent more than in 1980. But during the decade 300,000 new legal immigrants moved into the state, according to Mr. Passel's calculations, along with an unknown number of illegal aliens.
 
The Replacement Theory
Roger Waldinger, a sociologist at City College of New York, says that what is happening may be less the sort of ''restructuring'' cited by Mr. Bean of the University of Texas, than what Mr. Waldinger calls a ''replacement phenomenon.''
''In New York the disappearing middle has been greatly exaggerated,'' he said, ''because there are still a great number of low-skill, mid-wage jobs in places like the garment industry and construction. It is the older people, many of them immigrants who used to hold these jobs, and their chldren and they have been replaced by new immigrants.''
Both Mr. Bean and Mr. Waldinger agree that the large flow of immigrants to both New York and California suggests that similar changes may be taking place at opposite ends of the nation.
They each said that although California still attracts a huge number of people from other parts of the country, the Los Angeles area is showing the first signs of longtime residents moving out in noticeable numbers. Whether it is due to economic restructuring, immigrants replacing those seeking less congested and less expensive climes, or some other process is not certain.
''We know we had ongoing internal migration during the 1980's and that in that decade there was some of the greatest immigration in our history,'' Mr. Bean said. ''We really don't know whether the two are related or not. We don't understand the underlying dynamics, and we can only hope the census will eventually help us understand.''

HEADLINE: The Nation;
In Politics, Will 1990 Be a New Beginning?

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The gulf crisis has become a lens through which Americans are focusing their ideas about a host of issues, foreign and domestic, military and economic, political and cultural. As the campaigns blah, blah, It has created oportunites for Republicans to revive themes and issues that had flagged, so to speak, but it also is bringing to vivid life the economic nationalism that some Democrats see as the last best hope for their party.
A nagging worry about foreign economic competition has been focused into an anger that the United States is being taken advantage of in the gulf by its trading partners and allies, particularly Japan. The abstract idea of an empire overextended is now a picture of 100,000 sons and daughters standing on the desert with a handful of allied Arab soldiers.
This has moved a new phrase, burden sharing, to the top of the debate about foreign alliances and military spending. America has even accepted -indeed, solicited - payment for its armies for the first time since the 18th century. 
But the crystalizing of these anxieties coincides with a resurgence of a macho patriotism - and just when the Republicans seemed to have run out the string on their symbolic use of the flag. The refrain of a song now popular on radio in Alabama ends thusly: ''we'll blow Baghdad off the map.''
In the very short run, the gulf intervention has clearly rescued President Bush and his party from public discontent over the economy and other domestic ills. But there may be long-run political benefits, too. The loss of the Soviet Union as an adversary took a weapon from the Republican political arsenal. In 1988, President Bush ran commercials saying he was the best man to look Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the eye and not blink. That is gone as a campaign theme. The public had only modest interest in last weekend's quickie summit meeting, according to polling by the Times-Mirror Company. But Americans remain riveted by the gulf crisis, the polls said. In 1992, will Mr. Bush's commercials say he is the best man to look Saddam Hussein in the eye?
''The political stakes are already enormous,'' Kevin Phillips, the political analyst, writes in the latest edition of his newsletter, The American Political Report. Indeed, the political effects of the intervention are so far-reaching, Mr. Phillips adds, that it could even produce a debate over whether politics was Mr. Bush's motivation.
''It's unclear whether there will ever be a debate over motivation,'' he continued. ''However, by way of citing a precedent that there could be, we'd remind that Franklin D. Roosevelt's economic, diplomatic and political motivations were under considerable suspicion in 1941-42, and if World War II had gone badly for the U.S., conservative Republicans would have captured Congress and investigated F.D.R. up one side and down the other.''
President Bush recognized the crucial moment when he went before Congress last week to speak about the Gulf crisis and its relationship to other issues, most notably the budget.
Americans overwhelmingly support Mr. Bush, but they remain uneasy about an intervention in which American blood is traded for Kuwaiti oil. So Mr. Bush went to great lengths to explain that the mission he had once said was to protect the American way of life was in fact to protect ideals and principles of international order.
 
Made to Order
Oil seemed an afterthought in the Tuesday night speech, mentioned in just one paragraph. But Mr. Bush went on for pages on the theme that America and its allies were at the birth of a new world order where tyranny and aggression were held in check by international cooperation.
Out on the campaign trail the gulf crisis has frozen out other issues. Oil companies have replaced savings and loans as the organizations a politician least wants to be linked to. But the intervention itself is not really a subject for debate, since close to 80 percent of the country supports it.
Just as Communism collapsed without sending more than a ripple through the campaign dialogue of 1988 and 1989, ''the new world order'' seems to be taking shape, too, without much dialogue between candidates and voters.
But there are glimmers of a debate about how Americans would define success in the Persian Gulf. If Iraq is driven from Kuwait but the United States has to pay most of the bill, will Americans view this as success or failure? If Mr. Bush's new world order is achieved but the peace dividend is spent, will there be tickertape parades?
Those who fail to know history are doomed to repeat it, so they say. But those who do know history seem doomed to an endless search to fit current circumstance to historical precedent.
Increasingly, this seems to apply to political analysts' efforts to understand the political impact of the Persian Gulf intervention, which has helped turn this midterm campaign season into a volatile and complicated one.
Will 1990 be like 1958? That was when President Eisenhower soared in the polls after sending troops to Lebanon, only to watch as a recession pushed the economy to the forefront by Election Day and Republicans took a drubbing. Or will 1990 be more like 1962? That was when Democrats seemed headed for trouble in midterm elections, until the Cuban missile crisis sent President Kennedy's standing soaring and boosted Democrats just before Election Day.
The effort to divine the balance between foreign and domestic concerns is surely relevant in this year of voter discontents. But the past may be poor prologue. It may turn out that this year is one that people look back on later and say, oh yes, that began taking shape in 1990.
 
FALL LINEUPS rrThe end of primary season is in sight. Last week, 10 states and the District of Columbia chose the finalists for their November elections, leaving only three more to vote. Here are some of Tuesday's results.
 
District of Columbia
The Democratic voters of the capital, already assured that their Mayor would not return, chose the only candidate for his job who spoke ill of him. The winner, Sharon Pratt Dixon, rose from last place among the five Democrats with a campaign that promised to rid the District of the organization that Marion Barry built. Even Mayor Barry volunteered, in a television interview, ''certainly, my case has been an example of what some people are very tired of.''
In November, Ms. Dixon, a lawyer, will run against Maurice T. Turner Jr., former police chief and recent convert to the Republican Party. He ran unopposed. About 90 percent of District voters are Democrats.
 
Maryland
The popular Gov. William Donald Schaefer, a Democrat, was easily renominated, and the hawkish Representative Roy P. Dyson, who had suffered the embarrassing disclosure that he was a conscientious objector during the Vietnam war, managed to hold on to the Democratic nomination. Otherwise, Maryland voters were not especially forgiving. They turned out the Montgomery County Executive as well as four state legislators who had opposed abortion rights.
Representative Dyson is expecting a tough campaign; the Republican candidate, Wayne T. Gilchrest, nearly defeated him two years ago. Governor Schaefer will face William S. Shepard, a retired foreign service officer who won the Republican nomination in a close race.
 
Connecticut
United States Representative Bruce A. Morrison, a former legal-aid lawyer from New Haven, was the Democrats' lopsided choice for governor, and the Republican candidate for that job, Representative John G. Rowland, was unopposed. But each has a tougher opponent in former United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., who is running as an independent in the three-way gubernatorial race.
 
Arizona
Evan Mecham, the former car dealer who was Governor for 15 months before his impeachment and conviction in 1988, failed to make a comeback (though he got one in four votes) on the Republican ticket. The winner was J. Fife Symington, a developer. The Democratic nomination went to Terry Goddard, who resigned as Mayor of Phoenix to run.
 
Minnesota
Gov. Rudy Perpich's reputation for eccentricity and his opposition to abortion were the big issues, but he survived with 56 percent of the vote. The Governor, a Democrat, was trailing in polls earlier this year and suffered heavy campaign attacks from Mike Hatch, a former state Commerce Commissioner and a supporter of abortion rights. (Mr. Perpich took to reading aloud on television from out-of-state magazines that described Minnesota as a nice place to live.) Republicans chose Jon Grunseth, a conservative businessman and an abortion opponent.
In the Minnesota Senate race, the Republican incumbent, Rudy Boschwitz, will face Paul Wellstone, a political science professor.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Japan, Not Knowing How to Act, Isn't Sure It Wants To

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
The Middle East crisis has plunged Japan into something resembling a full-scale identity crisis.
Like the characters in ''The Great Gatsby,'' the nation is pushing against a current, borne back ceaselessly into its past, the legacy of its brutal Asian conquests during World War II.
Forty-five years after its crushing defeat, Tokyo remains anxious that any move to assert its interests on the world stage will alarm its neighbors in Asia. Such alarm, in turn, could chill the atmosphere that has been hospitable to Japanese economic penetration in countries it had once sought to conquer militarily. 
Japan has grown comfortable - and wealthy -under the protection of its security alliance with the United States, its American-imposed postwar ''peace constitution'' renouncing the use of force and its military spending at only 1 percent of its gross national product. But Japan's vital interests are at stake in the Middle East today more than ever. For the first time, Japanese citizens have been taken hostage. The American call for Tokyo to think and act in a fashion commensurate with its status as an economic superpower found resonance in some parts of Japan. Yukan Fuji, a popular Tokyo newspaper, accused Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of being ''diplomatically tone deaf'' for failing to heed the call.
''We are passing through a rather agonizing stage of transforming ourselves into an international power,'' acknowledged Taizo Watanabe, the Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman, appealing for patience as Japan sought to resolve its quandaries. But the United States has watched with mounting frustration, deploring Japan's slowness in the face of its reliance on the Middle East for nearly 70 percent of its oil. Congressional resentment of Japan's lack of effort spilled over into a House resolution calling for a reduction of American troops in Japan if Tokyo did not do more to pay for them.
Even with Mr. Kaifu's announcement on Friday of another $3 billion for the drive to isolate Iraq, bringing its total contribution to about $4 billion, the criticism of Japan is unlikely to go away. The bulk of the $2 billion earmarked for economic assistance could come with strings attached, such as lengthy reviews by the International Monetary Fund. The other $2 billion is facing different sorts of problems: So far, Japan has been able to send only 800 four-wheel-drive vehicles because shippers have balked at taking goods into a combat zone.
 
Reasons for Slowness
The factors hampering quick Japanese action are varied. First, many Japanese, either because of self-interest or genuine differences in opinion, disagree that Japan should side with one set of Arabs against another. Business executives, for instance, have long been known for the kind of conservatism that has let them go along with an Arab-demanded boycott of Israel. After American hostages were seized by Iran in 1979, Japan declined to go along with sanctions, saying it would be better to remain on friendly terms.
Such caution has been echoed by senior members of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party and by bureaucrats who do not want Tokyo to spend money in the area. ''Japanese are concerned that once we get into this arena in a far end of the world, we may never get out,'' said Terumasa Nakanishi, professor of politics at Shizuoka University.
The deeper anxieties for Japan have to do with its Constitution and profound ambivalence over visibly asserting its interests - plus a related anxiety about beefing up its military forces.
But the Constitution is not very explicit. Its ban on the use of force would appear at first glance to rule out even the men and weapons that Japan already has in its carefully named Self-Defense Forces. Many analysts feel that because Japan has interpreted the Constitution so loosely, it can get away with another loose interpretation that would allow medical teams and other military personnel in the Middle East.
Then, too, many Japanese appear to be pacifist in nature, especially because of the past. The point was illustrated by a leading industrialist, who said that the first thing he thought of when Iraq invaded Kuwait was not what Japan could do to oppose Baghdad, but how similar Iraq's stated motives were to what Japan said in the 1930's when it annexed Manchuria. Then and now, he noted, the conqueror cloaked its aggression in calls for expelling Westerners, promoting Arab (or Asian) unity, and rallying the have-nots against the haves. The analogy, he said, convinced him that Japan had to avoid a direct military role in the Middle East.
Even so, a consensus seems to be emerging that Tokyo should do more to aid the military efforts of others. Emboldened by this attitude, Mr. Kaifu is expected to submit legislation enabling thousands of Japanese, some of them transferred temporarily out of the military, to go to the gulf in noncombat roles.
A final problem is a Japanese system in which even a Prime Minister is not powerful enough to force a decision if the party and the bureaucracy is divided. Rivals of Mr. Kaifu have made it clear they do not want him to get credit for sweeping changes in Japan's international posture. This bias toward inaction is what Karel van Wolferen, a prominent critic of Japan, calls the ''truncated pyramid'' of Japanese leadership - the lack of someone at the apex to provide action forced by accountability.
It would be hard to imagine Japan being able to live indefinitely in its world of political dependence. But the biggest obstacle Japan has to overcome may lie within. As Seiki Nishihiro, a longtime defense agency official, said, military forces of Japan will be dispatched once the Japanese develop ''self-confidence in their history'' and politicians develop ''self-confidence in civilian control'' of the military. So Japan's biggest challenge in expanding its international role is not whether to trust other countries, but whether to trust itself.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
If Lots of People Feel pain, Is That a Recession?

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Whatever the statistics say, millions of Americans have concluded in recent weeks that the United States is in a recession. They are probably overstating the case. But if the word recession is heard more and more, it certainly reflects the hardship, both actual and anticipated, that is spreading across the country.
Consider these numbers:
* Employment is shrinking in most of the nation. Until May, this had been the case only in New England and a few Midwestern states. But by August, the Labor Department found that over the previous year employment had fallen in six of the nation's nine regions, covering 33 states. ''The story isn't so much layoffs as companies not replacing people who leave,'' said Thomas Plewes, a Labor Department economist.
* Consumer confidence, as measured by various national polls, plunged steeply in August, after the Mideast shock. In past recessions, such sudden drops often appeared in the early months. What happens is that people become fearful about their jobs and the future and they stop making purchases. ''My sense is that the Mideast shock has not worn off and confidence remains very low in September,'' says Richard T. Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's consumer survey. 
 
* Retail sales, as if on cue, dropped sharply in August, the Commerce Department reported Friday. The total spent on gasoline should have risen enough, because of higher fuel prices, to offset lower spending elsewhere. But cutbacks in other categories were so sharp that total sales fell six-tenths of 1 percent -resuming a decline that had been in progress all year, except for June and July.
* In August, for the first time in a year, household income failed to rise in tandem with inflation. Smaller raises, fewer new jobs, less overtime, higher inflation from rising gasoline prices all combined to reverse the pattern. Personal disposable income, which is what people have left to spend after paying their taxes, fell by roughly six-tenths of 1 percent, after adjustment for inflation, said Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. ''When you have a really ugly turn on the income front, like this one, that is a classic signal that the economy is in trouble,'' he said.
There was, of course, bad news before August. Construction spending dried up last spring, and the real estate market softened in much of the country. Defense cutbacks brought thousands of layoffs. And budget cutting meant the Government would play a shrinking role in the spending that keeps an economy going. Still, the view that a recession has arrived meets with considerable resistance at the Federal Reserve, an arbiter of economic trends, and among economists in general. ''The economy is like a taut cord: you have to keep pushing it down to make it stay down,'' said Paul Samuelson, the Nobel laureate in economics. ''It simply does not have a tendency to stagnate on its own. That is a notion we inherited from the 1930's that does not apply to the postwar period.''
For a recession to occur, the economy has to contract for six straight months, a phenomenon that by definition is hard to document until well after it's happened. A prestigious research institute, the National Bureau of Economic Research, rules on when recessions begin and end, delegating this task to a committee of seven prominent economists. But the committee hasn't met since July 8, 1983, when it declared that the 1981-82 recession had ended the previous November.
The committee members do not like to meet until they have agreed among themselves, in telephone conversations, that enough evidence exists to pinpoint a turn in the economy. ''It is certainly possible that we might have another meeting soon if conditions continue to develop as they are,'' said Geoffrey Moore, a member from Columbia University. ''We generally wait until the evidence is pretty decisive before we spend the money on plane fares and hotel rooms.''
But while Mr. Moore, who runs Columbia's Center for International Business Cycle Research, isn't ready to insist on a gathering, he is gradually coming to the view that a recession has started. ''It is not at all certain,'' he said, ''but if a recession is under way, the likely starting month was probably June.''
The Federal Reserve, more than any other Government body, has the power to reverse the deterioration, by lowering interest rates. Lower rates, in turn, encourage people and companies to borrow and spend, thus stimulating the economy. But the Fed has lately resisted making any rate changes. As a result, interest on most mortgages and consumer loans remains above 10 percent.
The prevailing view among the Fed's 18 policymakers, as expressed by several of them in interviews, is that inflation - currently averaging more than 5 percent this year, as measured by the Consumer Price Index - is a greater long-term threat than recession. Specifically, they worry that stimulating the economy by trying to push down interest rates would only increase the odds of severe inflation in 1991.
The Middle East crisis has exacerbated the Federal Reserve's concern over inflation and so, undoubtedly, did the report Friday that the Producer Price Index for finished goods had risen by an alarming 1.3 percent in August, mostly because of higher oil prices. ''Monetary policy has to be patient and not darting here to there based on the latest statistics,'' said Wayne Angell, a Federal Reserve governor. ''There are signs,'' he added, ''that there will be some upward movement in the economy early next year.''
In a similar vein, Robert Black, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, said: ''Most of us at the Federal Reserve would take a little economic sacrifice in the short run if we thought the long-term trade-off, in reduced inflation, far exceeded the short-term discomfort.''
What the Federal Reserve is counting on, of course, is that the discomfort will not turn into official recession. A recession requires quite a bit of deterioration. The nation's wealth, as measured by the Gross National Product, would have to contract for six straight months. For the first time in years, there would be an end to the ever greater production of manufactured goods and the rising outlays for the thousands of services that Americans perform.
Through most of the 1980's, the G.N.P. grew by 3 percent a year or more, and many economists thought that the strong performance had continued well into 1989 - until the Commerce Department revised its figures in July. The new numbers showed that the economy, instead of growing strongly, had expanded since March of 1989 by just enough to stave off recession.
Most recently, in the second quarter of this year, the G.N.P. rose by only $12 billion, after adjustment for inflation, representing a minuscule annual growth rate of 1.2 percent for an economy that generates $4.16 trillion a year in wealth.
Nevertheless, the case for no recession has some arguments going for it. Auto and truck sales, for example, are holding steady at an annual rate of more than 14 million units, although many of the buyers are car rental companies. ''Sales to individuals have weakened, but not to recession levels,'' said Wynn Van Bussman, an economist at the Chrysler Corporation. More important, inventories have not shot up.
Indeed, inventories in all industries have not shot up. That is what ushers in a classic recession: Goods pile up, orders are canceled, factories slash production and lay off workers, and unemployment surges.
Such havoc has not yet appeared, perhaps because exports have taken up the slack as domestic retail sales have declined. Or perhaps Americans have not felt compelled to economize, although events in the Persian Gulf and the tight job market might now be changing their minds.
Or perhaps the current economic slowdown will develop differently from those of the past because of the huge debts that consumers have accumulated. The argument here is an ironic one. If a recession developed, many indebted companies and individuals might be forced into bankruptcy, making the recession unusually severe.
But some economists argue that Americans are well along in the process of working their way out of their debt problems. Just as the boom years of the 1980's reflected the big spending that rising debt made possible, the economic sluggishness of the last 18 months reflects a steady decline in new borrowing, particularly by the private sector.
Total debt rose at 12 percent or more a year in the mid-1980's, according to Federal Reserve data. But since 1987, there has been a sharp decline, and in the first quarter of 1990, debt for all sectors of the economy except the Federal Government rose at an annual rate of only 6.3 percent, the lowest since 1982, a recession year.
''Rather than a severe recession, we are going to have a long workout from the excesses of debt,'' says Albert T. Sommers, a senior economist at the Conference Board. ''And we won't have an upturn until people feel able to borrow easily again.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD: Powers That Be;
It's a New World, Much Like That Of 50 Years Ago

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Nine months into 1990, the world as Americans have known it for most of the last half-century has changed utterly. But in one major respect - the reliance of the free world on American power - it hasn't changed at all.
In the new world, there is no East or West, not in the cold war sense. The Soviet Union, spinning toward economic revolution or collapse - it's hard to tell which - seems incapable of opposing Western aims, so it goes along with them. Last week Moscow symbolically signed away its Eastern European empire in an agreement with the United States, Britain and France, the allied powers of World War II, to restore sovereignty to a united Germany after Oct. 3.
Perhaps this was a desperate, long-shot Soviet gamble that out of the economic ruins of Central Europe, a united Germany would help build a new pillar of prosperity onto which Moscow, too, could cling. 
That may yet be. What is clear now is that at least in the near term, a united Germany can no more be a superpower, in the American sense, than Japan is. Both are powerful economic entities that disastrously tried to project their power around the world; both now see regional peace as the way to allow their prosperous and stable societies to continue healing the wounds of war.
Nor is Europe a superpower, as its fragmentary and hesitant responses to American pleas for help in the gulf crisis show. Europe is, in some senses, an economic unity, and will be even more so after the single market of 336 million people is created at the end of 1992. But its profoundly different, and still sovereign, nation-states could not get together to bring that economic power to bear in any meaningful sense in the Persian Gulf.
Germany, asked to help pay for the $100-billion American military buildup, pleaded that it was contributing to Western security in other ways: paying $8 billion to get Soviet troops out of central Europe by 1994, and paying $60 billion a year or more until then to bring its new eastern provinces economically into the late 20th century, let alone the 21st.
France, outraged after Iraq raided its ambassador's residence in Kuwait last week, announced that it was sending 4,000 combat troops, tanks and other equipment to the gulf, bringing the forces it has there to 13,000, including 14 ships and 100 anti-tank helicopters. The French ships, like the United States Navy and British and other allied forces, are in the gulf to help enforce the United Nations economic blockade of Iraq, but operate under separate national commands.
A day earlier Britain, the European ally most eager to help the United States unconditionally, decided to move 6,000 to 8,000 combat troops, 120 tanks, and air and ground support units from Germany to the gulf in the coming weeks to supplement the ships, planes and ground support troops Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher had already moved to Saudi Arabia, Bahrain and Oman. But the United States has been adding that many troops and tanks to its force in the region every week for seven weeks. It does not belittle the British contribution, which Mrs. Thatcher made in direct response to the United States' plea for more help, to say that it was simply not on the same scale as the 100,000-strong American force. And she made it the way European powers, and indeed, the United States, have always made their decisions, in shrewd calculation of their own national self-interest.
In this respect the world is no different now than 50 years ago, when America was drawn back into European affairs after 20 years of isolation. But as the 20th century dawned, Americans were eager to become the world's policeman and make it safe for democracy.
Now, in the predawn of the 21st, they look around for someone to help them carry the burden. Why, they ask, has the world not become less threatening to the American way of life even after the cold war?
Some would argue that the real threat, somehow underlying the crisis in the gulf, is the poverty and instability of so many countries in the developing world, like Iraq and others in the Mideast, Latin America and Africa, that have turned to despotism and dictatorship partly in reaction to the Western imperialist past.
''The poor countries are getting poorer, and the rich countries are getting richer,'' said President Francois Mitterrand of France at a recent conference on hatred in Oslo. This, too, has consequences, as former President Jimmy Carter pointed out when he noted that of the 116 armed conflicts in the world, all but one - Iraq's invasion of Kuwait - are civil wars, not wars between countries.
Over the years the cold war often blinded both the United States and the Soviet Union to the root causes of third-world conflicts, leading them to arm surrogate tyrants to the teeth, thus prolonging the violence and adding to the underlying misery rather than alleviating it.
This began to change in the 1980's, as Moscow became disheartened in Afghanistan. But in the Arab world, things first started to change after the Arab-Israeli war of 1973. Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has turned the Arab world upside down once more, perhaps giving Egypt a chance to emerge again as its leader after years of being shunned by other Arab countries for having made peace with Israel. Last week even Syria, one home of anti-Western terrorism, was making friendly noises toward the United States, with President Hafez al-Assad receiving Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and agreeing, too, to send a force of 10,000 troops and tanks to face Iraqi forces on the Saudi peninsula.
But countries that are enemies today can turn into friends tomorrow. Iran, only two years after fighting the costliest war of the 1980's - against Iraq - edged closer to supporting Iraq against the Western embargo last week when its spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, declared that the struggle against foreign military forces in the gulf was a holy war for all Muslims.
For many ordinary Europeans, indeed probably for many Americans, Russians and Japanese, the temptation is to think that Iraq's annexation of Kuwait means no more than Hitler's annexation of the Sudetenland meant to Neville Chamberlain, the British Prime Minister in 1938.
''How horrible, fantastic, incredible it is that we should be digging trenches and trying on gas-masks here because of a quarrel in a faraway country between people of whom we know nothing,'' Chamberlain said then.
Now everyone knows better. But it is also tempting for politicians, particularly in Washington, to exaggerate both the burden of facing up to Saddam Hussein's aggression and the contribution that can realistically be made by the Western allies.
If this crisis had occurred a decade ago, the world would be teetering at the brink of World War III. It isn't today, and countries like Japan and Germany that, unlike the United States, have vastly improved their energy efficiency since the oil crisis of the 1970's are not so prone as Americans are to see a vital threat to their way of life when the price of crude rises above $30 a barrel. Even though they import virtually all their oil, they can afford to pay the price, and if necessary further improve their efficiency at using it.
But since the United States is the only superpower, it's hard to see either how the Japanese, the Europeans or anyone else can substitute for it, or how Americans can escape the burden of responsibility that comes with its power.
In Europe, a new era of German-Soviet detente in Mitteleuropa may be opening, but without the balance provided by a continuing United States commitment, the British and the French, not to mention the Poles, Czechs and Slovaks, could see it as a destabilizing threat.
In Asia, Soviet-Japanese or Chinese-Japanese detente on the scale of what has happened in Europe this year could easily lead to regional instability unless the United States provides a counterweight. This is especially true so long as China remains locked in its totalitarian straitjacket.
Taking the lead in devising a stable economic and political balance in the fragmented, economically devastated countries of Africa will be more challenging for the United States; a greater part of the burden perhaps should go to European countries with ties and interests there.
And as observers and government officials here see it, the United States will never have full credibility anywhere in the developing world until it builds a more enlightened economic and political relationship with all the states of Latin America.
''Roosevelt! Thou shouldst be living at this hour!'' wrote the British essayist Timothy Garton Ash in The Independent last week, recalling Franklin D. Roosevelt's dreams for a new postwar order that seemed, at first glance, to have come true. But after examining the complexities, he concluded: ''Roosevelt! Perhaps you're better off where you are.'' Would that it turns out that he's wrong.

LENGTH: 446 words

HEADLINE: Vietnam Is Not the Enemy

 BODY:
You thought it was 1990, and the enemy was Iraq. No. For some policy makers in the Bush Administration it remains 1975, and the enemy remains Vietnam. There's no other plausible explanation for the Administration's self-defeating decision to extend the U.S. economic embargo against Vietnam for one more year under the Trading With the Enemy Act of 1917. 
The embargo prevents Americans from most trading with Vietnam or with Vietnamese nationals abroad. American companies cannot organize tours to Vietnam, and individual American travelers cannot use credit cards.
There are limited exceptions for humanitarian activities and gift packages to individual Vietnamese. But U.S. phone companies can't provide service to Vietnam, a cruel hardship for Vietnamese here who want to stay in touch with family members.
The Vietnam War is over. The cold war is over. Washington and Hanoi have begun cooperating productively in efforts to achieve a political settlement in Cambodia. Progress is also being made on humanitarian issues, from the orderly departure of Vietnamese refugees to the search for remains or traces of American soldiers missing in action. Meanwhile, Vietnam is pursuing a serious program of market-oriented economic reforms. Businessmen from anti-Communist bastions like Taiwan and Singapore are moving aggressively to profit from Hanoi's liberal foreign investment code. American business organizations are pressing for an early end to the U.S. embargo, which punishes them at least as much as it punishes Vietnam.
U.S. restrictions have helped keep Vietnam one of the world's poorest countries, feeding the mass exodus of refugees toward Hong Kong and the countries of Southeast Asia. The pressure is sure to grow in the coming months as Soviet aid is scheduled to be cut back drastically. Some argue that the pressure could spark a revolt against Communist rule. More likely, increased economic contacts with the West would increase pressure for democratic political reform.
The Bush Administration made just that argument last spring when it extended China's trade privileges in the face of Beijing's post-Tiananmen hard line. The same logic applies even more clearly to Vietnam, which is moving toward reform.
Congress has no say over the Administration's action, which came by executive order. But Representative Howard Berman of California, recognizing that person-to-person contacts can advance democratic values far more efficiently than embargoes, has introduced a bill that would ease U.S. travel restrictions for countries where Americans face no special dangers. Renewal of the embargo against Vietnam shows how badly such reform is needed.

HEADLINE: Japanese Cars Aren't More Fuel Efficient

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Washington's Mood Worries Detroit'' (Business Day, Sept. 3) discusses the concern of the automobile industry over possibly more stringent fuel-efficiency requirements, perhaps based on a percentage reduction in fuel consumption for each manufacturer's fleet.
You say, ''Japanese-made autos are already more fuel efficient than those of American companies.'' That is not true. Japanese manufacturers simply make fleets of smaller cars. Thus, their fleet mileage averages are higher. The very fine new Nissan Infiniti is a gas guzzler, while none of the Chrysler, Ford or General Motors models in the same Environmental Protection Agency-designated ''midsize'' category is. And there are 22 domestic models in that class. Even the ''two-ton behemoth,'' the 1991 Buick Roadmaster, which will be in the ''large car'' category, will not be a gas guzzler. It may be legitimately argued that that is fuel efficiency.
One can certainly be critical of our industry for not doing a better job of making small cars and so letting that segment of the market get away, but one cannot say the Japanese cars are more fuel efficient because of fleets of little cars.
You also confuse efficiency and economy with consumption. That is important because there comes a point at which efficiency cannot be increased, and for the manufacturer to cut consumption means cutting size, weight or performance. (Economy requires public involvement - that's something else.) That's why the Japanese are upset. A percentage reduction means that all cars, small and large, would have to have their fuel consumption reduced. This at a time when the Japanese are set to move further into the larger car mar-ket.
 
GERTRUDE I. MCWILLIAMS
Editor & Publisher, Concerning Cars
Pound Ridge, N.Y., Sept. 4, 1990
