HEADLINE: When the Two Germanys Unite, What Happens to the Bavarian Yodeler?

BYLINE: By Peter Schneider; Peter Schneider, a novelist who lives in West Berlin, is writing a book on the new Germany for Farrar Straus & Giroux. This article is translated from the German by Eileen Baum.

 BODY:
Dec. 17, 1989, Was the day i lost confidence in my television's remote-control device. It was just after the evening news broadcast on West Germany's ARD network, and Alois Moig, a 200-pounder attired in Alpine dress, appeared on the screen surrounded by a group of Bavarian yodelers and promising 90 minutes of folk music.
By pressing the remote-control button, I hoped to escape to East Germany's Channel 2, where I had often taken refuge from Alois Moig by watching Italian and French detective films from the 1960's. This time, I couldn't believe my eyes: instead of Claudia Cardinale or Gian Maria Volonte, instead of Simone Signoret or Jean Gabin, who should appear on the screen but another corpulent master of ceremonies, a carbon copy of Moig, from shoelaces to Loden coat. The only difference was that on the East German program, the members of a brass band lifted their instruments to their lips as they thundered onto the stage in formation.
The host introduced them as the Gasworks Band of Schwarze Pumpe. Was that the voice of Alois Moig? Or did he have a twin in the Erz Mountains whom the revolution had brought into the spotlight? A look at my TV guide straightened me out. I was watching one of the first East German-West German TV programs, transmitted live from the East German city of Cottbus - and presented by none other than Alois Moig. 
As the evening wore on, the program hammered away at the message, Music Knows No Borders. Thigh-slapping Bavarians whooped it up to melodies from this Saxon factory orchestra, Swiss yodelers found their echo in the Erz Mountains, dancers from deepest Bavaria stamped their feet on the wooden floor in time with folk groups from Thuringia, zither players from the Alps vied with fiddling tractor drivers from Mecklenburg. Whatever 40 years of opposing educational systems had done to make the two German peoples different, lederhosen, blond braids and dirndls caused them to forget in minutes.
The musical reunion of the two Germanys would have met with professional interest in Minneapolis and St. Paul, because there, right in the Twin Cities, Prof. Thomas J. Bouchard Jr. has for the past 10 years been conducting a long-running study on twins.
The eminent professor has taken it upon himself to solve one of mankind's ancient puzzles: is it nature or nurture that determines human behavior? Bouchard's investigations have shown that identical twins, even when separated at birth and reared in totally different environments, exhibit personality traits that are similar to the point of absurdity.
The most famous case is that of the Jim twins, separated at four weeks and raised in different Ohio cities. Thirty-nine years later, each brother had divorced his first wife, named Linda, and remarried, to a Betty. Their sons were named James Allan and James Alan. Each had a dog named Toy and each had worked first as a gas station attendant and later as a sheriff's deputy. Each brother drove a Chevrolet, and each had a garden with a tree encircled by a wooden bench that he had painted white.
The German equivalents - the Hansel or Gretchen twins - have yet to be documented. But the psychologists nevertheless have their work cut out for them. The area stretching from the Rhine to the Oder River presents a vast laboratory - an involuntary experiment for the subjects, a stroke of good luck for researchers. The question, frivolously put: What happens to a people reared for decades in such radically different boarding schools? Which character traits will prove resistant to change and for how long? Which will disappear overnight?
For years now the experts have entertained two diametrically opposed hypotheses. One hypothesis, which might be referred to as the icebox theory, maintains that Communism has acted as a deep freezer, preserving intact the historical peculiarities and passions of the East German people. Now that the refrigerator is set on defrost, they will take up exactly where they left off 45 years before. All the lovely socialist virtues and achievements that have been rammed down their throats will melt away like old snow. National character traits, which developed over centuries - the good as well as the bad - will, on the first day of spring, reawaken intact and thereafter will continue to determine behavior.
The champions of the nurture theory insist that social experience (even the starved Communist one) molds people at least as decisively as their inherited traditions. Forty years of differing curriculums must have left a mark on the pupils, differences that can be seen in child-rearing practices, relations between the sexes and other aspects of social behavior.
For lack of access to the subjects, these questions remained purely speculative until now. Since the opening of the Berlin Wall, however, some preliminary results are in. At first glance the evidence overwhelmingly favors the proponents of the icebox theory, with one citizen in particular presenting the pattern for the rest of his compatriots. On Aug. 12, 1961, an East German man had borrowed three books from the American Memorial Library in West Berlin. The Berlin Wall, which was begun on Aug. 13, afforded him ample time to read but caused him to miss the due date by 28 years. The first thing this faithful book borrower did when the wall opened up was make his way to the American Memorial Library. He returned the books, in excellent condition, on Nov. 10, 1989, 28 years late.
Yet it is inevitable that two such diverse historical experiences will affect the psyche and behavior of citizens in both Germanys. Equally certain is the fact that these differences will provide fertile ground for mutual misunderstanding. But which of these real or imagined differences will survive this East-West encounter and which will disappear? The answers should not be long in coming, now that a firm date has been set for unification - Oct. 3 - and agreement has been reached on all practical aspects of the merger.
Among the short-lived characteristics of the East German species, treasured above all by Western admirers, is the so-called Nischenkultur. The term refers to virtues that flourish in a culture of neighborliness, and though it carries a touch of nostalgia for times past, it is grounded in reality. It is a society of ''helping one's neighbors,'' ''human warmth,'' ''judging an individual on his merits, not his success.'' ''Friendship still counts,'' one hears, and ''life moves at a slower pace in East Germany.''
East German citizens recognize these characteristics, born of privation, only after arriving in the West, where they are absent. East Germans are bothered by the coldness of a society founded on competition, by glitzy facades behind which there is nothing, by the general climate of harshness and materialism.
But virtues that basically owed their existence to privation and failure disappear with unexpected speed when the conditions themselves disappear. One can sometimes even observe an about-face. More than a few East Germans, accepting without question the official picture of the West as heartless, seek their salvation in success at all costs. In vain, Westerners try to explain to them that even in the capitalist world one can find a Mensch.
There is one characteristic that has an excellent chance of surviving. Because East Germany suffered greater economic dislocation as a result of the Second World War, East Germans are laying claim to a Lastenausgleich - an equalization of burdens - that East German historians have estimated at scores of billions. These claims have given rise to a pattern of behavior among East Germans - Anspruchsverhalten, as it's called, or a sense of entitlement - that West Germans regard with increasing irritation. Their usual reaction is to turn a resolutely blind eye to history.
West Berlin taxi drivers complain of East German passengers who, when it's time to pay the fare, say, ''Um, I'm from the East.'' One bar owner reported that large groups of East Germans in those infamous stone-washed jeans hoped to pay their bill with: ''How about a free drink? We're from over there.''
In the first weeks after the wall came down, West Berlin's elderly looked on with envy as their counterparts from the East simply waved their blue East German passes when boarding buses or entering the subway, normally a $1.50 fare. Suddenly, East German passports were being traded on the black market like stocks and bonds: for $60 to $90, West German citizens voluntarily transformed themselves into East Germans.
Even the well-to-do felt compelled to sound off about problems that one would not exactly call life-or-death. Mercedes owners were angered that they had to pay the tow-away costs of their illegally parked cars, while East German Trabis - the little two-stroke Trabants - remained untouched. Sales managers grumbled about the ''museum pace'' of clients from the East who gazed devoutly at the goods but didn't buy. Trummerfrauen - the women who cleared away the rubble of Germany's bombed-out cities by hand - invoked the heroic days after '45: ''We also had to start from zero, and no one helped us!''
Here two incompatible versions of postwar history collide. The conflict is programmed and will continue well into the future. When West Germans say ''I've worked hard for all this,'' East German visitors counter with: ''You were just lucky.'' Neither side is willing to take lightly the issue of hard work and who deserves what. Here, sterotypes, perceptions and mutual finger-pointing become hopelessly entangled. A West German story tells of a baker from East Germany who, when he learns during his initial job interview that West German bakeries are never short of flour, takes off, unwilling to give up the daily breaks caused by a lack of materials. Such tales quickly become popular and take on the authority of statistics. According to one poll, two-thirds of West German employers have noticed ''a lack of certain qualities'' in the emigres, and complain of poor performance, lack of teamwork and low motivation.
The griefs and sorrows of West German employers are answered by an East German chorus. Employees complain about the ''inhuman work tempo,'' ''demeaning treatment,'' and ''unpleasant tone'' they have encountered in West Germany. Used-car dealers from the West are already notorious; they unload their lemons on East Germans at fantasy prices. One East German story tells of how a West German plasma company extracted blood from currency-hungry East Germans at bargain rates. The headline in West Berlin's Communist newspaper read: ''West German vampires suck East German blood.''
Socialist habits will face hard times. But in areas where the socialist experiment serves the self-interest of a majority of the experimental subjects, it will continue to have an effect. The right to work, guaranteed in the old East German Constitution, will be sacrificed to unification. But it cannot be deleted with a mere wave of a pen, at least not from people's heads.
Economists estimate that introducing a market economy will cost at least 2 million East Germans their jobs; other estimates run as high as 5 million unemployed. The majority of East German voters expressed a willingness to accept high unemployment as a cost of reform. But when it actually happens, many will remember the advantages they have renounced: cheap rents, guaranteed jobs, a leisurely work pace, the tyrannical but protective hand of the state, which removed citizens from the decision-making process but also relieved their anxiety about the future. However East German citizens finally evaluate their 40-year experience, compared with the Federal Republic, they lived in a society of equals. It doesn't take a crystal ball to predict that that experience could prove socially explosive. In an economic crisis, the East Germans will find themselves second-class citizens.
The East German response to Nazism will also resist change. Anti-fascism was official state doctrine in the German Democratic Republic, from the state's inception until its demise. Former National Socialists were removed from their posts in education, the civil service, the judicial system, administration, the schools, the postal and railroad systems, physicians' groups and above all in the trade and industry of the young German state.
But the accompanying ideological music made the whole achievement dubious. Ver-gangenheitsbewaltigung - coming to grips with the Nazi past - was described in the East German Constitution of 1949, Article 6, Paragraph 1, as already having been successfully completed: ''The German Democratic Republic . . . has, within its national borders, uprooted and destroyed militarism and Nazism.'' This instant success was possible only by bureaucratic fiat: whoever joined the party was clean. Card-carrying replaced remorse. In the course of time the anti-facist refrain grew into a full-blown historical lie: according to it, East Germany was not only the post- but also the pre-1945 home of the anti-fascist resistance. The Nazi monster had miraculously stopped at the Elbe.
The success of this propaganda effort is documented by a school class's compositions commemorating the end of the war in Europe. A majority of pupils expressed their conviction that East German troops fighting at the side of the Red Army had freed Germany from Hitler's fascism. Unlike other subjects offered by the socialist curriculum, this revision of history has taken root among the populace. The government's need to legitimize its dictatorial policies coincided nicely with the desire of the governed for relief from historical responsibility. The result of East Germany's educational policy has been Germans with a clear conscience.
No one would seriously maintain that citizens of the Federal Republic have over the last 40 years been overcome with guilt because of their National Socialist past. But the assertion that their society had recognized its guilt and ''uprooted and destroyed Fascism'' would not be credible because it could too easily be proven false: too many Nazi judges, Nazi doctors and Nazi professors enjoyed and still enjoy their pensions undisturbed in West Germany. Every attempt to smooth over Nazi crimes and find excuses for the Germans has triggered strong protests both internationally and in West Germany. So a peculiar result of all this has been that the Federal Republic, which never made such a radical political break with its past, has repressed its Nazi past less - was less able to repress it - than the anti-fascist German Democratic Republic.
Democracy imported from the Western Allies gave the Federal Republic the chance to undo the worst inheritance of German history: the culture of subservience to authority. In the German Democratic Republic, on the other hand, this inheritance was taken over and continued by the socialist dictatorship. As a result, East Germany has no experience with any form of democracy, which many of its intellectuals regard with utter contempt. Subservience to authority was first questioned during the 1989 revolution.It remains to be seen how deep the change really is. Less than a year of grass-roots democracy is up against 56 years of dictatorship.
But let's get to the most pressing issue: how did the postwar division affect the German character, that unpredictable creature?
Dr. Hans Joachim Maaz, head of psychotherapy at the Protestant Social Services Foundation in Halle, recently made headlines with his finding that ''the average East German citizen is authority-dependent, emotionally repressed, and above all incapable of experiencing pleasure.''
But another East German professor, from Leipzig, claims to have found that the ''rate of orgasms in East Germany is higher'' than in the West: 37 percent of the East German women questioned said they had reached their target every time or almost every time they had sex; among their West German sisters, on the other hand, only 26 in 100 obtained their objective. The East German news agency, A.D.N., reported this piece of news under patriotic headlines: ''Experts Fear Cooling of East German Sex.''
So much for the pleasure principle. Dr. Maaz's other two characteristics are equally suspect. The dictatorship caused the typical East German to construct more of a barrier between himself and the outside world than the West German, but anyone who had the opportunity to talk to East Germans during the days and months of upheaval had to be amazed at the forthrightness of their comments.
The species that will prove itself most capable of surviving is the East German woman; she is the one product of which East German culture can be proud. To the West German man, weakened by the battle of the sexes, she is a puzzle: employed, self-confident, a decision maker yet feminine. He doesn't understand the mix. And even more important, she still desires men, although not him, the West German softie, although she does admire him.
In carrying out the simple dogma of Friedrich Engels that emancipation begins in the sphere of production, socialism has been comparatively successful. More than 90 percent of East German women are employed; in neighboring West Germany it is roughly 50 percent. East Germany has spared no expense to insure equal opportunity for its women. A full range of social programs cushions the contradictory demands of work and motherhood: kindergarten guaranteed and virtually free; one year off with full pay after the birth of a child; complete freedom of choice concerning abortion. Although of one mind on the abortion issue, East and West German women exhibit differences that have been programmed into the two cultures. West German women criticize their East German sisters for relieving their spouses of household and child-rearing duties. But the West German woman must face the fact that although she has trained her husband to cook and change diapers, she is still economically dependent on him.
In one area, especially, East and West German women do not see eye to eye - their choice in men. The East German woman admits that when it comes to housework and child rearing, she is still living in the 19th century. But she finds the insecure male who now populates West Germany and the United States a perfect horror: she'll take an East German roughneck anytime.
In fact, under the wings of the strong yet domestically traditional East German wife, a prehistoric male species has survived: the East German macho. I see little chance of his survival, and for this reason I wish to put in a good word for him. Could we not set aside for him a small nature preserve guaranteed by Greenpeace, or a heavily guarded conservation area, if only in the interest of maintaining diversity of the species?
I am not saying that the East German male will no longer be represented in the Western zoo. But in the West such an unadulterated macho type can be observed today only in the underworld. The West German male 40 and under changes diapers in a thoroughly professional manner, to the astonishment of his East German counterpart. He's a passionate cook and even does the dishes on occasion. He discusses with his wife or girlfriend which one can go out on a given evening and which one has to stay home and baby-sit; he cooperates in contraception. The East German woman is the first to discover a flaw in this ideal figure. She compliments him, but she finds him schlapp - wimpy. The worst shock has been his introduction to the East German macho. How is it possible for a beautiful, desirable, emancipated woman to be happy with this dinosaur?
In fact our enlightened Western male finds himself more provoked by East Germany's machos than by West Germany's emancipated women. Freshly weaned smokers are especially sensitive to cigarette smoke. East German machos parade in front of the West German male all the vices the West German has tirelessly sought to free himself from and prizes them as effective weapons of erotic competition. What does this Neanderthal have to offer? He puts his feet on the table, demands to be waited on, doesn't even earn as much as his wife. He wouldn't dream of cooking, washing or changing diapers. Nevertheless, he is preferred, even loved. He must have something that the West German male doesn't know about and the East German woman won't reveal.
All these ethnological differences could turn out to be exciting. They promise curious collisions, amusing imbroglios, marvelous misunderstandings and productive fights. But the test subjects must recognize their learned responses and be prepared to face criticism, instead of cooking the differences together in one Unity pot. In the political arena, the economic victor must not be smug with victory.
Meanwhile, the wall has been coming down. Dozens of streets are being rejoined, subway lines reopened. Berlin, which now has two of everthing - city halls, television towers, zoos and citizenries - is creating a unified face for itself. The city's two Mayors have agreed to completely eliminate the wall. But why?
The wall is the last tangible reminder of Germany's war guilt, an open wound that could not be closed. Removing the wall completely may also eliminate the memory of guilt. It may perhaps paving the way for the successful introduction into a unified Germany of East German culture's deadliest product, the German with a clear conscience It's over. We are a normal people once again. Does anyone still mistrust us? The neighbors' fears we understand, but they are hopelessly out of date. These historical anxieties are a disguise for your fear of our hard work and efficiency and of your own sloppiness. There's no law against becoming an economic superpower - it's the marketplace that decides. And by the way, you victorious allies, listen up, no one is forced to play the role of No. 1 when he's no longer in the economic position to do so. Still, it's curious that Germany and Japan, the losers of the Second World War, come out the real winners 45 years later. You can find some of the reasons by consulting the works of Marx and Engels, and by the way, history isn't just. Are we interested in a new armed conquest of Europe? You don't even believe that story yourself. And it just so happens that armed conquest is no longer necessary! That is the nightmare version of German unity. But there is also an optimistic version. A normalization of the situation might even make the Germans more normal, meaning self-confident in the generous sense of the term, more tolerant, friendlier to foreigners, funnier. In short - one hardly dares write it - happier.
The uncanny efficiency of the divided Germans received nourishment from the same root that fed fascist subservience to authority: weariness with life, general unhappiness, and the resultant virtues and vices: discipline, punctuality, obstinacy and that ''I know better'' attitude. Discontented nations, even when they are rich, remain dangerous.
But now, for the first time in modern history, Germans have no ''knife-in-the-back'' canard, no Versailles, not even a wall - nothing to trigger their phobia about feeling surrounded. More important, thanks to the turmoil of reunifying two economic and cultural systems, Germans will have to renounce their excessive demands for personal security. They will be faced with conditions like those in Italy: chaos, disorder, criminality, all of it homemade. Perhaps as a result, their approach will be more laissez-faire and good humored.
It's not easy to believe in this optimistic version. However, there is no other choice but to hope.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 52, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3370 words

HEADLINE: Inside The Arsenals

BYLINE: By John H. Cushman Jr.; John H. Cushman Jr. is a correspondent in the Washington bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
For weeks, an endless military caravan has disgorged metal and explosives onto the sands of Saudi Arabia. No sooner did the American buildup begin than Pentagon commanders started to draw up the so-called order of battle - an ever-shifting account of the forces arrayed on each side. They calibrated the speed, reach, accuracy and deadliness of weapons, and worked on a strategy to take advantage of their strengths and Iraq's presumed weaknesses.
The mustering of such immense armies belies the notion that large-scale mechanized warfare vanished with the cold war. Since the Vietnam War, American technology has, in fact, produced an awesome arsenal: a laser-guided artillery round that costs $30,000 a shot, planes virtually invisible to radar and mobile computerized boxes that belch rockets. The most potent ones are untested in combat, but they share one thing: almost incomprehensible destructive power. Yet with all their impressive infrared optics, digital computers and laser range finders, they are not invulnerable to desert heat or human error.
For its part, Iraq is deep in tanks, artillery, armored personnel carriers, missiles and a muscular modern air force that backs up the country's million fighting men. 
Saddam Hussein spent oil earnings and borrowed heavily to buy weapons from countries as diverse as the Soviet Union, China, France, Brazil, South Africa and Austria. Some weapons even originated in the United States. Some were delivered by way of Saudi Arabia, and many, paradoxically, were financed by Kuwait.
Even though they blitzed defenseless Kuwait in a matter of hours, the Iraqi forces are actually tailored for a prolonged war. The 10-year war against Iran was a war of attrition: of artillery barrages and haphazard missile strikes against distant civilian targets. The United States force now assembled in the Middle East, in contrast, prefers rapid, fierce fighting. Protracted standoffs are not part of the new American military thinking.
American strategy is based on supremacy in the air. Early in the buildup in the Persian Gulf, the United States and its allies achieved numerical superiority: hundreds of fighters and bombers flew into the region, and five aircraft carriers - four American and one French - were deployed in surrounding waters. In all, the allies had more than 700 warplanes available early this month.
But the Iraqi Air Force is formidable. According to Periscope, a data base of the United States Naval Institute, Saddam Hussein's forces in the sky depend on 100 Mirage jets from France, 30 Hunter fighters of British origin and about 400 Soviet planes. Most of the Soviet craft are MIG's, many of them modern, highly capable fighting machines. Iraq also has perhaps 120 Chinese J-6 and J-7 jets, which are less impressive. The latest reported addition is a small number of Soviet Fencer long-range bombers.
The Mirage, when armed with French Exocets and other air-to-ground weapons, is well suited for attacks on ships and other large targets, like oil refineries. In 1987 an Iraqi Mirage launched two Exocet missiles at the Stark, an American frigate on patrol in the Persian Gulf to protect oil tankers. The Stark, unprepared for the attack, was gutted, and 37 crew members died. The Iraqis insisted the strike was an accident.
The overwhelming air power now facing Hussein's forces is built around Awacs - the E-3 Airborne Warning and Control System. Using modified Boeing 707's, the system's aircraft carry a saucerlike radar above the fuselage and communications devices that link the whole field of battle into a single picture. The Awacs can detect low-flying targets 230 miles away and can see higher-flying airplanes at even greater distances.
Five American and five Saudi Awacs are in the region now. So are several Hawkeyes, similar craft that take off from aircraft carriers.
According to Aviation Week and Space Technology, which quoted unnamed Israeli analysts, French electronics could be loaded onto a Soviet transport plane, the Il-76, to do the same job as an Awacs. But experts doubt the Iraqis have enough of the planes, or a proficient enough air force, to make good use of the technology.
The unarmed American and Saudi Awacs are defended by F-15 Eagles, which are equipped with missiles as well as jammers and other protective devices. Perhaps 200 American and Saudi F-15's are based in Saudi Arabia; they are bolstered by similar British and French aircraft. A few dozen Kuwaiti jets also escaped to Saudi Arabia when Iraq attacked.
Americans also fly the F-16, which, like the latest models of the F-15, can be equipped for nighttime raids on ground targets, and the AV-8B Harrier, a Marine Corps jump jet that can take off vertically and hover like a helicopter.
The FA-18 Hornet, flown by the Marines from airstrips in Bahrain and by the Navy from aircraft carriers, illustrates the flexibility the military has in arming planes. The Hornets have nine external weapon stations, which can carry air-to-air and ground-attack missiles as well as various bombs, including laser-guided ones.
The Navy's F-14 Tomcats also fly from the aircraft carriers. Pairs of these powerful planes, stationed on a carrier just outside the Strait of Hormuz, circle near Kuwaiti waters day and night. Refueling in midair, they are the first line of defense for allied warships.
In dogfights, the gutsy pilot swooping down on his adversary with machine guns blazing is a relic of wars past. Nowadays the strength of an American fighter jet is in its missiles, principally the Sparrow and the Sidewinder.
Like many air-to-air missiles, the Sidewinder is guided by infrared sensors that home in on heat signals from a jet's engines. Unlike most missiles, which have to be positioned behind an enemy jet to detect the heat signals, the latest Sidewinders can attack from all angles, including head-on. Gone too are the days when a pilot caught a glimpse, however fleeting, of his opponent. The Sidewinder's range is more than 10 miles. The Sparrow, guided by radar instead of infrared sensors, has a range of more than 30 miles and can also attack from any angle.
The Americans' most potent missile for combat in the air, however, may be the Phoenix, carried by Navy F-14's. Its range is up to 127 miles, and it flies at five times the speed of sound. The F-14, reportedly able to track 24 targets at once, can launch six of the missiles, which use their own radar to hit targets.
But the Phoenix has never been used in combat, and it was plagued by problems during tests. At one time hundreds of them were stockpiled while the Navy looked for a fuse to detonate the warhead at the right moment. That problem was reportedly fixed in 1988.
Iraq has several Soviet-made air-to-air missiles, some guided by their own radar but none with the Phoenix's range. Iraq also has the French-built R.530 air-to-air missile, which has a relatively short range.
Air Force F-111's, some based in Saudi Arabia, and the A-6, flying from land bases and naval aircraft carriers, are the most effective planes for deep strikes - against targets like runways, control towers, and fuel and arms depots. They can drop anything from immense cratering bombs to cluster bombs full of grenades or small mines.
Simultaneously, the F-4 Wild Weasel could destroy enemy air defense systems outright, launching Shrike and Harm missiles, which are drawn to their targets by the very signals ground radar emits as it searches for attacking planes. The American forces also have powerful electronic jammers on many airplanes that can confuse or blind enemy radar.
Lumbering B-52's have been stationed within striking distance of Iraq. So have about 20 Stealth fighters, the Air Force's boxy, swallow-tailed machine made of composite materials that elude radar. Like its larger cousin, the batlike Stealth bomber, which is not yet ready for combat, the little fighter is intended to catch enemy defenses off guard.
Saddam Hussein's forces are mightiest on the ground. He is estimated to have a million men under arms and 5,500 tanks in his armored divisions.
Tanks are intimidating, but in modern armies they are married to infantry (mostly riding in vehicles), artillery, helicopters and rockets - an alliance of frighteningly destructive firepower.
The Iraqis are believed to have about 500 T-72's, the most potent Soviet tank, and an indeterminate number of impressive British-built Chieftains. They may have only 30, as the Naval Institute Data Base has reported, or they may have captured hundreds of the tanks from Iran, according to Jane's Armor and Artillery. But many Iraqi tanks - while still deadly - are nearing obsolescence. For example, Iraq has 1,000 Soviet T-62 tanks, which, Jane's says, have a 50-50 chance of hitting targets from 1,500 meters, if the tanks stop moving before they shoot. Iraq is also equipped with thousands of even less effective tanks, from the Soviet Union and China.
The best American tank, the M1 Abrams, has unparalleled speed, armor, accuracy and range, but it hasn't proved itself in combat. Weighing more than 50 tons and propelled by a powerful gas-turbine engine, the tank is best suited for leading an assault and has substantial advantages over any Iraqi armor. It can shoot on the move and fire every few seconds. Aiming it is no more difficult than operating a video game, and it can be as deadly at night as in daytime. The newest M1 can shoot a 53-pound projectile two miles - a distinct improvement over previous models. Because of their weight, the tanks had to be sent by ship, so the first M1's didn't arrive in Saudi Arabia until the end of August.
The first American tank on the scene, flown in with the 82d Airborne Division, was the relatively light Sheridan. With its gun-fired Shillelagh missile, the Sheridan is an old tank that did not perform well in Vietnam.
The Marine Corps arrived later with M60 tanks, which, supported by guns, helicopters, planes, antitank weapons and some 40,000 troops, quickly formed the main blocking force south of the Saudi-Kuwait border.
The Saudis themselves have 300 French-built tanks as well as older American machines that are capable but not overwhelmingly proficient.
The tanks' prowess has inspired the tank killers.
The most notable American antitank weapon, from the infantry's perspective, is the TOW - short for tube-launched, optically tracked, wire-guided missile. The missile is launched from a tube carried by a soldier or set up on a vehicle. The weapon's main risk is that the soldier firing it can be threatened by the target tank. The danger is reduced when the TOW is launched from its maximum range of over two miles, out of the reach of most, but not all, tanks. Experts say the TOW's optics have trouble penetrating the shimmering glare of the desert, reducing its effective range.
Some newer tanks have thickened armor, and others have sheets of explosives on the outside to deflect warheads. In response, the latest TOW has not only a more powerful warhead but also a nose probe that detonates an initial burst to trigger these tanks' defenses before the main round explodes.
Iraq has similar antitank weapons. Some are Soviet-made, but others, like the HOT and the Milan, were made by Western European consortiums.
But the most powerful antitank weapons are fired from great distances, and here the Americans have a decided advantage. Most of the Cobra and Apache helicopter gunships are equipped with Hellfire missiles or TOW missiles similar to the ones used by ground troops. The Hellfire, a laser-guided antitank weapon, and the bigger Maverick antitank missile, guided by lasers or aimed by cameras in its nose, can also be launched by A-10 aircraft, which support ground troops by shooting up tanks. Despite the A-10's heavy armor, it is a daring pilot who flies into the defenses surrounding enemy columns. Hellfires and Mavericks can be launched from several miles away.
The laser-guided Copperhead is another formidable addition to the artillery. It is shot from a gun but boosted like a missile and steered with fins. Within 10 miles, it can be guided to land smack on top of a tank. A spotter, possibly an infantryman in his dugout but preferably one protected in an armored vehicle, aims a laser beam at a target from a relatively safe distance, and a sensor on the Copperhead's nose follows the reflection. The laser can also be aimed from a helicopter or plane. Laser weapons are particularly suited to the barren desert. But coordinating the Copperhead's fire is an art that requires considerable practice, and with rounds costing $30,000 each, this has been hard to obtain.
Of all the Iraqi weapons, chemical agents and long-range ground-to-ground missiles have caused the most concern. Both figured in the war with Iran. But both have drawbacks in the standoff against the forces now fielded against them in the Middle East.
Iraq's use of poison gas would risk massive retaliation, and the American forces are protected by gas masks and protective garments. As for the long-range missiles, mostly Soviet Scuds that can be altered to fly many hundreds of miles, they are effective against cities and sprawling oil installations,but they are not accurate enough to destroy particular military targets.
For exposed troops at the front lines, Iraq's ordinary big cannons, not its missiles or chemicals, are the most terrifying weapons. Howitzers and other field artillery can strike from many miles away, without warning and with shattering force. Iraq has far more of the big guns than the assembled forces in Saudi Arabia.
The United States has the big M198 artillery, whose range varies from 10 to 20 miles. It can not only shoot conventional high explosives, which can demolish entrenched positions, but also scatter mines and other munitions useful against lightly armored trucks and infantry.
Experts estimate that Iraq has 100 South African G-5 howitzers, considered the best such guns in the world. They are similar to the M198 and accurate at almost 20 miles or more. Iraq also has hundreds of big Austrian-made howitzers, which fire standard NATO ammunition. These guns, and thousands of smaller artillery, massacred waves of Iranian troops in the 1980's.
On both sides, some of the heaviest guns are mobile: known as self-propelled artillery because the howitzers don't have to be towed into position, the immensely tracked vehicles resemble tanks with elongated guns.
Saddam Hussein has Saudi Arabia to thank in part for his strong arsenal of mobile howitzers. In 1982, Iraq, which had just started its war on Iran, ordered some $600 million worth of the weapons from France, according to Jane's Armor and Artillery. The Saudis already had a number of the guns, and, fearful of Iranian fundamentalists, handed them over to Iraq while it waited for its order to be filled.
To counter the Iraqi howitzers, the United States Army has its own powerful mobile weapon: the Multiple Launch Rocket System, which is carried around on the chassis of a Bradley troop carrier. The gun holds two boxes, each holding six rockets. The 12 rounds can be fired singly, or in one rippling salvo that lands on a broad swath of territory.
The rocket system's warheads are not sophisticated enough to hit individual tanks with precision, but they can destroy enemy artillery batteries, decimate unprotected troops and wipe out concentrations of lightly armored vehicles. A one-minute salvo can strew nearly 8,000 bomblets, each with the power of a hand grenade, across a 60-acre area. The rocket's range is said to be 20 miles, somewhat farther than that of most artillery. It has never been tested in combat.
Iraq also has rocket launchers, perhaps 200 of them. Many are the Brazilian Astros, also found in the Saudi arsenal, which can fire a warhead more than 30 miles, even farther than the American rocket system.
Once fired, Iraq's big guns are vulnerable to high-tech response. The Firefinder radar, which performed well during the American presence in Lebanon in 1983, tracks the trajectory of incoming artillery rounds and instantly pinpoints the guns' location. Computers can then direct precise return fire, even before the enemy's first round hits the ground.
The Americans have various options to protect them from sky attack. Soldiers on the ground have the shoulder-fired Stinger and the mobile Chaparral and Hawk missiles. In the war in Afghanistan, the American supported rebels used the Stinger to deadly effect against Soviet jets and helicopters, driving aircraft high into the sky. Mounted on vehicles, the Chaparral can also fend off helicopters. The Hawk is for high-flying jets.
More sophisticated still is the Patriot antiaircraft missile. The missile, never used in combat, is fired from a truck and has a range of well over 60 miles. United States Army officers claim it can outmaneuver any airplane as it homes in for the kill at three times the speed of sound.
The Patriot is even believed able to shoot down ballistic missiles like the Iraqi Scud and al-Husayn, which so intimidated the Iranians.
Though they lack such advanced apparatus, the Iraqis are also equipped to resist attack from the air. According to the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London, they have 60 Roland missile launchers, built by German and French companies. With a range of 10 miles, they are designed to fend off low-flying aircraft or helicopters like the Apache and Cobra gunships. The Rolands are mobile and travel with the troops, tanks and artillery. Hussein's forces can also deploy various Soviet antiaircraft weapons, including several types of missiles and two air-defense guns, which airmen respect for the barrage of bullets that spew from multiple barrels.
During the Iran-Iraq war in the 1980's, when it escorted oil tankers through the Persian Gulf, the United States Navy operated virtually independently of the Army and Air Force. Now it finds itself in a supporting role.
The main purpose of the current naval buildup is to add to air forces. With four well-defended aircraft carriers in the region, the Navy has added at least 150 armed jets, including the important F-14's.
Most of the naval armada is intended to support and protect the aircraft carriers or to enforce the United Nations economic sanctions against Iraq. The first American shots fired in the confrontation came from the U.S.S. Reid, which fired a warning volley across the bow of an Iraqi tanker last month in an attempt to enforce the embargo. Frigates and guided-missile destroyers, the ''small boys'' of the Navy fleet, are designed to protect friendly ships against surprise attacks. The speedy, maneuverable ships carry helicopters and are armed with guns and missiles, meant mainly to defend the fleet against air attack. About a dozen American frigates and destroyers are in the Red Sea, the Persian Gulf or nearby waters at any one time.
If Navy ships came under attack, they could employ the Aegis guided-missile cruiser, a kind of seaborne Awacs. The Aegis has a mammoth four-faced antenna, and long-range missiles and guns to shoot down enemy missiles and planes.
Three Aegis cruisers (along with less capable American cruisers) are in the Middle East with various aircraft carriers. Two Aegis ships, the Antietam and the Philippine Sea, also have offensive ability, carrying dozens of Tomahawk cruise missiles. The cruisers can sail north in the gulf, bringing the missiles in range of many targets on Iraqi soil. The conventionally armed Tomahawk packs a very powerful warhead. It has demonstrated in tests that it can land precisely on target after a flight of more than 400 miles, and its maximum range is even greater.
The Navy multiplied its firepower in the gulf on Aug. 24, when it moved the battleship Wisconsin through the Strait of Hormuz. Brought out of mothballs and modernized, the vessel still carries its thick armor plating from World War II and is considered invulnerable to conventional missiles and guns. Its 16-inch guns can lob shells able to pummel targets more than 20 miles away. And its cruise missiles could reach across the length and breadth of Iraq.

PUB-DATE: September 16, 1990

SECTION: Section 6; Page 38, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 5179 words

HEADLINE: Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Liberal? Conservative? Or Just Pat?

BYLINE: By James Traub; James Traub is the author of ''Too Good to Be True: The Outlandish Story of Wedtech.''

 BODY:
Few people relish being right quite so fiercely as Daniel Patrick Moynihan; and just now, New York's senior Senator is taking particular delight in being right at the right time. He has specialized, in years past, in unseasonable, unpalatable truths - about the breakdown of the black family, about the paralysis of the United Nations - and he has publicly reveled in his martyrdom. This time, however, history has caught up with him. In recent months, Moynihan has insisted that the collapse of the system built on the cold war permits - in fact demands - a return to old American political principles, above all a respect for international law. Late last month, Harvard University Press published Moynihan's 15th book, ''On the Law of Nations.'' And at virtually the same moment, the United States, acting through the United Nations, orchestrated a worldwide response to Iraq's aggression against Kuwait. For once, everybody was riding Moynihan's hobbyhorse. 
Just in case I missed the point, Moynihan read to me, over lunch, a speech in which President Bush had used the words ''international law'' three times. He picked up a copy of his new book to cite a speech in which Mikhail S. Gorbachev had quoted - in Latin - the ancient maxim ''agreements must be honored.'' Moynihan had just come from a highly satisfactory session with Thomas R. Pickering, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, and he pulled a copy of the U.N. charter from his breast pocket to recite the passage governing intervention by armed forces.
Moynihan is a tall, stooped man with silver hair and a face that could have been designed by a cartoonist - a long face, very red, with pouchy cheeks and eyebrows cocked in a forbidding expression of skepticism. As is his wont, the Senator was holding forth. I was having trouble following some portions of what he was saying, owing to Moynihan's oratorical style, a peculiar sequence of plosives and mumbles and distended polysyllables sometimes mistakenly considered British.
''This is an economic war,'' he said, ''and economic wars are rare, contrary to what you were taught at my age. We went to endless lengths in my day to prove that the munitions makers started World War I. Previously, most wars were, actually. But the 20th century has been an age of totalitarianism. The Boer War was an economic war. The Chaco War was an economic war.'' The Chaco War? ''The Paraguayans, the Uruguayans and the Argentinians.''> We were moving into the trackless terrain of Moynihania. (I discovered only later that, Moynihan's assertion notwithstanding, the Chaco War was a land dispute carried on from 1932 to 1935 between Bolivia and Paraguay.) What about Iraq, I asked a bit desperately. Should American soldiers be prepared to die in an economic war? Moynihan said he backed President Bush on the sending of troops to Saudi Arabia. But that wasn't the point he wanted to make. ''What I care about,'' Moynihan said, ''is that we are acting meticulously in terms of the charter in the first post-cold war crisis. If we can bring it off, then we have a second chance to see if the system works.''
Abstractions - the United Nations system, international law - matter dearly to Moynihan. This makes him a perfectly normal intellectual, but a most unusual United States Senator, one who insists that ideas matter, and not just interests. He stands inside the political process as no intellectual has in several generations, perhaps since Woodrow Wilson; he stands outside the process as no one else in Congress does. Moynihan's friends like to say that he occupies a category of one, by which they mean he's so large that he can have a category all to himself, and that his political principles are too personal to be typecast in Washington's limited vocabulary.
''He thinks he is unique, and I would agree with that,'' says a former aide, Tom Melia. ''I tend to share his overblown view of himself.''
''He is the only one of the 100 Senators whom I would call indispensable,'' says the columnist George Will. ''There are lots of well-schooled people, but in the sense of an educated man, one conversant with the great ideas, the large issues of the 20th century, he's it.''
Pat Moynihan worked for every President from Kennedy through Ford, and has been considered, at various times, a Kennedy Democrat, a neo-conservative, a neo-liberal and a classic, Northeastern liberal. ''There has always been a view of Pat that he was chameleon-like,'' says Lawrence Kudlow, a Wall Street economist who was a fellow traveler in Moynihan's neo-conservative moment.
I made the mistake of testing this hypothesis myself. Our first interview was held in Moynihan's office in Washington, and the Senator had stationed himself some 12 feet from me, perhaps to establish that he was delivering a lecture, not conducting a seminar. He was explaining his view that ''the national security state,'' the secret intelligence apparatus established to counter the Soviet threat, had deformed American principles at home as the militarism of the cold war had done abroad. When, a little bewildered, I remarked that he sounded surprisingly like his former left-wing critics, Moynihan fairly wheeled on me, his white eyebrows rising into a launch-on-warning posture. ''I've been in the belly of the beast,'' he said, majestically. ''I've been there. I know what it is.'' Then he lowered his voice to convey disdain: ''They don't.''
Do not presume to tell Pat Moynihan where he stands. He knows; you don't. The problem is that it's often not a recognizable place. Moynihan has argued, in a vast cataract of books and articles, that he stands for the liberal tradition, a set of principles that were obscured by the cold war and by the radicalism of the left and right. It is the ground that has shifted, Moynihan insists; he has stood firm. In the 1960's, when he was among the core group of intellectuals who founded and contributed to the neo-conservative journal The Public Interest, Moynihan argued that campus activism was ''a heresy of liberalism,'' a revolt against the basic American faith. Liberalism meant tolerance, reason, a respect for due process. Instead, he wrote with his typical flair for hyperbole, ''chaos is increasingly our condition.'' Fifteen years later, he would say much the same thing of the Reagan Administration.
Indeed, it's instructive to recall the moment when Moynihan went from neo-conservative stalwart to Reagan bugbear. He had been elected Senator in 1976 and had gathered a staff consisting largely of neo-conservative intellectuals. In his first speech, Moynihan had opposed the nomination of Paul C. Warnke as head of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, on the grounds that Warnke was too sympathetic to the Soviets. ''That,'' as his former legislative aide Elliott Abrams puts it, ''is who he was.''
With Jimmy Carter's Presidency going increasingly slack, the neo-conservatives, with their appeal to blue-collar and middle-class voters, had become the most forceful tendency in the Democratic Party. Among that group, people looked to Moynihan for leadership. In his writings, New York's new Senator pictured a world hanging by a thread: democratic values were under ''unremitting assault from totalitarianism''; the Russians, he warned, were preparing to push on from their beachhead in Afghanistan to seize Pakistan, and the West, above all President Carter, was reacting just as Chamberlain had at Munich. Norman Podhoretz, the editor of Commentary and a key member of the group of intellectuals who had grown disaffected with Democratic philosophy during the 60's, described Moynihan as his ideal Presidential candidate.
At this moment, when longstanding ideological alignments seemed poised on a pivot, that pivot was occupied by Pat Moynihan. He was a figure as frightening to the left as he was inspiring to some elements on the right. The Nation, hoping to short-circuit his supposed Presidential bid, devoted an entire issue to exposing Moynihan as not only a conservative, but also a fraud. One journalist, Fred Powledge, regretted that he had written something nice about the man in the 1960's, when he appeared to be a liberal. A fellow social scientist, Philip Green, called him a ''demagogue,'' ''a political know-nothing,'' and ''a poseur,'' and concluded, ''he does not pursue truth, nor respect it.'' To many liberals, Moynihan wasn't just an adversary; he was a traitor, a man who had abandoned the common faith. And then Pat Moynihan turned around and betrayed the other side. For one thing, he didn't challenge Jimmy Carter's nomination. (He had never really planned to.) Then, with the election of Ronald Reagan, Moynihan swiftly went into opposition. With his polemicist's gift for memorable overstatement, he assailed the 1981 Reagan tax cut as ''an auction of the Treasury,'' ''a great barbecue'' predicated on ''a magic theory of taxation'' - though polemics notwithstanding, he voted for the cut.
Afterward, he insisted that Reaganomics, with its combination of tax rate cuts and defense expenditures, was a ''conspiracy,'' masterminded by his own former disciple David A. Stockman, to ''defund'' and destroy the welfare state. Moynihan correctly predicted the immense deficits that would ensue, and helped shame Republicans as well as Democrats into undoing some of their more malignant handiwork the following year. He also opposed the invasion of Grenada and, after 1984, military support for the contras.
Moynihan's former aides, who had eagerly signed up with the Reagan revolution, looked on in disbelief. Elliott Abrams, who served as Reagan's Assistant Secretary of State for Latin America, is persuaded that Moynihan abandoned the true faith out of political expediency. ''The profile now,'' Abrams says, ''is of a liberal Democrat.'' This is also the semiofficial Washington take on Moynihan. ''He used to be a hard-liner in foreign policy,'' says James K. Glassman, editor of Roll Call, the local field guide to Capitol Hill. ''Now he's almost completely flip-flopped.''
It's almost certainly true that Moynihan emphasized his liberalism to forestall a potential challenge from the left in 1982; his friend and political adviser Richard Ravitch admits as much. (It's also true that the Senator's rhetoric has a way of outrunning his voting record.) But when the challenge failed to materialize, Moynihan continued his harsh criticism.
More to the point, Moynihan hasn't shifted in synchrony with the national mood, but against it. He moved right when the nation moved left and left when it moved right. As he had with 60's activism, he saw in Reaganism a radical and dangerous attack on the traditional center. The dubious legerdemain of the tax cut, and later the Administration's secret war in Central America, were more than enough to bring out Moynihan's horror of radical experiments. He has always been, essentially, an extremist of the center, defending liberalism from the inevitable onslaught. Opposition, in any case, suits his temperament. ''He's a controversialist,'' as Stephen Hess of the Brookings Institution puts it.
Moynihan came by his brand of liberalism almost genetically. Born in Tulsa, Okla., in 1927, Moynihan grew to adulthood in the now legendary world of Hell's Kitchen on the west side of midtown Manhattan, a Runyonesque neighborhood of tenements, barflies, gangsters, stevedores - and party bosses. There, as in almost all working-class New York neighborhoods, the Democratic Party apparatus, and its Roman Catholic hierarchy of precinct captain, district leader, boss, functioned almost as a secular church. The system was corrupt in numberless but mostly petty ways; more important, it was supremely responsive to the vox populi, and generally progressive. Moynihan has always waxed impatient at the ritual bluenose denunciation of ''the machine,'' and once wrote that his first experience of voting was much simplified when the precinct captain handed him a slip of paper telling him whom he would vote for.
Picturesque this life may have been, but it must have been hard, too. His father was a journalist and an alcoholic who moved the family around a lot until he vanished permanently when Pat was 10. His mother owned a bar in Hell's Kitchen, and Pat, the eldest of three children, always worked. Moynihan has been proud to relate that he was working as a longshoreman when he enrolled at City College.
People who know Moynihan testify to the chip he carries on his shoulder about his working-class background, which makes an odd contrast with his dandyish accent and Anglophile manner. (He calls his country home, near Oneonta, N.Y., Derrymore.) ''There's a certain touch of class warfare in Pat Moynihan,'' says one of the Senator's current aides, who recalls a $1,000 campaign contribution arriving from a wealthy backer along with a note chiding the Senator for moderating his support for Israel. Moynihan sent back the check, spluttering, ''No socialite is going to tell me how to do my job.''
Moynihan's career was not marked by spectacular early success. After serving in the Navy and graduating from Tufts University, Moynihan enrolled at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts. He wanted to be a diplomat, but he flunked the Foreign Service exam. He then received a Fulbright scholarship to continue his studies at the London School of Economics. But Moynihan decided he wasn't cut out to be a scholar. He returned to New York, and landed a job in 1955 as an aide to Gov. W. Averell Harriman. For the next four years Moynihan learned politics firsthand.
And then John Kennedy came along. Kennedy was an embodiment of Moynihan's idea of liberalism: optimistic, patriotic, a firm believer in the American Century. Moynihan, by then writing a history of Harriman's governorship, campaigned for Kennedy's Presidential bid and subsequently became Assistant Secretary of Labor.
The wonderfully clear window of the future shattered, for Moynihan and millions of others, on Nov. 22, 1963. ''We will never be young again,'' the 36-year-old Moynihan told the columnist Mary McGrory. But it wasn't only the trauma of Kennedy's death that infected Moynihan's idealism; in the days after the assassination, convinced that Lee Harvey Oswald was in danger of assassination himself and that no one would thence know whether Kennedy had been killed by conspiracy, he begged Kennedy insiders to put Oswald in protective custody. It was Moynihan's first experience of seeing the peril that others ignored. ''I then realized,'' he wrote a few years later, ''it is possible to grow enormously successful and powerful in America without knowing that the world is a dangerous place. I suppose I had always known this.''
Moynihan continued as assistant secretary under Lyndon Johnson and began to focus on the economic situation of blacks. He had recently published, with Harvard professor Nathan Glazer, the pioneering study of ethnicity, ''Beyond the Melting Pot.'' Spurred by statistics on family structure, as well as by the work of such black sociologists as Kenneth B. Clark, Moynihan came to conclude that the experience of slavery and racism had had a catastrophic effect on the black family, and that for this reason poverty would now perpetuate itself even in the absence of racism. The antipoverty program would have to focus on what Clark had called the ghetto's ''tangle of pathology.''
Moynihan's report, titled ''The Negro Family: The Case for National Action,'' became a key document of the War on Poverty. President Johnson virtually repeated Moynihan's argument in a major address at Howard University in June 1965.
The family-breakdown thesis arrived at just the moment the 60's exploded, vaporizing the liberal consensus along with so much else. Black rage stunned white liberals, who suddenly found themselves accused of ''paternalism'' and unacknowledged racism. Civil rights leaders denounced what came to be known as the Moynihan Report; so did social scientists on the left. And though 20 years later the N.A.A.C.P. executive director, Benjamin L. Hooks, would be calling for a thorough examination of the problems of the black family, friends from that time say Moynihan was deeply hurt.
In 1966 Moynihan was offered a post at Harvard. He had risen through so many strata of society; now he had arrived, an American success story, at the very doorstep of the WASP establishment. Moynihan is very sensitive about his credentials, especially about Harvard. As a former aide recalls: ''He once called me into his office and closed the door, and said, in a conspiratorial way, 'I have been invited to give the Godkin Lectures at Harvard.' And then he sat back, like, 'How about that?' And I said, 'Yes?' Usually he doesn't much care for the reaction of staff people, but he was very proud, and he said: 'Don't you understand, the Godkin Lectures. Does that not mean anything to you lads?' '' Sorry, said the aide. And the Senator, exasperated, declared: ''I've given the commencement address at Harvard, I've given the freshman orientation and I've given the Phi Beta Kappa. I've done them all now; I've done all the major addresses at Harvard.''
Moynihan joined Harvard just as campus upheaval was rocking the Ivy League, and his reverence for the institution seemed to drive him to heights of outrage. He was furious at the upper-middle-class vocabulary of revolution, and he was disgusted to see the ''frightened patriciate'' surrendering to the authoritarian demands of the students. It was as if his role was to bring the harsh realism of Hell's Kitchen to the dreamy spires of Harvard Yard - to protect liberalism from its own complacency. The 60's drove Moynihan, along with many of the other ''policy intellectuals'' at Harvard, into the arms of Richard Nixon.
Moynihan joined the Nixon Administration as assistant to the President for urban affairs, and got along with the President famously. Nixon, who had always felt intellectually underestimated, was delighted to have enrolled a legitimate Kennedy Democrat and a Harvard professor, and he loved reading the scholar's grandiose memos, which were ''veritable invitations to become part of history,'' as the two men's mutual friend Leonard Garment recalls.
Things did not work out very well for either of them, of course. In late February 1970 Moynihan's infamous ''benign neglect'' memo to Nixon was leaked to The New York Times. The memo read like a pragmatic, and unsympathetic, program for dealing with the hostility of blacks. ''The issue of race,'' Moynihan wrote, ''could benefit from a period of benign neglect.''
Moynihan hadn't said that black people themselves merited neglect; his real meaning seems to have been that the Administration's angry bluster and attack-dog tactics were playing into the hands of black radicals.
Previously, Moynihan had managed to maneuver into Congress a guaranteed minimum-income program, known as the Family Assistance Plan, over the objections of hostile White House conservatives. Nevertheless, because of the memo, he became known as the man who told the President to ignore blacks. ''It killed me,'' Moynihan told The Times a few years later. ''It won't ever be forgiven; that's all there is to it.'' The Moynihan Report had alienated civil rights leaders and some scholars; the term ''benign neglect'' alienated liberals in general. In liberal eyes, Moynihan became an effigy, a disgruntled intellectual who used ingenious phrases to convey a racist message. He became, like Nixon, a man it was permissible to hate. And the Family Assistance Plan languished in committee, then died altogether.
One thing you can say for Moynihan, though, is that he knows how to savor his martyrdom. When I asked how he felt about the abuse he'd received, he gazed at a point several feet above my head and said: ''Truman was an object of contempt - I knew that. I have lived through the days when John F. Kennedy was a fascist. So it didn't come as a great surprise when the same people learned that I was a fascist. I've seen them be disdainful to an awful lot of people.''
After two years back at Harvard, Moynihan was appointed by Nixon in 1973 to the job of Ambassador to India, thus gratifying the old dream of foreign service. During his two years in New Delhi, Moynihan completed the tedious yet valuable job of negotiating the retirement of India's debt to the United States. But he also came to some alarming conclusions about the world: In 1975, in a widely read article in Commentary titled ''The United States in Opposition,'' he wrote that democratic values were profoundly threatened by a growing totalitarian spirit in the third world, and nobody was willing to recognize it. The governing elites, as always, were complacent, paralyzed.
Henry A. Kissinger, then Gerald Ford's Secretary of State, admired the article (he found it ''staggeringly good,'' Moynihan later wrote) and suggested Moynihan for the job of chief delegate to the United Nations.
Moynihan's United Nations tenure was a sort of recapitulation of his whole career. He went intending to preach the gospel of liberal internationalism, and he wound up laying about him with a meat ax. He became infamous for his scathing attacks on third world countries, and what he took to be their Soviet sponsor. In his final days, after a Soviet delegate had suggested that the United States ''take care,'' Moynihan responded, ''We are not intimidated, we are not afraid. We will not 'take care,' we do not give a damn.''
After his United Nations tenure, Moynihan barely bothered to unpack his suitcases at Harvard before casting his porkpie into the ring as a candidate for the U.S. Senate. The incumbent, James L. Buckley, was clearly too conservative for New Yorkers, and none of the announced liberals were unbeatable. Still, it was probably The New York Times that decided the election. The editorial board, led by John B. Oakes, whom Moynihan always blamed for the storm over the ''benign neglect'' memo, wanted to come out for Bella Abzug, then a New York Representative, in the Democratic primary. But The Times's publisher, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, overruled the board, and the paper gave its support to Moynihan, who beat Abzug by only 10,000 votes. Moynihan, of course, went on to win the election, and also to become famously obsessed with The Times. ''We were talking about some issue,'' recalls a former aide, ''and he said, 'Such-and-such from my speech was not covered.' And I said, ''Senator, it was on the front page.'' And Moynihan paused for effect, and said, ''Below the fold.''
Moynihan has nowb been a Senator for 14 years. He has become a fixture, the intellectual-laureate of the Senate. A former aide to the late Senator Frank Church, Peter Fenn, recalls his boss coming back from the floor of the Senate to say of Moynihan, ''That man just got up and spoke for 45 minutes with no notes and no reference materials, and proceeded to delineate the entire history of the Panama Canal.''
If Moynihan is considered a donnish blowhard, it's not easy to find anyone who will say so. ''He has moved into positions of power as well as respect,'' says Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, ''and I just find that he is a national resource. I think he has put together as substantial a body of work as anyone who has ever sat in this body.''
Probably no state is represented by two such unlike figures as Moynihan and Alfonse M. D'Amato, the backslapping former machine pol from Nassau County. D'Amato, still trying to earn esteem in the Senate, has recently been chatting up Moynihan in private dinners. But in one respect, at least, D'Amato has the advantage. It is a truism among veteran New York political figures that if you want something done, you go to D'Amato, a reputation that rankles Moynihan. A Moynihan aide, in fact, made a point of telling me that in 1987 the Office of Management and Budget selected his boss its ''king of pork,'' for having sponsored more local projects than any other Senator. Nonetheless, some hardheaded businessmen who have worked with Moynihan on local issues complain about lack of follow-up after the eloquent speech is done.
With his colleagues, Moynihan is considered affable and, to use Bradley's word, ''civilized''; in the lower reaches of the Capitol, where reputations are formed, Moynihan is notorious for his rather imperial personality. Many Senators affect, or prefer, a democratic manner, and are known to staff members by first names. Moynihan is known as ''Senator.'' He is not an easy man to work for, and he appears to have established records in staff turnover. He tends to use his legislative aides the way a professor working on a book might use his graduate students, as pack animals of research, and he is notoriously impatient with inadequate work. Moynihan also has to be humored a good deal. ''It's not possible to flatter him too much,'' a former aide says. ''He'll take it as his due.''
And then there is the lingering question of how much Moynihan drinks. The subject has been kept alive not only by the media but also by Moynihan's political opponents, however gingerly. Lawrence Kudlow, now vice chairman of the New York State Republican Party, notes that ''personal problems'' precluded that theoretical Presidential campaign back in 1980. Meaning drinking? ''Drinking and health,'' Kudlow specifies. ''I think he's sort of pulled that back under control. But since I don't know anything about it, I don't want to get into it.''
There are many unattributable quotations to be solicited. At times, according to former aides, Moynihan drinks so much at night - perhaps because he has trouble sleeping - that he is groggy the following morning. Two veteran Capitol Hill reporters say they don't recall seeing Moynihan intoxicated on the floor of the Senate, and certainly not in recent years. Other reporters, however, speak of telephoning the Senator and finding him all but incoherent.
In sum, it appears that Moynihan drinks on occasions when a great many people drink, and possibly on occasions when they don't. On the other hand, he appears to have a stronger mind after three drinks than most people do when sober. As George Will once wrote in response to a whispering campaign that grew audible before the 1988 election, Moynihan has written more books than many of his colleagues have read. So perhaps we should let the poor man drink in peace. Certainly, Moynihan has made a point of keeping his private life private. He has been married for 35 years and has three grown children. His wife, Elizabeth, is an architectural historian who was also her husband's campaign manager in his last election, which he won by a smashing majority of 67 percent. The Senator's habit of speaking his mind is not unrelated to the fact that he neither aspires to higher office nor fears the prospect of the next election.
Moynihan has long since mended fences with the liberal wing of the party. His rating from the Americans for Democratic Action, which he once lectured on the need to make common cause with conservatives, hovers around a comfortable 85. In 1988, he finally realized his dream of reforming the welfare system, 23 years after he started trying. The Family Support Act, as it was called, mandated funds for education and job training at the state level and instituted experiments in ''workfare.''
As the senior Democrat on the Finance Committee, Moynihan wields real power on issues of taxation, especially since he and the committee chairman, Senator Bob Dole, often see eye to eye. For several years Moynihan has been complaining that the Social Security Trust Fund wasn't a trust fund at all, since the surplus that was building up was being used to pay for the deficit. This offended his sense of fiscal integrity.
Last Dec. 29, Moynihan called a news conference to propose that a coming Social Security tax rate increase - the third in seven years - be canceled, and that previous increases be rolled back. At first, the idea was ignored altogether. But then something delightfully perverse, something truly Moynihanian, began to happen. The conservative Heritage Foundation supported the cut, while the Bush Administration, which was not about to forgo the trust fund surplus, ridiculed it. The Democrats, desperately intent to prove their maturity and readiness to govern by raising taxes, simply fled. ''It was such an intellectually honest liberal position that none of the members wanted to look at it,'' says James Glassman of Roll Call. Indeed, It was the first tax cut proposal in memory that the purists supported, and the politicians opposed.
The payroll tax cut proposal, as Moynihan well knew, was both hard to refute and popular. By the spring, both Democrats and, warily, Republicans, began to sign up. The proposal, says George Will, ''has changed the whole trajectory of debate in 1990.''
The conflict with Iraq, on the other hand, has changed the trajectory of matters at home. Moynihan's tax-rollback proposal is expected to come to a vote sometime in the next month, and with the military commitment draining national resources and the deficit looming, pragmatism may win out over logic, equity and poetic justice.
But as the Senate's designated thinker of large thoughts, Moynihan has bigger things than payroll taxes in mind. He wants to hold hearings in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on the question: How do we reconstitute the American Government in the aftermath of the cold war? The idea may strike some of his colleagues as windy and aimless, but, says Moynihan, characteristically providing his own footnote, ''As the world is new, you must think anew - so said Abraham Lincoln.''
Beyond that, it's clear that Moynihan hopes to establish the conditions for a revival of the liberalism that once inspired him and his generation. It's striking, in one who was once so passionate an advocate of the cold war, to hear Moynihan speak of how obsession with the Soviets has led us to forget the principles of open government and ultimately, in the case of the Iran-contra scandal, to undermine the Constitution. The national security state, he says: ''controls the Presidency. It controls most of the executive departments. And it will not break out of the task for which it was designed, which is to control Communist expansion.'' The Russians have begun to confront the consequences of the 50-year war, he says. We have not.
A great deal of history stands between this country today and the country of Woodrow Wilson, the hero of ''On the Law of Nations.'' In 1917, as Moynihan recalls, a violation of international law was enough to commit the nation to a terrible war. Our principles were clear then; so much was clear. ''And then,'' he rumbles at the bottom of his register, ''it was lost to us in the fog of cold war.'' Moynihan joins his fingers beneath his chin, lifting his long red face higher still.
'' 'The fog of cold war,' '' he mutters, as if to himself. ''Nice phrase.''

SECTION: Section 8; Page 3, Column 1; Sports Desk
