HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Yankees Are in Critical Condition as Their New Era Begins

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
They will finish in last place for the first time since 1966, the second time since 1912 and only the fourth time in the 88-year history of the franchise. They will very likely finish with their worst record since 1913. They have already suffered the first season-series shutout (to Oakland) in their history. They also failed to win a game at Fenway Park for the first time ever.
Their team batting average is the lowest in the league, and they have scored the fewest runs. Their pitching staff has one of the league's highest earned run averages, and they may not have a starter with 10 victories.
These are the Yankees as they enter the post-Steinbrenner era, and they are in as critical a condition as a team could be as a new regime assumes command. If the Yankees were a Broadway show, Robert Nederlander, their new managing partner, would close them and move on to another project. 
The new high command consists of Nederlander, General Manager Gene Michael and Manager Stump Merrill. All three were George Steinbrenner's personal choices.
''They needed a turnaround expert, someone with credibility in the business who wouldn't take backseat driving from George,'' said one astute baseball man, who for years has had intimate knowledge of the Yankees' operation and the way Steinbrenner conducted the operation. ''You don't have that with these people. You have the suspicion that George is still there.'' On request, on condition of anonymity and with no animosity toward the Yankees or Steinbrenner, he provided a candid assessment of the problems the club's new hierarchy faces and the problems he feels the hierarchy itself presents.
Nederlander told the owners at their meetings in Pittsburgh last week that he hadn't spoken with Steinbrenner since the principal owner resigned as managing partner Aug. 20. ''He's clean,'' the baseball man said of Nederlander, ''but he's a Steinbrenner camper. George made the limited partners a lot of money. They're not going to do anything he doesn't want. They're loyal to George. No one's going to have any confidence in the plan.''
No plan is in place yet, but the baseball man said: ''It's got to be a straight rebuilding deal. They have to trade down in age, move some of the veterans like Barfield for prospects.''
That plan sounds logical, but it has an inherent problem, he cautioned.
''Yankee fans aren't going to put up with the rebuilding stuff,'' he said. ''The Yankees should do what the Pirates and the Reds did when they fell from grace. But I don't know if they'll do that because of the attitude of their fans.''
The alternative to rebuilding with young players is the continued, or even intensified, pursuit of free agents. Do they take that approach?
''I don't think anybody is going to particularly want to play there,'' the baseball man said. ''People are cognizant that New York, the city, is in bad shape. Some guys will go there for the money, but a lot of players won't.''
Some reluctant players, he added, might be less reluctant if the new hierarchy could instill greater confidence in the club's future by installing some ''heavy hitters'' at the top. He cited Whitey Herzog and Dallas Green as the type of person he meant. He also named Jeff Torborg of the Chicago White Sox and Jim Leyland of Pittsburgh - ''They're tremendous,'' he said - as the kind of manager who could provide strong leadership for young players.
''If they had hired people like that, there would be greater confidence,'' he said. ''But there's no reason for optimism.
 
Answering the Critics
 If any Nolan Ryan critics remain, especially those who use Ryan's won-lost percentage against him, let them consider the last month. In six starts, the 43-year-old Ryan compiled a 1.31 earned run average but only a 2-1 record.
He allowed more than one earned run only once and he won that game. He allowed no runs in 10 innings of one start and one run in each of two other starts (seven innings and eight innings) and he emerged with no decision in all three instances. Besides permitting seven earned runs (nine runs altogether) in 48 innings, he gave up 20 hits and 11 walks and struck out 58.
 
Strange Times in Kansas City
 Perhaps they were plunged into a state of shock by the failure of their $19 million worth of pitching Davises (Mark and Storm) or by the double-barreled injuries suffered by their top two pitchers, Bret Saberhagen and Mark Gubicza. But the Kansas City Royals have had a bizarre season, and the other day they added another strange twist.
The Royals, who were supposed to be serious challengers to the Oakland Athletics, stumbled out of contention early when they lost 16 of their first 22 games. They needed three and a half months to raise their victory total to the level of their losses, and then they managed to sneak over .500 at 63-62, 64-63 and 65-64.
But just when they appeared to be moving in the right direction, they threw themselves into reverse, losing 13 of 15 entering last night's game. Not that they ever challenged the Athletics, but their latest skid fattened their games-behind number from 15 to 25.
If there was ever a candidate to be dismissed as manager, it was the Royals' manager, John Wathan. The Royals, however, rewarded Wathan with a contract for next season. And to think that 10 years ago, Dick Howser was dismissed as the Yankees' manager after winning 103 games and a division championship.
 
No Freedom
 Jack Clark, Tom Herr, Dave Smith, Gary Gaetti, Mike Witt, Willie Randolph and Ken Griffey Sr. have been in the major leagues for six years or more and have contracts that expire at the end of this season. That means they can be free agents, right? No, in their cases, it means they can sign a new contract with their current team or they can go to salary arbitration. Those seven players and 18 others cannot be free agents because they were free agents less than five years ago and are subject to the repeater-rights clause of the free-agent rules.
Jack Morris, Detroit's 18-game loser, is in a similar position, but he has a unique difference. He can exercise an option in his contract calling for a $2.1 million salary next season. He has until Nov. 1 to make that decision. Given his record this season, he should probably not procrastinate.
 
Economics Lesson
 The last time the major leagues expanded, in 1977, Seattle paid $6.25 million for a franchise and Toronto $7 million. The cost of living and the cost of baseball franchises has soared since then. To join the National League with one of the two new teams for the 1993 season, a prospective owner will have to pay $95 million. Is the fee a rip-off? ''It's what the marketplace will bear,'' Commissioner Fay Vincent said. ''Some people are eager to pay that amount. The marketplace is always correct. If people buy at that price, the marketplace is correct. I really am a resolute believer in the marketplace.''
Vincent, who acts and speaks differently from his predecessors, has wandered into an area where most commissioners, Bowie Kuhn particularly, feared to tread. If a commissioner says the marketplace should set the price for an expansion franchise, he could not very well disagree with the players' long-held view that the marketplace should establish players' salaries.
''Sure, it should,'' Vincent said. ''I don't know any other way. How could we do better than the marketplace?'' Vincent, though, offered one cautionary note. The marketplace, he said, can go down as well as up. He cited the current real estate market as an example.
''One of these days,'' he said, ''it could happen with clubs and players. You might see an adjustment.''
Vincent predicted that expenditures in this winter's free-agent market would not be as robust as last year's. But he added, ''That's not saying much because last year was so robust.''
As for the $95 million price tag on the new franchises, it could be seen in two ways:
 1. It's an outrageous price for the right to field a team of washed-up veterans or inexperienced youngsters, considering that the two most recent sales of existing franchises were for $78 million (Seattle) and $70 million (San Diego). The Padres are light years closer to winning a division championship than an expansion franchise.
 2. The average player salary at the time of the purchase of the Seattle and Toronto expansion teams was $51,000. It's now in the $600,000 area, or about 12 times greater. If the franchise price of $7 million were multiplied by 12, it would be $84 million, or not very far from the posted price.
Of course, the new owners will have to pay those salary rates on top of their purchase price. That would seem to make the first view more logical, but as the commissioner said, people have lined up - 18 groups in 10 cities - and taken a number for what they may think is a bargain-basement sale.
 
TALK IS CHEAPER
 
Based on the Mets' comments about Darryl Strawberry, management does not believe he is worth the five-year, $23.5 million contract the Oakland Athletics gave Jose Canseco earlier this season. Value can be based on factors other than statistics, but here are the key statistics the two players have produced in their major league careers (1990 numbers are through Thursday's games):

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Just Give Me $10 Million, Baby

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON

 BODY:
In their disappointment and disgust, some Oakland people burned their Raider jackets and T-shirts. And in nearby San Leandro, Calif., at Ricky's sports bar and restaurant, where Raider jerseys once worn by Ken Stabler and George Blanda are shrines, the huge white banner announcing ''Welcome Home, Oakland Raiders'' in silver-and-black lettering was taken down.
''We folded the banner ceremonially,'' the proprietor, Ricky Ricardo, said, ''like you do an American flag at a funeral.''
Oakland is in mourning. The Raiders, once so close to returning there, are committed to staying in Los Angeles, at least for now. If the Raiders had returned, Oakland would have welcomed Al Davis as a prodigal son. But now most people there despise him more than ever. You don't put people's hearts up for auction. 
Once upon a time, Davis's motto for the Raiders was ''Just win, baby.'' But now it's ''Just give me $10 million, baby.''
Three years ago, the Raiders' managing general genius accepted $10 million, nonrefundable of course, from Irwindale, Calif., politicians just for thinking about transplanting his team to that Los Angeles suburb best known as the gravel-pit capital of the word. As soon as that $10 million cleared the bank, Davis stopped thinking about moving there.
In agreeing last Tuesday to a proposed 20-year deal that would keep the Raiders in Los Angeles rather than return them to Oakland, from which they should never have been hijacked, Davis accepted $10 million as an advance. He also accepted forgiveness of still another $10 million that the franchise owed the Los Angeles Coliseum Commission.
If everybody has a price, it's obvious now what Al Davis's price is: increments of $10 million.
Just give me $10 million, baby. And if you forgive me another $10 million, so much the better.
Perhaps for old times' sake, Al Davis was willing to give Oakland a 50 percent discount. In his hours of decision last Monday night, he demanded an advance of only $5 million from Oakland's negotiators in the $124 million deal that had been restructured after an outcry by Oakland citizens over a $602 million offer. When the Oakland politicians balked this time, their negotiations ended.
''We thought we had the Raiders a week ago,'' said George Vukasin, the president of the Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum Complex. ''And if they hadn't gone 4-0 in their exhibition games and then beaten Denver in their opener before a big crowd, I think we'd have them now. But even so, Al always leaves a side door open.''
In accepting the $10 million advance and the forgiveness of the $10 million debt, the Raiders have agreed to remain in Los Angeles only through the 1991 season. If by then the private financing of $145 million in Coliseum renovations, including at least 150 luxury boxes, is not in place or if the approval of government environmental and landmark groups has not been obtained, Davis is not obliged to sign the proposed 20-year Coliseum lease.
Until that 20-year lease is signed, sealed and framed on the wall of Al Davis's very own silver-and-black luxury box in the Los Angeles Coliseum, keep in mind that his autograph is easier to get than his team.
Through the years Davis has signed various other agreements with the Los Angeles Colisem Commission. Three years ago, he signed the Irwindale deal. Early this year, he signed a $602 million deal with Oakland that collapsed when its citizens understandably complained that a city still recovering from last October's earthquake needed to finance its real problems instead of a pro football franchise.
In between, Davis romanced Sacramento, Calif., which was reportedly willing to offer $50 million and a $100 million stadium. But when the Sacramento politicians dared to suggest part ownership, not even five $10 million increments were enough. Just forget it, baby.
Shortly before the National Football League season began, whispers circulated that Davis would accept a restructured Oakland offer that would soon return the team to its ancestral home. But now Davis has committed to Los Angeles for the next two decades unless that deal were to collapse. As it could.
If the current economy doesn't improve, will Spectacor, the company that manages two dozen stadiums, arenas and convention facilities, or other private financiers be willing to invest $145 million in a face lift for the the aging Los Angeles Coliseum, which was constructed for the 1932 Olympics?
Other questions must also be answered. Even if the financing is obtained, would a face lift alter the image of this dowager of American stadiums protected by its stature as a national landmark? And if more Coliseum parking lots need to be created for more vehicles in the la-la land of smog, would environmentalists approve?
In the confusion, Oakland is twisting in the wind. After 12 consecutive seasons of Raider sellouts and two Super Bowl titles, it turned out to be pro football's Brooklyn: abandoned for Los Angeles despite the devotion of its fans. And just when it thought Davis would accept its latest offer, it was slapped in the face.
In discussing expansion for the 1993 season, some N.F.L. owners insist there's a moral obligation to grant Oakland a franchise. Others disagree, insisting that the San Francisco 49ers fill the Bay Area's need for a team.
To some Oakland people, an N.F.L. expansion team would never be quite the same as the Raiders. To others, an expansion team might eventually prove to be as popular in Oakland as the expansion Mets have been in New York despite the departure of the Dodgers and the Giants to Los Angeles and San Francisco more than three decades ago.
But when the N.F.L. owners vote next year on expansion cities for their 1993 timetable, don't expect Al Davis to vote for Oakland. If his latest deal with Los Angeles starts to get lost in the smog, he'll still want Oakland for himself. Just give me $10 million, baby. Or if it's Oakland, only $5 million.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: 10 Years of False Starts;
Of Britons, Bahrainis and a Block of Brownstones

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Although American creativity is at the core of the office tower and museum planned on Manhattan's West 53d Street, it took a development team whose roots are in Bahrain and Britain to put the deal together.
After a decade of false starts, it appears that a new building may finally rise on the block east of the Avenue of the Americas, where a row of brownstones now stands. A three-story cube, with 40,000 square feet, would be the Museum of American Folk Art. Offset somewhat from that base would be a 31-story tower of about 160,000 square feet designed to attract tenants who are looking for - and can afford - ''boutique'' office space: small floors in a choice location.
The project, which may cost about $85 million and is to be finished in 1992 or 1993, is being developed jointly by Lionel R. Kustow, whose London & New York Estates concern operates on both sides of the Atlantic, and Investcorp, based in Bahrain, London and New York. The New York office of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill is designing the building. 
London & New York Estates, of which Mr. Kustow is chairman, principal and major shareholder, also developed the 461 Fifth Avenue building, at 40th Street, together with Mitsui Fudosan (New York). That 26-story office tower was completed in 1988. Investcorp, an international investment bank, has not ventured before into commercial real estate in New York but is well known as the purchaser of Saks Fifth Avenue, Tiffany & Company, Gucci, Carvel Corporation and Dellwood Foods. Its equity comes largely from institutional and individual investors in Bahrain, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.
''We did another project with London & New York in downtown Boston,'' said Damien Abbott of Investcorp, speaking of 70 Franklin Street. ''Because we knew them, we decided it would be appropriate to do this kind of transaction.''
What they have bought into is a project that has been 10 years in gestation.
In 1980, the Museum of American Folk Art bought two brownstones, Nos. 45 and 47. These had just been vacated by the Rehearsal Club, a boarding house for young actresses. It sheltered Shirley Booth, Carol Burnett, Blythe Danner, Sandy Duncan and Margaret Sullavan (to name a few) and inspired the play and movie ''Stage Door.''
In short order, four adjacent brownstones came on the market, including the one at No. 49 in which the museum was then leasing its gallery space. The museum bought these as well and took eightyears to relocate the more than two dozen tenants.
Almost from the start, museum officials envisioned an office tower with Folk Art galleries at the base. The attraction was the location, with neighbors like ABC, CBS and the Museum of Modern Art; the drawback was its size, plus the fact that it sat in a tiny zoning pocket that would have limited the building to about 160,000 square feet.
''That was a problem for most of the developers we talked to,'' said Ralph Esmerian, president of the board of trustees. ''They loved the idea of the museum and a cultural organization on that street, but the dollars and cents - they weren't able to stretch.''
In retrospect, the museum's original strategy appears to have been a bit backward, if esthetically well-intentioned. They chose an architect, Emilio Ambasz, before they had a builder. ''Unfortunately, marrying something that is strong in design with a developer's commercial sense is very difficult to do in this town,'' Mr. Esmerian said. ''It became an impossible design for anyone to build and so, unfortunately, we had to drop that.''
Mr. Kustow came on the scene more than three years ago and there followed what Mr. Esmerian described as ''on and off'' negotiations for month after month after month. ''I had to respect his tenacity in holding on to us,'' Mr. Esmerian said. ''He kept coming back to us with counter-proposals. There was certainly a personal interest on his part.''
As they put the deal together, the developers sought to increase the project's allowable bulk through a zoning change that would effectively add 15,000 square feet and through a merger of the 53d Street zoning lot with that of the City Athletic Club, 50 West 54th Street, directly to the north. Under that merger, 25,000 square feet of surplus development rights would be shifted from the nine-story clubhouse to the new tower.
Although Community Board 5 has been greatly concerned about density in mid-Manhattan, it concluded that the existing zoning on the 53d Street parcel was anomalous. ''Bringing that site into parity with its neighbors and restricting the use for the museum was certainly in the zoning context for 53d Street,'' said Jack Goldstein, chairman of the community board.
As part of the deal, the museum will turn over to the developers title to the land under four brownstones, Nos. 49 through 55, and will keep the land under Nos. 45 and 47. The building will be a condominium in which the developers own the office tower and the museum owns its quarters.
The physical envelope of the museum will be constructed by the developers. ''We build the entire structure, finished to the core and shell, and the facade,'' Mr. Kustow said. ''In consideration for us having the right to develop, the museum says: 'Don't give us money and tell us to go to another site. Build us a museum.' It's a very sensible arrangement.''
The museum, which has been without a formal home since 1986, has a gallery in the Two Lincoln Square building on Columbus Avenue, between 65th and 66th Streets, which is ultimately to become a satellite.
Museums and towers seem to mix on West 53d Street. Just down the block is Museum Tower, a condominium apartment building that sits atop and interlocks with the West Wing of the Museum of Modern Art, which is otherwise a completely separate space, built and owned by the museum. Across the street is the American Craft Museum at the base of the former E. F. Hutton headquarters tower, now known as 31 West 52d Street (it faces both 52d and 53d Streets). The building is divided into two condominium units, with the museum owning its space and the developer, Gerald D. Hines, owning the tower.
The developers of the new building, 53 West 53d Street, hope to complete the structure by early 1993. Financing will involve debt and equity, Mr. Kustow said, although the exact mix and sources are not set. The development will be speculative. It is not the kind of building that would be leased in advance by a large space user but rather by tenants who could do some ''tire kicking.''
As soft as the market is, Mr. Kustow said, a small building ''is the type of project that is probably holding out pretty well, where the buildings with big floor plates are having problems.'' Moreover, he said: ''Fifty-third Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, is a key location and always has been. It has a good, institutional quality to it. It feels good, from a real estate sense.''
As if to underscore that contention, but otherwise coincidentally, the law firm of Phillips, Nizer, Benjamin, Krim & Ballon is subleasing 115,000 square feet at 31 West 52d Street from Shearson Lehman Brothers, which acquired Hutton and its leases in 1988.
''The Sixth Avenue corridor over the years has been able to lease space to very good companies,'' said Barry Shaw, managing director of the Williams Real Estate Company, which represented Philips, Nizer. ''In lieu of being a pioneer in some of the more western properties on Seventh Avenue or Broadway, they felt more comfortable with a fully tenanted building and, when it got down to economics, it seemed to fit.''
There were other attractions. Thanks to the building's notched shape, there are 12 corners on each floor. ''That made it even more appealing to a law firm,'' Mr. Shaw said, ''on the basis that they can accommodate a lot of partners without the typical in-house problem of, 'Who's going to get the corner office?' In this case, every senior partner is going to have a corner office.''

HEADLINE: Easing Interest for Called Up Reservists

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
Armed Forces reservists who are called to trade their split level in suburbia for a tent in Saudi Arabia can take some comfort, at least, from a World War II law that reduces their mortgage interest rate to 6 percent and protects them and their families from mortgage foreclosure while they are on active duty.
The Soldier's and Sailor's Civil Relief Act of 1940 also puts the 6 percent cap on car payments, credit card balances and other installment debt, and allows the servicemen to break rental leases without penalty.
On Wednesday, the House Veterans Affairs Committee heard Pentagon officials testify that the act should be expanded, particularly a section barring evictions of active-duty soldiers from rental apartments.
President Bush has authorized the call up of 47,000 reservists in the Gulf crisis. About 19,000 have answered the call so far. 
Thrift industry officials believe that the financial impact from even a call-up of the full complement of reservists authorized would be greatest on the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac.
The two big federally chartered, investor-owned mortgage syndicators, which buy bank mortgages and convert them to investment instruments, have made commitments to absorb the lost interest income on their mortgages.
Kenneth A. Mills, vice president for public relations for Chase Manhattan Bank, said his company had already cut interest rate payments for about 100 servicemen involved in the commitment to the Persian Gulf crisis.
''We feel that we want to cooperate with these people in any way we can,'' Mr. Mills said. ''They are having their lives disrupted, and the least we can do is to make sure we do what the law requires.''
James Grohl, a spokesman for the United States League for Savings Institutions, estimated that the largest impact of the law would be on issuers of credit cards, where interest rates routinely top 18 percent.
''My guess would be that not all of the reservists have mortgages,'' he said, ''but they probably do have credit cards.''
Second-mortgage home improvement loans, another high-interest form of credit, would also come under the law, he said, as do all other installment debts.
In all cases, the 6 percent rate applies only while the soldier is on active duty, and the reqular rate resumes once the soldier puts on civilian clothes again. The lost interest income is lost to the bank forever, so while the secondary mortgage market will absorb most of the loss, banks holding the lowered mortgages in their own portfolios must absorb the lost interest income themselves.
There are about 12.5 million outstanding home mortgages in the country, with an average balance of $56,300.
The Relief Act passed during the first months of mobilization following the attack on Pearl Harbor, prevents a creditor from attempting to foreclose or to repossess a serviceperson's property while he or she is away on duty, unless the creditor can show a court that ability to pay is not materially affected by the call-up.
But even that approach may be difficult for an impatient mortgage lender. According to an analysis of the act prepared by the Pentagon, a person on active duty has an almost automatic right to a postponement of such a court action.
Indeed, Fannie Mae conceded that it would accept payments at a less than 6 percent rate, or even no payments at all, if the serviceman could not make them. But the missed payments below the 6 percent level would have to be made up later.
''Lenders should encourage the reservists to pay as much as possible, however,'' a Fannie Mae p0licy statement warned, ''because the mortgage should be brought to a current status when the active duty ends.''
The last time the 1940 act took force was during a Vietnam-era reservists' call-up in the late 60's, Mr. Grohl said. Mortgage rates were under 6 percent at the time and credit card use was limited, so the impact on lenders was minimal.
Although most of the attention of the law's impact is likely to be on its affect on savings and loan mortgage lenders, the act's broadest protections go to renters, including renters of business space and agricultural land.
A serviceman called to active duty may break a lease with one month's notice and the payment of a final month's rent, according to the Pentagon. If the lease is on a yearly basis, the landlord must refund any overpayment. Security deposits are also refundable when the month is up.
The act currently prohibits landlords from evicting reservists from apartments costing less than $150 a month because of non-payment of rent, a figure the Pentagon wants Congress to raise to $750.

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 1, Column 2; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2011 words

HEADLINE: Gulf Crisis Slows Decline at Military Plants

BYLINE: By JOHN ARUNDEL

 BODY:
THE crisis in the Persian Gulf could soon affect Connecticut's economy, injecting new life into the state's hard-hit military-equipment industry but possibly dealing a blow to the flourishing commercial aerospace business, military and industry analysts say.
Several small military suppliers in the state have already received new orders, as the Pentagon hastily scrambles to replace parts fouled by the desert of Saudi Arabia. And larger Connecticut military contractors, like Pratt & Whitney and Textron Lycoming, could soon benefit from the proposed sale of tanks and jet fighters to the Saudis.
On the reverse side are higher fuel prices, which could reverberate through the aerospace industry in the form of canceled orders for airplanes.
Although many analysts have warned that the boost to the military industry will not offset recent large-scale layoffs, some politicians, like United States Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of New Haven, say they are optimistic. ''Overall, our involvement in the Persian Gulf will renew interest in the Connecticut defense industry,'' Senator Lieberman said. ''We are making products that are relevant to third-world contracts.'' 
These products include the M-1 tank, whose engines are made by Textron Lycoming, in Stratford, and the F-15 fighter plane, powered by engines from Pratt & Whitney, in East Hartford, which the Saudi Government has requested to boost its defenses.
President Bush has authorized the sale of 24 F-15's to be delivered now and has approved plans to sell another 24 next year as part of an $8 billion package of military hardware for the Saudis.
Pratt & Whitney could also benefit from possible orders for C-17 cargo planes and the Air Force's twin-engine Advanced Tactical Fighter. The cargo plane, built by McDonnell Douglas and powered by Pratt & Whitney engines, could now be saved from scheduled cutbacks, because the Persian Gulf crisis has underscored a shortage of American airlift capacity. The conflict could also revive the $38 billion jet-fighter program, which Congress has threatened to suspend because of the budget deficit.
Other countries have also expressed an appetite for Connecticut-powered tanks and helicopters.
On Sept. 4, South Korea announced plans to purchase components for Blackhawk helicopters. The airframe, rotors and other parts would be produced at Sikorsky Helicopter's Stratford plant, but the aircraft would be assembled in Korea. The deal could be worth as much as $650 million, analysts said. The company has already delivered 12 of the helicopters to Saudi Arabia this year and is bidding to co-produce 200 of the helicopters with Turkey.
Textron Lycoming, which makes the 1,500-horsepower gas-turbine engine that drives the M-1 tank, said it has also seen a boost in military sales. Egypt has ordered 550 of the latest M-1 tanks, and Saudi Arabia signed a deal in July to buy 315 in July and requested an additional 385 in mid-August.
''We're pushing hard for foreign sales,'' said a Textron spokesman, Richard Berman. ''We firmly think the M-1 will become more attractive to foreign governments because of its performance in the Persian Gulf conflict.'' Some military contractors in Connecticut have already benefited from the buildup of United States troops in Saudi Arabia, where the desert's blowing sand and baking heat have had erosive effects on American military hardware. Several of the more than 2,000 military contractors based in Connecticut have reported sales of replacement parts, Senator Lieberman said. He declined to identify the companies.
Despite the gains from the short-term burst in military sales, economic analysts and military officials concede that it is improbable that these developments will be enough to reverse the massive work force reductions at Connecticut's military contractors in the last two years following the long buildup during the Reagan years.
''Regardless of what happens in the Middle East, we're still going to see a contraction in the defense industry,'' said Russell F. Farnen, a political science professor and director of Hartford campus of the University of Connecticut. ''Things are going to get worse before they get better.''
 
Rise in Jet-Fuel Costs
Professor Farnen said the showdown with Iraq could have a negative effect on the aerospace industry. Pratt & Whitney has a backlog of nearly $20 billion in commercial aircraft engines, he said, but the sharp rise in the price of jet fuel and a drop in passenger traffic as the economy has declined could mean fewer orders and even some cancellations in the coming months. ''The effects could be devastating on Connecticut,'' he said. But others disagreed. ''I don't think Americans are going to stop using airplanes because of a rise in fuel'' costs, said United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, a Hartford Democrat.
Either way, Pratt & Whitney, which long ago diversified into non-military products and last year received $12 billion in orders for commercial jet engines, is preparing for leaner times because of military cutbacks announced by the Bush Administration. Officials at the state's largest private employer on Aug. 2 that the company would be eliminating 3,800 jobs in Connecticut and Florida by 1993, mostly through attrition. Half the cuts would be in its Connecuticut operations, the company said, mostly among its white-collar workers.
''The Persian Gulf situation may forestall cuts, and it could even generate some sales in certain areas,'' said a company spokesman, David Long. ''But we're still not sure, because we have to hear from Congress first.''
 
Cutting the Deficit
Contractors like Pratt & Whitney have been bracing for peace for more than two years, as the cold war has thawed. While massive cuts in the defense budget have not yet been approved by Congress, Connecticut's other military contractors have also been scaling down in anticipation of the passage of President Bush's deficit-reducing proposals to wipe out or scale down some programs, like the M-1.
Textron officials have told nearly a third of the company's 4,000 employees that they could be laid off in the next couple of years if the tank program is eliminated. ''We have to keep the tank plants open, so we can fill these foreign orders,'' said a Textron spokesman, Bill McDaniel.
An orderly slowdown of tank production would also allow the company time to increase its business in the commercial sector, he said. Textron is looking into selling engines to airplane manufacturers and other commercial buyers. It has also completed work on a transverse-mounted engine that would free up 76 cubic feet of space in the M-1 that could be used for a larger gun, more ammunition or additional protective armor. This development would make the M-1 even more attractive to foreign buyers, if not the United States Government, Mr. McDaniel said.
 
'Lean and Efficient'
''It is abundantly clear that there will be defense cuts,'' said a company spokesman, Neil D. Ruenzel, ''and we we want to be prepared for them by being as lean and efficient as we can.''
Responding to the announcement, United States Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of East Haddam, said, ''I can't imagine the Navy shutting down the only yard in the United States that's exclusively dedicated to building attack submarines.''
Last week, as the defense budget was taken up in Congress, members of the Connecticut delegation said that the Persian Gulf situation will slow reductions in defense spending.
''Clearly, the events in the Middle East have reinforced the need for a strong conventional defense system,'' Representative Kennelly said. ''I believe that certain individuals got carried away with the peace dividend, and that will be remedied in the budget process.''
She said the Persian Gulf crisis will mean ''stability'' for the F-15 jet-fighter program and a ''stronger possibility'' to go forward with funding of the C-17 cargo plane. Congressional funding of the Advanced Tactical Fighter program, she said, ''remains to be seen.''
And Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Bozrah, predicted ''some marginal turn-arounds'' in the defense package because of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ''If this crisis gives us anything, it gives us time,'' he said. ''Time for conversion.''
 
Aid for Workers
A bill that would aid workers, businesses and communities affected by the loss of military contracts and help them make a transition to commercial production was introduced in late July by Senators Lieberman and Dodd. The measure, slowly wending its way though Congress, would provide laid-off defense workers with severance pay and health benefits for one year. It would also create a council on economic diversification to assist workers, communities and businesses affected by the cutbacks, and it would create a fund to encourage defense contractors to switch to commercial production and to retrain their workers.
''We have an extraordinarily talented work force, and it would be foolish to walk away from that,'' Senator Lieberman said.
Connecticut's economic planners say they are already making progress in efforts to help some military-product manufacturers convert to other lines. The State Department of Economic Development administers the Manufacturing Act of 1990, which earmarked $2 million in grants and low-interest loans for companies dependant on military contracts. It made a $500,000 loan this summer to Data Products New England, a company in Wallingford, to help it convert one of its most sophisticated products, a data processor, to commercial use.
The department is preparing to announce a grant to UNC Naval Products, in Montville, which builds nuclear reactors for submarines. The company has been hard hit by a cost-cutting directive by the Federal Department of Energy that gave all future work to UNC's competitor, Babcock & Wilcox, of Lynchburg, Va. Since the decision, UNC has laid off more than 40 percent of its personnel, more than 350 people, and scrapped a nearly completed $100 million plant. More than 1,500 workers stand to lose their jobs by the time UNC closes its doors by 1991.
The company has not explored commercial markets in 38 years, said the director of the Department of Economic Development, Stephen Heintz. ''We're going to help them inventory their options in new markets,'' he said.
Bruce Andrews, the company's president, said it hopes its nuclear reactors can be used for projects like the Federal Supercollider program, the Savannah River power plant or the Strategic Defense Initiative.
 
Conversion Has Begun
Connecticut's weapon-making history goes back to the flintlock rifles used by the Continental Army. Today, more than 25 percent of the state's manufacturing exports are defense products, a state task force reported in May.About 100,000 workers in the state are directly dependent on the military industry, and another 400,000 are indirectly affected, the report said. About 70 percent of the state's manufacturing jobs are defense oriented.
Some conversion of Connecticut's economy has already taken place, said state officials, who said the diversification will soften the shock of a sudden loss in military orders. They point out that while defense receipts accounted for almost 20 percent of Connecticut's gross product during the mid-80's, defense work now accounts for only 6 percent of the state's $80 billion gross annual product.
''Our economy has diversified dramatically,'' said the department's Deputy Commissioner, Andrew A. Brecher.
G. Ronald Hertenstein, vice president for research at Forecast International, a defense and aerospace analysis firm in Newtown, said cuts in defense spending will not affect Connecticut more than any other state. ''Connecticut will always have a defense industry,'' he said.
Senator Lieberman agreed. ''Many contractors in the state have significant order backlogs that will keep them going for three to five years,'' he said. ''That will give us time to fight for more contracts.''

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 1, Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1071 words

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
3 Familiar Faces Vie for the Title Of Mr. Outsider (And Governor)

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
NOW that United States Representative Bruce A. Morrison, of Hamden, has secured the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, several economic concerns remain the major issues for November's election: the state's yawning budget deficit, the possibility of a state income tax and a sluggish economy that is forcing the layoffs of thousands of workers, particularly in the military industry.
But more than fiscal concerns, voter dissatisfaction may become the most important factor in determining whether Mr. Morrison's primary victory last week over State Representative William J. Cibes Jr., of New London, can carry him to success in the general election. Mr. Morrison faces United States Representative John G. Rowland, of Waterbury, the Republican nominee, and former United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., of Greenwich, a Republican running as an independent on the Connecticut Party ticket.
Mr. Weicker's campaign, which has held wide leads in all voter-preference polls since he entered the race in March, is based almost wholly on attracting the support of voters who have become increasingly cynical or apathetic about politics and the two major parties. Mr. Rowland and Mr. Morrison are also eager to portray themselves as political outsiders or reformers, who will make sweeping changes in the current Democratic administration, which has become saddled with a reputation as a bloated bureaucracy that has done too little and acted too late to solve the state's financial problems. ''They are all against the immediate past,'' said Morton J. Tenzer, an associate professor of political science at the University of Connecticut at Storrs. 
Though these roles as outsiders may be appealing to an increasingly alienated electorate, they are also curious casting, since Mr. Morrison is a four-term member of the Democratic-controlled House of Representatives, and Mr. Rowland has spent 10 years as a legislator in Hartford and Washington.
The outsider label is also ill-suited for Mr. Weicker, who is running the most aggressive anti-politician campaign. Although he has long and carefully cultivated a reputation as a maverick liberal in the Republican Party, Mr. Weicker has spent a quarter-century in the Senate, the House of Representatives and the General Assembly. ''It is an interesting twist for someone who started in politics in his 20's and is now in his 60's,'' Mr. Tenzer said.
Analysts say that more and more candidates are now offering themselves as alternatives to ''politics as usual.'' Charles E. Cook Jr., the editor of The Cook Report, a Washington newsletter, noted the independent Congressional campaign of the Socialist and former Burlington, Vt., Mayor, Bernard Sanders; the campaign of Boston University's president, John R. Silber, for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in Massachusetts, and the victory of the socialist New Democratic Party in Ontario.
He also cited the upset victory by a businessman, Bruce Sundlun, in last week's Democratic gubernatorial primary in Rhode Island over the Mayor of Providence, Joseph R. Paolino Jr., and the strong campaign for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate in Louisiana by David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader who is now a state legislator.
''The anti-politician sentiment may be squelched by the Persian Gulf,'' Mr. Cook said. ''But when that disaffection and cynicism is captured by a strong personality, like a Weicker or a Sanders or a David Duke, it still works.''
Questions remain, though, about whether any candidate, even an independent like Mr. Weicker, can successfully exploit alienation, particularly in Connecticut's gubernatorial battle, a confusing three-way contest in which the Democrat paints himself as running against two Republicans, the Republican contends he is running against two Democrats, and the independent candidate attempts to appeal to members of both parties.
 
Doubts on Income Tax
Some voters may also suspect that Mr. Morrison supports a state income tax more than he has indicated. He has said he would support one if approved by the voters in an advisory referendum. Conversely, voters may doubt that Mr. Rowland will be able to keep his pledge to solve the state's fiscal crisis without raising taxes. And as for Mr. Weicker, voters appear to be unsure whether he supports or opposes a state income tax, probably because he has said that he will neither rule the idea in or out.
''There is a high level of cynicism out there that comes from the things like the Congressional pay raise and Republicans supporting raising taxes,'' Mr. Cook said. ''It's sort of like they can't even trust Republicans not to raise taxes anymore.''
Professor Tenzer said a more likely result of the alienation would be a lower voter turnout, which is what occurred last week, when only 19 percent of the eligible voters participated in Connecticut's Democratic Party primary.
In the Republican primary in the Third Congressional District, in which State Senator Thomas Scott, of Milford, defeated former State Representative Gerard Patton, also of Milford, only 6 percent of the eligible voters participated, a figure skewed by the fact that unaffiliated voters in Connecticut can cast ballots in some Republican primaries but not Democratic ones.
''There is a higher level of apathy out there than there has been on previous occasions,'' said Prof. James W. Dull, a former political reporter and chairman of the political science department at the University of New Haven.
 
Distracted Voters
Besides alienation, the low turnouts last week are also linked to the fact that this is an off-year election, meaning that there is no Presidential race, as well as the current lack of a statewide incumbent candidate, and the notion that political campaigns do not become interesting until the final weeks.
Some politics watchers, like Professor Tenzer, also noted that some of the apathy emanated from the Persian Gulf conflict, which has distracted potential voters and overshadowed local political news.
''I think that's changing,'' he said. ''And by October, more interest will be focused on the political races.''
Others, though, have another explanation. ''I attribute it to the anti-government feeling that grew during the Reagan Administration,'' Professor Dull said. ''There are a great deal of people out there that don't believe government can make a difference.''

HEADLINE: Florio and the Need To Raise Taxes

 BODY:
Re: ''Florio's Response to Tax Critics Is Questioned,'' Aug. 5:
I hate to pay taxes as much as anyone, and certainly the prospect of Governor Florio's substantial increases gets me where it really hurts. On the other hand, the behavior of the leadership of the anti-tax Hands Across New Jersey movement galls me even more.
At a meeting with the Governor, the tax repeal people, according to press reports, had nothing substantive to say as to how to manage our state's economy without new taxes. They talk of budget cuts but do not indicate just where they would act to effect economies. Apparently all they could identify as extravagant was the cost of the telegram sent to invite them to the meeting. 
Our State Constitution requires that all New Jersey children receive an adequate education. Our Supreme Court has determined that this is not taking place and has ordered that more money must be spent in poorer districts. How do the anti-taxers and their petition signers intend to pay for the added costs, or do they propose to change the New Jersey Constitution?
Toxic sites pollute our drinking water and the air we breathe. Do the no-sayers want something done, or are they content to ignore the danger?
Just how many police officers and firefighters should be fired to reduce the costs of government? Should some prisons be closed and their inmates released? Highway maintenance could be reduced, allowing the roads to further deteriorate. Crews could stop filling potholes, mowing lawns in summer and spreading salt and plowing in winter.
Casino revenues now dedicated to help senior citizens pay for their utilities could be diverted to the State treasury.
Yes, it is going to cost each and every one of us about three cents more for a roll of toilet paper, perhaps $3 a year - but maybe, just maybe, it might be worth it.
 
ARTHUR L. YEAGER, D.D.S.
 Westwood

LENGTH: 266 words

HEADLINE: Initiative Amendment: Dissenting Views

 BODY:
Mr. Hochbaum argues that because our Legislature in recent years has become more ''open,'' and because it has spawned a growing bureaucracy of specialized committees with larger and larger staffs, it is well equipped to make good decisions for us. He says that the public's use of referendums would amount to amateur meddling, and that we should patiently wait for the next election if our representatives outrage us. 
I find that preposterous. Far from ''weakening our system of representative government,'' the initiative and referendum amendment would give us an indispensable tool to encourage our elected officials to pay attention to our needs and wishes on an on-going basis, and not just immediately prior to an election.
Open access? Mr. Hochbaum argues that committee meetings of the Legislature are announced in advance and that interested citizens have the right to testify, and that we should confine ourselves to such participation in government between elections. How many of us can take time to attend every committee hearing in Trenton that is considering legislation that could affect us?
Who does send experts to testify? Only pressure groups who hold the Legislature hostage to single-issue voting blocks, or well-heeled lobbyists whose money the legislators may find hard to ignore. So much for the ''open'' access to the process.
We need initiative and referendum to make legislators pay attention. And we need it quickly so that this tax package can be rolled back before it throws New Jersey's economic engine into reverse.
 
H. TIMOTHY MCCANN
 Madison

LENGTH: 955 words

HEADLINE: Orchestra Gambles To Win The Young

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

 BODY:
WHEN a summer downpour forced the Philharmonia Virtuosi to move its popular free outdoor performance of Vivaldi's ''Four Seasons'' from Kensico Plaza to the cavernous County Center one Tuesday, gloomy orchestra officials predicted that few members of the audience would follow inside.
More than a thousand showed up in the center, carrying picnic dinners and blankets, many with children. ''We figured no one would come,'' Richard Kapp, the orchestra's musical director, recalled with a grin. ''Then we saw all those people and we said: 'Wait a second. If people will bring their kids in the rain on a Tuesday, why wouldn't they come back on a weekend in the fall?' '' 
The chamber orchestra has decided to find out. In an unusual effort to encourage more people to attend its subscription concerts and to build future audiences, the Philharmonia Virtuosi has announced a new ''Kids Attend Free'' policy, allowing children between the ages of 8 and 18 to attend subcription concerts at no charge if accompanied by a subscriber, with a limit of two free children with each adult.
 
The Audiences of Tomorrow
Leaders of other symphonic groups in the metropolitan area agree the policy is unprecedented and say they will be watching the results closely. ''It's a risk, but where else are the audiences of tomorrow going to come from?'' Mr. Kapp said. ''I have never felt price should be a barrier. Music should be as accessible as the movies.''
Recalling the crowds that attended the orchestra's free outdoor concerts this summer at Lyndhurst, the National Historic Trust property on the Hudson in Tarrytown, and at Kensico Plaza in Valhalla, Mr. Kapp said: ''It was very exciting for those people to be there, as they all wanted to be there. The desire to participate is more important than the $20 we could get if we charged for each seat.''
Under the old policy, parents who took children to Philharmonia Virtuosi concerts at the Performing Arts Center on the State University of New York campus in Purchase paid $40 a subscription for each child, Mr. Kapp said. But if they left their children home, he added, ''the price for a babysitter is still $25. Parents are caught between Scylla and Charybdis, so we decided to remove the barriers.''
 
As Patrons Grow Older
The new policy is also an attempt to strengthen the orchestra's shrinking subscriber base, a two-year decline that Mr. Kapp called slight but worrisome. The problem, he said, is one that arts organizations around the country face as patrons grow older without an accompanying increase in younger audiences.
A nationwide Harris Poll about two years ago found overall attendance at arts performances to be down by 12 percent from the previous year, matching the subscriber decline the Philharmonia Virtuosi is experiencing. The poll cited graying patrons as one factor, together with the reluctance of a younger generation to pay the prices charged for tickets and the competition for diminishing leisure time.
As long as there are seats available, Mr. Kapp said, now is the time for orchestras ''to decide who they want in them.'' The Kids Attend Free Policy reflects the orchestra's belief that a new audience ''can only be found through people's value systems,'' Mr. Kapp said. ''Otherwise, there is no way to market and sell those seats.''
 
A Look at Westchester
In Westchester, a downturn in the economy has also dampened subcriber enthusiasm, Mr. Kapp said. ''Westchester has changed immensely. People are spending less, and money is definitely tighter.'' Telephone calls to non-renewing subscribers confirm that many are moving from the county in search of better working and economic conditions, Mr. Kapp said.
Officials of the New Orchestra of Westchester, which presents a series of double concerts at the State University of New York in Purchase each season, are also noticing a trend toward an older audience, said Sara McClure, its executive director.
She said ''normal attrition'' among subscribers was 15 percent. ''The overall report is that we are doing very well, and you would be hard-pressed to find a seat at our SUNY concerts on Saturday night,'' Ms. McClure said. But the orchestra's audiences ''are getting a little older,'' she added, ''and we don't have a lot of 35-year-olds subscribing.''
The New Orchestra of Westchester charges $5 for children under 18 with a subscriber, and Ms. McClure said that this year, for the first time, a special marketing effort was being made to notify parents of that policy.
 
A Change in Ticket Purchasing
Subscriptions at the Westchester Symphony Orchestra are down 10 percent from last year, said Dr. Henry N. Oppenheimer, president of the orchestra. He added that more people were purchasing tickets individually instead of by subscription. ''People don't want to commit for a subscription,'' Dr. Oppenheimer said. ''With so many offerings around, you could tie up all your weekends for the year.''
The Westchester Symphony is concerned about building an audience for the future, Dr. Oppenheimer said, and a special family package is under consideration. ''Looking at our current patrons,'' he said, '' we can tell they are not the ones who go to rock concerts.''
The Philharmonia Virtuosi is hoping its new marketing ploy will be as successful as some unusual techniques it has tried in the past. For a special performance at Carnegie Hall several years ago, for example, the orchestra decided to charge only $7 a seat to attract an audience unfamiliar with the Westchester-based group.
''We took out an ad that said for $7 you can stand in line to see a movie or you can join us in Carnegie Hall,''' Mr. Kapp said. ''And we sold 3,500 tickets in 24 hours.''

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Houston;
Skywalker's Successor

BYLINE: By LETTICE STUART

 BODY:
 "Since the proposal is two years old, Mr. Cordish is in the process of updating his economic analysis," said City Attorney Clarence West. "We may be ready to move forward in several weeks."
The convention center, in the heart of the downtown theater district, has been vacant since the new 601,000-square-foot George R. Brown Convention Center opened 14 blocks away three years ago. 
Skywalker had proposed to transform it into a glitzy complex of restaurants, clubs, participatory games, shops, movie theaters and water-oriented activities on the Buffalo Bayou -- all tied into a Star Wars theme. A 100-foot-tall globe covered with glimmering lights was to be the project's signature.
But complications developed over a contract involving a 60-year lease and negotiations over splitting the costs of capital improvements with the city.
The project was scrapped when Japanese investors with whom the developers had been working for more than a year lost interest in it. Efforts to find other financing sources were unsuccessful.
According to Mr. West, the City Council purposely left the door open in 1988 to reconsider the Cordish proposal should the Lucas proposal fall through.
The Cordish proposal, said Arlene Cho, the company spokeswoman, includes a mix of retail, entertainment and restaurant space highlighted by an enclosed arboretum with a 60-foot waterfall spilling out of the building down to the bayou. The architect is D'Agostino, Izzo, Quirk Architects of Cambridge, Mass.
The original financing commitment from Winthrop Financial Associates, an affiliate of the Boston real estate firm First Winthrop, is no longer in place, said Mrs. Cho, but "we feel certain we will be able to get financing for the project."
Founded in 1967, Cordish has developed other festival marketplaces around the country, including Rainbow Center in Niagara Falls, N.Y., Trappers Alley in Detroit and Trolley Square in Salt Lake City. The company soon will begin construction of a hotel and conference center in Philadelphia.

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Augusta, Ga.;
Riverside Plans Generate Hope

BYLINE: By FORD RISLEY

 BODY:
 Until a few years ago, it was virtually impossible to get to the river from downtown. A 56-foot-high levee was built early in the century by the city to keep it from overflowing and, although dams and lakes later were built, the levee remained.
In 1986, the city breached the levee and two years later opened the first section of a mile-long riverfront park. Earlier this year, the final part of the park, known as Riverwalk, was completed. 
Port Royal is being developed by Port Royal Associates, a local development company, and C.F.I .,a Parisian investment group. It includes an 80,000-square-foot shopping mall and a 13-story condominium tower, said Wayne Rogers, vice president of Port Royal Associates. Completion is due next March .
The Riverfront Center originally was to be finished about the same time, but ran into financial problems. Those were resolved when William S. Morris, chief executive officer of Morris Communications, a local publishing company, became a limited partner in the development firm, Augusta Riverfront. Now the opening is expected early in 1992.
Riverfront Center will include a 240-room hotel, a 140,000-square-foot office building and a 30,000-square-foot conference center, said William Bailey, president of Bailey & Associates, another partner in Augusta Riverfront. The hotel and conference center are being financed partly through a $7.5 million grant from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development and $8 million from the City of Augusta.
Hotel business downtown has slumped in recent years, with the occupancy rate averaging 65 percent in 1989, and no hotel operator has been signed yet for the Riverfront Center. Port Royal officials hope the mall will be 80 percent leased before opening but admit they are far from that goal.
Except for the annual Masters Golf Tournament, the city has never been a big tourist destination and most residents shop in suburban malls. Mr. Rogers said the Riverwalk already has started to bring tourists and residents downtown by making the river accessible. The city's Fourth of July celebration this year on the Riverwalk attracted about 250,000 people downtown, he said.
"It's amazing," Mr. Rogers said, "how many residents have never had the opportunity to see the river from our vantage point."

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Portland, Me.;
First Venture By Japanese

BYLINE: By JEFFREY L. SMITH

 BODY:
 The project, Back Bay Tower, is a joint venture of Gleichman & Company of Portland and Mitsui Kensetsu of Chicago, a subsidiary of Mitsui Construction Company of Tokyo.
Thirty-four apartments have been set aside for tenants whose income is below the median for the area. A family of four, for example, earning no more than $18,900 will be able to rent a two-bedroom apartment for $326 a month. 
Market-rate rents vary from $675 a month for a one-bedroom to $1,450 for a three-bedroom penthouse with a wrap-around terrace. About 40 percent of the units, including about a dozen for low-income tenants, have been rented.
The project, designed by Sasaki Associates of Waterton, Mass., was financed in part by a $4.5 million low-interest loan to the developers by the city through a Federal grant in exchange for setting aside the low-income units.
Most apartments have views of either Casco Bay or Back Cove and there is an indoor pool, exercise equipment, a half-acre private garden, a doorman and covered parking for 128 automobiles with 18-hour manned security. Parking spaces rent for $55 a month.
The Portland City Council approved the project in 1984, but changing Federal tax policies and bureaucratic delays caused early investors to back out, said Pamela Gleichman, owner of her company.
The project was able to retain its low-interest loan when Mitsui Kensetsu became a financial partner in 1986.
Mitsui officials had started looking at Portland for possible investmentto strengthen the new sister-city relationship between Portland and Shinagawa, which is a Tokyo borough, said Shinichi Sugiura, executive vice president of Mitsui Kensetsu. The company ultimately invested $2.25 million.
Ms. Gleichman, 46 years old, who founded her small company in 1979 and who has has developed similar subsidized housing projects in Connecticut and Maine, said she has invested more than $1 million in the $16 million project.
Gov. John R. McKernan called the project a significant capital investment in an otherwise slow economy.

HEADLINE: Focus: The Midwest Market;
Demand is Strong and Prices Are Rising

BYLINE: By Jennifer Stoffel

DATELINE: CLEVELAND

 BODY:
In marked contrast to the housing picture in the rest of the country, the demand for homes throughout the Middle West remains robust, with brisk sales and rising prices signaling the region's emergence as the strongest market in the country.
The number of resales rose 4.2 percent in the second quarter throughout the region's 12 states, compared to a year earlier, in contrast with a decline of 0.5 percent nationally, according to the most recent survey by the National Association of Realtors. The states are Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North and South Dakota, Ohio and Wisconsin.
In that same period, 50 of the 98 metropolitan areas throughout the country surveyed by the trade group posted price increases at or above the 3.4 percent national average, with four in the Midwest showing double-digit gains. They were Chicago (an 11 percent rise in the median resale price of a one-family house, to $116,600); Indianapolis (16.1 percent, to $82,300), Lincoln, Neb. (10.9 percent, to $61,900), and Rockford, Ill. (14.9 percent, to $68,700). 
''The Midwest has just not been subject to the big run-ups in price that have happened on the coasts,'' said Norman D. Flynn, president of the National Association of Realtors. ''Sure, it's not remarkable, it's not a super boom, it never will be. It's steady as she goes.''
For much of the region, as the overall economy experienced a rejuvenation during the late 80's - the stock market crash of October 1987 had little effect here - housing also made a rebound.
''New home product sat and there was virtually no building in the early 80's,'' said Vincent Aveni, president of Realty One of Cleveland, where stagnating sales and foreclosures accompanied the economic recession in the early 80's.
''Now,'' he added, ''with new jobs being created, the overall move-up market is good. With every first-time home buyer there is a filtering up which creates three more transactions.''
The National Association survey reported that the Cleveland area's increase of 7 percent, to a median home price of $81,500, was surpassed in Ohio only by the gain in Columbus, 7.4 percent, to $82,400. And the number of sales statewide, the survey found, was up 5.8 percent.
Yet, while signs of more prosperous times are welcomed here, on closer examination the housing figures reveal a pattern of growth and development that, if it continues, will leave many cities drained. The acceleration of migration to the suburbs, a decades-old trend, is prompting a debate about public policy and the future of city housing.
In particular, the market for move-up houses in suburban subdivisions has prospered in recent years from the region's changing economy.
Smokestack industries no longer dominate and jobs in manufacturing have remained flat after a drop of 22 percent in the early 80's. Thus, in Cleveland and the rest of the Middle West, the recovery is attributed to a growth in service industries.
Changing life styles also appear to be spurring suburban growth and the continued strength in sales of higher-priced houses. In addition to better schools and less crime, recreational amenities - such as pools and jogging trails - ample green space and large lots are typically what lure young professionals with children to new developments.
''Young people want to do everything today,'' said Lois Latina, a principal in Latina & Latina Builders, a local developer. ''And why not? Why wait to give yourself and your kids the good things in life?''
The continued growth of such Cleveland suburbs as Strongsville exemplifies the trend.
As the largest suburb in land area in Cuyahoga County - with 24.5 square miles - and with downtown Cleveland just 18 miles to the northeast by way of Interstate 71, Strongsville had the right combination to justify predictions of growth. In fact, a decade-long residential housing boom added 2,737 single-family homes during the 1980's.
Expecting expansion to continue and new suburban housing to remain attractive to move-up buyers, Parkview Corporation, a local developer, started a planned unit development of one-family homes in Strongsville in the late 70's. It consists of two distinct communities - High Point and Deerfield Woods - that share such amenities as 46 acres of open space, tennis courts, a pool and a jogging trail.
When the 230-acre High Point development is completed in mid-1991, it will have 608 one-family residences, 122 of them detached cluster homes, built around the open-space area. As it stands now, 500 homes are completed.
Prices in the development range from $145,000 for a 1,500-square-foot, two-bedroom villa in a cluster site to $500,000 for four- and five-bedroom homes of 4,000 square feet.
The other community, Deerfield Woods, has been proposed for an adjacent 78 acres. Approvals have not yet been received from the city, but the developoment is expected to comprise single-family homes of 3,200 to 4,200 square feet starting at $275,000.
Similar projects ring the metropolitan area. At Rolling Brook Estates, in Solon, on the far southeastern side of Cuyahoga County, 20 miles from downtown, most homes are over 4,000 square feet and begin at $450,000. Sales began there in 1987, aimed at professional families in their late 30's to 40's with children; 34 of 38 five-acre lots have been sold.
Another local developer, Transco Construction, began construction in Solon last month of Cambridge Park Estates, 41 one-family homes beginning at $275,000 on one-acre lots. Since the initial offering earlier this year only 18 lots remain.
Yet local officials and planners concede there is a downside to the economic resurgence that is driving the boom in suburban development.
Across the state, suburbs prosper as people continue to abandon cities, and new construction is out of balance with the number of new households, according to a study released in June by the Ohio Urban University Program, a consortium of seven urban Ohio universities.
Further, the study indicates, the flight from the cities is being reinforced by policies as varied as public financing of road improvements and school expansions - with much of the work in the suburbs - and mortgage assistance programs for first-time home buyers.
The study covered Akron, Cincinnati, Cleveland, Columbus, Dayton, Toledo and Youngstown.
''The state and Federal Government enable and invite people to move out,'' said Thomas E. Bier, director of housing policy research at Cleveland State University and a contributor to the study. ''I'm not saying there is an easy answer to this, but over the long term we will literally empty the cities.''
Among Ohio cities, the study showed, Cleveland was second only to Youngstown in both population loss and housing surpluses through the 80's, with a ratio of 1.8 new housing units to one additional household.
If the trend continues as predicted, the report anticipates that 14.7 of the households and 17.8 percent of the population will leave Cleveland for the suburbs this decade, creating an 18.8 percent housing surplus in the city.

HEADLINE: Sands Bloom With Growth In Las Vegas

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

 BODY:
Out in the desert suburbs, far from the casinos' bright lights, workers are hurriedly building monuments to the assumption that this city will always come up a winner.
As fast as stucco can dry, subdivisions, apartment complexes and shopping malls are rising in the sandy wastes to accommodate the horde of newcomers who have helped Nevada's population grow by almost half over the last 10 years.
While the population of Nevada is only 1,193,000 people, according to preliminary census data, that represents a hefty increase from 800,000 in 1980 and 489,000 in 1970, making it the fastest-growing state in terms of percentage over the last 20 years.
Most of the growth in the last decade took place in Las Vegas and surrounding Clark County.
Many new Las Vegas developments have names like Bay Breeze, Sunset Bay and Bermuda Springs, as if the aquatic imagery could defy the dust and pale rock all around. More than 1,000 single-family homes are built each month, in contrast to the trend almost everywhere else in the country. 
 
Migration to Sun Slows
In the 1980's, Americans continued their long migration to the warm climes of the Southwest. But recently the Sun Belt dream of limitless space for unending growth has faded. It has fallen victim to the polluted haze of traffic in Los Angeles and has turned sour with the real estate slump in Phoenix. Not here. ''In Las Vegas, we believe in looking forward and making big plans,'' said James Cashman 3d, president of a construction and mining equipment company. ''Sometimes we maybe make our plans too big on purpose, but that's because we expect to grow and want to grow, and that very attitude makes it happen.''
And there is little nostalgia for the ways of a small city, left behind in the 1960's as Las Vegas took on urban problems like street gangs, drug abuse and overtaxed public services.
''This is not a town of looking-back people,'' Mr. Cashman said.
 
Rewards of Growth
Since the mid-1980's, rapid expansion of gambling and tourism has fired up the Las Vegas economy, creating thousands of jobs. Gambling receipts have climbed 30 percent in the last two years, enriching the state government, which collects a 6.4 percent tax.
Also, the absence of any personal and corporate income taxes and the availability of relatively inexpensive real estate 280 miles from Los Angeles have proved a powerful draw for retirees and businesses. In effect, Las Vegas has become Southern California's most far-flung suburb.
Only the first apprehensions over growth are being whispered here. ''I could not have imagined a traffic jam in Las Vegas even a few years ago,'' said Mr. Cashman, a rare third-generation native. ''Now we're starting to get them - little ones compared to anywhere else - and it makes me wonder whether we couldn't just take a breather to catch up some before we keep on going.''
In the 1970's, the population of the metropolitan Las Vegas area grew about 70 percent, from 273,000 to 466,805. In the next decade, the metropolitan population grew 31 percent more, to 612,602. Some suburban communities in surrounding Clark County, like Henderson, grew by nearly 150 percent in the 1980's, according to the census figures.
School enrollment figures show acceleration in the second half of the 1980's. In September 1985 the number of students in the Clark County public schools was up 2 percent over the previous year; in every year since then, the rate of expansion has increased. The district expects enrollment to be up about 7.6 percent this year.
It is in the schools that keeping up with growth has proved most difficult. A number of schools have twice the number of students they were designed for, said Ray Willis, a school district spokesman. Classrooms have been partitioned so that they could be used by two classes at once, he said, and several schools are holding two sessions a day, obliging half the students to begin classes at 6:30 A.M. and the other half to stay until late afternoon.
So new schools are being built. Eleven new schools opened for the first day of school this year, and eight more are under construction.
For the first time, several prominent candidates for local and state offices are campaigning on promises to take account of the costs of rapid growth to the environment and public services. Gov. Bob Miller, a Democrat who will face the voters in November, proclaims that Nevada is at a crossroads and that ''the time has come to define our goals.''
The debate in the Las Vegas area, which is home to about 60 percent of the state's population, still focuses on whether efforts should be made to manage growth while encouraging it. So far, there has been no large audience for the kinds of proposals to restrain growth that are now regularly debated elsewhere in the West.
''It hasn't happened yet, but you can sense that a political change is coming,'' said Jeff German, a columnist for The Las Vegas Sun.
 
Upgrading the Image
But for the moment, Las Vegas is still reveling in what many people here perceive as a radical improvement in its image.
''We are starting to be seen as more of a typical city,'' said Mr. German. ''Even though we still have the gambling and the glitz, the rest of the country no longer thinks of Vegas as a sin capital run by organized crime. Now there is legal gambling all over, whether it is state lotteries, casino ships or Atlantic City.''
The spread of gambling has not only legitimized Las Vegas but also presented it with widespread competition. In response, the big corporations that now run many of the major hotel casinos have gone after the convention market and developed new attractions that are virtual theme parks under a single roof.
Two such establishments, the 3,000-room Mirage and the 4,000-room Excalibur, have opened within the last year to vast and appreciative crowds. The Mirage has a tropical island motif,, while the Excalibur is a medieval fantasy world complete with jousting matches. The properties, which dwarf Atlantic City's newest offering, the 1,200-room Trump Taj Mahal, increased Las Vegas's hotel capacity 10 percent, to nearly 70,000 rooms. Another establishment, the Sahara Hotel and Casino, is adding 600 rooms, bringing the total to 2,100.
Some of the older casinos announced layoffs this summer, though, prompting industry analysts to ask how much more growth can be sustained and whether some of the aging landmarks on the Las Vegas strip will be able to compete with the new resorts.
Although Las Vegas has attracted a number of financial services companies, some light manufacturing and several large warehousing and distribution operations, the growth in gambling and tourism has overwhelmed efforts to develop a more diversified economy.
In the years of the city's rapid expansion, tourism and gambling have consistently provided about 30 percent of the employment in Clark County and taxes on gambling have accounted for nearly half the state's revenue. The dominance of this industry is Las Vegas's most frequently cited vulnerability.
''If you look at the city's fiscal and economic dependence on this one activity, then it is a house of cards,'' said R. Keith Schwer, director of the Center for Business and Economic Research at the University of Nevada in Las Vegas.
But he added, ''If you look beyond the casinos to an entire tourism business and the growing ties to a market of 29 million people in California, then it looks much more solid.''
