HEADLINE: High-Tech Medicine At High-Rise Costs Is Keeping Pets Fit

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
For 30 minutes, as much time as it takes to place a patient inside the metal doughnut of a CAT scanner and make a cross-sectioned study of his cancerous throat, the fate of Buster hung in the balance.
Luck was on the side of the 7-year-old West Highland terrier. Pictures from the computer-controlled imaging device showed that the cancer was not widespread. Ahead lay a seven-week regimen of chemotherapy and cobalt radiation and a $4,000 medical bill for Buster's owner. The guarded prognosis: Buster could have good ''quality of life'' for another year or two. Without treatment, he would die by Christmas.
Although prize livestock and racehorses have always received high-level care because of their value as property, in the last decade household pets, mostly dogs and cats, have become beneficiaries of medical and technologically advanced diagnostic treatments perfected on humans. 
The most advanced procedures, like brain and heart surgery, bone transplants and nuclear medicine, are available at regional training hospitals. Advanced skills and treatments less dependent on special training or equipment are making their way into neighborhood clinics.
As the reach of medicine helps more animals at an ever-higher cost, a debate is gaining momentum on veterinary school campuses and in professional journals that veterinary ethics are not keeping pace, especially with changes in social attitudes toward pets.
''What's different is the unbelievable elevation of the importance of the human-animal bond and evidence that humans have benefited emotionally from the presence of pets,'' said Dr. James Wilson 3d, a bioethicist at the University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine. ''More than two out of three Americans think of their pets as family members; some 20 percent in surveys say they are as important as a child.''
Americans spent nearly $6 billion on veterinary services in 1987, up 20 percent from the previous survey in 1985, said J. Carl Wise, an economist for the American Veterinary Medical Association, the profession's governing body, which has 49,875 licensed members. $4,000 Operation on Pet Not long ago, $250 was considered a high price for veterinary services for an injured or dying pet, because advanced treatment was limited and euthanasia was relatively common and accepted.
Today nearly that much can be spent at a local animal hospital for a single ultrasound examination. Major orthopedic and heart surgery can cost $1,500 to $4,000. Most such services are not covered by insurance.
There are many people, including pet owners, who consider it unseemly, even shocking, to spend thousands of dollars on advanced pet care in a society where humans often have little or no access to such help.
But Bruce Jennings, an associate for policy studies at the Hastings Center, a medical ethics research institute in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., said that kind of reaction was misplaced.
''As long as the money comes out of an individual's pocket and not public resources, it makes no particular sense to single it out from other economic purchases such as jewelry or a fancy car. From an ethical point of view, aiding an animal may be a more noble expenditure than jewelry.''
 
Animal Charity Hospitals
Rising costs do pose a quandary for veterinarians, though. Even as they profit from medical advances, they are coming under pressure to provide for animals from low-income households.
''Many people can't afford anything but euthanasia,'' said Dr. Michael W. Fox, vice president of the Humane Society of the United States. ''The big question for animal doctors is what to do for a loving elderly person with limited resources whose pet needs a $6,000 operation. It suggests the need for community support for a network of full-service animal charity hospitals like the ones provided in England.''
Jerrold Tannenbaum, a lawyer who teaches a required ethics course at Tufts University's veterinary school, said rising costs of the new services pose the question of whether veterinarians - who on average earn $51,000 a year, just 40 percent of what physicians make - should offer more low-cost or free care.
Another question for some veterinarians is the kind of moral claim animals - at least a select number of companion animals - have on humans. They say choices about treatment are being made within a social and legal tradition that animals are chattel and can be put to death on a whim or on grounds of economic utility.
About 7.5 million dogs and cats -healthy or disabled, old and young -are killed each year in this country, according to the Humane Society of the United States. Dr. Wilson, the bioethicist, said veterinarians were beginning to balk at an owner's demand that an animal in basic good health be destroyed.
 
Animal Rights Issues
''They are saying that the pet may be the owner's property, but they won't push the plunger,'' Dr. Wilson said. ''This is especially true of the younger graduates influenced by the animal rights movement.''
He described the situation of a young veterinarian whose identity he would not disclose. ''An elderly widow with a terminal disease wanted her pregnant 3-year-old dog put to sleep because she couldn't afford the cost of a Caesarean procedure and she was afraid, in any case, no one would care for her dog after she herself was gone,'' he said.
The veterinarian offered to drastically cut his fee, but was unable to change her mind. Although he agreed to destroy the animal, he could not bring himself to do so and delivered the litter at his own expense and found homes for the mother and pups. When the dog owner learned what he had done, she was outraged. She sued him and complained to the state licensing board.
''He did the right moral and ethical thing and faces having his license lifted,'' Dr. Wilson said.
For Dr. Mike Shires, acting dean of the veterinary school at the University of Tennessee in Knoxville, there is another spin in the ethics debate.
''Despite a poor prognosis, many people pursue all sorts of extreme medical treatments for their pets that weren't available a few years ago,'' he said. ''In cases where continued treatment is cruel, we still have the option denied in human medicine and we recommend euthanasia. If they still insist, and you only have to be in this business a short time to learn there are a lot of oddballs out there, we tell them to take their pet somewhere else.''
 
Supply of Advanced Equipment
The demand for the best in pet care has created a secondary market for medical technology. CAT scans and ultrasound diagnostic equipment used on humans are sold to animal hospitals at cut-rate prices when hospitals replace them with state-of-the-art equipment. Similarly, $5,000 pacemakers that go unused beyond recommended shelf life are sold for about $100 and implanted into dogs for about $700, compared with $12,000 for the same procedure on a human.
''If expense is not a consideration, veterinary medicine can do anything on dogs and cats that we can do on human patients,'' said Dr. Michael Garvey, medical chairman of the Animal Medical Center in New York, where Buster was treated. It is one of a score of teaching hospitals around the nation where the latest treatment is available for pets. ''I like to say we work out the bugs on humans and when it's safe enough, we adapt the procedures for animals.''
The center handles 70,000 pet visits a year. Its surgeons repair defective heart valves, do double hip replacements and use dialysis to get cats through a dangerous kidney infection.
At the University of California at Davis, veterinary students volunteer their time to a telephone counseling line. ''Pet owners can't express their grief in the usual ways because some people might think it's silly,'' said a fourth-year student, Jennifer Martin, 24 years old. ''But consciousness is being raised as more and more clients are demanding it from the profession.''
 
Element of Human Nature
''I don't push the advances on owners with geriatric pets or ones without good quality-of-life prospects,'' said Dr. Jane Mason, of Chantilly, Va., who graduated from Auburn University in 1986. ''It's funny how human nature is, but people with lots of money sometimes won't do anything to save a pet and those who have to scrape every dollar together want to go on with the CAT scans and try chemo.''
For those who can pay, the price seems worth it.
''Hey, you don't put a price tag on the life of someone in your own family,'' said Buster's owner, Noel Cooper, of Rego Park, Queens, who owns several laundromats. ''He's like our child. How could I do anything less for someone that gives me so much pleasure?''

HEADLINE: Superpowers Seeking an Angola Agreement

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
In another sign of growing superpower cooperation, the United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to work jointly as mediators to revive Angola's stalled peace talks and end civil strife there, American and Soviet officials say.
Angola's intermittent 15-year conflict pits a Marxist Government, backed by 1,100 Soviet advisers and $800 million a year in Soviet military aid, against a guerrilla group, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, which receives more than $50 million in annual aid from Washington.
The war has devastated the southwest African country's economy and has continued even after the negotiated withdrawal of 50,000 Cuban troops and advisers beginning late in 1988.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, discussed Angola at length last month in Siberia and agreed to work together to encourage their allies to work out their differences. 
Their diplomatic push comes at a time of increasing Soviet and American coordination in attempting to wind down the civil wars in Afghanistan and Cambodia. But as in those conflicts, the two sides fighting in Angola have such deep mutual disdain that even the best efforts by Washington and Moscow may not be enough to bring them together.
 
Pressure to Settle
Several factors are leading the superpowers to act now, including pressure in Moscow and Washington to wind down their expensive commitments to a conflict that both Governments view as peripheral to their interests. Fears are growing inside and outside Angola that if a cease-fire is not reached sometime in the next several months, a spreading famine could kill many thousands of people next year.
Moreover, the Persian Gulf crisis has underscored Angola's potential importance as an oil producer. The African country currently produces 500,000 barrels a day, far below its potential.
American oil companies based in Angola are quietly pressing the Bush Administration to settle the conflict. But conservatives, and some officials in the Central Intelligence Agency and National Security Council, are urging the White House to help the guerrilla leader, Jonas Savimbi, achieve a military victory.
A senior State Department official said that although the Bush Administration was continuing covert efforts in Angola to boost Mr. Savimbi, it did not share the Reagan Administration's hard commitment to the struggle and realized that Congressional opposition was growing.
''You can't go on forever getting aid from the hill for Unita,'' he said, referring to the guerrilla group by its Portuguese acronym. ''We're in the end game.''
By a narrow margin, the House Intelligence Committee earlier this month secretly voted to continue covert aid to the guerrillas. But opponents of the policy have threatened to bring the issue to the floor, which could embarrass the Administration. A bruising battle is also expected in the Senate. Covert aid is usually tucked into budget bills and not openly debated.
Both the Angolan Government in Luanda and the guerrillas have expressed their desire to end the war and hold multiparty elections. But in three negotiating sessions over the last five months, distrust has blocked meaningful progress. Meanwhile, the guerrillas have gone on the offensive in the northern provinces, apparently with renewed military support from right-wing South African elements.
The Portuguese Government, Angola's former colonial ruler and the current sponsor of the talks, has asked the superpowers to press both sides to compromise.
Leonid Sofanov, counselor of the Soviet Embassy in Washington, said the superpowers ''could act as sponsors or mediators, or act as co-chairmen'' in the peace talks.
The Soviets have been pressing a partial peace proposal called the ''triple zero option,'' which called on Moscow and Washington to stop military aid to Angola, and on the two sides not to accept weapons from anyone else. Angola accepted the proposal, but Washington turned it down, saying it would only benefit the Marxist Government in Luanda.
 
Baker-Shevardnadze Contacts
American officials said Mr. Baker approached Mr. Shevardnadze about a joint effort on Angola in March, when the two diplomats joined in independence festivities in Namibia, which borders Angola. Mr. Shevardnadze agreed that the superpowers could cooperate to end the Angolan war as they had in helping bring Namibia to independence.
Since the Baker-Shevardnadze meeting last month in Siberia, lower-level diplomats of both countries have intensified discussions on Angola.
To this point, Luanda and the Unita rebels have discussed only the broad outlines of a statement of principles governing a final settlement. Unita has said it would recognize the authority of President Jose Eduardo dos Santos until there are general elections. In return, it wants legal status as a political party.
The Angolan Government has said that it wants the country to evolve into a multiparty democracy. But the two sides disagree over the pace of democratic change. Mr. Savimbi wants elections immediately. Mr. dos Santos believes that it will take many months or years to prepare the nation for a vote.
Maj. Gen. Roberto Monteiro, chief military adviser to Mr. dos Santos, said relations with the United States would be difficult as long as the Bush Administration insisted on arming Unita.
During a visit to Washington this month, General Monteiro insisted that his Government was fully committed to economic and political reforms. In an interview, he said, ''We're closer on how to get to a cease-fire and how to create a national army.''

HEADLINE: American Jesuit in Sri Lanka Is Missing and Feared Dead

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE; Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Sept. 16

 BODY:
An American Jesuit missionary who spent 41 years in Sri Lanka building up a well-known vocational school for boys has been missing since Aug. 15, and may have been killed in fighting between rival ethnic factions in a renewed civil war.
According to his family in Lafayette, La., the priest, Eugene J. Hebert, 66 years old, was last seen driving a motor scooter from Valachehenai to Batticaloa on Sri Lanka's east coast, where he lived.
In addition to offering courses in welding, electrical work and refrigeration to unemployed young men, the priest's vocational school had been trying to rehabilitate former guerrilla fighters, giving them a trade to help them return to civilian life. 
Father Hebert, a familiar figure around Batticaloa, where he also coached basketball teams, had been visiting Muslim surviviors of an attack by Tamil guerrillas. A Red Cross worker told his family that after comforting the victims, Father Hebert went to the site of the massacre, in Eravur, before returning to Batticaloa.
 
'We Just Want to Know'
According to those who saw him last, he had given a ride to a Tamil boy. Father Hebert's niece, Yvonne Dumesnil, said in a telephone interview last week from Louisiana that one theory suggested to the family by fellow priests and aid workers in Sri Lanka is that enraged Muslims may have attacked the Tamil boy, drawing her uncle into the fight.
''We are trying not to think the worst,'' Ms. Dumesnil said. ''But we just want to know something.'' She said that other Jesuit priests in Sri Lanka had been warned not to go into the area to look for Father Hebert.
Thomas Gradisher, a spokesman for the United States Embassy in Colombo, the Sri Lankan capital, said that American diplomats are in constant touch with the Foreign Ministry and the army, but that no progress had been made in solving the case.
Other diplomats in Sri Lanka say that they are putting aid programs on hold and withdrawing foreign workers until a semblance of security is restored to the Batticaloa region. Father Hebert's school was supported by Norwegian and Canadian aid programs.
 
Hit-and-Run War
Tamil guerrillas, ethnic Sinhalese, who dominate the army as Sri Lanka's largest ethnic-linguistic group, and Muslims, who consider themselves a separate ethnic entity, have been clashing since mid-June. A series of attacks and reprisals began after the last armed guerrilla group in the field, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, reopened a hit-and-run war for control of the east coast, singling out Muslims for not cooperating with them.

HEADLINE: Leftist Journal Concludes Allende Killed Himself

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Saying that the ''historic truth'' should be known, a Chilean news magazine identified with the left has published a special report concluding that former President Salvador Allende committed suicide 17 years ago.
Although a reputable witness and ample other evidence had pointed to this conclusion from the outset, the article in the magazine Analisis last week seemed to be aimed at making the fact acceptable to the Socialists, Communists and others who supported Dr. Allende. The article appeared a week after Dr. Allende's remains were exhumed from an unmarked grave in Vina del Mar and brought to Santiago for a public burial attended by his family, President Patricio Aylwin and his Cabinet, and tens of thousands of mourners.
Although Mr. Aylwin, a Christian Democrat, was a strong opponent of Dr. Allende, his participation was seen as part of an effort by the six-month-old democratic Government to heal old wounds. 
Analisis said the version that Dr. Allende was killed by the army as it captured the presidential palace was invented and spread by the Moscow radio and President Fidel Castro of Cuba within days of the coup on Sept. 11, 1973. ''In that way, the world left generated its own truth about what had occurred in the last minutes of the life of Allende,'' the magazine said.
 
Political Significance
It said that the claim of either assassination or death in battle took on a political significance that was useful in opposing the 16-year military regime that followed the fall of Dr. Allende.
Admitting the suicide ''would have been to recognize total defeat,'' the magazine continued, while assassination ''created better conditions for confronting the usurpers.''
Analisis does not publicly identify with a particular political group, but it has been known for having unusually good access to guerrillas, the Communist Party and others of the far left.
Juan Pablo Cardenas, the editor, aroused international sympathy during the former Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet when he served a sentence of 541 nights in jail for offenses to the armed forces. He spent his nights in jail and continued to run the magazine during the day.
Dr. Allende had served less than three years of the six-year term to which he was elected when the armed forces overthrew him in response to widespread public opposition to his socialist economic policies and general economic chaos.
A subsequent investigation by a United States Senate committee led by Frank Church, a Democratic Senator from Idaho at the time, found that the Central Intelligence Agency had helped to finance some of the groups that opposed Dr. Allende with strikes and other actions.
 
Physician's Evidence Cited
It also found that the Nixon Administration had tried, in 1970, to persuade Chile's Christian Democrats to vote against Dr. Allende when the final electoral decision went to Congress after no candidate received an absolute majority of the popular vote. But the Church report found no evidence of direct United States involvement in the coup three years later.
The Analisis article, written by the political editor, Francisco Martorell, said the suicide had been confirmed by the physician and Government officials who exhumed Dr. Allende's body before the recent reburial and examined the remains.
The magazine said those doing the examination were able to confirm that Dr. Allende's face had been partly destroyed by a bullet and that the rest of his body had not been struck.
This coincides with the account of Dr. Patricio Guijon Klein, Dr. Allende's personal surgeon, who was in the palace that day and reported seeing the President fire a rifle pointed upward from between his knees.
The magazine said that Mr. Castro, on Sept. 28, 1973, in Havana, had claimed that Dr. Allende, while advancing toward army troops firing his own weapon, had been struck by a bullet in the stomach, another in the chest, and had finally died in a hail of bullets.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
U.N. Seeks Wider Embargo In Vote Assailing Iraqi Acts

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 16

 BODY:
The Security Council unanimously condemned Baghdad early today for acts of violence against foreign embassies and their personnel in occupied Kuwait and promised new, unspecified steps to tighten the mandatory trade embargo against Iraq.
Diplomats said the new measures would probably include an expansion of the embargo to include air traffic.
Today's resolution marks the seventh time the Council has condemned Iraq since it invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The most significant provision, diplomats say, is a commitment by all 15 Council members ''to take further concrete measures as soon as possible under Chapter VII of the Charter in response to Iraq's continued violation of the Charter, of resolutions of the Council and of international law.''
 
Turning Up the Pressure
Although not spelled out, these measures are likely to include a new resolution intended to turn up the pressure on Iraq by authorizing an air embargo, diplomats say. Chapter VII of the United Nations Charter empowers the Council to blockade countries flouting its orders. 
In addition, France has called for a secondary embargo against countries caught trading with Iraq and Kuwait in breach of the existing Security Council embargo. And the United States is suggesting seizing Iraqi merchant vessels around the world to insure they are not used to bring in forbidden supplies.
An air embargo would authorize countries to cut all air links with Iraq and occupied Kuwait by closing their airspace to planes traveling there and denying the aircraft landing and refueling rights.
It probably also would allow countries with warplanes deployed in the Persian Gulf to intercept aircraft suspected of violating the sanctions and to order them to land for inspection or turn back. But lawyers planning the new measures say the Security Council cannot authorize the shooting down of civilian aircraft even if they are clearly breaking the sanctions because this is banned by international law.
 
Immediate Enforcement Sought
After today's resolution was voted, the American United Nations representative, Thomas R. Pickering, said he hoped agreement on the new measures could be reached later this week. He called for the five permanent members of the Security Council, which have veto power, to start work ''immediately, and today if possible'' on new enforcement steps.
The permanent members are Britain, France, China, the Soviet Union and the United States. Tonight, their representatives held discussions at the French United Nations mission in New York.
After this morning's vote, France's representative, Pierre-Louis Blanc, whose country's embassy in Kuwait was the most seriously violated by Iraq, said the international community ''is now determined to adopt other measures'' as a result of Iraq's refusal to withdraw from Kuwait.
Britain's representative, Sir David Hannay, warned that Iraq's intransigence would ''lead to an intensification of pressure to bring it into conformity with the decisions of this Council.''
 
Warning From the Soviets
The Soviet representative, Deputy Foreign Minister Yuli M. Vorontsov, told the Council it had given Iraq ''a strict warning that its failure to comply will result in futher measures against it.''
Iraq's Deputy Representative to the United Nations, Sabah Talat Kadrat, attacked the Council for moving so rapidly against his country while taking no action against Israel for occupying the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.
He denied that the Iraqi army had violated the French Embassy's diplomatic immunity in Kuwait and accused France of creating a pretext to justify ''an expansionist policy'' in the Middle East aligned with that of the United States.
The Security Council has already imposed a mandatory ban on all trade by land, sea or air with Iraq and Kuwait and barred financial dealings with the countries under the terms of Resolution 661, which it approved on Aug. 6.
Nine days later, the Council voted to give the United States and other countries with warships in the gulf the right to enforce the blockade by halting shipping headed for Iraq and Kuwait, even though the United States and Britain said they already enjoyed such a right under international law.
 
New Legal Issues
But an air embargo promises to raise thorny legal problems, experts warn, because of the possible clash with international agreements safeguarding the rights of civilian aircraft operators.
In particular, the 1944 Chicago Convention governing international civil air traffic bars the use of military force against civilian aircraft except in self-defense, making it illegal for any country to attack a plane breaking the trade sanctions.
This ban was written into the Chicago Convention in 1984 after the Soviet Union shot down a Korean Air Lines passenger jet that had strayed from its flight path into a closed military area.
Warning of these difficulties, Alfred Rubin, Professor of International Law at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University, said, ''The legal situation could become so complex that the essential rectitude of our mission might come into question.''
But although force may not be used against civilian aircraft, diplomats say a Security Council resolution imposing an air embargo on Iraq and Kuwait would help deter violations of the sanctions by making it difficult - and probably impossible - for commercial aircraft operators to obtain insurance for planes flying to these countries or get them serviced at foreign airports.
 
A Surprise Unanimity
The Security Council's unanimous adoption of today's new resolution, known as Resolution 667, came as something of a surprise because Cuba and the Council's only Arab member, Yemen, have previously sought to weaken sanctions against Iraq, often abstaining on key resolutions or voting against them.
But several Council members expressed doubts about the Council's adoption of ''further concrete measures'' against Iraq and Kuwait, fearing that they might increase the risk of war.
China described the threat of further measures as ''too wide'' and said it had reservations about that portion of the resolution even though it voted in favor. Cuba said some countries might use the passage to justify military action against Iraq. Another third world member, Malaysia, said that the Council must show ''resolve'' in enforcing its embargo but that there was no need ''to resort to more force.'' ---- Italy Expels Iraqis ROME, Sept. 16 (Reuters) - Italy expelled Baghdad's military attache in Rome today and said it would urge the European Community to take stronger measures against Iraq to force it to pull out of Kuwait.
Italy banned Iraqi embassy aides from leaving the capital without permission and ordered the expulsion of the military attache and his staff after Iraqi troops were accused of raiding a French Embassy residence and other Western missions in occupied Kuwait.
The Italian Foreign Minister, Gianni De Michelis, who will head a meeting of the European Community Council of Ministers in Brussels Monday, said he would urge the community to adopt a joint strategy against Iraq.
''It's necessary to exert a stronger pressure because I see it unlikely that Hussein will yield to the current conditions,'' he told reporters in Cernobbio, near Como in northern Italy. ''A more severe embargo is needed.''
The Iraqi military personnel in Rome have 10 days to comply with the expulsion order, a statement of the Foreign Ministry said. Italian Government sources said six or seven people were affected.
France, which on Saturday ordered more troops to join the United States-led force in Saudi Arabia, expelled 29 Iraqis today under armed guard by air to Amman, Jordan.
The group included three people who officials said were suspected of spying and 26 military personnel. It did not include 11 Iraqi diplomats declared personae non grata who were given several days to pack and leave. Eight of those flown out of France had been at Brest, where they were studying new radar systems. Another 12 had been at a military base at Rochefort.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Israelis, Irked by Arms Sale To Saudis, Ask More of U.S.

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Israeli officials expressed alarm today over American plans to sell more than $20 billion in advanced weapons to Saudi Arabia, and they began making efforts to get more military aid for themselves.
Defense Minister Moshe Arens is expected to press Israel's case for more arms when he meets in Washington early this week with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney.
Even before the huge sale to Saudi Arabia was reported, Mr. Arens told the Parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee last week that Israel is losing its edge over its Arab neighbors in the quality of its arsenal because of sales of advanced weaponry to other countries.
President Bush is expected to notify Congress officially this week of his decision on the Saudi deal, which has been approved by the Pentagon. Congress appears willing to permit the sale. 
 
Fighter Jets and Tanks
The $20 billion arms deal, a record peacetime sale to one country, would include some of the latest weapons, including F-15 fighter planes, about 385 M-1A2 Abrams battle tanks with advanced armor, 48 new Apache antitank helicopters and 26 Patriot ground-to-air missiles. A separate arms package valued at $2.2 billion was ordered by the Saudis last month.
''This is a staggering amount of weapons and money,'' Avi Pazner, an adviser to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, said. ''That kind of weapons and money could gravely affect the Middle East balance of power.''
The Israeli Cabinet discussed the Saudi arms purchase today at its weekly meeting. Housing Minister Ariel Sharon, the hard-line former Defense Minister, assailed the deal ''as a major danger to Israel'' as he emerged from the session.
Health Minister Ehud Olmert said the Cabinet feared that ''the huge increase of such weapons given to Saudi Arabia'' might be used for purposes other than confronting Iraq. ''We might be the target,'' he said.
 
Army Chief Urges a Balance
The Army Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Dan Shomron, said the arms sale was ''definitely not a formula for stability.''
''I hope this situation will be balanced in order to guarantee our technological superiority and our deterrence,'' he said.
Asked in an Israeli radio interview whether Israel expected to receive anything to balance the American sale to the Saudis, the general replied, ''I don't know if it will be as an exchange or directly, but it's clear there must be equilibrium.''
Israel, which is still technically at war with most of the Arab countries in the region, has been critical of previous American arms sales to Saudi Arabia. But in deference to Washington's wishes, it has been keeping a low profile as the United States tries to assemble a pro-Western Arab alliance to oppose Iraq's takeover of Kuwait.
Saudi Arabia is at the geographic center of this new alliance, and the arms sale is intended to bolster the Saudis' relatively weak capability on the ground. Embassy Complains to U.S. In Washington, the Israeli Embassy said in a statement that the sale ''represents an additional risk for Israel'' that it termed ''very serious.''
The statement said Israel expected the Bush Administration to consider ways ''to prevent this drastic change in the balance of power, and to keep the qualitative edge of Israel.''
Israel receives about $3 billion a year in American economic and military aid, the largest sum of any country. It received its first two Apache attack helicopters in a ceremony last week as part of a $350 million arms deal with the United States.
Israel was the first country that Washington permitted to acquire the helicopters, which carry 16 laser-guided Hellfire missles, 76 rockets and 1,200 rounds of 30-millimeter ammunition.
The American Ambassador to Israel, William Brown, said the United States was providing the weapons because ''we treat with utmost seriousness our commitment to safeguard Israel and preserve its qualitative edge.''
Prime Minister Shamir hailed the arrival of the two helicopters as ''an omen for further equipment we will receive in the next weeks and months.''

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Hopeful on a Budget Deal

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Congressional leaders from both parties said today that they thought negotiators working on a new Federal budget could resolve differences over tax policy and reach a compromise as early as Monday night to reduce the deficit.
After taking the day off on Saturday, White House officials and Congressional leaders resumed their budget talks at Andrews Air Force Base nearby in Maryland today, meeting in small groups during the day and in a full session this evening.
Stung by partisan disclosures of information last week, participants on both sides refused today to discuss publicly the substance of a potential agreement.
But interviewed on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press,'' the Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, a Washington Democrat, and the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, said they hoped an accord could be reached by Monday night. 
On the ABC News program ''This Week,'' Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady suggested that votes in the House and Senate be postponed until a budget agreement was struck so the negotiators would not be distracted.
 
Disagreement on Capital Gains
The main issue that has stymied the talks has been the Republican insistence on a reduction in the tax on the gains made when investments are sold, and the Democratic determination to block a cut in that tax unless it is accompanied by higher rates on the earnings of wealthy taxpayers.
It is now agreed that without an offsetting tax on the well-to-do, a capital gains tax cut would be regressive: it would mean that the wealthy pay a smaller share of their incomes than other taxpayers. ''We have to have a balance,'' Mr. Dole said today. ''We have to have progressivity. And I think we're going to have it.''
Mr. Foley also hinted at a compromise, saying Democrats could ''conceivably agree'' to a capital gains reduction ''if there was a balancing burden sharing by high-income, wealthy taxpayers.''
Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, one of the strongest Republican supporters of a capital gains tax cut, also suggested that a compromise was likely. Also interviewed on the ABC News program, he said: ''I think, A, that a capital gains tax reduction will take place. We need it to strengthen the economy. I think, B, it will be offset so that the system does not get less progressive.''
At their meeting tonight, participants said, Republicans and Democrats modified their tax proposals somewhat in search of a compromise, but no concensus was reached.
President Bush has adamantly opposed an increase in income tax rates, the vestige of his ''no new taxes'' campaign pledge. But there are other ways to adjust tax policy so that the wealthy pay more .
The White House, for example, has proposed limiting the amount of state and local income taxes that could be deducted on Federal returns. The proposal would directly affect only taxpayers with incomes higher than about $100,000 who pay state income taxes.
But lawmakers from states like New York, New Jersey and California that rely on high state income taxes have vowed to vote against any package that contains a limit on those deductions.
 
Limiting Other Deductions
Some legislators from those states say they could support a ceiling on all deductions, not just those for state and local income taxes. But such a proposal would surely be opposed by the real estate lobby, because the price of expensive houses would be brought down by a limit on the amount of mortgage interest that could be deducted.
Democrats have suggested a 20 percent surtax on taxpayers with incomes above $500,000. Fewer than 100,000 taxpayers would be affected. But many experts fear that the effect of such a policy would be to give rebirth to the tax shelter industry.
If no budget policy is in effect by Oct. 15, two weeks after the next fiscal year begins, across-the-board spending cuts of more than 40 percent in most Government programs would be automatic. Both parties agree that the economy would collapse under such large cuts.
The lawmakers on the television programs today emphasized that there would be unpopular aspects of whatever budget agreement is reached.
''Balancing the budget is like going to heaven,'' Senator Gramm said. ''Everybody wants to do it. They just don't want to do what you have to do to make the trip.''

HEADLINE: Use Oil Reserves? When, if Not Now?

 BODY:
The U.S. has spent billions of dollars creating the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, 600 million barrels of oil stored in salt domes along the U.S. Gulf Coast, to protect the economy during emergencies. Yet the Bush Administration has refused to tap the reserve in the wake of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the immediate loss of four million barrels of oil exports each day from the region.
Energy Department officials say there is no emergency because there is no ''shortage.'' And releasing oil to smooth price shocks smacks of price controls that shackled the economy during the oil crises of the 1970's. Others argue that the reserve can't be used because it's full of the ''wrong'' type of oil - sour crude that contains too much sulfur for most refineries. 
These fears are excessive. On Thursday, Energy Secretary James Watkins came close to admitting as much when, finally, he held out the possibility of opening the reserve. He need not wait. The reserve was created to shelter the economy from a rainy day. Saddam Hussein has made it rain.
The Energy Department is correct on one score: Unlike the 1970's, there is no shortage of oil because the Government no longer imposes price controls. Now, no matter how much oil supplies fall, prices rise to squash demand and eliminate shortages. Under the Energy Department's definition, that means there is no emergency, and therefore no need to use the reserve.
This position is nonsensical. A central purpose of the reserve is to ward off panic buying, thereby mitigating price shocks. In the crises of the 1970's, a drop of just a few percentage points in oil exports from the Persian Gulf led to a tripling of oil prices, which then helped drive the U.S. into recession. Modest releases from the reserve can stop that type of overreaction.
Measured use of reserve oil would lower current prices by several dollars a barrel. That would still leave them well above pre-invasion levels, and thus still provide ample incentives for consumers to buy less and producers to supply more. And the economy would be spared an unnecessary blow.
Economists have suggested a number of methods to manage the reserve. Some would make the oil available at a cost somewhat above the market price; that would calm jittery markets, permitting prices to fall, and even generate revenue to restock the reserve. Others recommend releasing a modest amount of oil each day, say 500,000 barrels. Either method beats abstinence, the current policy.
Some raise another problem with releasing reserves: that it's mostly sour crude and can't be readily refined. Yet most experts agree that refineries are flexible and can blend the reserve oil with lighter crudes from elsewhere. The sour crude is a troubling but manageable problem that government planners say they've anticipated.
The Strategic Petroleum Reserve can soften the economic devastation of temporary supply shocks. Why, after all, was the reserve established in the first place, if not to use in situations like the present one - and without further delay?

HEADLINE: Bank Insurance: Proceed With Care

 BODY:
Yes, the Federal insurance fund for bank deposits needs fixing. No, despite some dire talk in Washington, it is not on the verge of collapse. Members of Congress, badly burned by the savings and loan crisis, now itch to ''do something'' before the banks' problems become even more costly. Haste could do more harm than good. 
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's insurance fund is shrinking; starting in 1988, annual pay-outs to depositors of failed banks have been $2 billion greater than premium income from insured banks. At year-end, the fund will be $14 billion, roughly 70 cents per $100 of insured deposits. That's the lowest ever, and far less than it should be. If the fund is wiped out, as the Federal savings and loan fund was, taxpayers will be socked again to make up for it. Two agencies of Congress, the General Accounting Office and the Congressional Budget Office, offer worst-case scenarios more serious than the S.& L. scandal. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan says they exaggerate. Many banks are in trouble from weakness in real estate and foreign loans. A recession would make matters worse. But Mr. Greenspan foresees no disaster of S.& L. proportions.
What to do? The Treasury will make proposals in a few months, and Congress is developing its own ideas. The options boil down to three basic approaches: Replenish the insurance fund. Reduce coverage. And strengthen the banking system.
Two bills were introduced last week to remove the ceiling on premiums. The F.D.I.C. plans to raise them as much as the law allows on Jan. 1 - up 30 percent, to 19 1/2 cents per $100 of insured deposits. Uncapping makes sense, but could wait for broader reforms; for instance, one promising idea with wide support would set a bank's premium according to the riskiness of its portfolio.
The idea that gets most attention is also the worst - reduction in the $100,000 coverage for each account. Cutting coverage would incite a legitimate public outcry and possibly heavy withdrawals. Reducing coverage to $100,000 per depositor is no better. Anyone can have multiple $100,000 accounts now, all insured. A per-person limit may sound reasonable, but evasion would be easy.
The coverage of huge institutional funds is a more likely target. Pension funds now subdivide their multimillions into smaller amounts representing each pensioner, and deposit those amounts in insured accounts. Still another thorny issue is the ''too big to fail'' policy. Because the failure of big banks can reverberate far and wide, the Government has extended full coverage on all their accounts - over the $100,000 limit and even to uninsured deposits in branches abroad. That's a drain on the insurance fund that hasn't been faced.
None of these issues address the fundamental matter of bank soundness. Federal insurance was established to protect depositors after a catastrophic run of failures in the Depression. President Franklin D. Roosevelt approved it reluctantly, pointing out that it would also let banks be less prudent. One sure way to make them be more careful is to require stronger capitalization; if owners and stockholders have more at stake, they'll take less risk. Another essential is closer regulation, accurate measurement of the actual value of banks' assets, and authority to close banks that are close to the edge.
Resolving these issues will be difficult. It is urgent that they be resolved. But not in haste.

HEADLINE: Immigration Bill Invests in America's Future

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Give Me, Also, Your Skilled'' (editorial, Aug. 27), arguing for immigration reform, graciously mentions my family unity and employment opportunity bill, H.R. 4300, pending before the House of Representatives. You are wide of the mark in criticizing as ''punitive'' the proposed assessment of a fee on medium- and large-size businesses that import workers to pay for education and training for United States citizens.
And it is hard to take seriously the charge that a bill that increases family- and employment-based immigration could smack of the old-time fear of foreigners. The most sweeping immigration reform in 25 years shows no fear of foreigners. It is hardly punitive to make it easier for employers to hire immigrants. 
Common sense shows the connection between American industry's unfilled needs for highly skilled workers and the failure of our schools to provide them. In charging larger companies a modest fee for immigrant workers, all my bill proposes to do is make a contribution to solving our long-term educational problem while answering our immediate need.
The fees are not large - $500 for a medium-size company, $1,000 for a large company, and small businesses and nonprofits would be able to hire immigrants free. Large companies that import workers for highly skilled jobs that cannot be filled from our domestic labor pool pay much more just for the paperwork. The employment-based immigration system I propose will be far simpler. Employers will save money bringing in workers -and they'll make money when the workers are here.
My bill proposes to use most of the fees to help states establish education and training programs. For example, Connecticut workers need to begin shifting from defense industries to high-tech, export-oriented industry. The rest of the fees will go for math and science scholarships for students in need.
American unemployment is relatively low, except where it is shockingly high. How can that be? The answer is that we have a swiss-cheese economy. Let's use expanded immigration to help fill in the holes. Let's not forget those Americans who are not ready, but who could be prepared in the future, if education and training are improved.
The classic liberal formation that everybody should pay for education and training is flawed. It is the same lesson taught by our budget mess: When everybody is supposed to pay, nobody seems to get the bill.
Fees to establish an American workers educational trust fund will not raise enough to pay for the massive investment we must make in better education and training. However, it will be a step in the right direction.
 
(Rep.) BRUCE A. MORRISON
Chairman, Subcommittee on
Immigration, Refugees
and International Law
 Washington, Sept. 4, 1990

HEADLINE: Immigration Bill Invests in America's Future;
Burden on Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Our nation of immigrants still benefits from newcomers who contribute energy and skills to our economy. Congress is considering immigration bills that would increase the number of people who come to this country every year (editorial, Aug. 22). The United States should continue to be the most generous country in the world in immigration. We should also realize that immigration is a mixed blessing.
New people demand jobs, housing, education and other social services. There is room in our economy to absorb some new people, but it is not unlimited. Immigration policy should take into account our ability to offer these immigrants a high quality of life while providing for our own citizens.
Legislation being considered in the House of Representatives would greatly expand the level of immigration when our economy is growing more slowly. It would increase the number of people admitted for their job skills from about 24,000 to 75,000. More important, it would ask America to absorb approximately 770,000 immigrants without regard for job skills or employability.
The bill sponsored by Rep. Bruce Morrison of Connecticut would also impose an immigrant tax on those who employ immigrants.
These problems and the bill's provisions giving preferential treatment to certain nationalities and amnesty to more illegal aliens are more than differences to be ironed out. They are flaws that make this legislation bad policy, not worthwhile reform.
 
(Rep.) LAMAR SMITH
Vice Chairman, Subcommittee
on Immigration, Refugees
and International Law
 Washington, Sept. 4, 1990

HEADLINE: Immigration Bill Invests in America's Future;
Quota Inequities

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Give Me, Also, Your Skilled'' (editorial, Aug. 27) perpetuates an unfair myth by stating that in 1965 ''Congress gave more favorable treatment to immigrants from Asia and the Western Hemisphere.''
While the 1965 amendments eliminated the highly discriminatory national origins quota system, it did not replace it with a system that favored regional geographical areas. The 1965 reforms treated all countries equally, that is, it allowed a maximum of 20,000 immigrants per year per country under the quota system. More immigrants came from Asia and Latin and South America because of suffering economies in those areas.
One could wonder about the fairness of a system that allocates the same number of immigrants regardless of the sending country. Consider India, with its approximately 775 million, and Mexico, with its proximity to the United States and a population of some 85 million, compared with Ireland, with some 3.5 million.
Finally, while the present system of bringing in needed workers is complicated and needs simplification, its philosophy is correct and should not be substantially changed: The system rewards those with green cards whose services are needed by the United States economy, irrespective of educational level. Live-in domestics are in short supply and greatly needed in a society where both parents commonly now work. But physicians, despite the common misconception, are not.
As those of us who practice immigration law long ago recognized, the easiest way for a physician to obtain a green card is to marry a nurse, of whom, despite their fewer years of training, this and other urban areas are in great need.
 
PETER HIRSCH
 New York, Sept. 2, 1990
The writer is an officer of the New York chapter of the American Immigration Lawyers Association.

LENGTH: 712 words

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Politics Of Hate

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Edwin O'Connor drew the classic picture of Massachusetts politics in ''The Last Hurrah.'' It was a world of hacks and scoundrels, of lovable rogues and rented dogs. O'Connor modeled his tainted hero on James Michael Curley, the Mayor, Governor and Congressman who served a term in Federal prison.
After a spell of reform, Massachusetts these days is rapidly sinking back into the Old Politics. But with a difference: There is nothing funny about the games being played now, and nothing lovable about the characters. 
Consider an episode that played out last month. If O'Connor had put it in his novel, critics might have dismissed it as too far-fetched.
Gov. Michael Dukakis nominated as a trial judge the head of the organized crime division in the United States Attorney's office, Diane M. Kottmyer. Judges and lawyers uniformly said she was a superb choice. But she was defeated by a vote of 5 to 4 in the Governor's Council, a Colonial relic, one of whose few remaining functions is to confirm judges.
The Councilor who led the fight against Ms. Kottmyer was Joseph Langone 3d, a mortician to whose funeral parlor reputed organized crime figures go when they die. He said he wanted ''to bury'' Ms. Kottmyer.
Why? Mr. Langone served six months once, for assaulting a Federal narcotics officer. He said he opposed Ms. Kottmyer because she was law clerk at the time to the judge who sentenced him. When that proved untrue, he said, ''I just believe she hates Italians.''
A factor in that disgusting episode, as in much else in Massachusetts today, is the collapse of Governor Dukakis's influence here after his defeat for the Presidency in 1988. The lack of leadership has been devastating as the state has felt the economic misery afflicting all of the Northeast.
Tax revenues fell off badly with the recession. That created a state budget crisis, and an inept and divided Legislature dithered for months over how to meet it. As a result, the financial services have given Massachusetts bonds the lowest rating of the 50 states.
The fiscal disaster and the politicians' craven ineptitude in dealing with it have heated public distrust of politicians to the boiling point. The atmosphere here is poisonously hostile to government and anyone who has had anything to do with it.
In that mood, there is a very good chance that voters in November will pass an initiative proposal to make massive cuts in state taxes and fees. Revenues would be cut by as much as 15 percent. When schools then close and towns go bankrupt, the public will no doubt be unhappy. But right now it is enough to say ''We'll teach them a lesson.''
This week Democrats and Republicans pick their nominees for governor. And here again the hateful atmosphere has had its influence. One of the Democratic candidates, John Silber, is running as the last angry man.
Mr. Silber, the president of Boston University, is making his first run for public office. But he comes on with the certainty of his own rightness that makes Donald Trump look shy.
He vents his spleen on not only politicians but racial groups. Early in the campaign he denounced the small group of Cambodian refugees in the state. In a debate last week he was asked why he had not spoken in a predominantly black area of the city. He replied:
''Well, I will tell you something about that area. There is no point in my making a speech on crime control to a bunch of drug addicts.''
Mr. Silber's meanness and arrogance have made him enemies. But he still might win the primary, so hostile is public feeling toward those who have been in power. His opponent in the Democratic race is Frank Bellotti, longtime State Attorney General, an old-style politician.
Competing for the Republican nomination are Steven Pierce, minority leader in the State House of Representatives, a conservative, and William Weld, former United States Attorney, a Yankee moderate. Mr. Weld said of the Kottmyer affair: ''Only in Massachusetts would a convicted felon be able to . . . tell us who's fit to be a judge.''
Both Republicans have endorsed the tax-cut initiative; both Democrats opposed it. It will be rough justice if a Republican wins, as seems increasingly likely - and has to deal with the fiscal consequences of the voters' anger.

LENGTH: 1234 words

HEADLINE: Deficit Threat and Tax Ire Greet Trenton's Fall Session

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
State legislators returned to the capital this week facing the sobering possibility that the slowing economy would create yet another budget deficit, despite their approval of the biggest tax increase in state history in June.
Administration officials and the Democratic majority have few major new initiatives in mind, and are hoping for a relatively quiet session. Republican leaders, however, have let it be known that they will lose no opportunity to respond to this summer's wave of taxpayer anger.
The most recent legislator to urge actively reconsidering the explosive tax question is Senator Gerald Cardinale, a Bergen County Republican, who suggested that Democrats and Republicans ''work together'' to find ways to roll back the tax increases.
Democrats like Senator Gabriel M. Ambrosio, also of Bergen County, say they would like to move on to matters like health insurance and new ethics laws, but concede that the tax questions are not likely to fade away. 
Given that political backdrop, administration officials have made it clear that they will be talking about fiscal matters in terms of cuts instead of new revenues.
''If in fact over the course of the budget year the $280 million surplus budgeted is gone and more is needed, it will be found with spending reductions,'' said Steven P. Perskie, Gov. Jim Florio's chief of staff and chief legislative tactician.
But Mr. Perskie, the Governor and Treasurer Douglas Berman agree that projections for the size of the drop in revenues that kept this year's budget to only a modest 2 percent increase may very well turn out to be too optimistic, and a revenue shortfall could occur.
 
Hints of Possible Shortfall
The hints by the Governor and top members of the administration about a possible shortfall come during calls by most Republicans and some members of the Democratic majority in the Legislature to roll back all or some of the $2.8 billion in new and increased taxes.
Even as legislators began assembling for committee hearings before the floor sessions begin on Oct. 1, Mr. Berman, at the request of the Governor, ordered all department heads except the prisons commissioner to start finding ways to cut their budget proposals by 8 percent for fiscal 1992.
When the state budget was drawn up this spring, a national economic slowdown was foreseen.
But a crisis in the Mideast was not, and the oil price increase that is resulting - and the chance that the rise in oil may slow the economy even further - could depress tax revenues enough to create a shortfall even in the current budget.
''I think we have been very conservative in our budgeted revenue projections,'' Governor Florio said in an interview this week. ''But I have already told the commissioners they have to start thinking about giving me another 8 percent off central management in their departments.''
''There undoubtedly will not be a $280 million surplus,'' he said. ''The energy crisis, the national economic downturn, will both have an effect. The $280 million is a minimum cushion in a $12 billion budget.''
 
Surplus Is Expected to Shrink
Mr. Perskie, who will be replaced as chief of staff on Oct. 2 by a longtime Florio friend and political strategist, Joseph Salema, said, ''None of us expects we will finish with the full surplus.
''We all expect it will be tighter than that,'' he said. ''Whether it will be tighter by some of the surplus or all the surplus or more than the surplus, we can't evaluate.''
When the $2.8 billion tax package was passed, the Governor's plan was to use $1.5 billion of the tax increase to close existing deficits and the remaining $1.3 billion to revamp school aid and hold down local property taxes. But that plan was quickly overshadowed by the storm of protest across the state at the increases.
The tax package increased sales taxes from 6 to 7 percent, a change that was projected to bring in $1.3 billion in new revenue. Income taxes were raised for high-income taxpayers; the change was expected to bring in another $1.3 billion. The addition of items like soap, paper products and heavy trucks to the sales tax list, along with new taxes on alcohol and cigarettes, was to raise another $200 million.
 
Tax Repeal and Recall Sought
One grass-roots protest group, Hands Across New Jersey, says it has gathered 600,000 signatures on a petition calling for repeal of the taxes and for the creation of a mechanism for the recall of state officeholders, including the Governor, and for the initiation and repeal of legislation by referendum.
Republican leaders have joined the outcry, calling for repeal of all or part of the taxes, and supporting the call for a recall mechanism and for popular legislative initiative and referendum.
Last month, in a televised rebuttal to a speech Governor Florio gave in defense of his tax package, Chuck Haytaian, the Assembly minority leader, called for a partial rollback of the tax increases, to be offset by a 5 percent reduction in state employees' salaries and by spending some of the surplus.
But he later retreated, saying he actually meant a 5 percent reduction in salary outlays through attrition.
 
Tax Outcry Continues
Still, the outcry over taxes continues, with bills already introduced to eliminate outright the extension of the sales tax to paper products, a particular focus of outrage among tax protesters, along with a Democratic alternative that would exempt recycled paper products from the tax.
Other bills introduced by Republicans would amend the state constitution to allow for recall of officials, would repeal the tax on heavy trucks and would guarantee taxpayers' access to information about tax matters.
Before its late summer recess, the Legislature had given the Governor everything he had proposed in an ambitious legislative agenda, including the huge tax increases, a greatly revamped school-aid financing formula that will take state aid away from 15 percent of the wealthiest districts to give the other districts more money, a total revamping of the state's financially battered auto insurance system and a ban on sale of military style assault weapons.
Although continuing partisan battles over the tax package are likely and new initiatives loom - most notably in health care for the unininsured - the Governor and others predict a much quieter new session.
 
Health Care for Uninsured
''For the most part we're looking to refine and manage the things we have already done,'' Mr. Florio said. ''There is not a particularly aggressive new legislative agenda for the rest of the year.''
One major concern is likely to be how to provide health care to the more than 800,000 New Jerseyans who are without health-care insurance of any kind - 65 percent of whom have jobs - and what to do about the financially ailing Uncompensated Care Trust Fund, which currently underwrites health care for the uninsured.
Two commissions, one appointed by the Governor and another within the Legislature, are to report on recommendations by Oct. 1. The current fund expires Dec. 31.
The Legislature is also expected to deal with a package of ethics bills offered by the administation. They would limit the ability of former state officials to work for entities doing business with the state, establish rules for awarding no-bid contracts and provide for more public participation in an ethical standards commission.

HEADLINE: New York's Water Rules Worry Catskills

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

DATELINE: MARGARETVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 15

 BODY:
Little by little, from Woodstock to Delhi, the reality is sinking in: If New York City is to avoid spending $4 billion to filter the drinking water it draws from these parts, life in the Catskills will never be the same again.
Local residents have been circulating copies of the regulations proposed last Tuesday by New York City to control the pollution of six Catskill reservoirs that supply more than eight million people with drinking water.
What they are finding are provisions that could put thousands of acres of privately owned land off-limits for building and threaten the existence of dozens of dairy farms. The rules would even follow residents to the grave: cemetery expansion is regulated.
''A lot of people have bought property up here and paid taxes,'' said Russell Roefs, an Ulster County legislator who owns a septic tank business. ''And all of a sudden the watershed people come in and say they can't build.'' Whether addressing septic tanks or manure spreading, the new rules would essentially call for wider buffer zones between potential pollutants and streams in the watershed and reservoirs. The net effect would be to make many acres off limits to development or farming. 
 
Unfair Expense Charged
Catskill residents who have read or heard about the proposed regulations say they are concerned that the city intends to assure its water quality at their expense. If New York wants clean drinking water, they say, it should pay for it, not the people of the Catskills.
''It's not fair,'' said Dave Taylor, a Margaretville dairy farmer about six miles upstream from the Pepacton Reservoir in Delaware County. ''If New York City is going to come up here and say I can't use my land for anything, then they should buy it.''
Besides tourism, the underpinnings of the regional economy are building and farming. Changes that would be required by the proposed regulations could hurt an area with little money to begin with.
 
'Not a Lot of Money'
''When you look at the Catskills, you're looking at some of the lowest per-capita incomes in the state,'' said Michael Welsh, a local conservationist who supports stricter watershed regulation but is sympathetic to the economic situation here.
''There's not a lot of money for paying for measures that they don't see the benefit of,'' said Mr. Welsh, an official at the Catskill Center for Conservation and Development in Arkville.
For the first time since 1954, New York City is overhauling its regulations governing discharges of a wide range of pollutants - human and animal waste, fertilizer, road runoff - into the 18 reservoirs it owns in the Catskill, Delaware and Croton systems. An 85-year-old state law gives the city the right to take what measures are necessary to preserve the quality of its drinking water.
Mayor David N. Dinkins and his Environmental Protection Commissioner, Albert F. Appleton, want to avoid the appearance of forcing the new rules down the throats of Catskill residents. That will be difficult: distrust of big-city water officials already runs deep, and has festered since the first Catskill towns were flooded in the early 1900's to make way for the Ashokan Reservoir in Ulster County.
 
'We Want to Make Sure'
''Nobody is against pure water. But we want to make sure that they don't take any more of our land than necessary,'' said Marian Umhey, Shandaken's Town Supervisor.
City officials are also sensitive about the suggestion that the proposed regulations are thinly veiled zoning instruments.
''These proposed regulations are not anti-development,'' Mr. Appleton said. ''They are anti-environmentally irresponsible development.''
The Dinkins administration says it has a difficult choice: Impose stricter controls over activities in the Catskill and Delaware watershed or spend $4 billion to build a filtration plant by 2005.
Officials in both Washington and Albany are pressuring the city to do something about its drinking water quality. The Federal Environmental Protection Agency says New York must filter its water unless it can assure that the watershed is protected from pollution. But the State Health Department, which is responsible for carrying out the Federal water rules, goes one step further.
 
Debate Over Filtration
It doubts the city can adequately safeguard the Catskill water supply and proposes that filtration plans go forward. City officials hope the tougher watershed regulations will convince the State Health Commissioner, Dr. David Axelrod, who has final authority, that filtration is not necessary. Filtration would double the rates for city water users for a product that would not taste as good, Mr. Appleton asserts.
The city is already building a $600 million plant to filter water from the Croton watershed in Westchester and Putnam Counties. The 12 reservoirs there supply about 10 percent of the city's water needs. City officials point to the Croton experience as evidence of what can happen to the Catskill and Delaware systems if unchecked development is permitted.
A decision by Dr. Axelrod on the filtration question is expected by January, but with the stakes so high, the actual resolution will likely take much longer.
In the meantime the proposed watershed regulations will go through a two-stage review, a process city officials hope will allay upstate suspicions. This fall informal discussions are planned to give upstate communities an opportunity to air their grievances. Then a revised, formal draft of the regulations will be prepared, followed by public hearings. The final regulations could be ready by March, Mr. Appleton said.
 
Some Farmers Irate
In Delaware County, where dairy farming dominates the economy, New York City officials are headed into a buzzsaw of opposition over the regulations. Farmers are incensed and are using words like ludicrous and ridiculous to describe the rules.
''It will probably put a lot of farmers out of business,'' said Dean Frazier, a local agricultural extension agent.
Of the county's 310 dairy farms, 200 are in the watershed area, and all will be affected by the proposed rules, Mr. Frazier said.
To reduce nutrient flow into reservoirs, the rules would prohibit discharge of drainage from barnyards or feedlots within 100 feet or more of a stream and the spreading of manure or fertilizer within 100 feet of a stream. Also, runoff from grazing areas would have to be eliminated, even it meant building dikes along a stream to block the flow.
Mr. Taylor's picturesque dairy farm in Margaretville has 75 tillable acres. His property is crisscrossed by streams that eventually feed the Pepacton Reservoir. Corn and alfalfa to feed his 55 registered Holsteins grow next to or near streams. The cows cross a stream on the way to pasture. The main barn is within 100 feet of one. End to Dairying Feared ''If they go in and enforce these regulations, it's going to put us out of business,'' said Mr. Taylor, a 58-year-old lifelong farmer who wants to sell the operation to his son when he retires.
Mr. Frazier said the conditions on Mr. Taylor's farm were not unlike those found on any farm in Delaware County. But even if the rules are workable, he said, few farmers think they are necessary, because they doubt their operations are responsible for the increased nutrient flow into the reservoirs. How could they be, he asked, when their numbers have declined in the last 10 years?
The dairy farmers' feelings about the regulations may be best characterized by a drawing making the rounds of Delaware County. Above a caption saying ''Preserving N.Y.C. Water Quality,'' it depicts a cow with its bottom enclosed in a giant diaper secured by a large safety pin.

HEADLINE: After 2 Weeks' Groping, a New Approach on Crime

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
In late-night phone calls and early-morning meetings, over lunch with business leaders and a swordfish dinner with a public relations czar, Mayor David N. Dinkins and his aides have groped for two weeks to say and do what they think is right on crime in ways that others think is right, too.
They have fought over whether the Mayor should go to California for a speech and decided he should publicize meetings with community groups that had been held quietly before. They have prodded his Police Commissioner to push his brain trust's pencils faster and agreed that Mr. Dinkins must say what he means more clearly, even if that means saying it again and again.
Finally last week, Mr. Dinkins seemed to be playing the media game with more gusto. He gave two early-morning talks to police officers, had two meetings with community groups, used Time magazine's unpublished poll data to rebut its own cover story on how bad New York is, made his case in an Op-Ed piece for The New York Times and politely dared other politicians to help pay for the new police officers they insist he must hire. 
''I've had the ability to withhold the fire until I've seen the whites of their eyes,'' he said on Friday, referring to those who demand 5,000 new officers. ''And so what you have now is everyone on board, determined to do exactly what I asked them to do in the first place'' - decide whether more officers are needed and agree to help pay.
 
Behind-the-Scenes Soul-Searching
That may overstate the case, but that Mr. Dinkins could say it with such satisfaction, after addressing roll call at the 23d Precinct in Manhattan at the end of a week in which Gov. Mario M. Cuomo not-so-subtly upstaged him by agreeing to support calls for 5,000 officers, is testament to behind-the-scenes soul-searching.
And coming up, the Mayor will meet with major business groups including the Association for a Better New York, the Real Estate Board, the Convention and Visitors Bureau, the Fifth Avenue Association and the New York City Partnership to discuss crime, the police and how to finance their hiring.
''We thought we had previously done the obvious,'' said First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel. ''Now we obviously have to do the obvious again.''
The challenge for the Mayor is how to make his message heard on an issue that could permanently damage his credibility without changing his style in ways that would seem fake. Some of his closest aides say Mr. Dinkins has such an aversion to showboating that he does not appreciate the values of showmanship in public life.
 
A Little Public Relations Help
Among those who have gotten into the act are Howard Rubenstein, perhaps the city's most well-connected public relations executive. He met with the Mayor and senior aides for four and half hours Monday night, suggesting ways of making the Mayor's case.
When the aides said they had already tried many of them, he argued for doing them again.
Just after that meeting, Mr. Steisel appeared on ''Newsline New York'' on WNYW-TV and said the city was unequivocally committed to hiring unspecified thousands of officers - something the Mayor had suggested but never directly said before.
While Mr. Rubenstein and other power brokers volunteered their help privately, they were also putting public pressure on the administration. Two weeks ago, after Brian Watkins, a tourist from Utah, was stabbed to death in the subway, Mr. Rubenstein made the dire prediction that the killing could set back city tourism five years.
''They know that I have no political ax to grind,'' Mr. Rubenstein elaborated last week. ''I was sounding a warning to government.''
 
First, a String of Child Killings
Crime became the predominant issue after a string of children were killed by gunfire intended for others, and politicians, the media and the public clamored for more police officers. Mr. Dinkins, after backpedaling, squeezed money from the budget to hire 1,058 new officers.
The same day, the Mayor's senior aides revealed that he had ordered Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown to tell him by Oct. 1 how many new officers he needed and how to pay for them, suggesting the Mayor would find a way.
That bought time. But alarming crimes continued, Rikers Island erupted, an assistant District Attorney was killed by a stray bullet and then, on Labor Day weekend, Mr. Watkins, in town for the U.S. Open, was slain.
The killing turned the spotlight back on the Mayor, and found him watching the tournament in Flushing Meadows, to which he twice traveled by helicopter because of a tight schedule. Was Dinkins Outraged Enough? Then came complaints that the Mayor was not outraged enough by the killing, suggestions that he took the helicopter every day and demands that he not wait for Mr. Brown's report before hiring thousands of officers.
But meantime, business leaders including Felix G. Rohatyn and David Rockefeller were warning him in a luncheon meeting two weeks ago at City Hall (where a bowl of pasta salad cracked and spilled down Mr. Steisel's back) that higher taxes to pay for officers could hurt the city's economy.
Mr. Dinkins maintained last week that he was not unhappy with the way things stand. ''We've been able to just listen and withstand the critiques of all who demanded that a number be used'' to specify how many officers to hire, ''until we're in a position wherein everybody has now committed themselves to assist,'' he said after his talk to the officers on Friday.
Asked later whether he would hold politicians' feet to the fire on money for the new police, he replied: ''People will hold their feet to the fire.''
