HEADLINE: Review/Art;
Malevich's Search for a New Reality

BYLINE: By MICHAEL BRENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The Kasimir Malevich retrospective that opened Sunday at the National Gallery of Art is more than a landmark exhibition. It is an exceptionally moving event. For the first time the American public is being given a thorough look at the greatest 20th-century Soviet painter, one of the select few who helped shape the modernist imagination.
Because so many of his works were tucked away in Soviet museums during the cold war, inaccessible to the West, Malevich is a household name whose work remains largely unknown. The historical importance of his 1915 to 1919 Suprematist abstractions - those white squares, black squares and geometric fields diagramming a utopia in which nothing is tied down and everything has weight - has long been unquestionable. Now it is possible to see these paintings in the context of a career so consistently surprising that it can make you shake your head in reverential disbelief. This show is not easy. 
Suprematism - an attempt through abstract painting to define a new, supreme universal reality - is the heart of an exhibition that includes around 170 works, 91 of them paintings, but does not feel big. The installation moves quickly, in solid, thumping steps that reflect the compression of the paintings and the acceleration of Malevich's development. It begins with the Impressionist works from the early 1900's that reveal Malevich's feeling for outdoor life, attraction to Symbolist mood and color, and hunger to explore and test every inch of the pictorial space.
When Malevich moved from the Ukraine to Moscow in 1907, he came in contact with the work of the European avant-garde and met the painters Natalia Goncharova and Mikhail Larionov; like them, he was attracted to Russian folk art and icons. In his brightly colored Neo-Primitive paintings from 1911 and 1912, big earthy people stomp and brood their way to the edges of a picture frame that seems barely able to contain them. In 1912 Malevich's space flattens and his machinelike peasants suggest a belief in the compatibility of rural and industrial life. Space begins to become overloaded. In 1913, the forms are more and more abstract and they seem to stick together magnetically. In 1914, Cubist-inspired constructions begin to be inhabited by rectangles of pure color that press against the crowds of faceted shapes, on the verge of blotting them out or vacuuming them in.
Then the rectangles take over and Suprematism is born. Malevich did not want to be nature, unlike many artists in the tradition of Monet and van Gogh. He did not move step by step from nature to abstraction, like Mondrian. He wanted to get beyond nature and define a new reality in which the part would merge with the whole and human and cosmic laws would be combined. His Suprematism is a sudden, jolting leap.
Then this all-or-nothing artist apparently stopped painting for close to 10 years, concentrating on teaching, theory, applied art and cultural administration. The show ends with the puzzling and poignant figurative paintings of 1928 to 1935 in which Malevich stampeded from style to style while painting immobile people incapable of flight. In the end, as at the beginning, the quality of concentration is remarkable.
Malevich was a brilliant, grandiose, messianic figure: ''a fanatic pamphleteer,'' said Wim Beeren, the director of the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam; ''a mad monk,'' declared his artistic and political enemies during the early Stalin years; ''president of space,'' he appointed himself in 1917. He felt that art was a religion and Suprematism its Bible. Like other modernist pioneers, he believed in the possibility of an artistic tabula rasa. He did not want life to lead art but art to lead life, and to do that it had to be transcendent and new. He lived at a time when artists believed that revolutions in thought could be made through form. ''There is beginning, a renovation of life through artistic form,'' he wrote in 1928. Form could send a message to economics. It could be the prophetic sermon that would convince the human congregation to follow painting into the promised land. If it was going to change others, it had to change him first. ''I have transformed myself into the zero degree of form,'' Malevich said in 1915.
Malevich was not a painter of doubt. He was in the end not a painter of dynamism, although he was capable of creating a convincing sensation of movement. He was not a confessional painter; even the earnest, clerical, somewhat Edvard Munch-like self-portrait (from 1908) that begins the show and the ironic self-portrait of himself as a Renaissance prince (from 1933) that ends it hide more than they reveal. Malevich tried to turn the self into a non-issue. His force of personality and will can be felt at all times, but the identity of the man behind the iconic, mystical Suprematist mask is elusive.
The one constant in Malevich's Suprematism is the white ground. It is utterly selfless and anonymous yet distinct. It is a dense emptiness, or full void. It is atmospheric yet it has little air, and it does not suggest sky. It does not envelop or squeeze the rectangles, rings and lines. It is ready and available but not transparent. It is not open or closed but both at the same time. Some white shapes nestle inside it. Most shapes stick to it. Nothing is trapped. Everything seems held yet free. Shape and whiteness are different but they never struggle.
It may be impossible to believe in painting more than Malevich did. In his best work, the relationship between edge, texture, color and space has an authority that is hard to surpass. He may have been the first abstract painter to demonstrate the inexhaustible potential for meaning in the dialogues between edge and shape, color and texture, restless and silent form. ''Kasimir Malevich: 1878-1935'' is a revised version of the 1988-89 Malevich retrospective, which consisted entirely of works from the State Russian Museum in Leningrad, the Tretyakov Gallery in Moscow and the Stedelijk in Amsterdam, the largest Malevich repositories in the world. That was the first Malevich exhibition in the Soviet Union since 1929, when Stalin was in power and Malevich, like other avant-garde artists, was being oppressed. The director of the Tretyakov was imprisoned for organizing the 1929 show.
The current retrospective is a collaboration between the National Gallery, the Armand Hammer Museum and Cultural Center in Los Angeles - which will open with this retrospective in November - and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The consulting curator, the art historian Angelica Zander Rudenstine, who conceived the rigorously intelligent installation, included fewer early and late works in this show. She also added around a dozen paintings from American museums, including the Museum of Modern Art's 1918 ''White Square on White'' and the 1915 ''Suprematist Painting. Rectangle and Circle,'' from the Busch-Reisinger Museum in Cambridge, Mass., two of the works that make the Suprematist room seem like a gathering place for geometric abstract art.
The exhibition documents Malevich's involvement with costume, stage and fabric design and includes three of the ''arkhitektons'' he designed in the 1920's, transforming the shapes in Suprematist paintings into architectural models in which each unit seems mobile yet secure. As significant as this exhibition is, it is still only a beginning. It does not resolve the big Malevich questions. The best scholarship in the catalogue is in the chronology and checklist.
No essay addresses the formidable dating problems of the late works, although Mrs. Rudenstine offers her interpretations in her installation. No essay discusses why Malevich stopped painting between 1919 and 1927. There is no evaluation of his teaching or consideration of the relationship between his theoretical commitment to systematic thought and his artistic belief in the importance of illogic and intuition.
There is no attempt to interpret the late figurative works. Partly because they are not radical like the abstractions, they have been largely avoided or dismissed by critics and art historians for whom artistic and social progress remains the only measure of esthetic worth.
But these late paintings have to be addressed. Suprematism was a prodigious distillation of politics, religion, art and self into a new pictorial essence. Painted in the paranoia and repression of the Stalin years, Malevich's late figurative works seem to shatter his earlier hard-won unity into multiple personalities and styles. In their own way, however, the late paintings are no less absolute and proud.
The figurative paintings include many flat, frontal, faceless figures standing in fields. Some look like straitjacketed ciphers. But their blank faces, like the blank faces of the black and white squares, also suggest tabulae rasa, or clean egg-shaped slates in which something can be born or on which something new can be written. The importance of Suprematist geometry and color - red, white and black - remains.
In the late paintings, the prophet sometimes seems to be disguised as a dandy. There is plenty of irony and a feeling for manner and dress. In ''Red House,'' there is a building by a lyrical blue sea. Only the house is a windowless and doorless shack and the sea rises up behind it like a tidal wave. There is more than a touch of apocalypse here. There is also defiance: the house, like Malevich's peasants, seems indestructible. In the poverty and pain of his last years, Malevich continued to find in painting a life force, one that that enabled him to laugh, to delay the arrival of the hangman and to issue an utterance that will endure.
''Kasimir Malevich: 1878-1935'' remains at the National Gallery of Art through Nov. 4. It will travel to the Armand Hammer Museum of Art and Cultural Center in Los Angeles (Nov. 25 to Jan. 13), and then to the Metropolitan Museum of Art (Feb. 7 to March 24). At the National Gallery, the exhibition was financed in part by Philip Morris.

HEADLINE: Benefits Expected for Japan As the Yen Bounces Back

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
After weakening most of this year while the German mark and the Swiss franc reached record highs against the dollar, the yen is bounciing back.
At 136.95 against the dollar Friday in New York, the yen is at its highest level in 13 months. It has risen 14.4 percent since its low in April, and 9 percent in the last month. It has also rallied against the German mark and other European currencies. And a few forecasters predict that within the next year, the yen can near its all-time high of 120.90 against the dollar, which it reached in November 1988. 
 
Restoring Confidence
For the Japanese, the rise in the yen's value will help fight inflation by making imports, especially oil, less expensive. The stronger yen could also help restore investor confidence in the beleaguered Tokyo stock market, which fell 28 percent during the first quarter and has declined by 19 percent since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.
For the United States, the rise of the yen is just another indicator of the weakening dollar. And the focus on fighting inflation in Japan with higher interest rates - a policy that is also being pursued in much of Europe -makes it unlikely that the United States and its allies will take any substantive action to support the dollar. Such cooperation would require a lowering of interest rates abroad and an increase of interest rates here -moves that would not help Japan or Germany fight inflation or the Federal Reserve defuse a recession.
 
Interest Rate Trend
The rally in the yen has been long in coming, although one of the crucial determinants of currency levels - interest rates - has been moving in Japan's favor since the beginning of 1989. When one country's interest rates are higher than another's, investors tend to favor the currency of the country with the higher interest rate because of the greater return that can be earned on investments in that currency.
What has finally changed the equation, analysts say, is a new belief among traders and investors that the Bank of Japan will stick to its plan of fighting inflation, a policy that this summer pushed Japanese short-term interest rates to levels above those in the United States for the first time in a decade. But it has taken five increases in Japan's official discount rate since May 1989, including the most recent jump to 6 percent on Aug. 30, to consolidate this attitude.
''The Bank of Japan had been moving much too slowly,'' said Michael R. Rosenberg, the manager of international fixed-income research at Merrill Lynch.
 
Shift in Differential
Since February 1989, the interest rate differential between Japanese and American three-month government bills has moved from a spread of 570 basis points in favor of the United States to a 30-point spread in favor of Japan. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Although the interest rate differentials began to move in the yen's favor in early 1989, the yen - and other currencies - remained overshadowed by the dollar in part because foreign investors were clamoring to buy into the rising American stock and bond markets and ignored the narrowing of the spreads.
Then last fall, the dollar began to fall sharply against the German mark and other European currencies. Interest rates were falling here and rising abroad, making other currencies more attractive to investors than the dollar. And the prospect of the opening of Eastern Europe drew many investors to Europe, including the Japanese.
 
A Missed Rally
But the yen did not participate in the rally. Instead, it began to weaken sharply, falling to 160 yen to the dollar in April, even after the Bank of Japan raised its discount rate to 5.25 percent in March. Undermining the yen were the fall of the Tokyo stock market in the first quarter; Japanese buying of stocks overseas; a public dispute between the Ministry of Finance and the Bank of Japan over raising the bank's official discount rate, and the uncertainties about the new Government of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu.
The yen finally began to gain some strength as market interest rates moved higher at the end of June and in July, raising expectations of another increase in the official discount rate by the Bank of Japan. At the same time, the expectation of lower interest rates in the United States was reinforced by a small easing of credit by the Federal Reserve.
''The fundamentals are the key,'' said Kermit L. Schoenholtz, an analyst in Tokyo for Salomon Brothers. ''With short-rate differentials favoring the yen, appreciation is natural.''
 
Less Vulnerability
The rally was stalled briefly by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait as investors worried that Japan's economy would be seriously hurt by the big jump in oil prices. But Japan has proved less vulnerable to such shocks because it has reduced its dependence on oil, so the yen is rallying again.
The new confidence in the Bank of Japan and the resulting expectation of rising interest rates have been reinforced by the surprising performance of the Japanese economy this year, which has proved less vulnerable to the falling stock market or the weak yen than many had thought. It is, in fact, much stronger now than the economic policy makers would like, which is why they would consider raising interest rates further to ward off inflation.
''Even after the oil price hike, the Japanese consumer is still spending,'' said Shin Kawaguchi, assistant general manager of the economics department at the Sumitomo Bank Ltd. in New York.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Markets Worried by Fall of Dollar

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The recent decline in the dollar, which has received at least tacit approval from the Federal Reserve Board and the Treasury Department, is a source of growing concern to credit market participants.
After almost seven months of relative stability against major currencies, in late July the dollar began to sag, briefly touching a 42-year low against the German mark and a post-World War II low against the Swiss franc. The lengthening crisis in the Persian Gulf has produced more weakness, most recently against the Japanese yen.
Some American officials have suggested that the dollar's decline since Iraq invaded Kuwait may be exaggerated by distortions associated with the international freeze on Kuwaiti and Iraqi assets. 
 
Life for an Anemic Economy
But the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, recently suggested that the Fed would not be opposed to a further orderly decline in the dollar, a drop that presumably would increase exports and breathe some life into an anemic economy.
To private analysts, the logic of the Fed's tactics seem fairly clear, especially in light of Mr. Greenspan's strong suggestion last week that the Fed will delay any move to lower interest rates until after a ''credible and enforceable'' Federal budget package is passed. But some wonder whether the strategy will pay off.
''Even though economic conditions are weak, inflation is going up, and that is causing the Fed to slow down in lowering interest rates,'' said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank.
 
Milder Impact Seen
''As a result, the Fed may be looking to the exchange rate mechanism to help the economy,'' he added. ''The only thing I question is whether a depreciating dollar will have the economic impact it did in 1987. A depreciating dollar will have a much milder impact than it did two or three years ago, because the economy is a lot weaker now.''
Even if a drop in the dollar helps to bolster exports and capital spending, those benefits will probably take many months to show up, because of the lag in the effect that changes in currency values have on overseas orders and spending plans.
Of more immediate concern, analysts at Salomon Brothers said, was the effect a further drop in the dollar would have on foreign capital flows into the United States. ''Foreign investors are losing patience with our ability to come to grips with our fiscal problems,'' said Richard B. Berner, a vice president and economist at Salomon.
''With interest rates overseas higher than they are here and continuing to rise, we are starting to border on the edge of where foreign investors don't really seem to care about what our economic policies produce,'' he added.
 
Drop in Foreign Demand
Foreign demand for American portfolio investments was in a sharp decline throughout the first half of 1990, analysts at Salomon said. A further drop in the fourth quarter, when Treasury borrowing needs are likely to exceed $60 billion, could have highly negative ramifications for the credit markets.
During the first half of 1990, foreign investors bought a total of $9.4 billion worth of stocks and bonds, the Salomon figures show, the smallest amount since late 1987, when the dollar was also weakening.
In addition, the allure of higher yields and stronger currencies elsewhere attracted a record net purchase of $10.9 billion of foreign stocks and bonds by American investors in the second quarter, Salomon said, adding that those flows were likely to intensify.
''U.S. investors are considerably underweighted overseas,'' Nicholas Sargen, a manager of international fixed-income research at Salomon wrote in the firm's weekly Comments on Credit publication.
While not disputing the figures, other analysts said the capital movements in the first half of the year did not necessarily bode ill for the future.
 
'Unanswered Question'
In light of recent problems in West Germany and Japan, the ''unanswered question in all of this is which markets are attracting the capital,'' said David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International.
''Prices are being marked down in securities markets all over the world,'' he added. ''What we might be seeing is a global retreat into a more cautious stance by providers of capital.''
Moreover, the fallout from the Persian Gulf crisis may soon lead to a weakening of major European currencies against the dollar.
While a Federal budget agreement may emerge at any time, analysts are quick to point out that convincing members of Congress may take considerable effort. Conceivably, the job might not be finished until the middle of October, the last possible minute before automatic spending cuts become final under the Gramm-Rudman budget-balancing law.
 
Consumer Index Awaited
For market participants, this week's most important news on the economy is expected on Tuesday, with the release of the Consumer Price Index for August.
As with producer prices, which rose 1.3 percent last month, the surge in oil prices almost certainly bloated the consumer index, analysts said. An increase of eight-tenths or nine-tenths of a percent - the largest rise since January - is widely forecast.
Excluding the food and energy components, consumer prices probably rose last month by three-tenths or four-tenths of a percent, analysts said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Post or No Post, Dailies Face Flux

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The fate of The New York Post, be it life or death, raises the curtain on a period of tremendous flux in the city's already tense and economically distressed newspaper market -particularly for The Daily News, which is embroiled in its own showdown with unions.
Union leaders, industry analysts and executives at New York's dailies say that whatever happens, the struggle to save The Post will drastically change the city's newspaper landscape. Ultimately, either The Post or The News, or even both, will almost certainly disappear, they predict. They say the long-term importance of what happens at The Post today is its impact on The Daily News, which is far larger and more likely to survive.
After a week of intense negotiations, Peter S. Kalikow, owner of The Post, said on Friday that the paper's survival depended on whether the 350-member Newspaper Guild votes tonight to approve $5 million in wage and benefit cuts. The cuts would reduce weekly salaries for Guild members by about 20 percent. The paper's other eight unions, representing roughly 500 jobs, have already agreed to $15 million in cuts to keep the paper alive. 
The voting is scheduled for 6 P.M., and should the Guild's members reject the plan, Mr. Kalikow said tomorrow's issue of The Post would be the last.
''I think it's going to be very close,'' said Barry F. Lipton, president of the Guild, who has endorsed the proposal but faces strong opposition from many in the union who say the cuts are too deep. The Guild, the paper's largest union, represents news, advertising and clerical employees.
No other city in the nation has more than two big daily newspapers, but New York City has four - including The New York Times and New York Newsday - and their battle for survival has made this particular newspaper war a fascinating spectacle for the industry, rather like watching scorpions in a jar.
Interviews with senior executives at The News, The Post and The Times, who were willing to discuss the situation last week on condition that they not be named, suggest that every newspaper in the city, including New York Newsday, has a stake in what happens to The Post, if only indirectly. While The Times and New York Newsday are not in jeopardy of closing, they have a vital and conflicting interest in what happens to The Post because of the potential effect on The News and on the competitive climate in general.
Though New York Newsday has not yet made an operating profit on its own, its parent, Long Island Newsday, is quite profitable. Furthermore, the Times Mirror Company, which owns Newsday, has shown no sign of cutting back. Robert M. Johnson, publisher of Newsday and New York Newsday, said that what happens at The Post would have no effect on New York Newsday's fundamental strategy of slowly building circulation.
 
Pivotal Role of The News
What happens at The Post will either strengthen or weaken The News, which is the pivotal newspaper as far as The Times and New York Newsday are concerned.
Analysts and newspaper executives say New York Newsday would rush to fill the void if The News closed; The Times, on the other hand, would be helped if The News survives and acts as a buffer to New York Newsday, which with substantially more circulation could be a formidable competitor for the advertising aimed at affluent readers that now appears mostly in The Times.
As for The Post, newspaper analysts predict that the paper will get a temporary reprieve, at best, if Mr. Kalikow means it when he says he is unwilling to absorb more losses. The Post has been unprofitable for two decades, and its advertising has declined sharply in the last two years, along with that of the city's other papers, as part of a regional economic slump.
If a settlement is reached, inflation will almost immediately start to eat away at the savings that had been agreed upon. The paper must find new revenue to maintain an equilibrium.''It's as sure as death and taxes that costs go up,'' said John Morton, a newspaper analyst at Lynch, Jones & Ryan in Washington.
 
Kalikow's Strategy
Mr. Kalikow's strategy has been to hope for a strike at The News that The Post could exploit to win circulation and advertising, but union leaders have said that they will not strike The News under any circumstances.
In a strategic sense, The Post's existence is very important to unions as a bargaining chip in their negotiations with The News. Union leaders can point to the negotiations at The Post as a model of successful negotiating, putting public relations pressure on The News to do the same, rather than to continue pursuing its demands for ''management rights'' that would strip unions of virtually all their power.
On the other hand, closing The Post would help the management of The News by eliminating a rival and leaving unions wounded by the lost jobs. And if The Post closes on the basis of a union vote, it would be a public relations disaster for the unions.
 
Newsday Has Different Unions
And it is not lost on the labor leaders that while the same unions represent workers at The News, The Post and The Times, Newsday has different unions. The growth of New York Newsday does not translate into more jobs for their members.
George E. McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, said yesterday that the scenario of one union effectively throwing its brothers out of work would be so catastrophic that it might have been scripted by the Tribune Company, which owns The Daily News and which labor leaders consider virulently anti-union.
Since January, when bitter negotiations with The News began, the unions have acted in concert with unusual harmony, which has greatly strengthened their position.
The News would almost certainly try to exploit the crack in union solidarity that would result from a Guild vote to reject the Kalikow proposal.
The strategy of The News from the start has been to make favorable deals with some unions, like the Guild, and isolate unions representing the pressmen and delivery drivers, which News management has accused of featherbedding and other wasteful practices.
 
Anxiety Over News Article
Anxiety that The News was trying to sabotage the Guild vote ran high yesterday after an article appeared in The News on Sunday asserting that members of the drivers' union at The Post would get ''$100-a-week raises'' rather than a pay cut.
The story ran on page 3 of The News under the headline, ''Drivers Post sweet deal.''
Representatives of Mr. Kalikow and Michael J. Alvino, president of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union of New York, which represents the drivers, characterized the article and headline as misleading.
''The article was designed to put The Post out of business,'' Mr. Alvino said.
They said that from 90 to 96 of the paper's 263 drivers would be laid off and that those remaining would no longer receive guaranteed overtime pay, which averaged 10 hours a week, and would also lose some other benefits. Though the base pay would increase by $100 a week, they said, the take-home pay for drivers would decrease.
 
Reaction at The News
James P. Willse, editor of The News, said that the paper was reporting what information it had available at the time and that suggestions of ulterior motives were ludicrous. The News published an editorial in the same issue expressing hope that The Post would carry on. The potential ripple effect of The Post's survival or demise has made union leaders very sensitive to anything that they think might be calculated to harm the negotiations.
Union leaders were incensed last week when The News notified the Newspaper Guild that it intended to seek any concessions granted The Post through a portion of the Guild contract known in labor parlance as a ''me-too'' clause.
The News terminated all union contracts last spring as a negotiating tactic, and union leaders said there was no legal basis for seeking the concessions.
Then The Times declared that it, too, would seek any concessions granted to The Post, to the extent that they were created by overall economic conditions.
 
Lawsuits Threatened
Union leaders and Mr. Kalikow threatened lawsuits against both The Times and The News on the ground that they were trying to interfere in labor negotiations. Spokesmen for both The Times and The News said they were simply stating their intentions.
The Times is already negotiating with union leaders about the staffing of the paper's new, highly automated plant in Edison, N.J., which is scheduled to open this fall.
While The Times remains profitable, its advertising has dropped in recent months and profits are down. Though the framework of the Edison talks does not include considering overall economic conditions, the message to union leaders is clear: The Times is serious about saving money, too.

HEADLINE: Easing Local Phone Rules: Fight on Profit

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
A year ago the Government granted the American Telephone and Telegraph Company greater freedom to raise or lower prices while eliminating most controls on its rate of return. The idea was to encourage better services, cut costs and create savings for consumers and shareholders.
Experts disagree on how well the new system is working, but on Wednesday the Federal Communications Commission is likely to extend it to local telephone companies. Under the new system, price ceilings are set for broad categories of services, and close regulation of profits and specific prices are dropped. Rates on local telephone calls would not be directly affected.
 
Too Quick a Rise Feared
Because F.C.C. approval for the change is widely expected, the debate has shifted to how quickly the ceilings should rise for the local phone companies in coming years. An unlikely alliance of consumer groups and the two biggest long-distance companies, A.T.&T. and the MCI Communications Corporation, contends that the new ceilings will rise too quickly under the F.C.C. staff proposal up for approval. 
The alliance warns that over the next four years local telephone companies will be able to cut their costs for conveying calls from homes and businesses to the nearest long-distance switching centers by $5 billion more than they have estimated and will not be obliged to pass the savings on to long-distance companies. These payments, estimated to be about $50 billion over the next four years, are the most important factor in determining long-distance rates, and the alliance says the additional costs will be borne by customers.
If the price ceilings are allowed to rise more slowly, as the A.T.&T. alliance advocates, the long-distance carriers and consumers will benefit at the expense of the local phone companies.
Some consumer advocates have also warned that the new regulatory system will not give local phone companies enough incentive to invest in their networks, resulting in a decline in the quality of phone service.
 
Regional Bells Fight Back
On the other side are the local phone companies, led by the seven regional Bell companies created in the 1984 breakup of A.T.&T. They say that consumers will not suffer and that the proposed increase in price ceilings will barely allow them to cover their costs and maintain profit margins. The future cost savings predicted by A.T.&T. and its allies are impossible, they say.
The A.T.&T. alliance argues that raising the price ceilings at a slower rate would force the local phone companies to try to be even more efficient, stretching for even more savings. But there is much disagreement over whether further efficiencies are feasible. ''Stretching the companies is a good idea for the Government's purposes; we're just not sure whether that stretch will be too much,'' said Janice Obuchowski, head of the National Telecommunications and Information Administration, a Commerce Department agency.
A coalition of 30 companies and associations, led by A.T.&T., opposed the F.C.C. staff's plan in a petition filed last Wednesday and asked that any decision this week be tentative. If the commissioners make a tentative decision, they would have to vote again on the issue before price caps could take effect as planned Jan. 1. The extra vote would give the coalition time to lobby for amendments to some of the new rules.
 
Influence on Local Rates
A decision will not directly affect rates for local telephone calls, which are regulated by state commissions. But California, Nebraska and Vermont have already introduced price ceilings, and several other states are considering doing so. The F.C.C.'s decision may influence decisions by state regulators.
Price caps are currently popular with most economists in the United States because the system appears to address problems with the profit-based regulatory system that has prevailed for decades.
Under price caps, a weighted average of a phone company's prices for each of several very broad categories of services may rise, but less quickly than producer prices in the economy.
But the company has considerable latitude to change prices for various services in meeting these averages. And if a company keeps the rate at which its costs increase below the rate at which its price ceiling rises, the company can keep the difference, instead of being forced to distribute the savings to consumers, as required by the current profit-based rules.
 
Incentive to Overinvest
Under existing regulations, a local telephone company's profits are limited to a fixed percentage of any investments that are approved by regulators. The limits have often been set above comparable returns in other industries. So companies have had an incentive to overinvest in buildings and equipment to earn a high return on more money. This has meant a top-quality network but also rates higher than they might have been.
More important, current regulation has discouraged the risky development of new services by forcing companies to absorb the losses if the experiments fail but to distribute the benefits to consumers if the services prove extremely successful. ''In the past, when we have put in any efficiencies, we have not been able to share any of that with our shareholders,'' said Larry J. Sparrow, the vice president for telephone regulatory and governmental affairs at the GTE Corporation, one of the largest local phone companies.
The potential problem of price caps is that phone companies may cut costs and increase profits for shareholders at the expense of quality. ''There is a legitimate concern about creeping dilapidation of the network,'' said Patricia D. Dennis, a former F.C.C. commissioner who worked on the price cap plan for A.T.&T. and is now a communications lawyer in Washington.
 
Approach Called Almost 'Suicidal'
Local phone companies argue that state regulators already monitor quality closely, and that they must invest heavily to offer new and more profitable services. Cutting investment ''would almost be suicidal,'' said Danley T. Hubbard, the vice president of revenues and public affairs at the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company in St. Louis.
The results of price-cap regulation at A.T.&T. are unclear and disputed. The company says its long-distance rates dropped by $462 million during the first 12 months after it came under price caps on July 1, 1989. But most of the savings went to businesses rather than residential customers, and it is unclear whether the rate reductions resulted from regulatory change or competition in the long-distance telephone industry.
Even A.T.&T. is reluctant to call price caps a success, noting that only 21 percent of its price changes in the last year were made easier by the new regulatory system. ''It's really too short a time to make a realistic evaluation of how it has gone,'' said Thomas H. Norris, A.T.&T.'s corporate vice president for Federal regulatory affairs.
 
A.T.&T. Increased Prices
But some consumer and telephone user groups that criticized the introduction of price caps for A.T.&T. say that the results confirm their early fears. After repeatedly lowering long-distance rates since the divestiture in 1984, A.T.&T. used its freedom of pricing last November to raise its night and weekend long-distance rates by an average of 1.3 percent, they point out. And when the F.C.C. ordered local telephone companies on July 1 to reduce their access charges to long-distance carriers by $1.1 billion, A.T.&T. passed on only half of its savings.
''The residential customer is being shortchanged,'' said Gene Kimmelman, the legislative director and telecommunications expert at the Consumer Federation of America, a nonprofit Washington group.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
S.& L. Failures Benefit Seller of Troubled Assets

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
The misfortune of the savings and loan industry has brought good fortune to Joseph E. Robert Jr. Mr. Robert is chairman of the J. E. Robert Companies, an organization that was in the right place at the right time when the Government needed to contract for managers to dispose of the assets of failed institutions.
Robert Companies is scheduled to assume control today of the $2.4 billion in assets of the University Federal Savings Association in Houston. The contract from the Resolution Trust Corporation, to manage and dispose of the assets, is the largest awarded to date by the Government. 
The Robert organization, which is based in Alexandria, Va., will be paid about $21.8 million over three years to manage the properties that were owned by the association and $19.6 million to dispose of the properties over the same period. The fees will depend on the company's performance.
Mr. Robert said his company acted like a giant loan collection department and as a manager of property that has already been foreclosed. ''The better we do at maximizing the recovery, the better off the taxpayers are,'' Mr. Robert said.
Mr. Robert, 38, said he got into the real estate workout business ''by default'' when he was working for a Washington developer whose business failed in 1974. As the economy turned around most people got out of the workout business. ''The difference was, I stayed in it,'' he said.
From 1974 to 1981 he concentrated on such projects as condominiums. In 1981 he formed his company and began to focus on troubled debt portfolios.
In 1984 he won his first contract from the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. ''The business has grown since with the rising tide of failures,'' Mr. Robert said. Today the company oversees $10 billion in assets and is adding 80 to 100 employees to a staff of about 170, he said.
Mr. Robert grew up in the Washington area and attended three colleges without earning a degree, working in the real estate business at age 19 and going to school at nights, he said. ''I'm the only one around here without a degree,'' he added.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Kroger Picks President And Chief Adds Title

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
The Kroger Company, a major supermarket chain, has named a president and chief operating officer, and its new chief executive has added the title of chairman.
The new president is Richard L. Bere, who is 59 years old and currently a senior vice president. Mr. Bere (pronounced beer) also joins the Kroger board.
The management changes began with the naming in June of Joseph A. Pichler, 49, to be the chief executive, succeeding Lyle Everingham, 64. Mr. Everingham, chairman and chief executive for 11 years, was to have remained chairman until the age of 65 in 1991. On Friday, however, the Cincinnati-based company announced that Mr. Pichler had been elected to the additional post of chairman. 
A company spokesman said the succession plan had been accelerated because Mr. Everingham was planning to do some traveling, both for personal reasons and for the company. Mr. Everingham, who began as a clerk in a store in Adrian, Mich., in 1946, will remain on the board and was elected chairman of the executive committee, a post he will hold until his retirement in January.
In other changes, Patrick J. Kenney, 53, currently president of the Texas operating group, was named a senior vice president to succeed Mr. Bere. William J. Sinkula, 60, and David B. Dillon, 39, were named executive vice presidents. Mr. Sinkula will continue as chief financial officer and Mr. Dillon as head of Dillon Companies, a supermarket unit of Kroger based in Hutchinson, Kan.
The new Kroger team constitutes something of a brain trust. Mr. Pichler, a former dean of the University of Kansas business school, holds a doctorate in economics from the University of Chicago. Mr. Bere holds a doctorate in agricultural economics from Ohio State University.
Mr. Bere has been with Kroger for 33 years, having worked in St. Louis and Nashville before joining the headquarters staff as senior vice president in 1988. In the early 1970's, when he was in charge of produce merchandising, he took Kroger fruits and vegetables out of their plastic trays after customers complained they could not smell or touch what they were buying. The company said the move increased produce sales strongly.

HEADLINE: Tobacco Industry Sees Boon in Sales to Soviets

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The recently announced sale of American cigarettes to the Soviet Union will fatten the already rich profits of the tobacco industry in the United States to a larger extent than the numbers involved suggest, Wall Street analysts say.
''This Soviet deal is one of the most important things that has happened to the industry in a long, long time and not just because it is going to raise exports,'' said Lawrence Adelman, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
By using idle factory capacity, the deal will raise the profits on cigarettes sold domestically, he said, adding, ''This is an uplifting experience from a profit point of view.''
Cigarette companies earn in excess of 40 cents for each dollar of assets. 
 
Anti-Smokers' Outcry
The announcement last week that the Philip Morris Companies and RJR Nabisco Inc., the two biggest companies in the tobacco industry, would sell 34 billion cigarettes to the Soviet Union was quickly followed by an outcry from anti-smoking groups protesting that serious health problems would be exported.
''We fear that the Soviets will place the Marlboro Man in a place of honor right next to Lenin's Tomb,'' said John R. Seffrin, chairman of the American Cancer Society, on Friday. ''This is going to help bring about an epidemic of tobacco-induced diseases the likes of which the world has never seen.''
Mr. Seffrin called on Philip Morris and RJR Nabisco to place warning labels on the Soviet-bound cigarettes that would resemble the United States Surgeon General's warning on smoking and tobacco-linked illnesses, including cancer. The Soviet Union does not require such labels.
Since the Surgeon General's 1964 report attacking cigarettes, cigarette consumption in the United States has declined. Last year, Americans smoked about 524 billion cigarettes, a decrease of about 6 percent from the year before.
 
Some Price Resistance
Cigarette companies are still highly profitable because of efficient production and smokers' willingness to pay regular twice-a-year price increases. Still, the discount cigarettes known as generics have become the industry's most successful product introduction, indicating some price resistance among smokers.
Now, instead of trying to keep plant efficiency high by making generics, American factories can make higher-profit full-price cigarettes for the Soviet Union.
The brands to be exported include Philip Morris's Marlboros, the world's best-selling brand, and RJR Nabisco's Winstons, another top-selling brand. No price for the cigarettes has been set yet. But if valued at United States retail prices in 1989, excluding taxes, the shipments would be worth about $1.9 billion, or a little over a dollar a pack.
For Philip Morris, the Soviet deal means little in the short run, said Rebecca Barfield, an analyst with the First Boston Corporation. It will yield perhaps $40 million to $60 million in pretax profit annually for Philip Morris. That is about 3 cents a share for a corporation that last year earned $3.18 a share, or nearly $3 billion.
But tobacco accounts for nearly two-thirds of Philip Morris profit, and Philip Morris's strong cash flow has made it a favorite on Wall Street, especially among institutional investors. ''The fact that Philip Morris will surely be close to running at 100 percent efficiency means that their bottom line will be very favorably affected,'' Ms. Barfield said.
In addition, the Soviet deal will give Philip Morris nearly 5 percent of the Soviet market and RJR Nabisco, which is privately held, more than 3 percent. ''If Americans, and especially Philip Morris, penetrate the Russian market, I don't see why they couldn't get 20 percent or more in a relatively short period,'' said John C. Maxwell Jr., an analyst with Wheat First Securities Inc.
 
Smoking a Pack a Day
The Soviet Union is negotiating with tobacco companies in the United States and other countries to solve a shortage that already totals at least 50 billion cigarettes. The 70 million Soviet smokers are believed to smoke nearly a pack a day, but this is a lower figure than the nearly pack and a half a day smoked by 50 million Americans.
Darryl J. Jayson, an economic analyst with the Tobacco Merchants Association, a trade group, said per-smoker consumption figures are misleading because Soviet production could not keep up with demand.
Soviet smokers spend about 10 percent of their income on cigarettes, Mr. Jayson said. ''Even in a country where food and shelter are heavily subsidized, we're talking a very heavy smoker here,'' he said.''It isn't any wonder that there have been riots in the streets over cigarettes.''
The shortage has been developing for a long time. Mr. Jayson cited Agriculture Department estimates that Soviet inventories of domestically grown tobacco leaf have been declining for the last five years.

HEADLINE: Hungary's Chief Begins to Accept Popularity

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, Sept. 17

 BODY:
The shock of last year's tumultuous changes has begun to wear off for most Hungarians, but not for Arpad Goncz. The writer, translator and, for six years, prisoner in a Communist prison still has trouble getting used to the idea of being President of the republic.
''Somehow, I feel as if I fell into the middle of a cyclone,'' Mr. Goncz said before leaving on an unofficial trip to the United States. ''It has changed my life basically.'' 
On Aug. 3, Mr. Goncz, 68 years old, was officially elected to a five-year term as President after serving in a largely ceremonial post on an interim basis since May.
He had by then already established himself as one of the country's most popular figures, a sprightly man with a self-deprecating wit who stands out in a political landscape weighted down by solemnity. He sees his own role in family terms. ''At the moment, I feel as I were the grandfather of all of Hungary,'' he said in an interview with several reporters. ''It means if the children are fighting, you have to make peace.''
He again had to play that role recently, reminding politicians not to call each other names during a growing controversy over Foreign Minister Geza Jeszenszky's accusation that members of the opposition espouse ''Marxist, atheist, free-thinking and unpatriotic ideas.''
Even after parliamentary elections in the spring, Hungarian politics continued to be split between two camps, as the opposition keeps up its criticism on the shape and pace of Prime Minister Jozsef Antall's program for economic and social change.
Mr. Goncz was chosen last spring by both sides because he is one of the few public figures in Hungary who can cross the political divide. He was a founding member of the Alliance for Free Democrats, now the main opposition party. But in his youth, he was a rising young star in the Independent Smallholders, a rural party that is now part of the governing coalition. He also has personal ties to Mr. Antall, who is head of the centrist Hungarian Democratic Forum.
As head of state, Mr. Goncz greets foreign visitors and performs other politically neutral tasks. But this month, he drew fire by granting clemency to four spies who had worked either for the C.I.A. or West German intelligence. The four, all sentenced in the 1980's, were considered Hungary's last political prisoners.
Critics raised a moral question: whether a country, by changing its political position in the world, can redefine the terms of treason. Mr. Goncz acknowledged the complexity of the case. He said he privately considered the spies' behavior ''not very commendable,'' but said that under the circumstances they had served enough time in jail.
His decision was to grant not amnesty, but clemency, he noted.
 
Constantly Ringing Doorbell
''I did not want to make anyone a saint just because he was working for the Americans,'' he said.
A year ago Mr. Goncz, who during his career has worked as a laborer and an agronomist, became president of the Hungarian Writers Association - a post that he recently gave up to make room for his other duties. An author in his own right, he has also translated Saul Bellow, John Updike, William Styron and George Bush into Hungarian. He learned English in prison, where he was sentenced for his role in the 1956 Hungarian uprising, and was even drafted into doing translations for his jailers.
As President, Mr. Goncz said he had lost those anonymous hours he used to spend reading or writing in his small Budapest apartment. Now his doorbell is constantly rung by people looking for solutions to grievences and complaints that, he said, often date back to 1917.
Hungarians, many of who have found the last year to be a time of troubling uncertainty, have responded to Mr. Goncz's low-key charm with warmth and enthusiam.
''I'm sincerely surprised,'' he said about his popularity. ''But I have never promised anything I could not fulfill. As long they don't catch me lying, I expect I will be credible.''

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
IRAQ AIR BLOCKADE IS BACKED BY BUSH

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he was prepared to support efforts to extend the United Nations naval blockade of Iraq to halting the air shipments that are now a hole in the international sanctions against President Saddam Hussein.
Although the Administration has hesitated to take that step out of fear it could set off armed conflict, there has been growing pressure in the United Nations for an air blockade. ''I would be prepared to work with anybody to tie that additional knot in the sanctions,'' Mr. Bush said.
At a news conference, the President said that he worried about how long public support for the Persian Gulf military operation would last if the current stalemate dragged on or if open warfare broke out. 
He also conceded for the first time in public that he regretted United States efforts to improve relations with Mr. Hussein in the months before the invasion of Kuwait. But he insisted that this policy did not cause the current crisis.
Talking to reporters and editors from smaller news organizations, Mr. Bush said the American people are now ''magnificently united'' behind his Persian Gulf policy.
If there is war, he said he hoped the public would respond as it did during World War II. ''There was a lot of sorrow, there was a lot of regret,'' Mr. Bush said. ''Everyone identified with the families who lost loved ones, but the country stayed fairly well together.''
 
'How Long Is Too Long?'
If there is no open fighting and the deployment continues month after month with no end in sight, he said, ''I'm not clear in my own mind on how long this kind of support holds up,'' adding,''How long is too long? I think about those questions, but I can't define it for you.''
Mr. Bush declined, as he always does, to speculate about the likelihood of open warfare in the Arabian peninsula. But he said that despite the presence of troops from other countries and the need to consult with the American troops' Saudi hosts, the United States would make its own decisions about how and when to use military force.
''We're not going to have to stand around waiting for someone else to decide if there is some provocation'' that would justify a military attack, Mr. Bush said.
He also said, ''I have no hesitancy at all to say to the parents of the kids over there, or families, 'Should something happen that required combat, the command structure will function very, very smoothly.' ''
The Administration has been stung by recent newspaper columns suggesting that its policy of trying to improve relations with Mr. Hussein may have emboldened him to strike Kuwait.
Asked whether he now regretted the Administration's overtures to Mr. Hussein and its efforts to prevent passage of sanctions proposed in Congress against the Iraqi leader, Mr. Bush said, ''Absolutely.''
Mr. Bush said that at the time, ''there was reason to believe that perhaps improved relations with the West would modify the behavior'' of the Iraqi leader.
With the benefit of hindsight he said, ''You'd go back and say, 'This doesn't make much sense.' ''
But he added that he was ''not sure'' a different policy ''would have changed Saddam Hussein's intention to take over Kuwait.'' He said, ''I don't think this is caused by a miscalculation in United States policy. I think it's caused by a miscalculation by Saddam Hussein.''
On another issue, Mr. Bush said he had ''indirect assurances'' from Iran that it would not violate the trade embargo against Iraq. Benefit of the Doubt Referring to news reports that Iran had agreed to take Iraqi oil in exchange for food and other supplies, he said, ''Until I am shown that Iran is violating the sanctions, I'm not going to buy into the argument that they've made some secret deal to violate the sanctions.''
Although the United States led the way in imposing a naval blockade on Iraq, it has hesitated to try stopping air traffic into Iraq out of fear that such an operation would be provocative and could more easily initiate open warfare than the naval embargo, since it would risk clashes between warplanes from Iraq and other countries.
Administration officials have said that the volume of air traffic in violation of the embargo is too small to justify the risk of intensifying the conflict. But there has been growing pressure in the United Nations for an air blockade and Mr. Bush expressed concern about the continued air supplies to Iraq.
On Sunday morning, the United Nations Security Council adopted a resolution calling for ''further concrete measures'' to enforce the embargo on trade with Iraq and the council's permanent members met privately on Sunday and again tonight to consider ways to do that.

HEADLINE: Bush Again Calls on Negotiators to Adopt Cut in Capital Gains Tax

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
As White House and Congressional budget negotiators tried today to put together the final pieces of a deficit-cutting deal, President Bush renewed his call for a cut in the capital gains tax rate, saying a budget agreement that includes a rate reduction would be the best antidote to economic slowdown.
Although President Bush stopped short of saying he would reject a deficit package that did not include a cut, the budget negotiators ended their deliberations at Andrews Air Force Base tonight at loggerheads over that very issue.
House and Senate leaders from both parties are scheduled to meet Tuesday on Capitol Hill with Administration negotiators to see if they can find a way to compromise. ''It's not quite an impasse, but it's pretty close to one,'' said Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate Republican leader. 
 
Points of Contention
Democratic officials said that while there were some areas in which the two sides had narrowed their differences, the problem came down to the Republicans' insistence that the package include a cut in the capital gains tax rate and the Democrats' refusal to accept one unless it was accompanied by a rise in income tax rates for the wealthy.
''They have to choose between having an historic budget deal or having the whole thing go down in the flames of capital gains,'' said a Democratic spokesman.
Officials involved in the talks, which have been held for the last week and a half at the base, on the outskirts of Washington, said the two sides had tentatively agreed on $59 billion in tax increases over the next five years as well as $123 billion in spending cuts over the same period from programs in which benefits are automatic for those who qualify, like Medicare, Federal retirement benefits and farm subsidies. But the bulk of the tax increases that would be needed to meet the negotiators' target for cutting the deficit by $500 billion over five years remain to be settled.
The $59 billion in tax increases on which tentative agreement has been reached include a 10 percent luxury tax on boats and cars with prices of more than $30,000, electronic equipment priced at more than $1,000, jewelry costing more than $5,000 and furs costing more than $500; a tax on ozone-depleting chemicals, and a rise in excise taxes on spirits, beer and wine.
Democrats and Republicans exchanged deficit-reduction proposals again tonight, but the Democratic plan included a proviso that it was ''entirely contingent'' on not having a capital gains tax cut.
 
Both Sides' Offers
The Democrats are calling for a 20 percent surcharge on incomes of more than $200,000 and a broad-based energy tax. Republicans presented an offer stipulating that the current income tax rate structure be preserved. But their plan would limit deductions for state and local income taxes to offset the revenue that would be lost from cutting the capital gains tax rate. It also calls for new taxes on petroleum fuels.
On Capitol Hill earlier in the day, some lawmakers, including members of the budget negotiating team, raised the possibility of legislation to postpone the deadline, on Oct. 15, when automatic budget cuts will take effect if no agreement has been reached on reducing the Federal deficit.
Lawmakers, especially those in the House, who all face elections in November, are eager to wind up the Congressional session by the second week in October, but the uncertainty over a budget agreement is delaying action on a number of major bills.
Mr. Bush, in his comments, made to a group of reporters for regional newspapers, said he did not believe there was a financial crisis in the country or that the economy was in recession. ''The economy's growth is slow,'' he said, adding that he was ''absolutely convinced'' a reduction in the capital gains rate would spur growth by creating jobs and investment incentives. Of the budget talks, he said the negotiators had ''made some headway recently.''
Capital gains are currently taxed at the same rate as ordinary income, 28 percent or 33 percent, depending on the taxpayer's income level. Republican negotiators have been pushing for a 15 percent capital gains rate. But Democrats argue that a reduction in the rate would benefit mainly the wealthiest taxpayers.
 
Opposition to Limiting Deductions
Limiting the state and local income-tax deductions faces stiff opposition from lawmakers in both parties and especially from those from high income-tax states, like New York, California and Massachusetts, that rely on such taxes to finance a variety of programs and services. But capping all deductions might be equally unpopular.
In his comments to the reporters, Mr. Bush said that the final budget agreement must include real spending reductions and that Congress must devise a system to see that the spending cuts are enforced over the next five years. The negotiators have yet to agree on such a system.
With the Oct. 15 deadline rapidly approaching for imposition of the automatic spending cuts, Representative Silvio O. Conte of Massachusetts, the senior Republican on the House Appropriations Committee and who is part of the negotiating team, raised the possibility of legislation to postpone the cuts, which fall on domestic and military programs. But Congress faces a second deadline - an even tighter one - on Oct. 1, the start of the Government's new fiscal year, to approve 1991 spending bills.
The spending bills are currently in a sort of legislative limbo pending the outcome of the budget negotiations, and Mr. Conte said Congress might be forced to pass a huge stopgap spending bill to finance the Government.
''I have heard that ugly rumor,'' Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House Republican leader, told the reporters. He said a confrontation over how to handle the spending cut deadline and the growing legislative logjam could come when the Administration makes its request for additional 1990 military spending to help pay for operations in the Persian Gulf. That request is expected soon.
Mr. Michel said the Administration was expected to seek between $1.5 billion and $2 billion in additional military spending for 1990.
For 1991, Democratic budget negotiators have proposed a $10 billion cut in the military budget from current levels and a further cut of $23 billion in fiscal 1992.

LENGTH: 1201 words

HEADLINE: Politics in Massachusetts: More Division Than Vision

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
With a provocative remark about blacks and then angry attacks on the news media, John R. Silber, a candidate in the Democratic primary for governor,has thrown Tuesday's race into turmoil, apparently leaving Francis X. Bellotti in the lead.
A poll published over the weekend in The Boston Globe showed Mr. Bellotti, a former Massachusetts Attorney General, leading Dr. Silber, president of Boston University, 48 percent to 37 percent. The poll, of 457 likely voters, has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points.
But with Massachusetts voters angry at conventional politicians for a prolonged budget crisis, it was unclear whether Mr. Bellotti, who is 67 years old and first ran for governor in 1964, could hold his lead over the acerbic Dr. Silber, who has depicted himself as the candidate of change. 
Both candidates seemed to have damaged themselves in the past week - Mr. Bellotti with a rambling debate appearance and Dr. Silber by saying in a televised meeting that he had not campaigned in predominantly black sections of Boston because ''there is no point in my making a speech on crime control to a group of drug addicts.''
But some polls suggest Dr. Silber's remark has generated more support among white voters.
 
A Blue-Collar Appeal
Indeed, although Dr. Silber's comments have outraged many Massachusetts voters, they seem to have appealed to many disaffected blue-collar voters who believe the Democratic Party has become too liberal. By the very extremes of his remarks, he is perceived by some voters as an honest candidate willing to say what others are afraid to say.
The third Democratic contender, Lieut. Gov. Evelyn Murphy, withdrew last Monday from the race after a comic-opera attempt to seize power while Gov. Michael S. Dukakis was on a trade mission in Europe. Mr. Dukakis, the 1988 Democratic nominee for President, is not running for re-election.
The Democrats' mistakes, along with Massachusetts' continuing budget problems, have helped the state's small Republican Party, which will choose between two candidates for governor: Steven Pierce, the minority leader in the State House of Representatives, who is a strong opponent of abortion; and William F. Weld, a former United States Attorney who supports a woman's right to abortion.
Mr. Pierce had been ahead in polls, but Mr. Weld has surged in the last few weeks with a blitz of television advertisements that poke fun at Mr. Pierce for repeatedly filing his tax returns late.
The Republicans, who make up only 13.4 percent of the registered voters in Massachusetts, have not won the governor's race since 1970.
 
A Tax-Cutting Proposition
But whoever wins the Democratic and Republican primaries might have to cope with a proposition on the November ballot that would roll back taxes to 1988 levels, forcing the next governor to cut an estimated $2 billion a year from the $13 billion state budget. The proposal is sponsored by the Citizens for Limited Taxation, a conservative group led by Barbara Anderson, who helped win an antitax proposition in 1980 that has limited the ability of local communities to raise property taxes.
While Ms. Anderson has acknowledged that there will be big cuts in human services, welfare and health care if the proposition is approved, she has said she is confident a new governor and a new legislature can ''restructure government from the bottom up.''
Despite the likelihood that approval of the tax-cutting proposition will have drastic consequences, the plan is popular, having picked up further support since July when Governor Dukakis enacted the largest tax increase in the state's history while imposing spending cuts totaling 8 percent.
Both Republican candidates for governor back the proposal, while the two Democratic candidates oppose it.
 
'A Public Nervous Breakdown'
So far none of the four contenders have inspired voters with a new vision of how to cope with the state's declining economy. After an extraordinary decade of growth in the 1980's, Massachusetts has tipped into recession, with unemployment rising to 6.7 percent in August, double its rate a year earlier. The economic downturn has meant a sharp drop in state revenue, intensifying the budget problem.
Despite this sense of crisis, The Globe said in an editorial last week that it would not endorse a candidate for governor, contending that all the candidates had done was raise ''a Babel of politics-as-usual bombast'' without facing up to the ''unpleasant political and economic truths.''
The Boston Herald has endorsed Dr. Silber, although he has repeatedly denounced the newspaper's coverage of him as being ''distorted.''
The Globe said Dr. Silber, an articulate, forceful man who has helped build Boston University into an important institution of higher learning, ''flunked self-control and self-discipline.''
 
'A Threat to Democracy'
Dr. Silber's propensity for making provocative remarks was evident again last week with his comment about not campaigning before drug addicts, which a number of blacks denounced as racist.
Although he has a record of support for civil rights, dating to the 1960's when he was dean of the University of Texas, Dr. Silber soon found himself in a shouting match with television reporters pressing him over his comment. At one point, he said, ''This is why television is a threat to democracy.''
To try to undo the damage, Dr. Silber invited television reporters to cover him at what he said would be a speech on crime the next day at a street corner in Roxbury, a black section of Boston. But his appearance rapidly degenerated into street theater, with one black woman, Priscilla Flint Russell, yelling that she was not a drug addict and then shouting, ''Hey, man, get out of here!''
''I've got no time for that fanaticism,'' Dr. Silber retorted, abruptly ending his television appearance. The next day Ms. Russell was arrested on charges of passing a bad check, and it turned out that she had pleaded guilty last year to defrauding a bank of $67,800, according to court records.
 
Silber's Appeal and Liabilities
The incidents underscored both Dr. Silber's appeal and his liabilities in speaking so bluntly. The incidents also recalled the divided reaction in an earlier debate when Dr. Silber suggested that the state should consider rationing medical care. ''When you've had a long life and you're ripe, then it's time to go,'' he said.
Mr. Bellotti pounced on the remark, contending that it showed Dr. Silber's insensitivity to the elderly. But Dr. Silber replied that he only wanted to point out the need to contain rapidly rising medical costs.
On the Republican side, Mr. Weld is widely considered a more formidable candidate in the general election. He is on the popular side of the abortion question in Massachusetts and has raised more money than Mr. Pierce, a 12-year veteran of the Legislature.
''A Republican can win this year,'' said Tom Kiley, another Democratic consultant who is not connected to any of the candidates. ''These voters really want to vote for change, and sooner or later they are going to find a way to do it, regardless of how badly the candidates perform.''

HEADLINE: What's Fair for Unions, and the City?

 BODY:
The Dinkins administration is moving toward a settlement with the city unions that New York simply cannot afford. Unless City Hall reconsiders, all New Yorkers - including municipal workers - will suffer the grave and long-range consequences of deepening debt.
Mayor Dinkins is reportedly ready to give non-uniformed workers a 5 percent wage increase, perhaps leading to even higher settlements with other unions. A 5 percent increase, covering inflation, would be reasonable and just in normal times. Fairness and the morale of city workers is always important, as are competitive salaries from the suburbs. But New York City is in a recession. Everybody will have to sacrifice if the city is to remain economically viable. 
The Mayor has budgeted only for a modest 1.5 percent increase in labor costs this fiscal year, with the understanding that a final settlement would go higher. But the city's own budget figures show that a 5 percent settlement would help produce a budget gap of nearly $1 billion in the first year. If tax revenues fall below expectations, the deficit will be higher still.
City officials understand this and have found a way of covering most of the 5 percent increase in the first year. They start with the budgeted 1.5 percent. Then, their idea is to link the rest of the increase to union agreement on reducing the city's contribution to its employee pension funds by about $300 million yearly.
The prudence of that move is not evident. Can the funds afford to lose part of the city's regular contribution in this ragged economy? Moreover, any money saved from the pension fund might be better spent elsewhere, or not only on unions. Since union representatives make up half of the pension boards, they won't approve cuts in the city's contributions unless they benefit.
Even if the pension money becomes available, the city cannot afford a 5 percent increase over two or three years unless it raises taxes significantly or makes dramatic cuts in services. The city just imposed $900 million in new taxes, on top of new and higher state taxes, and is considering imposing a dedicated tax to pay for more police officers. City Hall will have to find more productive strategies than always raising taxes.
To sidestep the issue, officials talk about a one-year contract, instead of the traditional two or three years. That's no answer. It would raise expectations for a better settlement in only a year, and sentence the city to enormous uncertainty. A two-year pact makes more sense. It would provide some stability and, if the economy rebounds, a chance to go back to the table in a relatively short time.
Especially because Mayor Dinkins won office with union support, he has a responsibility to prepare the work force for a settlement below inflation. The private sector has suffered job and business losses. It is not unreasonable to ask the public sector to sacrifice as well. The alternative - an even more wounded economy that could force massive municipal job layoffs - benefits no New Yorker.

HEADLINE: Japan Would Like Some Say for Its Gulf Aid

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''Where's Their Fair Share?'' (editorial, Sept. 6), you criticize Japan for not paying its share of the United States-led Operation Desert Shield. I can understand why some Americans are angry over Japan's apparent vacillation on the American initiative to contain Iraq. But blaming Japan will not bring it to share the open-ended costs of the operation. 
Last month in Japan, I tried to persuade Government officials and politicians, including Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, to show Japan's support by promptly offering Japan's first burden-sharing package. I proposed three core actions: (1) Japan's immediate purchase of 300,000 tons of rice from Texas, Arkansas and other areas (the same amount of rice that the United States used to export to Iraq annually) and its direct shipment by Japanese ships and aircraft to the Persian Gulf together with other supplies for the multinational forces and refugees. (2) Immediate untied economic aid of $2 billion to Egypt, Jordan and Turkey to shore up their resolve. (3) Sending a medical contingent of 100 to assist refugee relief in Jordan.
The politicians saw the wisdom of my package, but the bureaucrats rejected it. There is nothing mysterious about Japanese politics. It is run by bureaucrats, not politicians. However, I was able to expose the inappropriateness of Japanese bureaucrat-led politics when Japan's belated offer of burden sharing met unequivocal disappointment inside and outside Japan. The Japanese have finally begun to debate the dangers of letting myopic bureaucrats chart Japan's course of action in this volatile world.
Misleading and conflicting demands from the United States have not only confused the Japanese Government, but also helped the bureaucrats drag their feet. United States demands that Japan send mine sweepers and soldiers to the Persian Gulf raised the suspicion that the hidden United States intention was to force revision of the Japanese Constitution, which, like the Constitution of West Germany, forbids sending military forces abroad.
The Japanese Constitution may have to be revised to fit the 21st century. However, revision should be carried out after the crisis in the Middle East subsides and be closely linked to possible revisions in United Nations roles in the global and collective security of member nations. New United Nations roles may include Germany and Japan as permanent members of the Security Council. United States demands that Japan increase its cost sharing for United States forces in Japan and buy American military hardware were seen as hasty attempts to exploit events in the Persian Gulf to settle bilateral trade and security issues between the United States and Japan.
If the United States needs the open-ended support of Japan, Germany and other countries, it should consult them on strategy for containing Iraq as a model for a future collective security arrangement under the stronger United Nations mandate. No nation would be totally willing to share in the ever-bulging costs of the United States-led operation unless it is also consulted first on the immediate and larger goals of such operations.
 
YOSHI TSURUMI
Professor of International Business
Baruch College
New York, Sept. 7, 1990

HEADLINE: Textile Bill Helps Workers, and Fair Trade

 BODY:
To the Editor:
America's textile and apparel deficit is a staggering $28 billion. Congress must respond to the human toll resulting from the deficit. Each $1 billion of excess imports over exports has eliminated some 25,000 American jobs. Since 1980, more than 400,000 garment, textile and shoe workers have lost their jobs to imports. Congress is considering a textile, apparel and footwear trade bill, H.R. 4328, to limit the growth of imports. It will aid workers who have been hardest hit, and it should become law. 
The United States garment and textile industry is the most productive in the world. It provides jobs for more than two million workers, including more women and members of minorities than any other United States industry. It contributes more than $50 billion annually to our gross national product and pays billions in Federal, state and local taxes.
Employment in the textile industry, despite its economic record, is at a 50-year low. Imports control 60 percent of the United States textile and apparel market, and footwear imports control 80 percent.
The economic base of New York is being eroded by the loss of its manufacturing industries. Our workers, consumers and communities have been devastated by the uncontrolled flood of imports. Every day, factories close and jobs are permanently lost to unfair competition from countries that pay workers as little as 16 cents a hour, employ child labor and subject workers to unconscionable conditions such as were outlawed here many years ago. A great number of these American workers have few other job options or skills and are forced to go on the public dole to feed their families.
Almost 75 percent of the American public favors legislation to restrict the growth of imports. New Yorkers have never been fooled by the myth of ''lower-priced imports.'' They know that retailers mark up the prices to those of domestic goods and have enjoyed inflated profits.
It is time Congress took a stand in favor of fair trade. The Senate has already passed H.R. 4328 by a 68-32 vote. The House of Representatives will vote shortly. I urge all members of the New York delegation to vote for H.R. 4328 and help their constituents to lead productive, independent working lives.
 
THOMAS VAN ARSDALE
President, New York City Central
Labor Council, A.F.L., C.I.O.
New York, Sept 6, 1990
