HEADLINE: Albany Practices Energy Conservation on State Vehicle Fleet

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As the commissioner with responsibility for New York State's fleet of vehicles and central purchasing program, I was very pleased by your Aug. 30 report that the state would buy 268 cars and buses powered by alternative fuels in the next five years.
Increasing vehicle energy efficiency certainly cannot be overlooked in overall energy conservation. I agree that raising fuel-efficiency standards for the state's vehicle fleet to 40 miles per gallon over the next 10 years is a laudable goal, and we are moving in that direction. However, pressure must also be placed on automobile manufacturers to produce more efficient vehicles and on the Federal Government to raise average fuel economy standards for manufacturers. Our efforts to improve the fuel efficiency of the state's fleet depend on the manufacturers to produce highly fuel-efficient cars for us to purchase. 
We are also taking actions within our control. For example, since the oil embargoes of the 1970's, we have added subcompact sedans and small-sized wagons to our fleet car contracts, discontinuing full-size sedans as a standard option for agency use.
Yes, the present fuel efficiency standard is 29 miles per gallon, but this is an aggregate figure for all types of automobiles and mini-vans. The state fleet vehicle contract for the 1990 model year (also available to local governments and public authorities) includes subcompact and compact vehicles with 34 and 32 miles per gallon ratings respectively. The midsize wagon in the contract has a 30 miles per gallon rating.
We have reduced the size of our passenger fleet by approximately 20 percent since Gov. Mario M. Cuomo called for such a reduction in December 1988. Our energy conservation efforts also include purchasing contracts for rerefined lubricating oil, recapped truck tires and remanufactured automotive parts. These contracts are available to public authorities and local governments, as well as state agencies.
The efforts of manufacturers, government at all levels and those in the forefront of the environmental movement will make possible a cleaner environment less dependent on foreign fuels.
 
JOHN F. HUDACS
Commissioner, New York State
Office of General Services
Albany, Sept. 5, 1990

HEADLINE: OBSERVER;
Just the Fax, Arnold

BYLINE: By Russell Baker

 BODY:
You are in a movie house on the edge of your seat because the Indestructible Thing from Ghastly Galaxy is sneaking up on Arnold Schwarzenegger with a spray gun carrying liquefied muscle-shrinking gas, one drop of which can reduce a weight lifter to a 97-pound weakling faster than you can say Schwarzenegger.
Suddenly the telephone rings in the next seat. ''Hello, this is Jason,'' says your fellow moviegoer, then, ''Jennifer! You got me at the movies, Jen . . .
''No, not Stallone. It's Schwarzenegger, but the special effects aren't so hot. Just that old thing with a guy's brain being squeezed out through his eye sockets. Speaking of Stallone . . . 
''Jen, I know you weren't speaking of Stallone. I was speaking of Stallone. Did you see the new Vanity Fair? The one with Stallone on the cover and the big print saying, 'I want to be Stallone'? Makes him sound just like Greta Garbo. 'I vahnt to be Stallone . . .'
''Who's Greta Garbo? Come on, Jen, nobody's that young. She's the one who said, 'I vahnt to be alone . . .' ''
By now Schwarzenegger has the Indestructible Thing by five of its tentacles and is squeezing its eyeballs out through its spray gun, and you no longer care, do you? You're too busy fighting the urge to squeeze Jason's cellular phone out through his tonsils.
Yes, this scene is fictional, but something very much like it is being played out nowadays in enough movie theaters to create demands for banning cellular phones in movie houses. In California, which is always first with the worst as well as the best of everything American, people are even saying there has to be a law, and you can guess what this will lead to. Yes, a movement. Just what this country needs, right? Another movement. There's no avoiding it once angry movie fans start leaning on governments, movie theaters and Jack Valenti to ban cellular phones from the Bijou.
I know, it's not the Bijou anymore. It's the Plex One, Two, Three, Four And Upwards Through Sixteen, but the ban makes more sense when we imagine it being enforced at a Bijou, because when Americans still went to the Bijou it was to see the movie.
When you go to places called Plex, whether Plex One or Sixteen, you probably ought to expect to have half the audience gassing on the phone. Since the typical Plex's screen isn't much bigger than the typical home TV, the distractions which Americans accept as normal parts of the TV night may seem natural there: going out for beer just as the Indestructible Thing aims its nozzle, working the crossword puzzle, using the phone to tell Jennifer who Greta Garbo was.
Nevertheless, excessively Plexed though America is, there are still real moviegoers - at least in California -who would rather fight than have their Plexes, small and grim though they are, turned into TV rooms.
They can expect angry resistance from telephone addicts. With enough lawyers and lobbyists, the nation's telephoners will have no problem finding a constitutional right to bear telephones wherever the bearing impulse dictates. After all, it's not telephones that disturb moviegoers, it's people using the telephones.
Why punish people who desperately need telephones in their pockets and purses when they go to the movies? What of the typical American investor, so crucial to the nation's economy, who needs up-to-the-second stock-market quotations from Hong Kong, London, Tokyo?
Should he be denied the right to relax for an hour or two in a Plex because purist movie extremists refuse to have Schwarzenegger's big scene spoiled by a call reporting an unparalleled opportunity to make a quick million in Hong Kong?
No wonder America is in danger of losing its Number One standing and becoming Number Three, Four, Five or even - Heaven forbid! - Number Sixteen. That we should ever see the day when movie fanatics trample the constitutional right to bear telephones . . .
But I am carried away in expressing the arguments that are so easily foreseeable in this business, when in fact my sympathies are all on the side of the phone ban.
The history of technological nuisances suggests that before this particular issue is settled, something even nastier than cellular phones will turn up at the Plex. I mean the portable fax.
I hear it already: A gasping Schwarzenegger is being crushed in the coils of an interplanetary robotic boa constrictor when the machine rings in the next seat.
''Jason here, Jennifer. Send all 500 pages. Just fax me at the Plex.''

HEADLINE: Korean Stores Win Restrictions in Boycott

BYLINE: By ARNOLD H. LUBASCH

 BODY:
A unanimous appellate court ruled yesterday that the New York City Police Department must enforce a court order to keep black-led demonstrators at least 50 feet away from two Korean food stores in a tense eight-month dispute in Brooklyn.
At City Hall, Mayor David N. Dinkins and Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown said the police will begin enforcing the court order today. When asked for his reaction to the court ruling, the Mayor said, ''My reaction is not to appeal, but to ask the Police Department to enforce that order.''
He also made it clear that the decision not to enforce the boycott had not been made at City Hall. ''This action, although people may not believe it, was the action of the Police Department,'' he said. 
Picketing of the two Korean-owned stores became a politically sensitive issue, putting pressure on Mayor Dinkins to end it. Commissioner Brown contended that police restraint reduced tensions and that the department should use its discretion in handling demonstrations.
The decision yesterday, by the Appellate Division in Brooklyn, came down strongly on the side of the order restricting the demonstrations, which began after a Haitian woman complained of being attacked by one of the store workers.
''We plan no appeal,'' the City Corporation Counsel, Victor A. Kovner, said after the decision. ''The Police Department has had a full hearing before the Appellate Division and now that the decision has been rendered, the 50-foot order will be enforced.''
Richard A. Izzo, the lawyer for the Korean store owners, said they are happy about the court decision but remain wary because of the past failure to enforce the order. He said he regretted that the store owners had to ''pay the emotional, financial price to see the process through to this point.''
Colin A. Moore, the lawyer for the woman whose complaint prompted the boycott, said he believes that the court decision violates the First Amendment rights of the demonstrators and will provoke more demonstrations ''feeding the flames of the boycott.''
Store employees said demonstrators, sometimes only a few and sometimes dozens, have continued to show up every day at various times to picket in front of the two stores on Church Avenue in the Flatbush section.
The nine-page appellate decision was written by Justice Sybil Hart Kooper, with the concurrence of Justices Richard A. Brown, Stanley Harwood and Vincent R. Balletta Jr. The panel affirmed an order issued on May 10 by Justice Gerald S. Held of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.
The dispute began on Jan. 18, eight months ago today, when Giselaine Felissaint complained that employees of the Family Red Apple, owned by Bong Jae Jang, assaulted her while she was shopping. Her complaint touched off the boycott of the store and a neighboring Korean-owned store, the Park Fruit and Vegetable Market.
''In the months that followed,'' the court said, ''the boycott often became volatile and racially charged in tone, resulting in several instances of violence, as the demonstrators, using bullhorns and positioning themselves in close proximity to the store entrances, exhorted and in certain instances verbally abused shoppers in order to dissuade them from patronizing petitioners' establishments.''
Police officers have been at the site since the boycott began, the appellate court continued, but the store owners have complained that the police presence failed to ''mitigate the intensity and racially strident character of the protests or to prevent the protesters from effectively intimidating their clientele and damaging their businesses.''
On May 10, Justice Held issued a preliminary injunction to bar demonstrators from congregating within 50 feet of the stores. He said he was balancing the constitutional rights of both sides.
The appellate court observed that when the demonstrators refused to comply with the order, the police did not enforce it, but tried instead to persuade the demonstrators to ''moderate their activities.'' On June 26, Justice Held ordered the Police Department to enforce his May 10 injunction.
 
City's Arguments Rejected
In appealing, the city argued that the police are not a party in the civil case, that they are not obligated to enforce court orders in civil cases between private parties and that they have exclusive discretion in law enforcement.
Rejecting the arguments, the Appellate Division said the court's ''power to compel the police to act derives from its inherent authority to interpret the Constitution, which the Police Department is sworn to uphold.''
Although the Police Department has ''a broad measure of discretion'' in tactics, the court said, law-enforcement personnel are not free to ''abdicate'' their responsibilities, regardless of their motives.
The boycott was organized by two small, loosely knit groups called the Flatbush Coalition for Economic Empowerment and the Flatbush Frontline Collective. The Family Red Apple's manager, Pong Ok Jang, has been charged with a misdemeanor involving the assault alleged to have occurred in the store, and has denied the charge.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Police Department will begin enforcing a court order today to keep demonstrators at least 50 feet from two Korean grocery stores on Church Avenue in Brooklyn that have been the target of an eight-month boycott. Protesters stood yesterday behind barricades in front of one store. (Steve Berman for The New York Times) (pg. B3)

HEADLINE: Cuomo Not Being Blamed for State Ills, Poll Finds

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 17

 BODY:
A statewide poll released today indicates that New Yorkers have grave concerns about the direction of the state, but that they are neither holding Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to blame nor turning to his Republican opponent for salvation.
The poll, conducted by the Marist Institute for Public Opinion, shows Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat, with a huge lead over Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican challenger in Mr. Cuomo's bid for a third four-year term. Although the poll indicated increasing concern about crime and the economy, the Governor was regarded favorably by almost two-thirds of those questioned. 
Among registered voters who expressed a preference in the Nov. 6 election, Mr. Cuomo was selected by 60 percent and Mr. Rinfret was chosen by 15 percent. Herbert London, the Conservative Party candidate, followed with 4 percent and Louis P. Wein, the Right to Life Party nominee, had 2 percent.
The poll of 821 registered voters was conducted on Sept. 10-11 and has a margin of error of plus or minus four percentage points.
 
Cuomo Leads Across State
The Governor held a substantial lead over Mr. Rinfret in all regions of the state, with his greatest strength found in New York City. Mr. Rinfret, a New York City economist making his first run for elected office, had the support of only 29 percent of the members of his own party and only 22 percent of those who identified themselves as conservative.
''Rinfret has managed not to even tie down his core base of support, which takes some doing,'' said Lee M. Miringoff, the director of the Marist Institute.
Taken when the state's economy is teetering on the brink of recession and when New York City has rising crime, the poll found that 56 percent of those surveyed thought the state was headed in the wrong direction.
Yet 65 percent said they had a favorable impression of Mr. Cuomo. He was viewed unfavorably by 27 percent. The Governor's favorability rating was down 15 percentage points from this time four years ago, but the number is still considered healthy by political analysts.
Mr. Rinfret, whose name was recognized by 62 percent of those polled, was regarded unfavorably by more people - 24 percent - than he was favorably - 14 percent. The Republican nominee's strategy has focused on attacking Mr. Cuomo's record on taxes and crime, but news coverage has been dominated by a series of political miscues and changing positions.
The poll also showed that only 26 percent of those surveyed had heard of the 21st Century Environmental Quality Bond Act, a nearly $2 billion measure that faces a referendum on Election Day.

HEADLINE: Welfare Rolls Show Increase, First in 7 Years

BYLINE: By DON TERRY

 BODY:
For the first time in seven years, the number of New Yorkers receiving public assistance has increased, another sign of the region's economic downturn, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday in his first annual review of city services.
Mr. Dinkins said the increase, in the fiscal year that ended in June, suggested that ''the economic downturn is hitting New York Citys's poorest residents the hardest.''
Nearly 860,000 residents received public assistance during fiscal 1990, an increase of 5.5 percent from 1989. 
Norman Steisel, the First Deputy Mayor, said the longer assistance rolls would put ''a lot of pressure on our social-services system'' - a system that has been overburdened for years.
 
Gains Amid the Gloom
At a City Hall news conference yesterday, Mr. Dinkins said he was generally satisfied with how the city was being managed but admitted that the 582-page report was filled with more pain and less gain than he would like.
The report said that homicides were up, more residents had AIDS and the streets were dirtier because there were substantially fewer workers to sweep them.
But there were also gains, Mr. Dinkins said.
There was a decline in child abuse cases, there were more homes for the homeless, the Emergency Medical Service improved its response time, and many crimes, including aggravated assault and rape, were down.
But for years the welfare rolls had been declining, and now they are up and that has Mr. Dinkins concerned.
Deputy Commissioner Allen Kraus of the Human Resources Administration, said there were several reasons for the increase.
 
Big Influx of Refugees
There are about 1,000 new cases involving people with AIDS and an equal number of new cases involving people in drug-treatment programs, he said.
An influx of Soviet emigres applying for public assistance accounts for about 4,000 new cases, Mr. Kraus said.
He said that the city had absorbed thousands of Soviet emigres recently but that the majority first received assistance from federally financed organizations and then found jobs and never joined the city's welfare lines.
''It's the biggest influx of refugees in many, many years,'' he said.
Mr. Kraus said that changes in public-assistance regulations had also contributed to the increase but that most of the rise was because ''of a general economic downturn.''
''Mainly it's people losing their jobs,'' Mr. Steisel added.
Mr. Kraus said he did not know how much the increase in welfare was costing the city.
 
Rise in Jail Population
Most of the new public-assistance cases involved single people, but the number of families receiving food stamps rose 6.4 percent, and a record total of 7.7 million meals were served by the Department for Aging, up 3.2 percent. The nonprofit Citymeals on Wheels program delivered 817,172 meals to the homebound, up 9 percent.
The city's jail population also rose, as did the length of time spent behind bars, according to the report.
The average daily census in Department of Correction jails was 19,643 inmates in 1990, up 12.6 percent.
The jail system was at 102.5 percent of capacity, up from 101.7 percent in 1989, and the average length of stay for inmates rose to 47 days.

HEADLINE: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;
Business Degrees Arm Physicians to Face Nonmedical Challenges

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D.

 BODY:
FOR most doctors, the eight years of medical classes and hospital training are long enough. But many doctors are now spending up to two additional years earning degrees in business, administration and management.
Some have gone into public service, like Dr. Woodrow Myers, Health Commissioner for New York City. Others have headed for Wall Street to analyze drug company stocks and to finance new ventures in biotechnology and health-related fields. Still others work for insurance companies.
Most go to work as administrators in hospitals and clinics to deal with increasing government regulations. They also develop marketing strategies to help medical centers attract patients, meet competition from large hospital chains and deal with growing problems of cost control and quality improvement. 
Some private practitioners have enrolled in business and management programs to run their offices more efficiently and profitably.
Dr. Thomas E. Baron, a urologist in Springfield, Ill., said he learned how unprepared doctors were to make many business and management decisions when he became president of a 67-member multi-specialty clinic.
''You can always hire consultants to tell you what to do but the problem is you don't know if they are giving you good advice,'' Dr. Baron said. ''You feel very helpless because you don't have the proper tools to make good decisions.''
Dr. Baron said the M.B.A. degree he earned by studying nights and weekends at the University of Illinois has helped the clinic decide whether to lease, buy or acquire a new piece of medical equipment such as a CAT scan X-ray machine that might become outdated in a few years.
''You want to find out how many patients will need it and what your break-even point will be so you can pay for the equipment without altering your ethics or practice plan,'' Dr. Baron said. ''You don't want to be put in a position where you buy something and say we have got to pay for it so we had better order unnecessary tests on every patient who walks through the door.''
Vast economic, organizational and political changes have eroded the independence the medical profession enjoyed before it was transformed in recent years into a huge industry largely controlled by the government and private health insurance companies.
Business and management degrees are weapons that doctors are using to increase their voice in the budgetary and decision-making process that is increasingly falling to legislators and business executives.
Physicians say that administrators who lack medical training cannot comprehend health care unless they have been up all night with a patient who is critically ill or with a family whose loved one is dying. But a growing number of doctors also realize they need a stronger grounding in business and management practices to work out a budget, to negotiate contracts and to develop a program and see it through.
Doctors once did that. But in recent decades few went into administration, and some were regarded by colleagues as misfits because they did not practice. The attitude was costly to the medical profession.
''Doctors have abdicated their management responsibilities over the last 30 years,'' said Dr. David B. Nash, a physician with a degree in business administration who is a health policy expert at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia.
In an era of unlimited spending for health care, doctors held to what many consider a romanticized view: physicians could concentrate on caring for patients and rely on non-physicians to manage the medical institution.
Then as the government introduced cost-cutting measures and imposed regulations on medicine in the 1980's, Dr. Nash said, ''many hospital boards woke up and said, 'Get us a doctor who understands the regulations.' ''
The demand is likely to increase as more boards of hospitals, universities and companies look for chief executive officers with such skills.
There are no national statistics on the number of doctors who also have degrees in management and business. The American College of Physician Executives, a group based in Tampa, Fla., says its membership of 5,200 has grown by 100 each month since 1987. However, not all of its members have business or management degrees and not all doctors with such training belong.
Some members have spent two years earning M.B.A.'s at leading business schools. Others have earned degrees in hospital and medical administration by taking courses at night and on weekends while they practiced medicine during the day. Some have earned such degrees while on sabbaticals from academic medical centers or in summer programs. A few graduate business schools have programs aimed at doctors. Stanford's Graduate School of Business is recruiting four doctors for a fellowship program sponsored by the John A. Hartford Foundation of New York City and the National Fund for Medical Education in Boston. The program is tailored for doctors who want to devote careers combining clinical practice and management in medical centers.
At the University of Wisconsin at Madison, Dr. David Kindig offers a two-year part-time program in which doctors study at the Wisconsin campus for short periods but do most of the course work at home.
Dr. Myers, the New York City Health Commissioner, said that when he earned an M.B.A. at Stanford, ''everyone told me I was crazy to do it.'' He added, ''Now they think otherwise.''
By learning ''the language of money and many other things that are daunting to a physician,'' Dr. Myers said, ''I was not afraid to step in another world, and when you can walk in two worlds you are better off than in one.''
Dr. Neal H. Cohen said he spent a sabbatical earning a business degree because he did not have the managerial skills he felt he needed as head of an intensive care unit at the University of California at San Francisco.
When he teaches young doctors, Dr. Cohen said, he is now more apt to discuss economic issues involved in the care of patients than he did before his sabbatical.
Dr. Cohen said that in learning a new vocabulary he had become skeptical of administrators who tried to impress health care workers by spewing jargon without understanding the words.
Dr. Cohen, who is an anesthesiologist, said his business training was helpful in representing the university hospital in negotiations with anesthesiologists at Mt. Zion Medical Center when the two hospitals merged.
Nevertheless, Dr. Cohen and others said they were frustrated because their superiors did not know how to use their newly acquired talents effectively.
Dr. Peter D. Mazonson, a physician who also has an M.B.A. degree, said he has became an entrepreneur, working for Genetics and IVF Inc. in Palo Alto, Calif., after interviewing with hospitals that told him he would have to practice for five years before he could also have a significant managerial role.
Yet the same organizations, Dr. Mazonson said, would not make a cardiologist practice general medicine for five years before they let him perform the special heart procedures he was trained to do.
Dr. Mazonson said most of his doctor colleagues also did not understand why he would enjoy the business side of medicine when he had trained to be a clinician. He said he found the challenge of getting the medical and business sides to agree on a venture equal to the satisfaction he derives in managing a sick patient.
Dr. Mazonson recalled meeting a researcher friend who railed about negotiating the financial aspects of becoming a professor at a university medical center.
Dr. Mazonson said he laughed and told his friend: ''Our goals are the same. We both are in business. The only difference is in business the financial aspects are up front and in academic medicine and private practice they often are tacit and covert.''

HEADLINE: Review/Dance;
A Wingding in Lyons a l'Americaine

BYLINE: By ANNA KISSELGOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LYONS, France, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Barely noticed during its first season in 1984, the International Dance Biennial in Lyons has grown into Europe's most ambitious dance festival.
A spectacular start was promised this past weekend when the biennial opened a mammoth and concentrated three-week celebration of American dance featuring 17 companies from the United States. Merce Cunningham's and Martha Graham's companies have already arrived; Cyd Charisse, her famous dancing figure as slim as ever, and Stanley Donen, revered in France as the ultimate musical comedy movie director, were on hand as co-chairmen of the festival's gala tribute to tap dancing and film musicals. They also awarded prizes at a Hollywood theme costume ball in a six-block-long meat market turned movie lot. 
Dream factories are just that, however: life intrudes. The American dancers and the festival as a whole were rocked on Sunday night when Steve Condos, who had performed so brilliantly as a tap virtuoso at Friday's gala, collapsed and died of a heart attack in a dressing room after finishing his solos. The program with veterans like Mr. Condos, who would have been 72 years old on Oct. 12, and new tap stars like the teen-age Savion Glover, was repeated for the third time on Sunday and had been added after the first two performances sold out a major concert hall, the Maurice Ravel auditorium.
Despite efforts backstage by David Parsons, a modern dancer who was on the same bill, to give Mr. Condos mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, he could not be revived. His fellow tap artists, who included the Nicholas Brothers, Jimmy Slyde, Eddie Brown, Lavaughn Robinson, the Jazz Tap Ensemble and Sarah Petronio (an American tap teacher from Paris), agreed with Guy Darmet, the festival's artistic director, to continue the show.
The news of Mr. Condos's death was announced to the audience and later at a reception here for the Graham Company, given by Robert J. Korengold, minister-counsellor for public affairs at the United States Embassy in Paris.
Even before his death, maintaining a festive tone had been something of an effort during the first few days of the biennial, which offered a more light-hearted start in 1986 with its hugely successful theme of ''400 years of French dance.''
Mr. Darmet made a point of emphasizing the toll that AIDS had taken in both French and American dance circles by placing votive candles at the entrance of the theater where the biennial officially opened on Thursday with a low-key performance by Annabelle Gamson and her company. Ms. Gamson is an American specialist in the dances of Isadora Duncan, and since Mr. Darmet has again chosen a historical context for his programming, the Duncan dances were suitable as well as beautiful.
The final piece, nonetheless, was Ms. Gamson's dignified tribute to victims of AIDS, ''Requiem,'' set to Mozart and subtitled, ''In Memory of My Friends and Colleagues.'' Saturday's Hollywood ball, a benefit for Lyons's dance activities, was pervaded by a joyless atmosphere of its own. The event was a grandly produced exercise in excess in the Halle Tony Garnier, a former slaughterhouse used for rock concerts and named after a local architect. Reportedly underwritten at a cost of more than $1.5 million, the ball featured a huge fountain of champagne and make-believe movie lots. A Cleopatra rose, drenched and upright, out of a pool in a mini water ballet at one point and a genteel rumble from ''West Side Story'' worked only as pastiches of a pastiche.
The French have often viewed the American myth through Hollywood's eyes. But the Lyonnais in particular seemed less than familiar with the allusions that the ball's organizers had provided with great care and humor. Of the 2,000 to 3,000 guests, who paid $170 to eat and dance until 7 A.M., most were content to dress in evening wear and few displayed the fantasy of the 1986 ball inspired by Jean Cocteau's film ''Beauty and the Beast.'' This correspondent, who came as Harpo, found only one Groucho in the crowd.
Given the slim competition, Rene Gimbert, an architect in Lyons, easily won first prize for the best costume by disguising himself as Leo the Lion, his head framed in the M-G-M logo.
Ms. Charisse, who needed no disguise as a Hollywood star, awarded him the golden plaque. Like Mr. Donen, she was besieged with existential questions from French reporters about the death of the American musical.
Speaking at a news conference earlier, Mr. Donen blamed economics and the demise of the studio system for the demise of Hollywood musicals. He said he would like to direct a film with Michael Jackson, but was warned he was too old to battle the protective ''army'' surrounding Mr. Jackson. Ms. Charisse said that ''many forget that no one is writing the wonderful music that Richard Rodgers, Irving Berlin and others composed for musicals.''
Asked about the threat of increased censorship of the arts in the United States, she replied: ''In my day, the censors were very strict. But musicals were very popular and perhaps you could get away with a little more in dancing than in a dramatic scene - as long as the neckline was not too low and the leotard not cut too high.''
Freedom within form was the keynote of the night before, with the Jazz Tap Ensemble from Los Angeles (Lynn Dally, Mark Mendonca, Sam Weber and musicians) and the veteran hoofers, who improved through the four-hour program.
The first half of the program was, unfortunately, a mishmash. In addition to Mr. Parsons in a magnificently danced solo, ''Caught,'' there were Kader Belarbi and Wilfried Romoli, Paris Opera Ballet dancers twitching as ''the Blues Brothers''; Lambert Wilson, a French actor singing Bernstein, Porter and Berlin with a British inflection; and Pierre Dulaine and Yvonne Marceau of the American Ballroom Theater.
Emmanuel Krivine conducted the National Orchestra of Lyons in Gershwin's ''American in Paris'' and leaped straight up in the air with feet flexed on the beat.
With its fund-raising and gala activities out of the way, the festival promises to find its true center when it gets down to the business of presenting the major companies and specially commissioned premieres.
Carole Armitage, Lucinda Childs and Ralph Lemon, for instance, will show new works to music by Frank Zappa, choreographed for the Lyons Opera Ballet. Like its controversial start (members of the press corps have likened the ball during the Gulf crisis to waltzing on the eve of World War I), the programming may not please all. Mr. Darmet has covered himself in advance by stating that the companies are his personal choices as reflected in the biennial title, ''An American Story.'' An American story through very French eyes.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The opening of the International Dance Biennial in Lyons, France. Steve Condos, third from left, died of a heart attack soon after. (Monroe Warshaw for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Oil Prices Climb on War Fears

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Crude oil prices climbed yesterday, breaking a seven-year-old record in futures trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Traders cited renewed concerns about a possible war in the Middle East.
Light sweet crude for October delivery rose $1.87 a barrel, or 5.9 percent, to settle at $33.63. The jump followed a $1.72-a-barrel increase last week in the benchmark contract for such oil. 
As the price keeps rising, the Administration is feeling growing pressure from both Congress and within its own ranks to stop resisting proposals to tap the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve. [Page D6.] Alarmed by French Move Traders were alarmed by the announcement on Saturday that France, which had close relations with Iraq through most of the 1980's, would send 4,000 troops to join the multinational force in Saudi Arabia, said Michael Wilner, the president of the Hilltop Trading Company, an independent trading and brokerage firm.
''The overall tone of the political situation is that there's less and less talk of peace,'' said Christian D. Gohler, an energy futures trader and vice president at Merrill Lynch Futures Inc. ''By the end of the week we could certainly see $35, and in a few weeks, potentially we could see $40'' a barrel, he added.
Prices also rose yesterday because speculators became convinced that the market had established a clear pattern of steady increases and rushed to invest, Mr. Wilner said, adding, ''There's nothing that brings participants into the market like a clearly trending market.''
 
Oilfields Could Be Destroyed
A war in the Persian Gulf could destroy production equipment at many oilfields and disrupt the supply of crude. Traders expect prices for the remaining supplies to soar if war breaks out because such a conflict probably would not reduce worldwide demand for oil and the military operations might even increase demand.
Michael W. Libbey, a spokesman for the Chevron Corporation, said the price of oil to make gasoline had risen by 29 cents a gallon since Aug. 1 while the company had raised the wholesale gasoline price that it charges service stations by 19 cents a gallon. ''We cannot absorb higher raw material costs indefinitely,'' he added. ''Eventually, prices will have to rise.''
The main reason prices have not risen further, and might continue to stay below $40, is that oil companies have large stockpiles of crude, Mr. Gohler said. These stocks accumulated during the summer partly because of production problems at refineries, and remained unusually high in the United States in the first week of September, the American Petroleum Institute said last Tuesday.
Trading was frantic in the closing minutes yesterday, with the October contract climbing 55 cents in the last five minutes, said Robert S. Jonke, an energy futures trader at Cargill Investor Services. ''It seemed everyone was scared,'' he added.
Many traders wanted to buy oil yesterday but delayed doing so in hopes that prices would fall, and were forced to buy at the end of the day when the hoped-for decline never came, Mr. Gohler said.
Yesterday's trading reflected a recent tendency of the oil markets to rise early in the week as bullish traders accumulated contracts, and then fall late in the week as traders sold those contracts to avoid holding large positions over the weekend, Mr. Wilner said. ''Two days is a long time if a news item hits and you can't get into the market,'' he added.
 
Rumor Helps Lift Prices
A rumor of pipeline problems that might depress Soviet exports helped push up prices in early trading. The rumor was later denied.
Gasoline for October delivery climbed 1.31 cents, or 1.4 percent, to 91.67 cents a gallon, while the heating oil contract was up 2.52 cents, or 3 percent, to 85.31 cents a gallon.
Product prices showed more modest percentage increases than crude oil prices because they depend more on domestic stockpiles and refinery capacity than crude oil prices, traders said.
The settlement price yesterday of the October contract exceeded the previous record of $32.20 a barrel, set in August 1983, and was the highest level since the Merc began the trading of oil futures contracts on March 30, 1983. But adjusted for inflation, the peak price in August 1983 would correspond to a price of nearly $44 a barrel now.
The benchmark light sweet crude includes 10 grades of oil that are easily refined because they are less dense and have less sulfur than other grades.
Spot and official Government prices for oil before 1983 are not directly comparable because they do not reflect the variety of blends allowed for delivery under the Merc contract, or the types of delivery allowed. Official prices ranged as high as $41 a barrel in 1981, although some countries undercut their posted prices so as to increase sales.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Plan on Lending Is Challenged by Banks

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
An organization representing the world's largest commercial banks openly challenged the International Monetary Fund today on one of the most sensitive points of its global debt strategy, the fund's willingness to lend money to countries behind in interest payments to commercial banks.
Escalating a dispute that will be discussed during next week's joint annual meeting of the I.M.F. and the World Bank, the banking organization, the Institute of International Finance, warned the practice would drive commercial banks from global lending.
The complaint was made in a letter by the institute's managing director, Horst Schulmann, a former senior Finance Ministry official in West Germany, to heads of policy-making committees of the fund and the World Bank, lending organizations charged with sweeping responsibilities in the global economic system.
 
U.S. Stake in Each
The policy committees gather here early next week on the eve of the annual meeting, a stock-taking of world economic issues, which opens on Sept. 25 with an address by President Bush. The bank and fund get their capital from their 151 member governments. The United States has about a 20 percent stake in both organizations. 
''Toleration of arrears to banks erodes standards of conduct and discipline towards all creditors and destroys the confidence of other would-be investors,'' stressed the letter, which was mailed today.
Commercial banks are riled by loans the I.M.F. has made in recent years to countries like the Ivory Coast, Costa Rica, Argentina and Ecuador, while those countries were still running substantial arrears to commercial banks.
 
Brazil Seeks $2 Billion
One possible new case is Brazil, which has paid no interest to commercial banks since last June and which is negotiating a $2 billion I.M.F. loan. Brazil signed a letter with the fund last week, setting forth conditions it would meet to get the money.
Brazil has proposed an escrow account to address the arrears question. But commercial bankers are unhappy with the arrangement because it implies they will receive no interest payments this year.
They also say Brazil, which runs one of the world's largest trade surpluses, projected this year at $15 billion, can afford to pay its arrears. The country is seeking the I.M.F.'s help for a program to curb inflation and reduce other economic imbalances.
The banks want the fund to condition its new assistance on settlement of the commercial interest accounts.
The I.M.F. declined to comment today on Mr. Schulmann's letter. But in earlier cases, its managing director, Michel Camdessus, contended that the agency could not afford to await completion of a package with the banks. His point was that the economic and political momentum for support of an I.M.F. program, usually involving some austerity for the country, would be lost.
Asked about the dispute today, the United States Under Secretary of the Treasury, David C. Mulford, seemed to side with the banks. ''As far as we're concerned, there should be interest payments to the banks,'' he said.
Referring to the Brazilian situation, he said that barring settlement of the arrears issue, ''it is very difficult to see how there could be a credible beginning on the I.M.F. program.'' $604.6 Billion Is Owed According to the institute's numbers, 50 leading borrowing countries will owe $604.6 billion to governments and other so-called official creditors, compared with $577.5 billion to commercial banks.
''Arrears are driving the process,'' Mr. Schulmann said in the letter. From the end of World War II until 1973, governments were the prime source of loans to developing countries. With petrodollars flowing into banks after the oil price increases of the mid-1970's, the commercial banks, anxiously seeking loans, then became the primary source of third world finance.
Now, Mr. Schulmann suggests that with the buildup of arrears, the tide may be turning again.

HEADLINE: FAG Bearings to Acquire Barden Corp. for $131 Million

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The FAG Bearings Corporation, the United States-based subsidiary of a large West German bearings and industrial systems manufacturer, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Barden Corporation for $66.50 a share, or $131.1 million.
The combination of the two reflects the growing consolidation in the bearings industry and the passing into foreign hands of another of the basic industries in the United States.
Barden, which is based in Danbury, Conn., is a maker of bearing products, precision plastic moldings and metal stampings and assemblies. Barden said it had sought to be acquired to survive the growing consolidation and increased competition in the industry. 
On news of the agreement, Barden's stock soared $30 - a 94 percent gain - in over-the-counter trading yesterday, closing at $63.
FAG Bearings is a subsidiary of FAG Kugelfischer Georg Schaefer, a bearing and industrial systems maker based in West Germany. The company last year had sales of $2.8 billion worldwide and of $270 million in North America.
The bearings industry is considered an important industrial component of the manufacturing economy, with about $4 billion in sales in the United States. Bearings, which reduce friction between moving parts, are used in virtually every mechanical product from automobile transmissions to yarn-winding spindles.
 
Bearings Industry Targeted
Analysts said that the American bearings industry had been increasingly a target of foreign companies in recent years to get around dumping cases, which have been brought against a number of foreign manufacturers.
Under the terms of the agreement, FAG Bearings will acquire Barden through a tender offer that will begin no later than Friday.
Stanley Noss, president and chief executive of Barden, said that the acquisition by FAG Bearings was crucial to the long-term survival of Barden. ''We have limited resources and this brings significant additional resources to our company,'' Mr. Noss said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Reports A 0.7% Surge In Inventories

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Business inventories rose seven-tenths of a percent in July, the biggest pileup in a year, and sales fell five-tenths of a percent, the Government said today.
Although the level of inventories is not recessionary, surging stockpiles are a danger sign, said Robert Brusca, the chief financial economist at Nikko Securities International Inc. in New York.
''When inventories rise faster than sales, particularly when sales are in a lagging mode, it's reasonable to assume you're going to see cutbacks in manufacturing output,'' Mr. Brusca said. 
 
'Not a Good Sign'
The Commerce Department said inventories in July totaled a seasonally adjusted $801.94 billion, up from $796.47 billion in June. It was the biggest increase since an eight-tenths of a percent gain in July 1989.
The combination of falling sales and rising inventories produced a 1.49 ratio of inventories to sales, up from 1.47 in June and the same as May's 1.49. The ratio means it would take 1.49 months to exhaust the backlog of goods at the July sales pace.
Mr. Brusca said he does not believe the ratio is dangerously high. ''But with evidence that retail selling is weak and that output is falling, to have inventories building is not a good sign for the economy,'' he said.
The June backlog had declined a revised five-tenths of a percent from the previous month, rather than the four-tenths of a percent originally reported.
Sales in July, meanwhile, dropped to a seasonally adjusted $539.52 billion, from $542.44 billion a month earlier. The June sales were also revised to a weaker six-tenths of a percent gain, rather than the 1 percent advance first reported.
Cynthia Latta, an economist with DRI-McGraw-Hill Inc. in Lexington, Mass., said sales rose only on the retail level in July. But she also noted that retail sales deteriorated in August, when they fell six-tenths of a percent, according to a Commerce Department report last week.
While retail sales increased four-tenths of a percent in July, the gain was less than half of the 1.1 percent jump for the previous month. Retail sales represent about half of all consumer spending, which itself accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
All the major business categories experienced gains in inventories. Manufacturing backlogs were up seven-tenths of a percent, to $373.3 billion. Wholesalers posted a five-tenths of a percent gain, to $192.2 billion. Retailers registered an eight-tenths of a percent advance, to $236.5 billion.
Manufacturing sales, meanwhile, declined eight-tenths of a percent, to $237.5 billion, while wholesalers posted a 1 percent drop, to $152 billion. Retail sales totaled $150 billion.

HEADLINE: Dow Advances by 3.22 in Quiet Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks drifted aimlessly yesterday in quiet trading, with the rising price of crude oil and continued wrangling over the budget keeping many investors out of the market. The Dow Jones industrial average added 3.22, to 2,567.33.
Even program traders - who often provide the only action in an otherwise lethargic market these days -seemed to have little interest. 
Birinyi Associates, which tracks such activity, said that the overall effect of what little interest there was lifted the Dow 6.5 points.
Trading volume slumped to 110.6 million shares. It was the slowest since the day after Labor Day, when volume plunged to 92.9 million.
Declines narrowly outstripped advances, 768 to 681, but while 16 stocks touched new highs, 151 hit new lows. Among them were Disney, Digital Equipment, AMR, Chase Manhattan and Clorox.
But Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist for the Cleveland investment firm of Prescott, Ball & Turben, found the current level ''encouraging.''
He noted that only a month ago, when the Dow slid to a 13-month low of 2,483.42 on Aug. 23, there were 707 new lows and only one new high.
''The new lows are declining in number,'' he said, ''and that's encouraging.''
But he added: ''We have a market with no direction. It's trying to react to a very oversold condition and is being kicked around by confusing signals: the budget talks, the gulf crisis and economic news.''
Speaking of the budget, he said, ''One day it looks like there's a resolution, but it keeps dragging on, not for days but for weeks.''
He said the Persian Gulf crisis was ''adding a lot more dimensions, making it difficult to see the ultimate outcome.''
Figures released yesterday on business inventories were higher than expected, he said, but had only a slight impact on the market.
Stock market data showed that yesterday's advance was fairly widespread in the big stocks and far less so in the smaller ones.
The Dow average of 30 industrial blue-chip stocks rose slightly more than a tenth of 1 percent but the Standard & Poor's index of 500 leading stocks rose three-tenths of 1 percent, to 317.77, up 0.94. The New York Stock Exchange index of common stocks also rose nearly three-tenths of 1 percent, to 174.62, up 0.47.
But the Nasdaq composite, still under pressure from technology stocks, actually fell close to one-tenth of 1 percent while the American Stock Exchange's market value index rose slightly less than a tenth of 1 percent.
Disney, which slid 7 1/4 last week, fell to a new low yesterday of 92 1/2 before bouncing back to 94 3/4, up 1/8.
Nike, the athletic shoe maker, which soared 6 3/4 last week, fell 3, to 72, in heavy trading. At its annual meeting in Portland, Ore., Josie Esquivel, apparel analyst at Shearson Lehman Brothers, said she could not explain the drop. ''Everything they said was great,'' she said. ''I advised my clients to buy.''

HEADLINE: Deposit Fund Bill Advances

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
The House of Representatives voted today to remove the ceiling on premiums the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation charges to insure deposits at banks and savings and loan associations.
The move came amid concern that the economic downturn in some parts of the country may threaten banks and increase pressure on the fund. 
 
Under the bill, backed by the
Bush Administration, the ceiling on what the F.D.I.C. can charge and the annual increase that it can demand from banks and savings and loan associations would be eliminated. It would require a 60-day notice period before the F.D.I.C., which administers the Bank Insurance Fund and the Savings Association Insurance Fund, could raises premiums.
The bill was approved in a voice vote after a brief debate.
Similar legislation is being proposed in the Senate by Donald Riegle, the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Banking Committee.
A savings and loan industry group expressed concern at a potential increase in premiums, but the American Bankers Association supported it.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continuing Its Slide Amid Prospects of Fed Move

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar continued to slide yesterday as traders anticipated a move by the Federal Reserve to push interest rates lower.
The market expected the Fed, facing growing evidence of a slowing economy, to nudge down interest rates when negotiators reach agreement on $50 billion in Federal budget cuts, said Ronald H. Holzer, the vice president and chief dealer with Harris Trust & Company.
Little progress was reported yesterday from the budget talks in Washington, but the market anticipated an eventual agreement. 
The dollar, like all other currencies, is supported by higher interest rates. When traders sense that rates are likely to fall in the United States, they sell dollars.
The American currency has fallen sharply in recent months amid continuing signs of economic weakness. The Persian Gulf crisis has also taken a heavy toll on the dollar.
Mr. Holzer said the dollar also fell on expectations of a widening in the United States trade deficit. The Commerce Department will release July trade figures today, while the Labor Department will announce consumer price figures for August.
The dollar managed to gain slightly against the Japanese yen, rising to 136.55 yen in New York, from 136.45 late on Friday. In Tokyo earlier, the dollar rose to close at 137.00 yen, from 136.55 yen on Friday. Later, in London, it was quoted at 136.47 yen.
But the dollar skidded against the British pound, which has been lifted in part by higher interest rates. Sterling rose to $1.9140 in New York, from $1.8930 late on Friday. In London, the pound rose to $1.9025, from $1.8980 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Friday, included: 1.54865 German marks, down from 1.5695; 1.2768 Swiss francs, down from 1.2990; 5.1870 French francs, down from 5.2565; 1,160.00 Italian lire, down from 1,171.75.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Prices Rise Sharply, But Less Than Jump in Oil

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures prices rose strongly yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York as fears of tightening oil supplies pushed crude oil futures to record highs, spurring some investors to buy gold as a hedge against inflation.
But precious metals analysts said gold's gains were relatively small compared with the advance in energy prices, suggesting that the historical relationship between the two markets had changed.
On other commodity markets, livestock and meat futures rose sharply, soybeans fell and grain futures advanced. 
Gold futures settled $4.20 to $4.30 higher in New York. The spot September contract was at $389.40 an ounce, and the more actively traded contract for delivery in October settled at $390.60 an ounce.
Silver futures ended 1.6 cents to 1.9 cents higher, with the September contract at $4.766 an ounce.
The rally in gold prices extended the run-up to five days since the September contract plunged $10.90 on Sept. 10. The contract has regained all but 10 cents of that amount.
John Jonat, a precious metals trader with Deak International Inc., said traders were focusing less on the inflationary implications of higher oil prices than on a perception that the oil jolt and the military buildup in Saudi Arabia would send the American economy into a recession.
Livestock and meat futures rose sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, led by gains of 2 cents a pound, the limit, in the pork belly market. The increases came amid reports of higher cash hog prices and strong demand for pork products.
Trading volume in the cattle pits is expected to drop in the next two days in anticipation of a monthly Agriculture Department report to be released tomorrow. The report is expected to show a year-to-year increase of about 4 percent in the number of cattle on feedlots in the seven largest producing states.
Live cattle settled 0.30 cent to 0.75 cent higher, with October at 79.37 cents a pound; feeder cattle were 0.25 cent to 0.80 cent higher, with September at 89.17 cents a pound; live hogs were 0.33 cent to 1.13 cents higher, with October at 53 cents a pound, and frozen pork bellies were 2 cents higher across the board, with February at 56.65 cents a pound.
Soybean futures prices fell on the Chicago Board of Trade in a move that some analysts attributed to weather forecasts and slow export demand and others to a technical correction after last week's gains.
Corn and wheat futures rose moderately, reversing the trend of the three previous sessions.
After the close, a weekly Agriculture Department report showed 5 percent of the American corn crop and 1 percent of the soybean crop harvested as of Sunday, slightly behind the usual pace.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Gulf Crisis Stirs Interest In Geology

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
SMALL liberal arts colleges like Wooster, in Wooster, Ohio, report growing student interest in geology as a major, as do engineering schools like the Colorado School of Mines.
This might be an obvious outcome of the Persian Gulf crisis, but the news comes with a twist because there is already a shortage of geologists.
Many geologists work for small environmental companies and local and Federal governments instead of for oil companies. Shortages are certain to increase as the oil industry's need for geologists, especially those with master's degrees, grows. 
Samuel Root, professor of geology at Wooster, said there was increased interest by students in the environment and such problems as water contamination and waste handling, both of which require geologists' skills.
''There is a tremendous increase in the numbers of geologists working on cleanups,'' he said. ''Many recent grads work with small environmental companies. Now, with the oil situation, we will need even more.''
He said that when he first joined the Wooster faculty in 1983 there were 20 to 25 geology majors. ''That dropped to 7 after a couple of years and now it has almost doubled, to 13 this year,'' he said. The liberal arts college has 1,800 students.
''Students find out from friends about good jobs and they get excited and declare a major,'' he said.
Today's geology majors, Dr. Root stressed, ''need a lot more chemistry, several courses in computer science as well as a course in the flow of fluids.''
Professors of geology also need to take more courses, he said, especially refresher courses, which are often given by professional associations.
''I now teach a hydro geology course,'' he said, ''Next week I am going to a three-day program in Sarasota, Fla., given by the National Water Well Association on the subject of contaminated waters and how to clean them up. I will work the material into my course.
''With the gulf crisis and higher oil prices, I think we are looking at a long-term need for more geologists. We will need more research and development in other energy areas -coal production, for example.''
Dr. Root has an academic as well as a corporate background. He received a master's degree from the University of Manitoba, Canada, and holds a doctorate in geology from Ohio State University. For several years, he worked for Exxon, mostly in South America.
''Students often ask what I did working for a large corporation and what interesting assignments I had,'' he said.
Samuel S. Adams, professor of geology and geological engineering at the Colorado School of Mines in Denver, says that students make up their minds about majors while they are in high school and even grade school these days.
''Students catch on quickly to economics and it filters down through high schools,'' he commented. For example, he said that in his department, before retrenchment by the oil companies and low oil prices in the mid-80's, there were 60 geology majors in each of the junior and senior classes, but that there were now about 15 majors in each of the classes. Students generally do not declare majors until the end of their sophomore year in college.
He explained that during that retrenchment, young people in Colorado watched their fathers and other relatives lose jobs in the oil industry, and turned away from the idea of becoming geologists or petroleum engineers.
But he says those effects are starting to wear off. ''Even without the gulf crisis we have turned the corner,'' he said. ''Geology majors now are getting jobs, research funding is moving up, interviews on campus are increasing.''
Mr. Adams explained that environmental issues had ''opened up jobs for our students, all of whom are also trained as engineers.''
''The word is getting around,'' he said. Aided by a grant from Amoco, he had brochures printed explaining careers in geology that his undergraduate students are handing out at Colorado schools. ''They are also giving talks,'' he said. ''Very young people don't want to listen to a gray-haired old fellow like me. My students are almost their peers.''
He likened the differences between geologists and petroleum engineers to the differences between linguistic experts in Romance languages and Slavic languages.
But geologists and petroleum engineers can work together effectively through computer graphics, he explained. ''We geologists are detectives and historians,'' he said. ''I can represent my views graphically by computer and the petroleum engineers can overlay their ideas on it, also graphically.''
Dr. Adams, who received his doctorate from Harvard, explained that cooperation between these professionals had become much easier because of $2 million in computer hardware and professional help provided by the International Business Machines Corporation to establish the I.B.M. Center of Geo-science Computing on campus.

HEADLINE: Amex Plans Expansion to Hawaii

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with an outside group to plan the development of a securities trading operation in Hawaii. The move is intended to give the American Exchange extended hours of trading, as well as increase its reach into Japan and the Pacific Rim.
Exchange officials said that over the next 18 months they hope to prepare a business plan to establish the operation with the Economic Development Corporation of Honolulu, a nonprofit organization leading efforts to set up a financial hub in Hawaii.
In a press briefing announcing the agreement yesterday, James R. Jones, the chairman of the exchange, said it expected to spend as much as $200,000 in the development of the project, much of that going toward travel expenses. 
Mr. Jones said the exchange had undertaken the project in an effort to win more business between the markets in Japan and the United States. Such an effort, he said, might create greater Japanese order flow into this country.
The business day of a trading operation in Hawaii would overlap the trading day in Tokyo, although specific times have not been set.
 
'Keeping Our Options Open'
Mr. Jones added, however, that the exchange had made no determination about how the trading operation would work and did not know if, at this point, it would include a trading floor. ''We haven't precluded anything,'' Mr. Jones said. ''We are keeping our options open.''
Competitors, like the New York Stock Exchange, have responded to the push for global trading by extending their hours, planning to trade 24 hours a day. Mr. Jones said yesterday, however, that he did not believe those efforts would work and that the American exchange needed to establish a presence in another time zone to develop its global business.
''I don't think you are going to see 24-hour trading or even 18-hour trading in only one location,'' Mr. Jones said.
Richard Torrenzano, a senior vice president with the New York exchange, defended its plan for 24-hour trading. The Big Board ''now has in place the most advanced trading and communications technology that can readily process orders from anywhere in the world,'' Mr. Torrenzano said. ''Hawaii is beautiful, but it seems unnecessary and expensive to travel thousands of miles to set up a redundant system when state-of-the-art facilities are in place and operational here today.''
The American Exchange is attempting a project that has proved daunting to other exchanges. In 1988, the Pacific Stock Exchange reached a similar agreement, only to abandon the project after a year of study.
Moreover, the project comes at an extremely difficult time for the American exchange. With volume dwindling, the exchange is not earning as much as it did in the 1980's, and the commitment adds an extra financial burden.
 
'A Great Forward Move'
But one executive with a company listed on the exchange said he hoped the project would go forward. ''We are very excited about what is happening,'' said John Hatsopoulos, chief financial officer of the Thermo Electron Corporation. ''We think it is a great forward move.''
Mr. Hatsopoulos said a large number of investors in his company are Japanese and that the establshment of operations in Hawaii would give them greater ability to trade their shares.
In a separate announcement yesterday, Mr. Jones said the American Exchange was planning to begin trading in put and call options on an index of Japanese stocks. The index, called the Japan Index, measures the aggregate performance of 210 leading stocks on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
Exchange officials said the product was aimed largely at retail investors who wanted to bet on the direction of the Japanese stock market. The exchange already offers warrants based on a Japanese index, and exchange officials said it was not clear what impact the new product would have on the warrants.
The option, which must still be approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission, was designed to compete with futures and options products based on the Tokyo market that are expected to begin trading on Sept. 25.

HEADLINE: Defining Souter, Some;
Undogmatic Middle-of-the-Road Nominee Is Surprise for Liberals and Conservatives

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
In his three days before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Judge David H. Souter defined himself as an undogmatic, middle-of-the-road Supreme Court nominee by what he said and what he chose not to say.
Judge Souter's silence was especially striking on Monday, his final day before the committee, when he passed up many chances to criticize modern Supreme Court decisions as examples of ''judicial activism'' or as undue intrusions into the affairs of other branches of government.
Pressed repeatedly by Senator Charles E. Grassley, an Iowa Republican, and other conservative senators to cite instances when the Supreme Court went too far in the direction of establishing new constitutional rights, Judge Souter appeared unable to think of any.
''Has there never been an occasion where the Court improperly created rights?'' demanded an exasperated Senator Grassley, who had declared earlier that the criminal procedure rulings of the Warren Court provided one example.
Judge Souter responded with a long defense of those rulings, particularly the landmark Miranda decision, which requires the police to inform criminal suspects of their rights. He described the 1966 ruling as a ''pragmatic'' effort by the Supreme Court to protect the pre-existing right against involuntary confessions. 
''Pragmatic'' and ''practical'' appeared to be words of high praise from Judge Souter. ''Courts have an obligation to come down with practical decrees that implement rights,'' he said at another point in his testimony. He offered no criticism, and perhaps even a veiled endorsement, of a recent Supreme Court decision that upheld Federal judges' authority to order local tax increases to pay for remedies for past discrimination.
As the Judiciary Committee moved into the next phase of the confirmation hearing today, taking testimony from supporters and opponents of the nomination, it was apparent that Judge Souter's silence as well as his words had been evaluated very differently by different parts of his audience.
Leaders of the two major abortion rights groups, the National Abortion Rights Action League and Planned Parenthood Federation of America, asked the 14-member panel to vote against confirmation because Judge Souter had failed to commit himself to retaining a constitutional right to abortion.
''After days of evasive answers and filibusters, we know nothing more about Judge Souter's views on reproductive rights than we did before the hearings began,'' Faye Wattleton, Planned Parenthood's president, told the committee. Leaders of several women's rights groups also testified against confirmation.
A number of public officials and lawyers who have worked with Judge Souter testified on his behalf, including prominent Democrats like Griffin B. Bell, a former Federal judge who served as President Jimmy Carter's Attorney General.
 
No Comment From Some Groups
The witness list today was notable for the liberal groups that chose not to testify against Judge Souter. People for the American Way, the Alliance for Justice, the American Civil Liberties Union and the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund decided not to oppose confirmation. All actively opposed the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork in 1987, as did the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, an umbrella group of 180 civil rights organizations. While some conference members oppose Judge Souter's confirmation, the conference as a whole testified to its ''serious concerns'' but did not declare opposition.
Before the hearing began last week, many of these groups were poised to oppose Judge Souter's confirmation. But as several senators said today, the portrait that emerged after three days of testimony was quite different from the outlines discerned from the rather spare record on constitutional issues that the nominee acquired in his years as New Hampshire's Attorney General and as a state court judge. He has served on the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, in Boston, only since late spring.
 
Contrast With Bork
From his first moments before the committee last Thursday, Judge Souter's testimony was strikingly different from Judge Bork's in both tone and substance.
While Judge Bork, whom the Senate ultimately rejected, criticized many modern Supreme Court decisions as illegitimate, Judge Souter took every available opportunity to assure the senators that he supports an active role for the Court in protecting individual rights, particularly in fulfilling the 14th Amendment's guarantee of equal protection. Conservative senators appeared most alarmed by Judge Souter's declaration that a failure by Congress to carry out its obligations under the 14th Amendment creates a ''vacuum'' in which the Court has a responsibility to act.
Judge Bork said the Constitution did not encompass a right to privacy or other rights not spelled out in the text. Judge Souter said he accepted the right to privacy as ''fundamental,'' at least in the context of protecting a married couple's right to use birth control. He said constitutional interpretation required a search for the document's ''meaning'' and ''principles'' rather than for the specific intent of the Constitution's 18th-century framers.
Judge Souter also said he saw a continuing need for affirmative action and indicated his support for the Supreme Court decision last June that upheld Congress's authority to design special economic opportunities for blacks and other racial minorities. That 5-to-4 decision was written by Justice William J. Brennan Jr., whom Judge Souter would succeed.
 
Pleasant Surprise for Liberals
Liberal senators and interest groups were pleasantly surprised by these statements. But they remained wary because much of Judge Souter's testimony was so general that it remained impossible to predict his vote in particular cases.
His comments on affirmative action did not indicate how he would rule on programs outside the Congressional context that award special benefits to members of racial minorities who have not themselves been victims of proven acts of discrimination.
His cautious comments on the right to privacy steered clear of any commitment to support the continued validity of Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision that found a woman's choice to terminate a pregnancy to be an aspect of the the fundamental right to privacy.
He said he supported the result in Griswold v. Connecticut, the 1965 birth control case that established a fundamental right to privacy in the context of marriage. He declined to say whether he thought that unmarried couples had the same fundamental right to privacy for their reproductive decisions, or whether the Court had properly extended the right to include abortion.
 
Attitudes on Precedent
Those searching the hearing record for tea leaves on the future of Roe v. Wade have other comments to consider: Judge Souter's views on what weight to give to precedent. He said the rule that the Court should ordinarily adhere to its precedents ''is a bedrock necessity if we are going to have in our judicial systems anything that can be called the rule of law.''
On the New Hampshire Supreme Court, he said, he had voted to uphold precedents with which he disagreed. He said one factor supporting adherence to precedent was ''whether private citizens in their lives have relied upon it in their own planning to such a degree that, in fact, there would be a great hardship in overruling it now.''
On the other hand, he said, a precedent merited less support when ''the prior case has simply been eroded, chipped away.''
If there is a Supreme Court decision that meets each of those considerations, it is Roe v. Wade.

They asked that the Supreme Court nomination of Judge David H. Souter be rejected. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times) (pg. A24)
