HEADLINE: Atlanta Selected Over Athens for 1996 Olympics

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 18

 BODY:
With a powerful display of personal lobbying and financial clout, Atlanta today won the right to hold the 1996 Summer Olympic Games, turning back a strong sentimental appeal by Athens to become the site for the 100th anniversary of the first modern Olympic Games.
The dramatic decision by the International Olympic Committee, announced tonight after five rounds of secret balloting, brings the summer Olympics back to the United States only 12 years after the Games were held in Los Angeles.
[There was jubilation in Atlanta while Greeks expressed shock and anger. Pages B9 and B10.]
Atlanta had fashioned a proposal to spend about $1.2 billion in private funds to hold the Games, with the expectation of generating about $1.4 billion in revenues from television broadcast rights, ($549 million) commercial sponsorships ($331 million), tickets ($337 million) and other promotions. 
But to the 300 delirious Georgians in the official delegation here, the Olympics' appeal was less in the profits, which officials said would be used exclusively to fund sports programs, than in the opportunity to display Atlanta as a symbol of racial tolerance and economic progress in the new South.
''I've never felt more elated in my entire life,'' declared Mayor Maynard Jackson in between rounds of embracing and crying with other delegates. ''I felt like an exclamation point has just been laid down in the life of our city.''
Members of the I.O.C. said afterward that Atlanta won the Games - to be held from July 20 to Aug.4 - because it offered excellent facilities in a secure environment and could guarantee large television revenues, matching if not surpassing the overwhelming financial success of the Los Angeles Olympics.
Atlanta brought computerized graphics and videos and a delegation of 300 people as part of its $7 million drive, perhaps the most elaborate and expensive bid in history. Also shown to the Olympic committee this morning was a special appeal for support by President Bush.
 
Young's Role Called Critical
But a surprising and crucial factor also appeared to be the work of Andrew Young, the former Mayor of Atlanta, who had lobbied hard among African, Middle Eastern and Asian countries based on his contacts as a former chief delegate to the United Nations in the Carter Administration.
''Without Andy Young, Atlanta could not have made it,'' said Jean-Claude Ganga, a committee member from the Congo who is also president of the Association of National Olympic Committees of Africa, a group Mr. Young addressed last December.
''We know Andy Young as a leader of black people in America, a civil rights leader and an associate of Martin Luther King,'' Mr. Ganga added. ''When he visited my country to push for Atlanta, he was cheered by crowds like some sort of a chief. He is a hero in my country.'' Athens Is Runner-Up The final vote of the I.O.C. was 51 for Atlanta and 35 for Athens. In each of four earlier tallies, the city with the fewest votes was eliminated and another balloting took place. First to be dropped was Belgrade, Yugoslavia, followed by Manchester, England, Melbourne, Australia, and then Toronto.
Until the end, many people thought Athens had the best chance. Its spirited drive was backed by Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis and other leading figures, plus endless recorded crescendos from Vangelis Papathanassiou, the Oscar-winning composer of the score from the movie ''Chariots of Fire.''
In Greece's favor was the fact that Athens had been the site of the first modern Olympics in 1896, when the Games were reborn in their place of origin under the leadership of the French baron, Pierre de Coubertin.
But Athens was hobbled by the perception that it was not equal to the task of coping with the modern and risk-prone extravaganza that the Olympics have become.
Its bid appeared to fall victim to an image of political instability, potential security problems, air pollution, traffic congestion and the fact that it would have to spend about $3 billion to improve its infrastructure of airports, roads, rail lines and other amenities.
There were also signs of some resentment over Athens's demanding that it be named as the site of the Olympics because of its ''historical right due to its history,'' in the words of Spyros Metaxa, a businessman who is president of the Athens Olympic Bid Committee.
 
Geography Hampers Melbourne
As predicted earlier by many Olympic officials, the bids with the least support were those of Belgrade and Manchester, the two cities eliminated first. Melbourne offered itself as a city with experience, having put on the 1956 Games, plus enormous enthusiasm from the Australians.
The city's theme was ''It's time for another continent,'' designed to appeal to the delegates' sense of fairness after decades of holding the Olympics in Europe, Asia and North America. But Melbourne's distance from other places turned out to be one of its biggest handicaps.
Toronto also brought huge enthusiasm, Olympic officials said, with promises to build a waterfront aquatic center and other facilities. A domed stadium was completed last year. But when Toronto failed on the fourth ballot, its supporters appeared mostly to go to Atlanta as the other city in North America.
One revealing aspect of the lobbying by Toronto and Melbourne was that the two cities emphasized that they had large communities of people of Asian and African extraction giving them an air of multiracial identity.
Their presentations stressing this theme appeared to underscore the sensitivity by the Olympic movement in putting on games in rich, prosperous countries of the West in which many athletes from poor countries in the developing world often excel.
 
Human Rights Theme
Mr. Young, who acted as chairman of the Atlanta organizing committee, said he sought to emphasize this theme by noting, for instance, that ''We Shall Overcome'' is now a popular anthem in Africa and elsewhere, although it began as a Georgia Baptist hymn adopted by the American civil rights movement.
''The human rights angle of the Olympic movement is something we really worked on,'' he said. ''The fact is, at least half the people of our city are of African descent, so when African delegates came and walked down the street, they saw people who looked like back home.''
Aside from fears about crime in Atlanta, the biggest obstacle Atlanta had to overcome, said William Porter Payne, president of the organizing committee, was invidious comparisons to Los Angeles. Some Olympic officials, while admiring the enterprise in those games, found the commercialization distasteful.
''The Atlanta Games will not be about money,'' Mr. Payne said he repeated again and again. ''They will not be about sponsorship. They will be about people. We have tried to eliminate the perception that Atlanta will be making a lot of money.''
He added that Atlanta would be much more low key about many aspects of commercialization than Los Angeles, and that its profits would be more limited, but he declined to provide details.
Atlanta began its preparations in early 1987 and then proceeded to win unanimous support from its City Council and from the Georgia State Legislature, a factor that also seemed to impress the delegates, especially after a group of Canadian dissidents demonstrated here against the Toronto bid.
In the course of its campaign, Atlanta brought more than 70 of the Olympic Committee members for tours of the city and held numerous sporting events of its own to raise money and enthusiasm.

HEADLINE: New York to Expand Putting the Homeless Into Welfare Hotels

BYLINE: By THOMAS MORGAN

 BODY:
Reversing a two-year effort to move homeless families out of run-down welfare hotels, New York City officials said yesterday that a sharp rise in the number of homeless people would force them to move many more of the homeless into the hotels.
The city said in papers filed yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan that 2,228 families came to welfare offices needing apartments in July and August, 27 percent more than in the same period last year. The Legal Aid Society had gone to the court in March seeking to force the city to stop placing homeless families in welfare hotels.
In court yesterday, the city asked to be released from an agreement to move all the homeless families out of the hotels by July 31 of this year. The city filed its motion to answer complaints by Legal Aid lawyers and advocates for the homeless that it had failed to live up to the agreement, which was signed on June 1. 
City officials yesterday portrayed the increase in the number of homeless families seeking apartments as a response not to the weakening local economy, which has contributed to the first rise in seven years in the number of families on public assistance, but to the city's recent success in providing low-cost housing to the poor. They said families not listed as homeless because they were living with relatives came forward for the first time because they had heard that apartments were now available.
''We had been moving families out of homeless shelters and hotels at such a high rate that we think it became fairly well known that this was a good time to come into the system to get an apartment,'' said Jeffrey Carples, executive deputy commissioner the city's Human Resources Administration, the agency that runs the city welfare system. ''We began to create our own demand.''
But Steven Banks, a lawyer with the Legal Aid Society's Homeless Family Rights Project, said: ''The reason why so many families are seeking shelter is because of the city's failure to provide sufficient permanent housing. If there was a comprehensive permanent housing program in this city, there would be no need for welfare hotels now.''
At the peak of the homeless crisis in 1987, more than 3,600 families were living in 62 welfare hotels, many of which were populated by drug addicts, prostitutes and child abusers.
 
High Cost Under Criticism
The use of the hotels had been criticized by housing advocates and others for several years, in part because the city spent an average of $1,800 a family each month to house the homeless in welfare hotels. The city now spends $2,300 a month for each family in welfare hotels, Mr. Carples said.
Mr. Banks said the Legal Aid Society would seek to hold the city to its promise to move the homeless families out of the hotels. ''The city plan was to have 3,500 lawful shelter units in place by the summer and to produce permanent housing to end the use of welfare hotels,'' he said. ''The numbers of families in the system needing housing are still less than 3,500 units of lawful housing agreed to.''
Since January, city officials said, they have placed 4,158 families in apartments in public housing projects and apartments renovated by the city's Housing Preservation and Development Department. In addition, more than 2,370 families have been placed since January in what officials call transitional housing, with kitchenettes and private bathrooms.
But 428 families are now being kept in five commercial hotels in Manhattan, Queens and Brooklyn in direct violation of the court order.
Mr. Carples played down the effect of the economy in driving families to seek city housing. But Mayor David N. Dinkins said on Monday that the economic downturn had hit the city's poorest residents the hardest. He announced then that the city's welfare rolls had increased for the first time in seven years, rising 5.5 percent in the 1990 fiscal year from the year before.
Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional Commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics said that while the economy was not the biggest factor in creating homelessness, a downturn in the economy could force people living on the margin into homelessness.
''Once they get an economic shock,'' he said, ''they find it difficult to recover from it.''
Often, the city welfare agency is an unknowing player in creating family chaos, which sometimes leads to homelessness. When welfare checks are cut off for administrative reasons, like missed appointments with social workers, families may hover at the brink of homelessness.
 
No More Welfare Checks
Calixta Velez, who lives in a decrepit apartment building in East Harlem, worries that she might be evicted soon because the city canceled her welfare checks, food stamps and housing subsidy when she missed an interview earlier this year.
Mrs. Velez qualified for public assistance and rent subsidies for herself, a mentally retarded son and four other children. But she speaks little English and finds welfare regulations hard to understand. Despite her appeals through social workers from a Catholic agency, she has been unable to get the city to restore the welfare payments or to pay rental subsidies from February to September.
Already her landlord has sent a letter threathening to evict her for nonpayment of rent since February.
''I'm afraid I'm going to be thrown out on the streets,'' she said through an interpreter. ''I worry about losing the apartment. I have nowhere else to go.''
Advocates for homeless families have long argued that the city's plan to provide housing for homeless families only accounted for those families already in shelters. A continuing problem, they say, is a lack of city planning for the more than 100,000 families that city officials agree live doubled up with friends and relatives.
Mr. Carples said the city would respond to future housing needs for low-income families if, through negotiations with the state, it could adopt a $30 million proposal to keep families from joining the ranks of the homeless.
 
Legal Services
That proposal includes providing legal services to families facing evictions to stop such actions, payment of rent arrears, and more social-service workers in the housing courts to help families understand rent regulations and alternatives to eviction.
But only $12.5 million has been allocated for the program in the city's capital budget, Mr. Carples said.
City officials said that if the demand for housing had matched the historical demand, the city would have met its goal of vacating the commercial hotels and would have been ''in compliance with the stipulation.''
In June, for example, 947 homeless families applied for housing, up from 890 in June 1989. The number grew to 1,057 families in July 1990, compared with 872 a year ago.

GRAPHIC: Photo: ''I'm afraid I'm going to be thrown out on the streets,'' said Calixta Velez, right, shown with her family at their East Harlem apartment. They face homelessness because her welfare checks and other benefits were canceled after she missed one of the periodic interviews the city requires. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times) (pg. B4)

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Jordan Seems to Have Quit Shipping Food to the Iraqis

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RUWEISHID, Jordan, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Jordan appears to have stopped its shipments of food and other goods to Iraq, after more than a month of argument and delay.
Jordan, Iraq's closest ally, came under strong criticism from the United States and other countries last month for not strictly adhering to the United Nations sanctions against Iraq.
Last month 200 trucks a day were rolling across the border toward Baghdad, carrying tomatoes, oranges, rice, cotton, sheet metal and a wide range of other items.
Ten days ago visitors to Ruweishid reported that shipments were still proceeding across, though in smaller numbers. But here at the border today, nothing was being allowed to pass into Iraq, though several truckers were trying. 
 
No Trucks In or Out
''They're not giving permits,'' complained one Jordanian trucker, standing beside a flatbed loaded with cotton. ''Customs won't allow it past.'' ''No, no, no,'' said another trucker standing nearby. ''Nobody's being allowed to go.''
In his office a few yards away, Nabil Hindawi, acting director of the Jordanian Customs office here, shook his head as he said: ''Trucks are not coming in or going out. That is the policy.''
There is no chance that trucks are sneaking in through some other route, either. The landscape here is inhospitable, rock-strewn desert. There is no other road, and off-road travel is impossible. Neither of Jordan's Arab neighbors, Syria and Saudia Arabia, would allow passage through their territory, since those countries are arrayed against Iraq.
Today the Ruweishid customs yard was filled with dozens of empty, flatbed trucks. Many suddenly unemployed Jordanian truck drivers were trying to earn a few dinars by carrying furniture and household goods for the steady stream of Kuwaiti refugees from Iraq, heading toward Amman.
''I used to make 1,000 dinars for a run to Baghdad,'' said Farid Ali, a trucker who was standing, arms crossed, next to his empty flatbed. A dinar is worth about $1.50.
''Now I stand here all day and just hope for a run with furniture for 200 dinars.''
 
Oil Tankers Still Roll
While Jordanian shipments to Baghdad appear to have stopped, the long, desolate desert highway was crowded today with tankers carrying crude oil from Iraq to refineries in Jordan, although the United Nations embargo precludes all trade with Baghdad.
''The only thing between us and Iraq now is the oil,'' a senior Government official said. ''We don't have any trucks going to Iraq, none at all.''
Another senior official added: ''We get 80 percent of our oil from Iraq. We can't cut that off until someone is willing to replace the supply. So far no one has offered.''
Almost as soon as the United Nations imposed the trade sanctions on Iraq last month, Jordan said it would comply but added it needed time to study the language to see what kind of trade with Iraq, if any, would be allowed. In the meantime, trucks continued rolling. Many carried goods arriving at the Jordanian port of Aqaba, and others ferried Jordanian produce and other locally produced goods to Baghdad.
The United States openly complained, and President Bush specifically criticized Jordan for continuing to import Iraqi goods through Aqaba.
Now, thanks in part to the United States naval blockade in the Red Sea, the port at Aqaba is virtually closed. As far as can be told, local goods are not being driven to Iraq either. As a result, 80 percent of the nation's 11,000-vehicle truck fleet is now idle, sad Bassam E. Kakish, chairman of the Aqaba regional authority.
 
'This Is a Genuine Crisis'
As Jordanian officials say they have cut off their exports to Iraq, they are also making fresh pleas for international aid to compensate them for losses. Iraq was by far Jordan's largest trading partner.
''You are talking about an integrated economy between Iraq, Kuwait and Jordan, and 800,000 of our people also worked in Iraq and Kuwait,'' said a senior aide in the Royal Palace. ''This is a genuine crisis.''
The apparent end of the Jordanian shipments to Iraq has been gradual. Three weeks ago, ''we couldn't cross the road, there were so many trucks,'' said Atef Atta, a mechanic, as he and his brother sat behind a greasy desk in their tiny garage in Azraq, looking out at the highway to Baghdad just 10 yards away. ''Now maybe we see three or four,'' he said. And judging from what truckers said at the border, even those are not being allowed to pass.
''We used to close at 8 or 9 at night,'' Mr. Atta added. ''Now, with the business falling off, sometimes we close at 1 P.M.''
Iraqis trying to ferry goods into Jordan do not appear to be having any better luck. The United Nations sanctions forbid both imports to Iraq and exports from the country as well.
An Iraqi trucker who would give his name only as Mahmoud sat in the incoming truck yard today and complained that he had been trapped, sleeping in his truck, for almost 10 days. The flatbed was loaded with fertilizer from Iraq.
''I can't go in,'' the Iraqi said, throwing up his hands. ''They won't give me permits. They won't even start the procedures. And I can't get permits to go back either. They say the load has already been imported, so it can't go back.''
Asked what he would do, the man shook his head and said, ''I'm just waiting for God to show his mercy.''

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: THE GENERAL'S ERROR;
Others Have Said as Much as Dugan But 'on Background,' Not on Record

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
In the final analysis, the problem wasn't really what Gen. Michael J. Dugan said that hurt him so much.
What cost the former Air Force Chief of Staff his job, Bush Administration officials and Pentagon-watchers on Capitol Hill agreed today, was the timing of his speculation on American contingency plans in the Middle East, how he went about it and who he was.
He was unguarded, speaking on the record, meaning that he could be quoted by name; he spoke at a moment when the diplomatic situation was delicately poised, and he made it sound as if generals, not civilians, decided such matters.
''In this town, in a crisis, you talk about options, not about decisions, unless you're the President,'' a White House aide said. ''I guess nobody told this guy Dugan about that.'' 
 
Undoubtedly an Option
No one in official Washington, or in Baghdad or Riyadh, for that matter, doubts that an air attack on the Iraqi capital is one option under serious consideration as President Bush ponders how he might force President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to pull his troops out of Kuwait if United Nations economic sanctions fail to do the job.
Military analysts in Washington think tanks, members of Congress knowledgeable about such matters and even a few Pentagon experts have been quite willing, in recent days, to discuss such an attack and evaluate its pros and cons. In fact, one of the commonplaces of discussion here has been the observation that it would be a mistake to engage in a war of attrition on the ground with the million-man Iraqi Army, and that air power would therefore have to carry a heavy burden.
For example, Senator John McCain of Arizona, a Republican, said last week that ''the very worst strategy we could follow would be a land battle in which we trade American bodies for Iraqi bodies'' and advocated the use of air and naval power rather than infantry, at least in the early stages of any conflict.
 
'On Background' Comments
A variety of Pentagon planners and other military authorities surveyed the week before said that Mr. Bush would inevitably seek to exploit vastly superior American technology, including lasers and infrared equipment as well as air power in general, to overcome the marked Iraqi advantage in numbers and familiarity with combat terrain and climate. Several of them mentioned the possibility of trying to kill or even kidnap Saddam Hussein.
But saying such things ''on background'' - not for attribution to any individual - is not the same as a member of the Joint Chiefs saying flatly that they have adopted a plan to ''decapitate'' the senior Iraqi leadership by making President Hussein and his inner circle the primary targets, as General Dugan did. And it is not the same as declaring that ''the cutting edge would be in downtown Baghdad.''
It may well be that the general was engaged in a bit of truth-telling, drawing back the curtain for a few moments on Pentagon contingency planning. It may be literally true that the Joint Chiefs of Staff believe, as he said, that only killing Mr. Hussein would do the job - although there were plenty of senior people in the Administration and more outside it who were willing to say today, on background of course, that they did not believe the Joint Chiefs held any such view and that if they did, it was thoroughly wrongheaded.
But nearly all Presidents, not just the security-conscious Mr. Bush, dislike the publicizing of staff recommendations, because that cuts down their freedom of action - especially on life-and-death matters of military tactics.
 
It Might Not Work
What is more, there are many reasons why the President might choose to disregard any advice from the Joint Chiefs to put ''the cutting edge,'' in the form of heavy bombardment, in downtown Baghdad. To cite just three: It might not work, any more than similar attacks on downtown Tripoli or downtown Hanoi forced Libya or North Vietnam to reverse their policies; it might be unacceptable to European allies in the campaign to isolate Iraq, such as France and the Soviet Union, and it would almost certainly inflame Arab public opinion, if not push Egypt and Syria back into Mr. Hussein's embrace.
Judgments on such political and diplomatic matters have to be mixed, in any ultimate decision, with whatever military judgments reach a President.
General Dugan may have been attempting a pre-emptive strike, trying to state the Air Force case in such a way that Mr. Bush would find it hard to ignore. But that cannot be done directly; the accepted Washington procedure is for a general to put ideas into the ear of a sympathetic columnist or commentator, or to ask a friendly Senator or Representative to make the public argument.
Some officers at the Pentagon were reported to have said that they would feel more inhibited about talking to reporters as a result of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's decision to dismiss General Dugan. But in fact, it is hard to imagine that there are many officers with significant experience, either in Washington or in the field, who would have taken it upon themselves, even before the Dugan episode, to state publicly what course of action the Joint Chiefs were recommending.
Quite apart from angering Presidents, quite apart from diplomatic considerations, such disclosures could help actual or potential enemies, which is not what military officers ordinarily seek to do. General Dugan, who also made public Air Force strength figures in the Persian Gulf that the Pentagon had been guarding closely, apparently thought the security risk small.
He had few defenders today at the Pentagon or elsewhere in Washington.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Iran, Holding Key, Hints at Hostage Release

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Iraq's invasion of Kuwait may have indirectly improved the chances of freeing American hostages long held in Lebanon, Administration officials said today.
In the confusion of the invasion, a group of prisoners whose fate is tied to that of the hostages were freed and are now in the hands of the Iranian authorities, the officials said. Iran has considerable influence over the Shiite Muslim factions linked to the fundamentalist Party of God, which holds most of the 12 Western hostages in Lebanon.
In 1983, 17 men were imprisoned in Kuwait for conducting a terrorist campaign against the American and French embassies and public buildings and oil installations. The primary condition for the release of some of the Western hostages was freedom for these prisoners, Iraqis who belong to Al Dawa, or The Call, a radical Shiite Muslim group outlawed by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq that was dedicated to exporting Iran's revolution. 
 
Iranian Predicts a Release
The first official hint of a possible hostage release came in statements today by Javad Mansoori, Iran's Ambassador to Pakistan, who said that some hostages may be freed in the next few days. ''The number and when is not known,'' Mr. Mansoori said at a news conference in Islamabad, The Associated Press reported. The Ambassador added that Iran had received ''promises'' from pro-Iranian groups holding the hostages in Lebanon.
In Damascus, President Hafez al-Assad of Syria announced that he will visit Teheran next week, where the fate of the hostages is expected to be one of the main topics. Syria, Iran's main Arab ally and the primary power broker in Lebanon, has helped bring about earlier hostage releases.
Islamic Holy War, a pro-Iranian group, has repeatedy demanded the release of the prisoners as a condition for freeing its hostages, Terry A. Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, and Thomas Sutherland, dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut, who have both been held since 1985. The leader of Islamic Holy War, Imad Mugniyah, is the brother-in-law of one of the prisoners.
''Iran has always had some ability to influence the hostage takers, but now their influence is greatly enhanced,'' said Zalmay Khalilzad, a senior analyst at the RAND Corporation and a former State Department official who followed Iran and Iraq.
The Kuwaiti Government, with strong United States support, consistently refused to bargain the prisoners for the hostages. But Iran has varying degrees of leverage over the loosely knit terrorist groups known collectively as the Party of God that hold six Americans, three Britons, two West Germans and an Italian.
The Teheran Government has occasionally used its influence to win the release of Western hostages, and President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran has indicated that all foreign hostages in Lebanon should be freed.
When Kuwait was invaded, 15 of the Dawa prisoners were still being held and 2 had been released after serving five-year sentences.
Administration officials do not agree on how the prisoners fell into Iranian hands. Some say that during the invasion the 15 prisoners escaped from the high-security Salibeyeh Prison. Most made their way to Iran, although some are believed to have fled elsewhere, probably to Lebanon, these officials said. Other officials say the prisoners were seized by Iraqi troops, taken to Baghdad and handed over to Iran to win concessions from Teheran. Baghdad has reportedly been trying to induce Teheran to help break the economic embargo imposed on Iraq after the invasion of Kuwait.
The release of the American hostages is of deep concern to the Bush Administration. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told reporters that he discussed the issue in his meeting last week with President Assad of Syria.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Security Council's Military Panel Reviews Naval Efforts to Enforce Trade Embargo

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 18

 BODY:
The military arm of the United Nations Security Council met informally today to review naval efforts to enforce the Council's trade embargo against Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait.
Their meeting came as the five permanent members of the Council moved toward agreement on a new plan to tighten the embargo.
Their emerging new resolution would impose an air transport embargo on Iraq and occupied Kuwait. It also would provide for the detention of Iraqi merchant shipping and tighten the freeze on Iraqi and Kuwaiti financial assets held abroad. 
The resolution also would threaten new trade sanctions against countries that violated the current embargo and encourage countries to reduce the size of Iraqi diplomatic missions.
The representatives of two permanent members predicted today that the full Security Council would approve the resolution by the end of the week.
Today's meeting of the Security Council's Military Staff Committee -its second on the Iraq crisis after a long period of cold-war dormancy - followed a meeting in Bahrain last weekend between senior naval officers from the countries deploying warships in the Persian Gulf. At the meeting, they discussed plans to coordinate patrols and other enforcement activities, Western diplomats said.
Today's meeting brought together military officers and their political advisers from Britain, France, China, the United States and the Soviet Union, five permanent Council members, which have a veto over decisions. All but China have deployed naval forces in the gulf area. The United States military representative was Col. Robert R. Anderson, military adviser at the United States Mission.
Western diplomats say such meetings satisfy a Soviet demand that the Military Staff Committee become more involved in coordinating enforcement action. They said the meetings also serve as a reminder that the gulf forces are acting in support of a United Nations decision.
 
Role of U.N. Military Committee
Under the United Nations Charter, the Military Staff Committee, made up of the Chiefs of Staff of the five permanent Security Council members, is supposed to direct military operations mounted by the Council.
Cold-war tensions kept the committee paralyzed until recently, when the Soviet Union suggested reviving it. The United States agreed, in part at least, to help secure Moscow's backing for the Council's embargo against Iraq and Kuwait, diplomats say.
China, the most reluctant of the five to consider military action against Iraq, has insisted that the committee discuss only operations approved by the Security Council. So the five agreed that the committee would discuss only naval activities in the gulf.
Details of the planned air embargo are still being worked, but officials say it would be aimed primarily at civilian cargo aircraft and not at regular passenger planes.
Under the plan, nearby countries would close their airspace to cargo flights heading for Iraq or Iraqi-occupied Kuwait unless they agreed to be inspected. The Security Council cannot authorize shooting down planes caught violating sanctions, since this is already prohibited by international law.
Diplomats say that no country that is likely to try to break the embargo has sufficient aircraft to be very successful at it. Civilian aircraft operators would find it impossible to insure planes flying to Iraq or Kuwait or get them refueled at foreign airports.
Today the Red Cross said that it would postpone an offer to dispatch $100,000 in emergency medical supplies to Iraq and Kuwait after a vigorous United States protest that it would violate United Nations sanctions.
The United States told the Geneva-based League of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies last week that it lacked evidence that these supplies were needed and that its plans for monitoring their distribution did not meet Security Council guidelines.
But Jose Aponte, Director of International Services for the American Red Cross, said today that the League would now await an assessment of Iraq's medical needs from Red Cross officials in Baghdad before deciding whether to send the supplies.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Embargo May Lead To Hussein's Ouster, C.I.A Director Says

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES

 BODY:
The Director of Central Intelligence said last night that intelligence experts expected dissatisfaction with Saddam Hussein's rule to grow among the Iraqi leader's closest associates as a global trade embargo began to crimp that nation's economy seriously.
The Director, William H. Webster, said experts believed that those associates would ''present the greatest threat'' to President Hussein's continued power, ''more so than those who wish they were in a greater position of power,'' like dissident minority groups. 
Mr. Webster's remarks came in a question-and-answer session at a meeting of the Foreign Policy Association, a private New York group that promotes public interest in foreign affairs.
 
Not Advocating Overthrow
Mr. Webster said he was not advocating the overthrow of Mr. Hussein. But his statement is the strongest suggestion to date that the Bush Administration is pressing the worldwide embargo vigorously in part because officials believe it to be the most effective means of unseating the Iraqi President.
Of Mr. Hussein's rule, Mr. Webster said only that ''the likelihood of those close to him deciding that he was no longer leading Iraq in the best interests of the country will grow with the effectiveness of the sanctions,'' especially their ability to create food shortages, a decline in living standards and difficulties in selling Iraqi goods abroad.
In answer to another question, Mr. Webster said the United States would not seek to assassinate Mr. Hussein, either by covert action or by more public means like a military strike.
But he added that the Central Intelligence Agency and other intelligence organizations were not barred from assisting foreign groups that might seek to remove Mr. Hussein, as long as his death was not an object of a coup plot.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: WASHINGTON TALK;
Did U.S. Overtures Give Wrong Idea to Hussein?

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
In an unusually reflective moment this week, George Bush gave Presidential prominence to questions lurking at the fringes of public debate since American soldiers first landed in Saudi Arabia: How did the United States get into this? Were the Administration's overtures to Saddam Hussein partly responsible?
At a news conference on Monday, President Bush insisted that his efforts to improve relations with Iraq had nothing to do with President Hussein's decision to invade Kuwait. But in saying that he now regrets those overtures and suggesting that part of Mr. Hussein's thinking might have been a calculation that he would not meet strong opposition, Mr. Bush left open the door for discussion. Members of the House leaped in today, in a hearing in which lawmakers from both parties accused the Administration of conducting appeasement based on ''fiction and fantasy.'' 
As the Persian Gulf crisis nears the end of its seventh week, this may be just a first taste of a problem that is not going to go away. Indeed, if Americans start dying in the Saudi desert or if the stalemate drags on interminably, it could prove to be the very thing that eats away at the public support that is so apparent now.
As he mused aloud on Monday about the endurance of public support, Mr. Bush was evidently sensitive to this. ''I don't think this is caused by a miscalculation in United States policy,'' he said. ''I think it's caused by a miscalculation by Saddam Hussein, and I think the American people understand that to a fare-thee-well.''
Throughout the year, the Administration sought to foster friendlier ties with Baghdad, lobbying against Congressional passage of economic sanctions against Mr. Hussein. According to some accounts, John Kelly, the Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, killed a Voice of America editorial lambasting Mr. Hussein. Last week, newspaper columnists said April Glaspie, the Ambassador to Iraq, had argued for ''better relations'' in a meeting with Mr. Hussein in July and said the United States did not want to meddle in disputes between Arab states. The suggestion was that Mr. Hussein took this to mean his argument with Kuwait over territory and oil prices.
Asked about these reports, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said it was ''stupid'' and ''ludicrous'' to suggest that the United States had somehow given Mr. Hussein the ''green light'' to enter Kuwait. But Mr. Fitzwater and other officials did not dispute the accounts of the Glaspie meeting.
Why did the United States court Mr. Hussein in the first place, since he had already used chemical weapons against his own people and was thought to be developing nuclear bombs? And did the Administration fundamentally misread Mr. Hussein and keep up its friendly gestures when he was intent on war?
The White House is groping for an effective reply.
Part of the answer lies in Mr. Bush, who prides himself on his ability a diplomat and relies heavily on personal contacts with world leaders, like King Hussein of Jordan, who was telling him to continue the overtures to Iraq. It is only hindsight that makes his policy seem misdirected, Mr. Bush said. ''There was some reason to believe that perhaps improved relations with the West would modify the behavior'' of Mr. Hussein, he said.
This carrot-and-stick argument is an old one. It is a diplomatic spear on which this Administration has been impaled before: Mr. Bush took much heat for his overtures to China after Tiananmen Square, when he chose the carrot and later confessed that it produced nothing.
Mr. Bush did little to put the question to rest this week in relation to Iraq. In light of the invasion, he said, one could argue that his policy didn't ''make much sense.''
A few minutes later, the President seemed to open a new rhetorical trap.
Mr. Hussein's invasion of Kuwait, he said, was ''clearly irrational'' if the Iraqi President had believed in advance that ''it would bring down the wrath of the United States and 20 other countries, and indeed the entire world at the United Nations.''
That left an obvious question hanging, that was not asked this time: If Mr. Hussein expected little opposition, was that at least in part because the United States seemed so interested in improving relations?

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Western Europe Urges Air Embargo Against Iraq

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Moving toward closer coordination of their military policies, nine Western European nations urged the United Nations Security Council today to extend the trade embargo against Baghdad to include aircraft entering and leaving Iraq and Kuwait.
At the United Nations on Monday, the permanent members of the Security Council agreed on a broad outline of a proposal including an air blockade, which has yet to be approved by the full 15-member Council.
The nine countries meeting here, all members of the Western European Union, a regional military organization, also agreed to tighten coordination between European naval, ground and air forces that have already been sent to the Persian Gulf region.
So far, only Britain and France have major military detachments in the area, although six other European countries have sent warships. The Netherlands said today that it was ready to deploy 18 F-16 fighter aircraft in Turkey, while Italy plans to move eight Tornado fighters to the region. 
With 28 European warships now assigned to the gulf area, France, Britain, the Netherlands and Italy also announced today that they had agreed on their respective patrol areas in the gulf and the Red Sea and that they would continue to share information and logistical support.
 
Meeting Called by France
The meeting today was called by France in reaction to the incursions by Iraqi forces into the French, Belgian, Dutch and Canadian Embassies in Kuwait last Friday. On Monday, the 12-nation European Community agreed to expel Iraqi military attaches from the region in retaliation for the raids.
A statement from the foreign and defense ministers attending the meeting today said they had agreed to adopt ''supplementary measures'' to increase the efficiency of the embargo against Iraq and warned that an air blockade could also be applied against countries that violate the trade embargo.
Britain's Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said the United Nations Security Council would determine the details of an air blockade, but he added that ''everyone is very keen'' on such a measure. ''A key element is the states over which planes may fly and their responsibilities,'' he added.
Echoing views heard from other ministers, Britain's Defense Secretary, Tom King, said he was ''very impressed'' by the progress by the long-moribund Western European Union in coordinating naval activities in the gulf since it first met here Aug. 21.
 
Overshadowed by NATO
The Western European Union has traditionally been overshadowed by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, but it has proved useful in recent weeks because, unlike NATO, it can operate outside Europe and North America. Further, with the European Community now unable to deal with military matters, it has helped bring order to the European response.
United States and British criticism of much of Western Europe's slow military reaction to the gulf crisis has nonetheless revived demands that the European Community's charter be revised so that it can take security responsibilities in future international crises.
Italy, which holds the rotating presidency of the community in the second half of this year, has even gone as far as suggesting the union be absorbed by the community, although three members of the community - Denmark, Greece and Ireland - are not members of the union and Ireland is neutral.
Jacques Delors, the President of the European Commission, has also strongly endorsed plans by community governments to discuss integration of their foreign and military policies at a conference dedicated to ''political union'' scheduled to open in Rome in December.
 
Security Community Urged
Sir Leon Brittan, the vice president of the European Commission, has proposed the creation of a European Security Community within NATO. ''As soon as the focus of the crisis moved beyond purely economic measures to military preparations and high-level diplomacy, the United States was forced to assume world leadership,'' he noted last week.
In the past, the United States has discouraged discussion of a security dimension for the community for fear that this could weaken NATO. Adding to American suspicions, the idea was often promoted by France, which does not belong to NATO's integrated military command and has often adopted an independent military policy.
The gulf crisis has led to broad rethinking of the shape of Europe. A sign of that came Monday when Italy's Prime Minister, Giulio Andreotti, suggested that Britain and France give up their permanent seats on the United Nations Security Council in favor of the European Community and Japan. Until now discussed only in private, this idea is strongly opposed by Britain and France.

HEADLINE: U.S. Says It Is Ready to Cut Philippine Force

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA, Sept. 18

 BODY:
The United States Government is prepared to reduce its military forces in the Philippines, an American official said today as talks on American bases opened.
The official, Assistant Defense Secretary Richard L. Armitage, made his statement the day after President Corazon C. Aquino said in a nationally televised address that it was time to discuss the ''orderly withdrawal'' of the 40,000 American troops stationed at six installations here.
In a statement, Mr. Armitage, the American chief negotiator at the talks, said ''the days of a very large presence of U.S. sailors and airmen are coming to an end.'' He did not specify a period for troop reductions, and he called for a nationwide vote on the issue. 
The American bases provide employment to 80,000 Filipinos and bring in aid worth $481 million a year. But Mrs. Aquino, whose address was her first call for a withdrawal of American military forces in the Philippines, said that while the American bases were important, ''they are not the heart'' of the Philippine economy.
The treaty, which expires in September 1991, allows the United States use of Clark Air Base, Subic Bay Naval Base and four smaller places. Demonstrators protested today outside Clark Air Base, 50 miles north of Manila, in the southern city of Cebu and in front of the American Embassy in Manila.
The Philippine and American Governments agree that the negotiators should seek a ''new relationship'' that addresses rising nationalism and increasing concerns about the violation of sovereignty in the Philippines. But the two sides have yet to agree on issues like the schedule, terms and conditions of an American withdrawal.
Mr. Armitage asked for ''appropriate time'' for the American military to reorganize, adding, ''What remains for us to determine is the rate at which this presence will be reduced and the nature of the relationship our two governments wish to pursue during and after this transitional period.''
He proposed that ''the electorate of the 21st century decide whether or not they believe a continued U.S. presence will be helpful.''
Rafael Alunan, the spokesman for the Philippine negotiators, rejected Mr. Armitage's broad proposal. In a statement, Mr. Alunan said, ''This matter is not to be decided in the 21st century; the time for decision is now.''
Government officials say the Philippines hopes for a stay of the American bases for, at the longest, 10 years after the security agreement ends in 1991.

HEADLINE: LAYOFF PROVISIONS BUOY AUTO UNION

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 18

 BODY:
The subject was unemployment, but the mood of auto workers employed by the General Motors Corporation was anything but bleak.
One reason is a provision of the United Automobile Workers' tentative contract with the company under which General Motors may lay off workers for only 36 weeks at most over the next three years even if car and truck sales plummet.
While any contract that envisions 36 weeks without a job might seem to provide little reason for cheer, this proposed safeguard on employment was greeted joyfully by the union, whose 310,000 members have been battered by shutdowns in the past decade.
''If the bottom falls out, you want to have something to fall back on,'' said John Chapman, an elected bargainer from Local 14 in Toledo, Ohio. ''No one likes to go through life with a cloud hanging over their head.'' 
The tentative contract was approved today by the union's bargaining council, a group of about 400 representatives elected by the company's hourly workers. Mr. Chapman and others predicted that all the workers would overwhelmingly ratify the proposed contract within two weeks.
 
Ford and Chrysler Next
In that event the union would begin negotiating with the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation on agreements that it says will be patterned on its contract with G.M.
At present, an auto worker who is laid off for more than a few months could run out of unemployment benefits almost entirely, depending on seniority and how much money remained in a fund provided by the company.
The American automotive industry has historically provided the largest and most secure job benefits of any industrial sector covered by collective bargaining agreements. This year G.M. and the auto union might break newer ground by providing employees with guaranteed income whether there is work for them or not.
''It's very exciting,'' said Richard Block, a professor of labor relations at Michigan State University. ''What G.M. has done is separate the issue of its plant capacity from the issue of jobs.''
In effect, Mr. Block said, the company would get the right to open or close as many plants as it needed by agreeing to make sure that all its workers have a salary. He compared the proposal to the lifetime employment at some Japanese factories, although he noted that Japanese companies are also more likely to reduce pay and benefits when the economy is weak.
David Cole, head of the office for transportation studies at the University of Michigan, noted that G.M. has an additional motive for improving its pensions and its provisions for buying out older workers.
''They've now got the flexibility to shut plants,'' Mr. Cole said, ''and they would like to get the older folks out.''
Under the call-back proposal, G.M. would agree to recall workers to their jobs once they have accumulated 36 weeks of layoff, during which time they would be protected by normal unemployment benefits. If there is no work to do, the company would continue to pay unemployment benefits that are close to normal straight-time pay.
While committing up to $4 billion to pay for layoff benefits, G.M. also appears to have strengthened its power to reduce its hourly work force, especially older workers.
Issa Fakhoury, 48 years old, of St. Clair Shores, Mich., a 20-year G.M. employee who works at the Cadillac plant in Hamtramck, had not heard the details of the proposed contract. But, he said, ''if they raise the retirement benefits to give us more money to get by on, I would consider retiring early.''
He reckoned he would be entitled to $800 a month of early-retirement benefits under the current contract, as against more than $1,500 a month for a worker with full-retirement benefits.
Under the current contract, G.M. workers must be at least 62 and have 30 years of seniority to retire with the largest possible pension. The proposed contract would grant annual raises on monthly pension payments for those who retire early and would pay lump-sum raises to workers who have already retired.
A company spokesman declined to discuss the contract, pending its ratification. But G.M. executives have long wished to reduce labor costs to match those of Japanese auto makers who have American plants. One way to do that is to encourage older workers to retire and to replace them with younger ones, who have smaller salaries and spend less in medical benefits.
The company would not necessarily have to spend all $4 billion it has allotted for income security. If it can regain some of the customers it lost in the last decade, G.M. may need some of the plants and workers that are now redundant.
Executives at Ford would probably not mind granting job and income security provisions similar to those in the G.M. contract, since the No. 2 auto maker reduced its size in the early 1980's and does not have much, if any, excess production capacity or work force. But Ford would probably not like a provision that forces auto makers to pay a higher financial penalty for every hour of overtime. Ford relies heavily on overtime by its workers rather than hiring new workers.
Chrysler, which has been in tough financial shape for the past 18 months, has announced it could not afford a labor contract based on a ''pattern'' agreement signed at Ford or G.M.

HEADLINE: Illinois Journal;
A Legacy Once Scorned Now Adored

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 18

 BODY:
There was a time in parts of this state when you could hardly give away a piece of furniture designed by Frank Lloyd Wright. Now the state has dug deep into its pockets to create a shrine to the man.
Earlier this month, Gov. James R. Thompson unveiled the painstaking $5 million restoration of a mansion in Springfield where workers had gone so far as to examine the walls by microscope to duplicate the paint colors. Upon seeing the house, a former draftsman under Wright said it was restored ''the way God would if He had the money.'' 
Emotions run deep in Illinois, where Wright did most of his early and important work a century ago. The state has the largest accumulation of Wright buildings anywhere, about a fourth of the 414 homes, office buildings, museums and churches he designed, not to mention the furniture and stained glass he created. Despite some critics, Illinois is rabidly, lovingly guarding its treasures.
For his part Governor Thompson tracked down pieces of furniture missing from the mansion and went to Christie's in New York himself to bid $130,000 and thus acquire a lamp Wright designed for the house. He bid $704,000, by telephone, for another Wright lamp; it now sits in the 86-year-old mansion's living room.
So far thousands of people have walked through the mansion's hand-trimmed entryway, seemingly oblivious to the criticism the Governor got when the state bought the house for $1 million during a recession nine years ago.
''The Governor took a lot of heat on this,'' said Susan Mogerman, deputy director of the Illinois Historic Preservation Agency. ''Now the Wright market has exploded and a million dollars seems like a fire sale price.''
While Wright's bold horizontal designs made him celebrated during his lifetime, especially in the first two decades of the century, his popularity ebbed in the 1940's and 1950's as people turned from his iconoclastic ideas toward conformity. But his work became more fashionable after his death in 1959 and reached new heights in the 1980's after Tom Monaghan, a Detroit pizza magnate, paid $1.6 million for a Wright dining room set, starting a run on anything with Wright's name on it and thus reminding Illinoisans of their good fortune.
In Illinois, seemingly anything can be forgiven if it involves Wright, who Illinoisans like to forget was born in Wisconsin. Citizens who may not be able to afford so much as a chip of a Wright-designed window these days seem to share a stewardship for the work of an adopted son.
When the second floor of a Wright house caught fire in suburban Oak Park last month, neighbors stood outside holding each other, as firefighters rushed to spread covers over the original Wright woodwork and furniture while putting out the flames.
One reason people take these things personally around here is that Wright structures are everywhere. The home and studio where he worked for 20 years stands as a monument in Oak Park, a town where virtually whole neighborhoods and even people's garages were designed by the architect. The recent fire has rekindled debate over just how much of a role Wright had in the house, whether it or any number of other Wright houses may have actually been designed by his apprentices and just what a Wright house is.
Most experts agree that the house that burned, known as the Beachy house, can safely be called a Wright house. But there are many high-quality lookalikes and many homeowners who insist they too have the real thing.
''Some people become very defensive when I tell them who really built their house,'' said Timothy Samuelson, a preservation specialist. ''They will deny the true creator. They react as if I'm telling them their BMW is a Chevrolet.''
Not so with the state's newest mansion. The house was built for a widowed socialite, Susan Lawrence Dana, whose estate sold it to a publishing company, which sold it to the state. The house was almost exactly as Wright designed it, high-back dining chairs and all.
Only a few pieces had escaped. And Governor Thompson thanks the people of Springfield for that. It seems that in the 1940's when Mrs. Dana became infirm, her conservators had a yard sale to raise money to care for her. Tables and chairs and cabinets that go for hundreds of thousands of dollars each now sat with no takers.
''The people of Springfield thought the furniture was weird and refused to pay even 50 cents for a chair,'' Mr. Thompson said. ''The furniture had to be dragged back into the house. Thank goodness.''

HEADLINE: Measure Urges Newspapers To Rely More on Recycling

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Calling used newspapers the nation's ''No. 1 solid waste problem,'' a Pennsylvania Congressman introduced legislation today to provide economic incentives for recycling newsprint.
The lawmaker, Representative Richard T. Schulze, a Republican, said that while many newspapers were doing a good job of printing on reused paper, others were doing little or nothing. Meanwhile, he said, newsprint is filling landfill space, which is already crowded, and causing ''the needless loss of millions of acres of forest lands.'' He added, ''Newsprint is the nation's No. 1 recycling problem.'' 
At a news conference, he made public the results of a survey conducted by his staff in August, on the amount of recycled paper used by the 100 newspapers in the country with the largest circulation. The newspapers with the best record were The Star Ledger in Newark and The Asbury Park (N.J.) Press, which print 100 percent of their newspapers on recycled newsprint.
The papers that recycled the least, the survey found, were The Wall Street Journal, which used 2.5 percent recycled paper and had a circulation of 1.8 million; USA Today, which used no recycled paper and had a circulation of 1.46 million, and The New York Times, which used 8 percent recycled paper and had a daily circulation of 1.1 million at the time of the survey.
 
'Relatively Low Supply'
William Adler, a spokesman for The Times, said the newspaper was a leader of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's state study group on recycling and was committed to the goal of using recycled paper for 40 percent of its production by the end of this decade.
Mr. Adler said that the best way to achieve recycling goals was through cooperation within the industry and that legislation was not needed.
James A. Ambrosio, manager of investor relations for Dow Jones & Company, the parent company of The Wall Street Journal, said that Representative Schulze failed to realize that there was ''a relatively low supply of recycled newsprint out there.'' He continued, ''The Wall Street Journal fully intends to increase our use of recycled newsprint and we are working closely with our suppliers to increase our use.''
The president and chief executive officer of USA Today, Thomas Curley, said tonight that the survey's findings on his newspaper were ''totally false.'' He said the paper was currently using 10 to 12 percent recycled newsprint and was entering into long-term contracts to assure greater supplies of recycled newsprint.
''Gannett has said its goal is to reach close to half recycled newsprint by the middle of the decade,'' Mr. Curley said.
Mr. Curley said the survey also incorrectly stated the circulation of USA Today, which he put at 1.85 million.
A spokesman for the American Newspaper Publishers Association said the industry was taking steps to improve the availability of recycled newsprint. Joseph Lorfano, manager of public information for the association, said that of 65 mills producing paper for newspapers in this country and Canada, only 9 produced recycled newsprint.
 
Tax Penalties Proposed
But Mr. Lorfano added that there were 16 projects under way in the industry to build new plants for recycling newsprint, to expand existing plants or to increase capacity for taking ink out of used newsprint, a vital function in producing recycled paper.
The legislation proposed by Representative Schulze would provide a 10 percent tax credit to newspapers and other businesses that buy recycling equipment and machinery. It would also impose what he said would be ''stiff'' tax penalties on newspapers that did not print at least 50 percent of their circulation on recycled paper within the next 10 years.
He conceded that prospects for passage of the legislation before Congress adjourns in late October were not good but insisted he would continue to introduce his bill until it was adopted.
The Environmental Protection Agency has reported that 13.3 million tons of newsprint are produced in this country each year, and one-third is recycled. Newsprint accounts for 8 percent of the nation's total solid waste, the agency said. An agency spokeswoman said she did not know if newsprint was the largest single component of solid waste.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 22, 1990, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about legislation to provide incentives for recycling newspapers misstated the amount of recycled newsprint used by The Asbury Park (N.J.) Press and The Star Ledger in Newark. The Press uses recycled paper for about 33 percent of its production and The Star Ledger uses it for about 18 percent, said spokesmen for the newspapers. Incorrect data from a survey provided by the legislation's sponsor had said the newspapers printed 100 percent of their newspapers on recycled newsprint.

HEADLINE: Alienation From Government Grows, Poll Finds

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Americans express even greater alienation toward their government and politics today than they did three years ago, and virtually all of the increase has been among people from families earning less than $50,000 a year, a new study of public opinion shows.
The study, conducted by the Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press and released today, concluded that there is ''a growing socioeconomic schism within the country.''
The frustration and disillusionment is affecting both political parties and undermining the political system, the study suggested. ''Despite the personal popularity of President Bush,'' the study said, ''cynicism toward the political system in general is growing as the public in unprecedented numbers associates Republicans with wealth and greed, Democrats with fecklessness and incompetence.'' 
It is just these sorts of attitudes that politicians around the country say they are confronting as midterm elections draw near. The anger of voters was a central element in both Massachusetts and Oklahoma as they held primary voting today.
In Massachusetts, fury at the Democrats who have controlled the statehouse was a driving force in both Republican and Democratic gubenatorial primaries. In Oklahoma frustration with the Republican Governor and Democratic Legislature fueled support for a proposition to limit the terms of state lawmakers.
The alienation, both personal and political, has been increasing fastest among poor and middle-income whites, the study said. On some issues they express levels of despair almost as great as blacks, traditionally among the most alienated of Americans.
By contrast, higher-income Americans, those from families with incomes of more than $50,000 a year, have shown only a slight increases or no increase at all in negative attitudes, the study said.
The Times Mirror survey asked 3,004 Americans a series of questions to gauge attitudes of mistrust, disillusionment and helplessness toward politics and politicians.
Asked whether officials in Washington generally lose touch with the people pretty quickly, 34 percent of those from families with incomes of under $30,000 agreed completly, up from 25 percent in 1987. Among those with incomes of $30,000 to $50,000, those agreeing completly increased to 32 percent from 18 percent. But among those with family incomes of more than $50,000 the increase rose only to 18 percent from 14 percent.
 
Economics and Alienation
The Times Mirror study tied rising alienation directly to increasing economic pressures on the lower and middle-classes, a connection that seemed consistent with the economic troubles of both Oklahoma and Massachusetts.
The respondents were asked whether they agreed or disagreed with the proposition that hard work offers little guarantee of success. About 20 percent of the whites earning more than $50,000 agreed, statistically unchanged from the 21 percent that agreed with this statement in 1987. But among whites from families making under $50,000, the percent agreeing that hard work offers little guarantee of success rose to 38 percent from 28 percent.
Among blacks overall there was little change, with 43 percent agreeing now and 41 percent in 1987.
The Times Mirror Center, established by the publishing company that owns The Los Angeles Times, Newsday and other newspapers, has conducted a series of major surveys since 1987 to analyze public views in more depth than many public opinion surveys. The survey for the latest study was carried out in May by face-to-face interviews. Of the 3,004 respondents, 1,000 were re-interviewed by telephone in August to measure possible changes caused by reaction to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The margin of sampling error for the entire survey is plus or minus two percentage points and for the reinterview it is plus or minus three percentage points.
While support for military spending edged back up and declining support for Israel was halted after the invasion, underlying political attitudes seemed unaffected, said Andrew Kohut, director of surveys for Times Mirror.
The $50,000 income line marked a divide in American political attitudes, said the study. About 15 percent of those surveyed were above that line and 85 percent below it, said Mr. Kohut, who also runs an independent polling firm, Princeton Survey Research Associates.
Mr. Kohut noted that even in the 1987 survey, substantial majorities expressed feelings of disconnection from government and politics. ''What we see in the current survey is an intensification of this unease,'' he said.
Both political parties suffered. Democrats held an advantage over Republicans as a plurality of Americans think of Democratic Party as the party more sympathetic to their concerns and more attuned to their position on issues of economics and social policy, like abortion.
 
Declining Faith in Competence
But among some of the party's traditionally loyal groups their is declining faith in the party's competence, the study found. For example, Times Mirror, in its polling, defined a group it called ''the partisan poor,'' composed of about 1 in 10 Americans of low income who look to the Democrats for social change.
''A large percentage of this group, which bears the brunt of the social ills of the nation, has become disillusioned with a Democratic Party that has not delivered,'' said the study. The percent of this group identifying themselves as Democrats fell to 57 percent from 89 percent, and those switiching to Independent rose to 39 percent from 11 percent.
But Republican can draw little comfort from this sort of shift, which was also visible among other Democratic groups in less degrees.
The percentage of all those surveyed who, without prompting, identified the Republicans with ''rich and monied interests'' rose to 51 percent from 18 percent in 1987.
About 28 percent described the Republicans as ''not being for the people,'' compared with 5 percent in 1987.
''This cynicism,'' said the study, ''Threatens to subvert traditional partisan politics or block the effective resolution of social and economic issues.''

HEADLINE: ACCUSATIONS BEGIN IN BUDGET TALKS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Democrats and Republicans spent the day today blaming each other for a budget deadlock that has come down to a fight over which party's policies are fairer and have a better chance of averting a serious decline in the economy.
With members of Congress increasingly eager to get home to campaign, the argument is also about which side will be able to sell its version of the inevitable tax increase and spending cuts as least painful for taxpayers in the short run and most likely to produce prosperity in the long run.
President Bush and his Republican allies in Congress are insisting on a deficit-reducing plan that would include a lower capital gains tax and other measures that they say would stimulate the flagging economy.
Democrats are advocating a plan that would force the wealthy to bear more of the tax burden and the military more of the spending cuts. 
 
Agree Only to Meet Again
Ten days of talks in seclusion at Andrews Air Force Base in nearby Maryland broke up in disagreement Monday night. A smaller group of top Administration officials and senior Congressional leaders could decide nothing more today than to meet again on Wednesday.
If no agreement is reached, across-the-board spending cuts of more than 40 percent in most Government programs, including the military, would go into effect on Oct. 15, two weeks after the new fiscal year begins.
Politicians and economists in both parties argue that the nation's economy could collapse under the strain.
But the prevailing view in the Capitol was that an accord would be struck before the economy was endangered. ''We have no choice but to go back in and get an agreement,'' said Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee.
Democrats said today that if Republicans would abandon their drive for a lower capital gains tax or agree to an offsetting tax on the wealthy, the rest of the agreement would quickly follow.
 
Unresolved Issues Cited
Republicans took issue with that view, contending that other issues also divided the budget negotiators. Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the senior Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, cited military and domestic spending, energy taxes and cuts in retirement benefits as among the issues that had not been resolved.
Today John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff; Richard G. Darman, the budget director, and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady met for more than an hour in the Capitol with the five highest-ranking lawmakers.
Although nothing was resolved, another session was scheduled for Wednesday. The theory seemed to be that this group would have a chance of striking an agreement, since some of the most partisan participants in the Andrews talks would be excluded.
Among them is Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip. Mr. Gingrich, freed of the restraints he felt at Andrews, called a news conference this afternoon to attack the Democrats for what he said was ''deliberate foot-dragging'' and ''deliberate misinformation.''
The Democratic oratory was equally strong. Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, who ranks fourth in the Democratic heirarchy, said at a news conference that the ''stalemate'' resulted from ''the insistence of Republican negotiators to maintain a benefit for the wealthy.''
An examination of the last plans placed on the table Monday night showed some justification for both views - the Democratic contention that the capital gains tax was the principal problem, and the Republican assertion that the two sides were far apart on many matters.
The latest figures calculated by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office and Joint Tax Committee showed that the Republican plan would lead to tax increases for taxpayers with incomes below $50,000 a year and tax cuts for those with incomes above that amount. It indicated that the Democratic plan would have the reverse effect, cutting taxes for those with incomes below $20,000 and increasing taxes for those with higher incomes.
Republicans contend, correctly, that the figures do not take into account the economic growth they say would result if capital gains were taxed at a lower rate than other income.
Beyond taxes, the two plans are closer to one another. Both would reduce the deficit by about $50 billion in the fiscal year 1991, which begins on Oct. 1, and $500 billion over the next five years.

HEADLINE: Cutting Gains Taxes: The Real Risk

 BODY:
Budget negotiators are tied in knots over a Republican proposal to lower the tax on capital gains - the increase in the value of stocks, bonds and real estate from purchase to sale. Lowering that tax, the Bush Administration argues, will spur new investment. Until now, the Democrats have sensibly rejected the proposal because it would add to the deficit and primarily benefit rich families. 
Now there are ominous signs that the Democrats are willing to compromise. They are said to have proposed cutting the top capital gains tax from 33 percent to 23 percent in return for a surtax on people with annual incomes above $200,000. Any such compromise would be a bum deal. The Republican tax cut plan is not just unfair, it's economically destructive. The damage can't be stopped by soaking the rich, only by burying Mr. Bush's obsession once and for all.
Republican negotiators are reportedly backing a plan to lower the maximum capital gains tax from 33 to 15 percent. The Democrats charge that an overwhelming percentage of the benefit would go to families with incomes in excess of $100,000. That's true - and that's why the Democrats have proposed offsetting any such cut with a tax hike on the rich, and why the Administration would accomplish the same end by capping deductions.
But the real harm of the Republican plan lies not in its inequity. It would open up a wedge, closed in the 1986 tax reform law, between taxation of ordinary income and taxation of capital gains. That would direct investment toward projects that minimize taxes rather than projects that maximize output of valuable goods and services. With one stroke of the pen, Congress would re-create the wasteful business of tax shelters for rich investors that prospered before 1986.
The Republicans' proposal also reeks of hypocrisy. If they were interested in economic growth, rather than generating billions in excess profits for their friends, the proposal would have excluded capital gains on old investments. The notion that creating windfall profits on old investments could promote future investment is ludicrous.
Nor, if economic growth were the true purpose, would the Republican negotiators have proposed a capital gains cut for assets like real estate, which are already subsidized by the tax code and warrant no further advantage.
The Republicans have one important argument on their side. Increases in an asset's value that merely mirror inflation ought not to be taxed because they do not represent true profit. Correcting this problem is essential to long-term investment.
So here's a compromise worth forging. Index the tax so that only capital gains in excess of inflation are taxed. Then restrict indexing to new investment in stocks and bonds. This would give Mr. Bush and the Republicans much of what they seek and everything the economy deserves.

HEADLINE: We Need a Corps of Inner-City Youth Workers;
No Jobs, More Crime

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Massive walls and fortifications have never kept cities civilized for long. Your prescription for more jails and more police (editorial, Sept. 6), addresses only one of the causes of the epidemic of brutal and irrational crimes, namely the breakdown of effective deterrence and punishment. 
But unless the crisis of jobs in working-class neighborhoods is solved soon, no amount of deterrence will stem the tide of crime.
Nor can the problem be fixed by schools. The official culture of the high school was never taken seriously as a reflection of local reality by lower-class youth. The culture of the shop floor was. But a shrinking pool of blue-collar jobs in the New York metropolitan area has eroded the traditional structure of aspirations that served as a powerful counterweight to the temptations of crime and drugs.
In the absence of an economic renewal that can generate the kinds of jobs that can sustain households, we will surely have to brace ourselves for more casualties and the end of urban life as we have known it in this century.
 
THOMAS BELMONTE
 Brooklyn, Sept. 7, 1990
The writer is associate professor of anthropology at Hofstra University.
