HEADLINE: Textile Bill: Unfair and Unneeded

BYLINE: By Carla A. Hills; Carla A. Hills is the U.S. Trade Representative.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The only good thing to say about the textile bill that passed the House yesterday is that the margin of approval fell short of the two-thirds needed to override an almost certain Presidential veto.
In all other respects, the bill is a disaster. It would expand three decades of protectionism, not only raising already artificially high U.S. apparel prices but also undermining global trade negotiations, now nearing completion in Geneva.
The bill, which would apply quotas to new items and make existing protections permanent, would badly hurt consumers, particularly at lower income levels. During the next five years, textile and apparel protection would cost about $160 billion, taxing every family of four about $2,600 a year. 
What's more, the added protection is unnecessary. Economic indicators show that the U.S. textile and apparel industries are doing well.
Domestic shipments were up 7 percent and exports were up 27 percent in 1989. Factories are running at an all-time high; a higher rate, in fact, than the average for all U.S. manufacturers. Unemployment in the major textile producing states is generally lower than the national average.
Worst of all, the legislation violates our international commitments under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Multi Fiber Arrangement and individual agreements with 38 of our trading partners.
Thus, at the very moment we are seeking to forge an historic alliance to confront Iraqi aggression, we are telling our allies that the U.S. is willing to ignore its international obligations. Indeed, the bill would violate recent agreements with Turkey and Egypt, two countries indispensable to our international efforts in the gulf.
Passing the bill also sends precisely the wrong message at a time when we are trying to convince other nations to dismantle their trade barriers. Approving such protectionist legislation after four years of negotiating to open world markets will be seen as the height of hypocrisy - in essence saying to the world ''Do as we say, not as we do.''
In Geneva, where negotiators are in the final stages of the Uruguay Round of talks on a new G.A.T.T. agreement, we are urging all nations to open their markets so that trade can expand. But on the verge of completing this agreement to open others' doors, we are closing our own.
If the bill were to become law, the Uruguay Round would collapse, with staggering economic costs. We would lose the $125 billion in increased U.S. output we expect to gain in the first year alone from greater access to foreign markets. The $60 billion that U.S. entrepreneurs lose annually from the theft and counterfeiting of their ideas would continue to grow out of control.
New markets would be lost for U.S. services firms, which export $90 billion annually and create 9-out-of-10 new jobs. We would lose the opportunity to get an agreement opening world markets to investment, which helps generate more than $240 billion annually, or two-thirds of total U.S. exports. And we would lose the chance to bring the developing world into the global trading system, which could increase U.S. exports by as much as 50 percent, or $200 billion, between now and the year 2000.
Beyond the economic tragedy of a failed Uruguay Round, we would squander a vital, proven framework of international collaboration. The collapse of the round would lead inevitably to increased protections and political instability.
Failure to come to an agreement also could destabilize poorer nations, including the emerging democracies. Without an agreement, these nations will continue to be drained by the costs of protections now imposed on them - costs that total two-and-a-half times the aid they receive.
How tragic it would be if the reform governments seeking to replace command economies with market-oriented systems were to fail because of restrictions erected by the world's trading nations, and were then replaced by authoritarian regimes.
The Uruguay Round presents 100 nations with the extraordinary opportunity to forge a new trading system that could trigger an economic renaissance. The 1990 textile bill risks all that. Those who are selling it to the American people are trying to pull the wool over their eyes.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: OP-ED

HEADLINE: Vote in Senate Alarms Exporters of Garbage

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
The Senate, in a move that alarmed New Jersey and New York, voted 68 to 31 today to permit states to ban imports of garbage.
The measure would allow states to bar out-of-state trash shipments or to impose higher landfill fees for imported garbage if the importing states demonstrate that they have a 20-year plan to manage their solid waste.
It was strongly opposed by New Jersey's Senators, Frank R. Lautenberg and Bill Bradley, whose state is the nation's leading garbage exporter. During the debate considerable rancor developed between the two Democrats and the provision's leading sponsor, Senator Dan Coats, an Indiana Republican, who was accused of insulting New Jersey residents and of engaging in political grandstanding. 
 
New Jersey Asks for Time
Responding to declining landfill space, New Jersey ships 55 percent of its garbage to other states. New York ships 11 percent.
In 1989 the two states accounted for 53 percent of the 15 million tons of trash that moved across state borders, the National Solid Wastes Management Association estimated.
In debate, Mr. Lautenberg and Mr. Bradley said New Jersey did not like shipping its garbage hundreds of miles but needed more time to develop trash disposal options.
After the vote, they expressed confidence that the provision could be killed in its next legislative forum, a House-Senate conference committee. The measure is attached to an unrelated broader bill that President Bush has promised to veto,the Senators said.
 
Running Out of Landfill
Senator Coats asserted that his state was running out of landfill space and resented being a trash can for New Jersey. He is running for re-election.
''Don't dump on us,'' said Mr. Coats, whose proposal clearly found a resonant chord in the Senate.
Indiana is not alone in receiving out-of-state trash. Every day hundreds of trucks also carry New Jersey and New York trash to landfills in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Kentucky. Ohio is the leading site for New York garbage.
Some importing states have tried to discourage trucks from bringing in trash. But courts have generally found that the Constitution precludes states from instituting curbs that interfere with interstate commerce. So Mr. Coats said Federal legislation was the only remaining avenue.
 
Florio Denounces Measure
Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey assailed the Senate measure.
''It's bad environmental policy,'' he said in a statement. ''It has the effect of forcing states to choose incineration, and that's not good economically and certainly not good environmentally.''
A state commission appointed by Mr. Florio called for a goal of 60 percent recycling by 1995. A four-month moratorium on new incinerator permits ended Aug. 1. Mr. Florio has said he does not think the state needs an incinerator in each of its 21 counties.
New York City will lobby against the measure because it limits disposal options, Steven M. Polan, the city's Sanitation Commissioner, said through a spokesman. It has been estimated that private carters may be exporting as much as 10,000 tons of garbage day from the city, instead of dumping it at the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island.
The measure ''does not take into account that the regional problem sometimes can't be solved within the region,'' Commissioner Po/lan said.
 
Election Issue at Stake
Indiana exports only 2 percent of its waste, Senator Coats said. Two years ago Indiana received only a small amount of garbage from out of state, but now as much as 30 percent of all waste buried in landfills there is imported, the State Department of Environmental Management reported. The remaining landfill capacity is eight years, Mr. Coats said.
In addition to the substantive differences, personal feelings also roiled the debate. Mr. Coats is running for re-election and the garbage import ban plays well with Indiana voters. He was appointed to his Senate seat after its former occupant, Dan Quayle, was elected Vice President.
''I don't think there is a Hoosier anywhere in this state who disagrees that Indiana ought to be able to regulate'' garbage imports, said Tim Phillips, campaign manager for Mr. Coats's Democratic opponent, Baron P. Hill.
 
TV Commercial Assailed
A recent Coats campaign television commercial portrayed one garbage exporter to Indiana as an overweight, cigar-smoking man with a heavy accent associated with the New York metropolitan area. The man wore a Cape May, N.J., T-shirt and a Yankees cap.
Mr. Lautenberg and Mr. Bradley said they were offended by this characterization and suggested it had been prompted by Mr. Coats's re-election bid.

HEADLINE: Youth Charged in Suspect's Killing Is Released

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT

 BODY:
Four days after he stabbed and killed a man who he apparently believed had mugged his mother, Victor Lopez returned to his South Bronx street yesterday as his neighbors expressed outrage that the young man, out on $2,500 bail, had been charged with manslaughter.
''I don't feel so good,'' Mr. Lopez said in his family's apartment in the Mott Haven section. ''I'm a little worried, a little scared. I don't know what is going to happen. I pray God that this works out all right.'' 
George Carabello, a security guard in the building across from where the Lopez family lives at 521 East 145th Street, summed up the mood of much of the neighborhood, a one-block stretch of public housing, old brownstones and glass-strewn, weed-choked lots.
''He did it for his mother,'' Mr. Carabello said. ''You love your mother; you're supposed to let her get mugged and do nothing? That other kid, the tourist, he tried to protect his mother and he died trying. Victor took the law into his own hands, but I would have done the same. It sure would have been worse if the guy had killed his mother.''
 
Possibility of Demonstrations
Mr. Carabello stood across from the Lopez apartment building, where many neighbors had gathered to show their support for Mr. Lopez. Some drew correlations between Mr. Lopez, 18 years old, and Brian Watkins, the young Utah tourist who was stabbed to death on Sept. 2 after defending his mother from subway muggers. They talked of drug dealers on nearby Brook Avenue, of drive-by shootings, of unstable crack addicts, of a lack of police patrols on their streets and of the possibility of demonstrations if Victor Lopez goes to jail for his actions.
''Everybody is against him going to jail,'' said Teresa Burroughs, 22, as she left the building where the Lopez family lives.
Alvin Rosario, 26, who also lives in the building, said: ''He did the right thing. The guy had followed his mother to the building. If Victor hadn't found him, maybe he would have followed her again.''
The incident began on Saturday morning, when Mr. Lopez's mother was returning home shaken after being mugged and molested on her way to work at Our Lady of Mercy Hospital. When she was almost to her building, Mrs. Lopez recognized one of her assailants and screamed for her children. Hearing his mother, Victor Lopez bolted barefoot from the family's apartment, followed by his brother, Ramon, 21. They then accosted the man, who swore he had not touched their mother. But he gave them the name and address of his companion, Lazara O'Farrill, 25, who lived two blocks away at 409 East 146th Street.
 
A Criminal Record
Ramon Lopez said that when he and his brother found Mr. O'Farrill, the man grabbed for something in his waistband, and that Victor Lopez then stabbed him in the right arm, right chest and right leg. Mr. O'Farrill ran away. He died at 1:20 P.M. at Lincoln Hospital.
Mr. O'Farrill had a criminal record beginning in 1989 that included robberies and grand larceny, the police said.
Yesterday, the Lopez apartment was filled with Guardian Angels, who were helping collect signatures for Victor's defense, and people from the neighborhood. One of them, Jose Davila, 27, an unemployed furniture mover, donated his savings of $700 to the family, At one point someone spotted a car outside carrying a relative of Mr. O'Farrill's. Within minutes the apartment was empty of Mr. Lopez's friends.
 
'I Don't Want You Downstairs'
''Chino, stay right where you are,'' screamed Mrs. Lopez, referring to Victor, who hesitated by the doorway. ''I don't want you downstairs.''
The young men confronted the relative, who they said was Mr. O'Farrill's sister, and a screaming and pushing match ensued before the woman and a friend drove off.
''I'm afraid for them all,'' said Mrs. Lopez, a 37-year-old mother of nine who got off welfare two years ago. Mrs. Lopez said she blamed herself for calling her children to her aid because she had struggled so long to keep them from the perils of the streets.
''I'm sorry for that dead boy, but I'm afraid now for my own children,'' she said. ''They are all in danger from revenge.''

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
At U.S. Military Bases, Schools Help Children Deal With Gulf

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
For thousands of American children, school began in the midst of a family crisis few other Americans share.
Older elementary school pupils, acting more like kindergartners or first graders, balked at going back to school in the first days. Distraught children would blurt out in the middle of class, ''I want my daddy to come home.'' Or ''Where is Mommy? Is Mommy O.K.?'' 
These pupils are the children of American troops sent to the Persian Gulf, and they fear for their parents' safety.
At the military bases that deployed tens of thousands of troops in Operation Desert Shield, schools have moved quickly in the last few weeks to help the children express their fears and cope with them.
 
Guidance in Expression
At schools at Fort Bragg, N.C., home of the Army's 82d Airborne Division, and at other schools with large numbers of military dependents, coloring books were provided to children too young to articulate their worries fully so they could express them on paper. For older pupils, there was guidance in writing stories or letters to parents. Photographs of parents in uniform were posted on classroom bulletin boards.
At Fort Campbell, Ky., home of the 101st Airborne Division, each base school had set up a child support system under the supervision of a guidance counselor by the time school began. Personnel whose teaching experience went back to the Vietnam War were consulted on how military children reacted during that conflict.
''There are similarities but with one big difference,'' said Ray McMullen, Assistant Superintendent at Fort Campbell. ''The buildup in Vietnam took place over years; now it's taking only a few short weeks.''
 
Frightening TV Coverage
The television coverage of the troop buildup, along with the repeated showings of victims of Iraqi poison gas, is frightening for the children.
''We saw a lot of separation anxiety in fourth and fifth graders. which tells us they are worried,'' said Rob Richardson, assistant principal of an elementary school at Fort Bragg, noting that this is a condition usually observed in kindergartners or first graders, who are more likely to worry about being separated from their parents.
About half the 4,750 military dependents educated on the base have parents, mostly fathers, on duty in the Mideast, he said. Still more children of military personnel attend public schools off the base in the Cumberland County district, and administrators, counselors and teachers there have also moved with dispatch.
''In August we instructed our principals to discuss the issues with their teachers to understand some of the worry the kids would be dealing with,'' said Dr. Rick Hollings, the supervising psychologist.
''We were not only concerned with the military dependents but also with Arab kids in the schools who may be scapegoated, and children of working people in the community who will bear a severe economic blow if the deployment lasts long enough.''
Fort Bragg is also the home base of the Army Special Forces units and the Delta Force unit formed for quick deployment, all heavily involved in the Mideast operation. More than 12,000 of the 44,000 pupils in the Cumberland schools are military dependents, and many of the teachers are spouses of service members.
''We had a taste of this in the Panama and Grenada fighting but nothing as prolonged or as dangerous as this,'' said Dr. Joe Guiendon, Deputy Superintendent of Schools.
The military has no systematic crisis intervention program exclusively for children, said Maj. Doug Hart, a Pentagon spokesman. He said the Defense Department monitored each school to insure that children's needs were met, with administrators devising their own strategies based on established methods of relieving stress and emotional trauma.
 
Anxiety From First Day
Dr. McMullen, the Fort Campbell school official, said: ''We detected anxiety in the children from the first day of school. No doubt it reflected the anxiety felt in their home. They were withdrawing from other children, there was an increase in hyperactivity, and they brought up in class what they had seen the night before on television news.''
Mike Hoover, a Colorado pscyhologist, has helped schools on military bases set up crisis intervention programs patterned on those developed to deal with suicides, gang violence and multiple-death accidents at schools.
''Depression in schoolchildren tends to go unnoticed by parents and teachers because children act it out differently,'' Dr. Hoover said. ''When adults become depressed they are less energetic and may go without eating. Children do the exact opposite. They act out verbally and often get into fights.''
The Fort Campbell teaching staff got firsthand experience dealing with crisis intervention with children in 1985 when a chartered airliner carrying 101st Airborne troops home from Europe crashed at Gander, Newfoundland, killing 248 soldiers.
 
Both Parents Sent Away
In the Mideast deployment, some children have both mother and father shipped overseas, and many others are in single-parent military households. Finding family, friends or neighbors to care for them indefinitely has been a problem and has exacerbated the anxiety of the children.
''The chance for abuse exists and we are watching out for it,'' said Dr. Eleanor Herndon, supervisor of counseling in the Cumberland schools outside Fort Bragg. ''We also have a lot of wives under a lot of emotional and financial stress who are moving in with other families to cut expenses.
''If the Gulf crisis goes on for another month or so, I'm afraid we'll see these women pull their kids out of school and move back home to grandma. Some kids may lose a full year of school.''
School administrators shudder when they contemplate the possibility of Mideast combat and high American casualties. Dr. Richardson said the crisis intervention programs in the base schools were prepared to handle isolated incidents like a plane crash with 50 or 100 deaths. But he said they would be quickly overwhelmed ''with 2,000 to 3,000 killed in a day, which Saddam Hussein is telling us is going to happen.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: The new school year has been especially tense for children who have parents serving in the Middle East. At Jackson Elementary School in Fort Campbell, Ky., Leslie Dreaden, left, helped kindergarten and first-grade pupils put up pictures of parents in Saudi Arabia. (Dan Loftin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: WINE TALK

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
WHAT does a wine merchant have in common with a quarterback? They both look forward to autumn with a mixture of excitement and fear. If they don't make it in the next three and a half months, they don't make it.
Many retailers count on the pre-holiday and holiday season for 50 percent or more of their annual business. So far, this has not been a great year for the trade. Business has been slowing for several years, and merchants talk of a growing anti-alcohol movement, heightened consumer health concerns and tougher restrictions on drunken driving. 
Now they are also talking recession; sales in the first half of 1990 were off 20 percent for some merchants. And there is concern that a new oil crisis could set off inflation that could dampen sales even more. On top of that, the dollar remains weak against the currencies of the important wine-exporting nations, France, Italy and Spain. Some store owners are predicting an $8 price tag on Beaujolais nouveau, which arrives here in mid-November; last year it was $5 to $6.50. Still, this is the season when people buy most of their wine. And there are, and will continue to be, good buys in wine. In good times and bad, so much wine is produced around the world - far more than anyone can drink - that there will always be plenty of bottles at reasonable prices.
Some of the best buys these days are American wines. Many are old favorites that have been praised here before. A few are newcomers; all are worthy of your attention and your shrinking dollars.
Here are 10 California cabernet sauvignons, each at $10 or less, each as good as some wines at twice the price:
Beaulieu Vineyards Beau Tour 1987, $7; Beaulieu Vineyards Rutherford 1986, $8; Guenoc 1985, $9; Liberty School nonvintage, $6; Franciscan 1986, $10; Estancia 1987, $8; Rodney Strong 1986, $8; Fetzer Barrel Select 1986, $10; Konocti 1986, $8, and Pedroncelli 1985, $8. (Bear in mind that prices vary from shop to shop and region to region; these prices prevail in the competitive New York area.) Many of these same producers turn out good chardonnay in the same price range. As a rule, however, distinctive chardonnay is more expensive than distinctive cabernet. A few inexpensive chardonnays worth sampling are Bridgehampton (Long Island) 1988, $10; Liberty School nonvintage, $8; Clos du Bois Barrel Fermented 1988, $10; Stratford 1988, $8; Fetzer Sundial 1988, $7; Hawk Crest 1989, $7, and Franciscan 1988, $10.
Liberty School is the second label of Caymus Vineyards and Hawk Crest is the second label of Stag's Leap Wine Cellars, two of the Napa Valley's most prestigious wineries. Just slightly above the $10 cutoff but definitely worth including here is the 1988 Joli Val, about $11; this is the second label of Clos du Val, Bernard Portet's famous Napa Valley winery. Zinfandel, California's own red wine (even if it did come from Italy or Hungary long ago), has suffered in recent years from its association with white zinfandel. White zinfandel is slightly sweet and a bit fizzy. It's made mostly from zinfandel grapes, which are red but are crushed so as to avoid most contact between the skins and the juice. The skins have all the color; the juice is clear. Chenin blanc and other grapes are sometimes used in white zinfandel to add sweetness.
True zinfandel is a full-bodied red wine that has fallen into such eclipse that several producers now call it ''red zinfandel'' to distinguish it from white (which is really pink).
Sutter Home, the best-known maker of white zinfandel, started out making the traditional style and still makes some of the best reasonably priced ''zins,'' as Californians call them. Some shops have the regular Sutter Home zinfandel these days for around $4 a bottle. Others to look for include Ridge Vineyards Paso Robles 1987, $10; Ridge Howell Mountain 1987, $10; Ravenswood 1988, $8; Amador Foothills Fiddletown 1986, $7; Caymus Vineyards 1987, $8; Rafanelli 1988, $10; Gundlach-Bundschu 1988, $8, and Franciscan Oakville Estate 1988, $9. Pinot noir, the grape of Burgundy and Champagne, is fast finding favor in California, and especially in Oregon. It is hard to grow and often costs more than other red wines of similar quality. The best American pinot noirs, like Chalone and Calera and Kalin, are expensive, but a few decent ones can be found at reasonable prices. If you are expecting Gevrey-Chambertin, forget it, but for a true pinot noir taste in a relatively light-bodied wine, some of these should appeal to you:
Saintsbury Garnet 1989, $9; Carneros Creek Fleur de Carneros 1988, $10; Knudsen Erath (Oregon) 1987, $10; Edna Valley 1985, $12; Robert Mondavi 1987, $14.
A final note: While this column has largely been confined to California wines, it's worth noting that there is still plenty of good Beaujolais from the 1989 vintage, one of the best in recent years. Particularly in the ''cru'' Beaujolais, the 1989's will last for a couple of years. Laying in a few cases now could be an excellent hedge against higher prices to come - for wines that may not be as good.
The ''cru'' Beaujolais are the wines from the 10 famous towns and special vineyard areas like Morgon, Fleurie, Chiroubles, Julienas and Chenas. Some of the best 1989 Beaujolais climbed up as high as $14 a bottle, but there are still plenty of good wines for less. For example, all the wines in Georges Duboeuf's ''Flower Label'' series can be found for $11 or less, with the simple Beaujolais selling for about $6 and the Beaujolais-Villages for about $6.50. The lovely Chateau de la Chaize Fleurie 1989 is about $8.50.
 
TASTINGS
 
Lustau Reserva Light Fino Sherry, Solera Jarana; about $8.
In Jerez and elsewhere in Spain, fino sherry, the lightest, driest and most delicate of the various styles of sherry, is served ice cold and with fish. It is higher in alcohol than the white wines traditionally paired with seafood, but the tendency is to drink less of it. The nutty flavor and sharp bite of a good fino are a perfect accompaniment to a broiled fish. La Ina from Domecq and Gonzalez Byass's Tio Pepe are the best-known finos, but this one from Lustau deserves to be better known. These are not wines to age. They are at their best soon after they are bottled and should be drunk within a few years. Once opened, a bottle of fino begins to lose its freshness. It should be kept chilled and consumed within three or four days. But fino, like most sherries, is more often taken as an aperitif than with meals. Fino sherry is an excellent aperitif because it is so light. It cleanses the palate and will never impair the taste of the table wines to come.

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Jump By 0.8%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Spurred by the disruption in Persian Gulf oil supplies, the Consumer Price Index jumped eight-tenths of 1 percent in August, the biggest rise since the exceptional cold of January, the Labor Department reported today.
While the increase was no greater than generally expected, analysts nonetheless expressed concern that inflation, which was heading upward before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, would continue to worsen even as the economy stumbled into a recession.
Also today, the Commerce Department reported that the nation's trade deficit jumped in July to $9.3 billion, the second-highest monthly level this year. And despite word of an Iraqi troop buildup, crude oil prices slipped 22 cents, to $33.41 a barrel. [Pages D9 and D10.] 6.4 Percent for Three Months Excluding food and energy, which bounce around for reasons that often have little to do with underlying economic forces, prices at the consumer level rose five-tenths of 1 percent and have increased by 5.5 percent over the latest 12 months, compared with 5.6 percent for the broader index, and at a 6.4 percent annual pace for the three months ended in August. 
''We have a definite problem with the 'core' C.P.I.,'' said Michael L. Penzer, a senior economist at the Bank of America. He called services, as opposed to commodities, a particular worry, citing a second straight rise of nine-tenths of 1 percent last month in the cost of medical care.
The latest figures could have political repercussions. With Election Day just seven weeks off, consumer inflation has become especially sensitive and could, some think, impel the Bush Administration to tap the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to roll prices back. Gasoline is often called the most visible, and politically potent, price in the economy.
 
Full Effects Not Yet Felt
Moreover, the full effects on retail prices of this summer's doubling in the price of crude oil have yet to be felt. Today's report captured only those price increases that occurred before Aug. 24, and the statistical jolt for September, when the seasonal adjustment factor anticipates a decline, is likely to be similar to that for August, said Patrick C. Jackman, a Labor Department official.
The report offered little, if any, encouragement to policy makers at the Federal Reserve, who by all accounts would like to try to head off a recession by cutting interest rates but who cannot do so, at least without an agreement to reduce the budget deficit, for fear of making inflation worse. It is the core rate that the Fed watches most closely, making less of forces that could prove temporary.
The eight-tenths of 1 percent increase in the August Consumer Price Index, twice the July rise, was considerably less than the 1.3 percent August surge reported last week for the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, which measures prices of domestically produced goods one step short of the consumer.
This reflects not only a quicker impact at the production stage but the fact that energy accounts for a somewhat bigger proportion of the producer index, which does not cover services, than of the consumer index. The energy component is 9.2 percent of the producer index and 7.4 percent of the consumer index.
 
Gasoline Rises by 7.6 Percent
Petroleum accounted for a bit over 40 percent of the advance in the Consumer Price Index. and almost 90 percent of the 1.8 percent surge in the price of transportation, the Labor Department report showed. Gasoline rose 7.6 percent, raising the increase so far this year to 16.1 percent.
The price of new motor vehicles was unchanged last month - and has risen just 1.9 percent since August 1989, while used cars rose modestly for the month but remain 1.7 percent below the level of a year before. Automobile finance charges fell 1 percent last month.
A 15.4 percent jump in the price of fuel oil, following six straight declines, contributed to an August rise of seven-tenths of 1 percent in the price of housing, which accounts for 42 percent of the entire Consumer Price Index. Cable television continued to surge, by an additional 1.1 percent, and telephone charges soared 1.9 percent, mainly because of higher prices for local service.
 
Fruits and Vegetables Down
Food prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent, less than in June or July, as a 1.4 percent drop for fruits and vegetables more than offset increases in the other four major grocery store food groups. A 1.3 percent rise for dairy products was the biggest since January.
Clothing prices edged up one-tenth of 1 percent, reflecting more restrained pricing of new fall lines than some specialists expected.
The latest in a seemingly never-ending series of rapid increases in the cost of medical care brought prices to a level 9.5 percent above those of August 1989, with hospital and related services rising 1.4 percent last month and professional services rising eight-tenths of 1 percent.
Over all, the index that covers all urban consumers has now climbed at an annual rate of 6.2 percent over the first eight months of 1990, up from 4.8 percent during the same period last year.
 
Commodities and Services Up
Commmodities, including fuel, rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in August, while services rose seven-tenths. They represent 45 percent and 55 percent, respectively, of the index.
Excluding energy, the index rose four-tenths of 1 percent in August compared with a five-tenths of 1 percent increase in July.
New York suffered the highest August inflation rate of the five metropolitan areas whose price indexes are published monthly. A 1.2 percent surge mainly reflected higher rents and other shelter costs, but the Labor Department was unwilling to state that the area's real estate market had stabilized. Prices rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in Chicago, seven-tenths in Philadelphia, six-tenths in San Francisco and five-tenths in Los Angeles.
Before rounding, the urban consumer index climbed 0.7662835 percent last month, a rate that if maintained and compounded over 12 months would produce annual inflation of 9.6 percent.
A companion inflation gauge, the index covering urban wage earners and clerical workers, also rose eight-tenths of 1 percent last month. This index, used for indexing Federal benefits and private contracts, now stands 5.4 percent above its August 1989 level.

HEADLINE: New York Developers Feel a Chill

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
There is little doubt that the deep slump in demand for offices and high-priced apartments has caught New York City real estate developers off guard, but different developers have been stung in different ways. While many are struggling with too much space and too few tenants, not all face the gargantuan financial pressures looming over Donald J. Trump.
The worst off, like David and Jean Solomon, young builders who invested heavily at the peak of the 1980's boom, put up large office towers without commitments from tenants to fill them. Among their troubled properties is a 35-story, 1.3-million-square-foot building at 1585 Broadway, between West 47th and 48th Streets.
Those less hurt by the slump, like Lewis Rudin, are members of long-established real estate families who approached the market conservatively. They tended to take on just one project at a time, sticking to proven commercial locations and obtaining traditional bank financing. The Rudin family's holdings are worth at least $1.5 billion, and include a 35-story office tower at the corner of Broadway and West 52d Street. 
 
Newcomers Hurt the Most
''Those who were newcomers to the process are taking the brunt of the downturn,'' said John R. White, the chairman emiritus of Landauer Associates, a real estate consulting firm. ''But I can't imagine there is a single well-known, long-term New York developer who won't survive this slump.''
One reason is that demand for new offices, although weak, is not dead and gone. Several large companies, including the Sony Corporation of America and the Bertelsmann Publishing Group, are known to be in the market for large blocks of Manhattan office space.
''There are going to be pockets of disaster and pockets of joy,'' said Maurice Solomon, manager of the midtown Manhattan office of Julien J. Studley, a commercial brokerage.
Most severely affected are investors who fueled the city's surge of conversions of rental housing to cooperative apartments in the early 1980's. Residential developers are also being squeezed, and are facing bank foreclosures on some projects.
Even so, some still thrive through luck or acute judgment. Here is how six city developers are faring.
 
Larry A. Silverstein
Showing Bruises, But Surviving
Larry A. Silverstein is a bruised combatant in the Manhattan real estate slump, but is a survivor so far. ''We are in a market that is generally faced with oversupply,'' the developer said, ''and the thirst for new product isn't there.''
Mr. Silverstein, the 59-year-old president of Silverstein Properties, made his biggest imprint on the skyline in late 1986, when his firm completed 7 World Trade Center, a 47-story, two-million-square-foot tower just north of the World Trade Center. The building immediately ran into trouble when Drexel Burnham Lambert Group, which had signed on to lease all of it, was rocked by an insider trading scandal and backed out.
Mr. Silverstein's problems worsened a year later, when the stock market crashed in October 1987. In November 1988, he was able to lease half of the space in the building to Salomon Brothers Inc. But even now, 20 percent of the space in 7 World Trade Center is vacant.
On other projects in the city, Mr. Silverstein worked with partners, and his developments mushroomed in the late 1980's. With two fellow developers, William Zeckendorf Jr. and Melvin Simon, he renovated the former Gimbels department store at Herald Square into A.& S. Plaza, a one-million-square-foot shopping mall. They also built Park Avenue Court, a condominium building that is nearing completion over the site of another former Gimbels store at 86th Street and Lexington Avenue.
With financing from the General Electric Pension Fund, he also built the Embassy Suites Hotel, a 460-room hotel at Broadway and 47th Street that is set to open next month.
In an interview, Mr. Silverstein denied rumors in New York real estate circles that he is pressed for cash and negotiating to turn over part of his equity in 7 World Trade Center and A.& S. Plaza to his lenders. He did say that he and the G.E. pension fund had recently tried to sell the Embassy Suites hotel to raise cash, but had not received an acceptable bid.
Mr. Silverstein began acquiring loft space in the 1950's, bought larger office buildings in the 1970's and now controls more than 10 million square feet in 13 buildings. Having decided not to invest in new projects until the city's economy recovers, he has dismissed 10 people from his staff of 110, including his head of development.
''I do not expect there will be any major new development activity for the next few years,'' he said.
 
David and Jean Solomon
Quick Successes, Then a Squeeze
David and Jean Solomon caught the crest of the New York real estate wave a decade ago and moved up from renovating lofts to building big office and condominium buildings. But the husband-and-wife team, both 38-year-old architects, are now struggling to fill huge blocks of space in the severely overbuilt office market in midtown Manhattan.
The Solomons, who own Solomon Equities Inc., began renovating Manhattan lofts in the mid-1970's and quickly moved on to bigger projects, scoring some resounding successes. One was Tower 49, an office building on 49th Street east of Fifth Avenue that they completed in 1984 and sold two years later to a Japanese company for a hefty $303 million, or $500 a square foot. That price sent waves of envy through their New York real estate competitors even at a time when values were surging all around.
They then joined several other developers who were moving aggressively into the western half of midtown Manhattan. Taking advantage of city zoning incentives that allowed them to construct bigger buildings than were allowed elsewhere, the developers turned the midtown side streets between the Avenue of the Americas and Eighth Avenue into a grid of noisy, dusty construction sites.
The Solomons built two office towers under the zoning program, one 35 stories with 580,000 square feet at 750 Seventh Avenue, between 49th and 50th Streets, and a larger 35-story, 1.3-million-square-foot building at 1585 Broadway, between 47th and 48th Streets. They also built one that did not qualify for zoning benefits, a 53 story, 545,000-square-foot building at 712 Fifth Avenue, at 56th Street.
Problems came long before the three buildings were completed this year, as the city's economy faltered amid continuing repercussions of the 1987 stock market collapse. The Solomons declined to comment, but a spokeswoman, Maureen Connoly, said none of the three buildings was more than 45 percent leased.
Real estate executives said that the Solomons were in a tightening financial squeeze because they took on only one partner in the the midtown development blitz, A. Alfred Taubman, the shopping mall builder, who helped to finance 712 Fifth Avenue. That leaves them with limited financial resources to rely on if their buildings do not attract more tenants soon.
 
Lewis and Jack Rudin
Old-Fashioned Empire Building
With a family real estate empire of 39 large Manhattan buildings, the Rudin Management Company appears to be weathering the slump better than most developers. ''We don't need marketing studies,'' said Lewis Rudin, who is 62 and runs the company with his brother, Jack, who is 66. ''When the time is right, we build.'' The Rudins' latest venture is 1675 Broadway, a 35-story office tower at 52d Street that was completed in September, as more than a dozen other new commercial towers were rising in that overbuilt part of midtown. But unlike most of the others, the Rudins' building has quickly filled with large tenants, including D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Inc., the advertising firm, and Entertainment Weekly, the new Time Warner magazine.
The Broadway building is one of three office projects the Rudins have finished since 1980. The others, at 560 Lexington Avenue and 40 East 52d Street, are nearly fully leased.
Analysts say the Rudins' real estate holdings are worth at least $1.5 billion. They have been assembled over more than 60 years, beginning with acquisitions by Samuel Rudin, their father. Lewis Rudin said the family had maintained a consistent approach to development, putting up one building at a time, operating without partners and relying on conventional bank financing. The Rudin family has never sold a building.
Even they have not escaped the real estate downturn unscathed. One of their office buildings near Wall Street, at 55 Broad, was left nearly vacant last year by Drexel Burnham Lambert, which collapsed and filed for bankruptcy protection. Drexel had been the anchor tenant.
 
Harry Macklowe
Seeing Chances In a Dim Market
The roaring '80s brought a turning point in the career of Harry Macklowe, and it came long before the real estate market began to falter. The developer's public image took a dive in 1985 when several buildings he owned near Times Square were bulldozed overnight, without regard to safety precautions. The action was taken to beat a pending city moratorium on the demolition of single-room-occupancy hotels.
The legal problems stemming from the incident were resolved. In fact, Mr. Macklowe got back $3.2 million this year that he had paid the city in compensation for demolishing the buildings when a court ruled that the city law requiring the compensation was illegal. And his real estate company, the Macklowe Organization, has flourished.
''Opportunities in a down market are more problematic, but there are still opportunities,'' said Kent M. Swig, the developer's executive vice president and son-in-law. Mr. Macklowe, who is 52 years old, declined to be interviewed.
With several new buildings in Manhattan, the Macklowe Organization's biggest problem appears to be 125 West 55th Street, a 23-story, 550,000-square-foot office tower that was finished in September. Tenants have proved elusive. Mr. Swig said only 20 percent of the building was rented.
Mr. Macklowe, who began his carreer as a commercial real estate broker in the early 1960's, has had better success with residential projects. One is Metropolitan Tower, a 78-story condominium just east of Carnegie Hall on West 57th Street, completed in December 1986 at the height of Manhattan's apartment-buying frenzy. Mr. Swig said all Metropolitan Tower apartments, except for one penthouse, had been sold.
Mr. Macklowe's latest project is the Hotel Macklowe, a 52-story, 638-room hotel on West 44th Street off Broadway - the site cleared when the single-room-occupancy hotels were demolished in 1985. The hotel opened in June to the praise of architectual critics for its lobby and interior design. Industry analysts expect it to capture a lucrative niche in the crowded Manhattan tourism and convention market.
Mr. Macklowe has also diversified outside this area. He is building a 400,000-square-foot office building in downtown Los Angeles, where demand remains stronger than in New York, and plans a hotel on land he owns next door. In July, he acquired the residential management operations of M. J. Raynes and Company, which manages more than 11,000 New York City cooperatives and condominiums. The price was not disclosed.
 
Francis Greenburger
A Troubled Realm For 'Co-op King'
To thousands of New Yorkers, being an ''insider'' in the conversion of rental housing to cooperative apartments was a fast track to wealth in the 1980's. Now no one knows the painful consequences better than Francis Greenburger, owner of Time Equities Inc.
Mr. Greenburger, who is 41, converted more than 10,000 apartments in New York to cooperatives in the early 1980's, earning the nickname the ''King of Co-ops.'' Starting with a row of tenement buildings in Greenwich Village, he bought more than 100 rental buildings and offered their tenants, protected from eviction by New York's tough rent regulations, the chance to buy their apartments at prices that were hard to refuse in a giddy real estate boom.
Where tenants did not buy, Mr. Greenburger sold occupied apartments to outside investors. The approach worked well until changes in the Federal tax law in 1986 eliminated many of the tax incentives that had attracted investors to rental housing.
That did not stop Mr. Greenburger. By using the rental apartments in his cooperatives as collateral for bank loans, he covered a large swath of the New York housing landscape with the Time Equities name, from a large complex in the middle-income Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn to the huge Tudor City complex next to the United Nations on the East Side of Manhattan.
More recently, in financial disclosures required by the State of New York, Mr. Greenburger said he was behind on bank loans or other obligations involving 88 of his buildings. In later filings, he said the delinquencies had spread to 102 buildings.
His problems are creating difficult choices for his lenders, which want some assurance of payment but are not eager to foreclose on occupied apartments and become landlords. But in the case of Time Equities, many have done just that. In an interview, Mr. Greenburger said half of the apartments he had put up as collateral had been taken over by his lenders, and that the lenders had made up any payments past due to the buildings for maintenance, reserve funds and other obligations.
''Where we haven't reached work-out situations with banks, we hope to do so,'' he said.
 
Martin J. Raynes
Greener Pastures Across the River
Martin J. Raynes brought mega-deals to the business of cooperative conversions. Now, to avoid financial collapse, he has given up a vast portfolio of real estate holdings.
Mr. Raynes, who is 44, the president of M. J. Raynes & Company, converted more than 20,000 rental apartments to co-operatives in the 1970's and 1980's, along the way building an apartment management and brokerage company that employed more than 400.
His biggest investment came in 1985 when he purchased 6,200 apartments, including the eight-building Lincoln Towers complex near Lincoln Center, from the MacArthur Foundation for $500 million. He made the deal as a partner with the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States and a fellow investor, Bernard Mendik.
But like other co-op converters, Mr. Raynes ran into trouble when tax changes in 1986 discouraged people from investing in occupied rental apartments. His problems grew worse as the entire co-op market sank in the last two years.
In June, he sold the management company he had formed, which had 11,300 apartments under management, to the Macklowe Organization.
And in July, unable to honor a $5.5 million personal loan guarantee, Mr. Raynes negotiated new terms with Mr. Mendik and Equitable that made him a limited partner in the MacArthur Foundation properties. The partners also refinanced a $170 million loan from the Chase Manhattan Bank, which had been extended with rental apartments in the buildings used as collateral.
Having all but left the co-op conversion business, Mr. Raynes has now joined a development team that includes William Zeckendorf Jr. and several investors in a large plan to develop a new waterfront community along the East River in the Hunters Point section of Queens.
In an interview, Mr. Raynes said he was also planning to build office parks for the University of Virginia in Charlottesville and for the University of Missouri branch in Kansas City. He also said he was forming a partnership with an investment banking firm and a residential real estate brokerage to invest in distressed properties taken over by banks and savings and loan companies in the Northeast. He declined to name his partners in the venture.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Cold War On U.S. Exports

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
LIKE the Berlin wall, barriers to trade in high technology are falling to the riptides of political change in Eastern Europe. And not a moment too soon, says Robert Kuttner, an economist and journalist, whose study condemning cold war export restrictions was released yesterday by the Economic Policy Institute in Washington. Zealously enforced export controls in the United States, Mr. Kuttner argues, have amounted to an ''industrial policy in reverse.''
The restrictions have not been particularly effective in preventing the transfer of militarily useful technology to the Soviet Union, he believes. But they have managed to undermine America's export advantage as the leader in high technology. 
The Export Control Act of 1949 gave the White House sweeping powers to limit the transfer of civilian technology that would improve the Warsaw Pact's military capability. The other anti-Soviet industrial powers - Japan, Western Europe, Australia - were pressed to adopt parallel controls on such ''dual use'' technologies. And the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls (Cocom for short) was created to keep the allies pulling in harness.
Dual-use controls were needed to slow the big Red machine, Mr. Kuttner concedes. But they have become ever harder to administer as the number of high-technology products proliferated and America's postwar monopoly on sophisticated technology eroded.
The Commerce Department's list of dual-use products, covering everything from chemicals to memory chips, now runs to 128 pages. Roughly 40 percent of American industrial exports fit into the category, and some 200,000 applications for individual export licenses must be processed each year.
According to a 1987 study by the National Academy of Sciences, most export applications were processed within two months and fewer than 2 percent were ultimately denied. But the system is complicated enough, Mr. Kuttner points out, to discourage smaller companies that balk at hiring $200-an-hour lawyers to grease the wheels of commerce. Speedier processing, moreover, gives foreign competitors an edge: the Japanese turn around an application in an average of three days.
Then, too, Mr. Kuttner argues, American regulators have been far less inclined than the allies to give exporters the benefit of a doubt. For example, in 1989, Siemens, the German electronics giant, sauntered away with a $1 billion order for personal computers from the Soviet Union after American regulators discouraged the Atari Corporation from competing. And the diffusion of technology to countries outside Cocom has compounded the problems of American exporters: If a comparable gadget could be purchased from Taiwan or Brazil at a comparable price, why fight American red tape?
The National Academy of Sciences put the cost of the restrictions at about $9 billion a year. Representative Sam Gejdenson, a Connecticut Democrat who is the chairman of a House subcommittee on international economic policy, says that American companies lose up to $50 billion a year in revenues. He may be inclined to hyperbole, but there is little doubt that American companies are hurting.
Under pressure from Congress and the allies -not to mention Mikhail Gorbachev - the Bush Administration decided this year to worry less and sell more. In June Cocom agreed to ease restrictions on exports to the Soviets and phase out all controls on sales to Eastern Europe. The same month the House passed a bill liberalizing United States controls. And just last week the Senate weighed in with its own liberalization plan.
Mr. Kuttner is encouraged, but is not about to break out the (California) champagne. While the new policy of building higher fences around fewer products makes sense, he believes that hard-liners in the Pentagon will still manage a rear-guard campaign against major changes.
Worse yet, Mr. Kuttner points out, the debate over which dual-use technologies can be exported to which of our former enemies will distract from a more urgent problem: preventing the diffusion of deadly technology through the non-industrial world. Cocom's 17 members compose elaborate lists of products that cannot be sold to the Soviet Union, but each nation is free to make its own export rules for Iraq, Libya and Iran.
Like almost everyone else, Mr. Kuttner believes it is important to keep weapons of mass destruction out of the hands of megalomaniacs. But that is easier said than done. Indeed, the problematic history of cold war restrictions on dual-use technologies suggests that it may not be doable. Saddam Hussein may not be able to nuke Riyadh (or New York), but give it time.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Successor to Chief Picked at Fannie Mae

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
The Federal National Mortgage Association said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, David O. Maxwell, will retire Jan. 31 and that James A. Johnson, currently vice chairman, will take his place.
Mr. Johnson, 46 years old, who has had a varied career on Wall Street and in Washington, joined Fannie Mae, as the association is known, in January as vice chairman. He had been an adviser to the company for five years. 
Mr. Maxwell, 60, said he had accomplished what he set out to do and was making way for fresh leadership after 10 years in the job. At a news conference in Washington, he said that Fannie Mae faced a big challenge in a changing economic and social setting and would be under increasing pressure because of the savings and loan crisis and the downturn in the real estate market. The Congressionally chartered, shareholder-owned company is the nation's largest investor in home mortgages.
So far it has done well, and Mr. Maxwell said that the condition of the company had never been stronger. At the end of the second quarter, Fannie Mae completed 10 consecutive quarters of record earnings and added $1.8 billion to capital and reserves, bringing the total to more than $4 billion.
Mr. Johnson said yesterday that despite problems in the economy, Fannie Mae ''has been more and more successful in making a contribution to housing in America and we feel extraordinarily well positioned for the future.''
Before joining Fannie Mae, Mr. Johnson was a managing director of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. for five years. Before that, he was president of Public Strategies, a Washington consulting firm, and served as an executive assistant to a fellow Minnesotan, Vice President Walter F. Mondale. Mr. Johnson grew up in a political household - his father was Speaker of the Minnesota House -and Mr. Mondale was a family friend. Mr. Johnson was chairman of Mr. Mondale's Presidential campaign.
Mr. Johnson holds a degree in political science from the University of Minnesota and a master's degree in public affairs from the Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton University.
Earlier in his career, Mr. Johnson worked for the Dayton Hudson Corporation, a Minneapolis-based department store chain; as a staff member in the Senate, and on the faculty of the Wilson School at Princeton, where he was also assistant director of the graduate program.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
A Top Position Is Filled By Alaska Airlines

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Alaska Airlines yesterday named Raymond J. Vecci, its chief operating officer, as its president and chief executive.
Mr. Vecci, 47, takes over the posts from Bruce R. Kennedy, who remains chairman. Mr. Kennedy is also president and chief executive of Alaska Air Group Inc., the holding company for the airline.
Mr. Vecci, who has been chief operating officer since 1986, comes from the Bronx and is a graduate of the City College of New York and New York University, where he received his master's degree in finance and economics. 
While going to school in New York, Mr. Vecci landed a part-time job with the International Air Transport Association. ''It was an accident that I got into the industry,'' he said. ''I just happened to hit on that job and I began to like it.''
After he finished school he took a job with United Airlines in Chicago and remained there for seven years before switching to Seattle-based Alaska Airlines in 1971.
Mr. Vecci began at the airline as assistant vice president for planning, and as chief operating officer, he was responsible for flight operations, maintenance, customer service planning, marketing and just about everything else. Mr. Vecci said the airline was looking for someone to fill the post he is vacating.
For years, the airline provided the air link between Seattle and Alaska and still does. But in the last 10 years, it has expanded as a north-south carrier, with many flights that go nowhere near Alaska. The airline, which flies to California points and four Mexican cities, is expanding its service to Mexico with new routes.
Next month, Mr. Vecci said, there will be Alaska Airlines flights from Los Angeles to Mexico. ''We think we can continue to grow on the West Coast,'' he said.
The other expansion is between Alaska and the Soviet Union, for which the airline has preliminary approval. If all goes well, it will start service next June from Anchorage to Magadan and Khabarovsk in the eastern part of the Soviet Union and operate through the summer initially.
''This is a virgin market,'' Mr. Vecci said. ''It's hard to tell how much business it will attract. We think we can generate an interest by tourists and Alaskan businessmen. But we'll have to wait and see.''

HEADLINE: Long Takeover Battle for UAL Raises Doubts Over Sale

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 18

 BODY:
A growing number of people following the takeover battle at the UAL Corporation are concluding that the parent of United Airlines will not be sold.
Analysts, stock traders and airline industry consultants agree that a sale of UAL is still possible. Indeed, UAL's stock surged by $7.625 today, to $105 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange after The Wall Street Journal reported that a $175-a-share bid was likely. One view is that UAL's board would at least listen to an offer below $201 a share, which an employee-led group offered earlier this year. 
''They won't necessarily dismiss such an offer out of hand,'' said Thomas Longman, an analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company. ''Given the current sluggish economic conditions and the higher fuel costs, the directors will have to consider those factors in light of any new offer that comes out.''
 
Reasons to Spurn Lower Bid
Rumors of a lower bid have been circulating in recent days, but the view is that the directors would reject such a bid. If the employee group lowers its bid to around $175, several reasons for rejecting it can be cited.
For one thing, at a meeting of the UAL board in early August, the employee-led group assured board members that financing for a $201-a-share offer could be obtained if the group was given extra time to line up the money. The board granted an extension, to Oct. 9.
Thus, if the employees came back with a new, lower offer, the board could view such a move as duplicitous. It could also conclude that the buyout group does not have a solid understanding of UAL's prospects.
Second, no compelling reason exists to sell UAL. Unlike in the past, when large institutional investors like Marvin Davis, the California financier, and Coniston Partners L.P., the New York-based group, were acquiring large blocks, there is no sign of anyone resembling a raider.
The company is not short of cash, and UAL's stock has traded well above $201 a share, suggesting that the company's directors, if they were sued by disgruntled shareholders, could justify having held out for a higher price.
''If the company is not sold, it will just go on operating as it has been,'' said Sharon J. Kalin, a stock trader who has followed the UAL situation since 1987, the year the first of five bids for the company was made.
 
Successful Asian Flights
Finally, United is doing well these days - better than most of its competitors and better than in recent years. This is partly a result of United's Chicago-to-Europe flights, which have been expanded recently. But the real key is United's East Asian flights, which are packed and which offer the carrier higher profits than the domestic runs.
With UAL's Asian business booming and prospects bright, the directors could conclude that they would be selling the company on the cheap if they accepted less than $201 a share. That offer is a third below the $300-a-share bid that a management-led group offered before it found itself unable to secure financing.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Climbs to $9.33 Billion

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit jumped in July to $9.33 billion, the second-highest monthly level this year, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. And the rising cost of imported oil suggests that for the rest of this year the deficit might remain stuck at $8 billion to $9 billion a month.
Still, exports remained strong enough in July, at $32.03 billion, to continue to serve as a big prop for the United States economy, which is in danger of moving into a recession. The concern among economists centered on imports, which rose to $41.36 billion in July, although the sluggish American economy should reduce the demand for foreign goods. 
Both the export and import numbers were roughly in line with the monthly averages in 1990 - $32.5 billion for exports and $40.4 billion for imports. June produced the year's only big departure from the norm; a surge in exports brought a record $34.2 billion in sales abroad, and the trade deficit declined to $5.3 billion, well below the $8.2 billion monthly average for the first five months of 1990. The high for the year was January's $10,2 billion deficit.
 
Closer to the Norm
Most economists view June's surge in exports as an aberration, while July's $32.03 billion in sales abroad is considered closer to the norm. Surveys of manufacturers, especially one by the National Association of Purchasing Management, show that exports are no longer growing at the robust pace that brought them from the level of $30 billion a month in 1989.
''Even with a weak dollar, which should give our exports a boost, we seem unable to push them up any further and keep the deficit shrinking,'' said Lawrence Chimerine, an economics consultant.
Until now, the deficit had declined steadily from $160 billion in 1987 and $118 billion in 1989. But with export growth subsiding and the rising cost of oil beginning to add billions to the nation's import bill, the deficit is likely to stick for a while at its current annual level of $95 billion, Mr. Chimerine and other economists said.
Two products accounted for nearly half of the $2.2 billion decline in exports from June through July. One was a $600 million drop in the overseas sale of soybeans, corn and other agricultural goods; the other a $490 million decline in the sale of commercial aircraft abroad.
Bumper crops elsewhere in the world helps to explain the drop in agricultural exports, economists said. Aircraft sales bounce around from month to month, and seem likely to recover in August, given the order backlog from foreign airlines for Boeing aircraft.
Imports rose by $1.8 billion from June to July, and robust purchases of foreign-made consumer goods accounted for nearly $700 million of this total, the Commerce Department reported. Most of these imports were clothing, jewelry and toys, items not likely to remain in great demand in a sluggish economy. ''With retail sales weak, such imports probably went into inventory, unsold,'' said Peter L. Bernstein, an economics consultant.
 
More Oil Imported
Although oil prices had fallen in July, the nation's oil imports rose in value by nearly $300 million, mostly because more oil was imported. Most economists expect the value of oil imports to rise much more sharply in August and September, reflecting the huge increase in oil prices since the Iraq invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.
Capital goods imports also rose strongly in July, reflecting the dependence of American companies on machinery, semiconductors and electronic equipment purchased abroad. East Asia is a big source of these goods, and imports from Singapore, Hong Kong, Taiwan and South Korea have risen all year, taking a particularly sharp jump in July. The nation's deficit with these newly industrialized countries rose to $2.45 billion from $1.34 billion in June.

HEADLINE: October Oil Contract Falls Slightly

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil for October delivery fell slightly in the futures market yesterday, after breaking a seven-year-old record on Monday.
The October contract fell 22 cents, to $33.41 a barrel, which was still the second-highest level since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, when the price of oil began to rise from about $23 a barrel.
The decline came despite word from the Pentagon that Baghdad has sharply increased the number of its troops and tanks in Kuwait and southern Iraq over the past week to 10 days. Traders attributed the decline to profit-taking after the rise in price the day before. 
Crude oil contracts for the next three delivery months were up slightly, reflecting the market's attempt to narrow the range of prices for oil delivered in the near term.
''It was sort of a day of consolidation,'' said Ed Kevelson, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
On Monday, crude oil jumped $1.87 a barrel, to $33.63, the highest level since the New York Mercantile Exchange began the trading of oil futures contracts on March 30, 1983. The previous record was $32.20 a barrel, set in August 1983. But adjusted for inflation, the peak price in August 1983 would correspond to a price of nearly $44 a barrel now.
Among other petroleum products, home heating oil continued to outpace unleaded gasoline because of seasonal fluctuations.
Heating oil was up 1.12 cents, to 86.43 cents a gallon, on October contracts, with other months also higher.
Unleaded gasoline fell 0.06 cent, to 91.61 cents a gallon, for October contracts, with November contracts down slightly and later contracts higher.
Natural gas rose to $1.560 cents per 1,000 cubic feet on October contracts, up from $1.537 on Monday.
After the market closed yesterday, the American Petroleum Institute released weekly inventory figures that indicated the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 and the resulting embargo were apparently beginning to have a physical effect in this country, with imports dropping to 6 million barrels a day for the week ended Sept. 14. Last week the figure was unusually high, 6.9 million barrels a day; a year ago, it was 6.4 million, according to the institute, the industry's main trade association.
As a result, stocks were down, to 369.8 million barrels, from 374.3 million in the previous week, but were still far ahead of last year, when they were 329 million barrels.
The institute also released figures that in more settled times would push gasoline and heating oil prices lower. Gasoline stocks reached 217.0 million barrels, up from 211.1 a week earlier and near the 218.6 million at this time last year; gasoline production was up to 7.4 million barrels a day, from 7.3 million in the previous week and 7.1 million in the previous year. Imports were up slightly, to 282,000 barrels a day, from 261,000 barrels a day in the previous week and 355,000 barrels a day in the same week last year.
Stocks of distillate, which is used as heating oil and diesel fuel, rose to 133.3 million barrels, up from 131.7 million in the previous week and well ahead of the 121.4 million barrels in the coresponding week last year.
Imports rose to 394,000 barrels a day, from 242,000 barrels a day in the previous week and 236,000 a year ago.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Curbing U.S. Oil Appetite: Why It's So Hard

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Oil, like ice cream or french fries, is something Americans enjoy but would be better off consuming less of. But it is also very hard to get away from, for engineering reasons as well as historical and economic ones.
The biggest obstacle is that no other fuel holds so much energy in such a small, light package, least of all the readily available substitutes of coal or electricity. What is more, 80 years into the automobile era, everything is built around gasoline, an investment of billions in refineries, tanker trucks and gasoline stations.
And even at the modestly elevated price now, few of the alternatives approach being economically competitive with oil. That is particularly important because many Americans have come to feel almost as if they have a constitutional right to low-priced gasoline and do not see much point in paying higher taxes or higher prices for substitutes. 
The addiction to oil is worse for the United States than for any other country. The American economy is the biggest and its thirst for oil the greatest. And per capita oil consumption in the United States is more than double that of France, Britain and Japan.
The main reason for the difference is the automobile. Of the 17.3 million barrels of oil used each day last year, 10.9 million, or 62.7 percent, went into transportation, most of it for gasoline. In a recent study, Lee Schipper, an energy analyst at Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, calculated that Americans used about 350 gallons of gasoline per person in 1987, compared with 150 gallons in West Germany.
Higher fuel efficiency would help; if the average American car were as fuel-efficient as the average German car, American consumption would have been about 75 gallons lower, he calculated. But about another 75 gallons of difference resulted because Americans travel more miles. Still another reason for greater gasoline use is that this country has more cars per 1,000 population. Americans traveled more than 11,000 miles by car that year, on average, while West Germans drove 5,000 miles. Americans, in a bigger country, tend to drive farther to work and play.
 
Drawbacks of Other Fuels
Candidates for a new transportation fuel abound, but they all have strong disadvantages.
Foremost are the technical reasons. No fuel, natural or synthetic, carries so much energy around in such a small package. A gallon of gasoline, which weighs about 7 pounds, has as much energy as 11 pounds of coal, and coal, as a solid, is more difficult to handle. Coal can yield a liquid fuel, methanol, but that has only about half the energy of gasoline per gallon. (Also working against this solution is that more than conventional gasoline, methanol from coal introduces gases that are thought to promote climate change. Also, burning methanol from any source produces formaldehyde and other pollutants.) A pound of natural gas will take a car about as far as a pound of gasoline, but the natural gas takes up much more space: The energy in one gallon of gasoline would require, at atmospheric pressure, a container of gas in a cube nearly 5 feet on each side. The natural gas can be squeezed into a far smaller volume, but that requires a very heavy tank.
And the amount of natural gas needed would be vast. For households that heat the structure, cook and heat water with natural gas, for example, converting the family car to natural gas would more than double their energy demand. If millions of vehicles were converted, more wells would have to be drilled and many more transmission pipelines built.
As for electricity, it is abundant because it can be made from coal, but the space problem is even worse than for natural gas. If the amount of energy stored in 12 gallons of gasoline were instead stored in lead-acid batteries like the ones typically used for cranking and ignition in cars, the battery would weigh nearly a ton and a half, about as much as a small car.
 
Historical Momentum
Providing nearly 100 billion gallons of gasoline a year has created a momentum that would be difficult for any competing fuel to overcome. ''It takes mucho, mucho billions, not only to develop and produce a fuel, but to produce an infrastructure,'' said Daniel Yergin, president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates of Cambridge, Mass. ''Gasoline won the struggle for automotive fuel at the turn of the century, and everything has been invested in that ever since.'' Mr. Yergin said that gasoline was once viewed as a useless byproduct of kerosene, which was used for home heating, and was therefore readily available when cars first appeared.
Cars at the turn of the century ran on everything from electricity to ''town gas,'' which was produced by heating coal at central stations, mostly for lighting streets and homes and for cooking. A variety of petroleum products including naphtha were also tried. Some Stanley Steamers ran on kerosene.
''At the very beginning of the auto industry, they didn't know what cars were going to run on,'' said James A. Wren, the chairman of the Society of Automotive Engineers history group. Alcohol was so popular, he said, that in France grape growers feared there would be nothing left for drinking.
Mr. Wren traces the dominance of gasoline to nearly simultaneous developments: the Spindletop gusher, the large oil find in Texas that pushed oil prices below 5 cents a barrel, and Oldsmobile's open two-seater runabouts, called the Curved Dash Olds, which ran on gasoline. At that point, in 1901, ''you had a mass-produced car and a cheap fuel.''
The range of options is larger now in a technological sense but not in an economic sense. Theodore Eck, the chief economist at Amoco, estimated that liquid vehicle fuel made from this country's most abundant hydrocarbon, coal, would not compete until oil prices reached $40 to $50 a barrel.
 
Turning to Unconventional Oil
Another possibility is ordinary gasoline made from abundant but unconventional oil, as from tar sands or shale, which generally requires mining rock and cooking it to make the oil come out. Chevron this spring estimated that such oils would be competitive with a world price of $25 to $40 a barrel in 1990 dollars. But while oil has jumped past $30 a barrel in recent weeks, oil executives say that because of the long lead times and heavy capital investments, it must be obvious to investors that the price will stay there. Today, that is like betting on Saddam Hussein's job tenure.
Some fuels are available today at a price lower than gasoline's, but they entail other costs. A kilowatt-hour of electricity, for example, will propel a van about two miles, and the national average cost is about 8 cents, which is equivalent to gasoline at 80 cents a gallon in a 20-mile-per-gallon vehicle. And utilities say they could sell power for much less in off-peak hours, for drivers who charged their batteries at night. But because of the current state of battery technology, the vehicle itself would be uncompetitive.
 
Other Costs Involved
Some utilities will sell natural gas for vehicle use at a price equivalent to 70 cents a gallon of gasoline. But switching fuels means developing a vehicle engine that runs on something else, which could cost hundreds of millions of dollars, and providing a network of fueling stations.
Amoco, which recently began selling natural gas at two stations as an experiment, puts the cost of adding a natural gas pump at about $250,000 per station. With environmental regulations governing underground storage tanks, costs for other kinds of fuels would also be high. And the United States has about 200,000 places that sell gasoline; a substantial fraction of them would have to offer a different kind of fuel before most Americans would buy it.
Mr. Eck at Amoco said that if Detroit would build cars that could switch from gasoline to natural gas, ''we could build the fueling stations a lot faster than they could build the cars.'' Sold in volume, he said, a car equipped to burn natural gas as well as gasoline would cost as little as $300 extra.
But the auto makers show little enthusiasm for heavy new investments for a product for which the public is not clamoring.
