HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Little Changed in Slow Day

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in slow but bumpy trading yesterday.
Reports on the merchandise trade deficit and consumer prices, which showed that the nation's trade deficit widened sharply in July and that consumer prices last month shot up by the largest amount since January, depressed the prices of fixed-income securities early in the day.
But a drop in oil prices and a softening in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market later forced traders to buy securities.
The funds rate, which traded at 7 3/4 percent to 7 7/8 percent early in the day, tumbled to under 7 percent early in the afternoon. 
 
No More Reserves Added
Although some market participants said the weakness in the funds rate might be indicative of an easing in Federal Reserve policy, most analysts attributed the decline to the amount of reserves in the banking system. The Fed, which added reserves to the banking system on Monday, did not add any more yesterday.
At this time of year, reserves are usually drawn because corporations and individuals make quarterly income tax payments.
''At the time the Fed would normally come in to the market, funds were trading at around 8 percent,'' said Darwin L. Beck, an economist at the First Boston Corporation. ''If the Fed had wanted to signal a policy change, that would have been a perfect time to do it. In my view, what happened was a temporary glitch in terms of reserve needs, and it means nothing in terms of a change in Fed policy.''
The Fed's target, or equilibrium, level for the funds rate has been at 8 percent since mid-July, analysts say.
 
Budget Talks Continue
Budget developments in Washington were not reflected in the credit markets yesterday. With the talks apparently at an impasse, some market participants said the chances were growing that on Oct. 1, the start of the 1991 fiscal year, $100 billion in cuts would be made under the terms of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings legislation for balancing the budget.
''Sequestration is a distinct possibility,'' said Peter Bass, a managing director at S. G. Warburg Securities Inc., referring to the across-the-board budget cuts that will take effect on Oct. 1 under the legislation unless a budget agreement is reached. ''I don't think it is as much of a long shot as it seemed two weeks ago.''
Mr. Bass and other participants said that while cuts of that magnitude would be very positive for the credit markets, the economic implications would be clearly negative.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 96 27/32 late yesterday, to yield 9.05 percent, unchanged from late on Monday.
After the release of the trade and inflation statistics, the yields on the benchmark issue rose as high as 9.09 percent. 10-Year Notes Down to 8.89% Among note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 1/32 in late trading, down by 1/32, to yield 8.89 percent. Meanwhile, the 8 1/8 percent two-year notes were unchanged, at a late-offered price of 100 6/32, to yield 8.01 percent.
By late in the day, three-month Treasury bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.36 percent, down by a basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by a similar amount, to a late-offered rate of 7.27 percent.
In the corporate bond market, the Security Pacific Corporation offered $150 million in three-year floating-rate notes through an underwriting syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation.
The notes, which have a final maturity of Sept. 30, 1993, were priced at $100, or par. Interest rates on the securities will be set at 25 basis points above the prevailing three-month London interbank offered rate on Friday. The rates on the notes will be reset quarterly.
The securities are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AA-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
Dormitory Authority Bonds
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, Dillon, Read & Company acted as lead manager for two negotiated offerings.
The Dormitory Authority of New York offered $314 million in serial and term bonds.
The yields on the serial bonds range from 6.40 percent on securities maturing in 1992 to 7.90 percent on bonds that mature in 2003.
The issue included an uninsured 7 7/8 percent term bond maturing in 2017. It was priced to yield 8.10 percent. In addition, a 7.50 percent term bond due in 2020 insured by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company was priced to yield 7.65 percent.
The uninsured securities are rated A by Moody's and BBB by Standard & Poor's. The insured bonds are rated AAA by both agencies.
 
Offering by Connecticut
In addition, Connecticut offered $200 million in general obligation bonds.
The yields on the issue, which is made up entirely of serial bonds, range from 6 percent in 1991 to 6.40 percent on bonds maturing in 1995, 6.90 percent on securities due in 2000 and 7.25 percent on bonds that mature in 2010.
The issue is rated AA by Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said prices of most issues were unchanged yesterday.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, traders said prices of most widely quoted issues dipped by a quarter to three-eighths point.

HEADLINE: C.D. and Bank Yields Mixed During Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were mixed for the week ended yesterday as interest rates continued to drift in the wake of the unresolved Middle East crisis and the budget talks in Washington, which are currently stalled.
At the Treasury Department's closely watched bill auction held each Monday, interest rates on the new three-month and six-month Treasury bills were down slightly. It is a widely believed that the results of these bill auctions have an influence over what many banks may eventually pay on money market accounts and certificates of deposit. 
The average discount rate for a new three-month bill fell by 2 basis points, to 7.39 percent, while the six-month bill rate fell by 4 basis points, to 7.30 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Steady in New York Area
In the weekly survey of New York area banks and savings institutions done by The Bank Rate Monitor, the average yields were nearly unchanged from the previous week. Commercial banks displayed most of the strength this week, as the average money market account held at 6.21 percent, while three-month certificates rose 3 basis points, to 7.63 percent, and six-month certificates rose 2 basis points, to 7.71 percent.
Yields at savings institutions, still higher than those offered by commercial banks but with the spread narrowing, were down. The average money market account increased by 3 basis points, to 6.42 percent, while a three-month certificate fell 4 basis points, to 7.88 percent. The yield on a six-month certificate fell 2 basis points, to 7.94 percent.
Outside the New York market and among 20 large banks nationwide, the average yield for a money market account was unchanged at 6.25 percent, while the average yield on a six-month certificate was down a basis point, to 7.52 percent.
 
Little Change at Credit Unions
Among some of the country's large credit unions, the yield picture was similar to that of a week ago. The average yield on a money market account was unchanged at 6.54 percent, while the average yields of a six-month certificate and a one-year certificate were down by a basis point, to 7.86 percent and 8.03 percent, respectively.
For the longer two-and-a-half-year certificate, the yield was unchanged at 8.17 percent and the five-year certificate was up again by a basis point, to 8.31 percent.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Collusion Interest Charge May Add to Owner Costs

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Arbitrators' awards of $113 million for lost players' salaries in baseball's ongoing collusion case could jump by nearly 40 percent, to the $156 million area, if the arbitrators grant the union's request for interest.
''We have claimed interest in these cases, and we're confident the arbitrators will award the players interest on the damage amounts,'' Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader, said at a news conference yesterday in Manhattan.
Fehr said that union mathematicians had not computed the possible amount of the interest, but using the interest rates called for in the labor agreement between the players and the owners, an independent computation determined that the interest could total $43 million. $250 Million Is Possible That staggering amount indicates that the eventual total the owners will owe the players could exceed $250 million. 
If George Nicolau, the arbitrator who on Monday awarded the players $102.5 million for lost salary in the 1987 and 1988 seasons, awards a similar amount for lost salary last year and this year and interest is then added, the overall total would be around $266 million, or more than $10 million a club.
Asked about a total in the $250 million area, Fehr said, ''Sure, it's in the realm of possibility, but I'm not going to speculate beyond that.''
The question of punitive damages and payment of the union's costs in the case also arose yesterday. Fehr said the union would very likely ask that the clubs pay the costs of its lawyers and economic experts. Furthermore, he said, union officials have discussed the possibility of asking for punitive damages but added, ''No such claim has yet been made.''
Charles O'Connor, the owners' chief labor official, said that punitive damages were beyond the scope of the arbitrator's authority.
Under the new labor agreement, any future collusion would cost the owners treble damages. That provision, if it had been in effect previously, would turn the $113 million in damages into $339, not including interest.
 
Owners Oppose Payment
The owners have opposed the payment of interest. Given the figures, it's easy to understand why. ''Our lawyers have opposed interest consistently from the beginning,'' O'Connor said.
But the players contend that if they do not get interest, the owners would have profited from their collusive actions that two arbitrators said hindered players' movement and bargaining power as free agents after the 1985, 1986 and 1987 seasons.
The labor agreement stipulates that when interest is called for, the rate should be 1 percent over the prime interest rate in effect at Chemical Bank of New York on the previous Nov. 1, with the number rounded to the nearest percentage point.
In the period in question, the Chemical prime rate ranged from 7.5 percent to 10.5 percent.
In making his $102.5 million award to the players, Nicolau designated $38 million for lost 1987 salary and $64.5 million for lost 1988 salary. In arguments before Nicolau, the clubs had proposed damages for the two years totaling $55 million to $60 million while the union had put the figure at around $125 million.
Using complex mathematical formulas, Nicolau said the salary shortfall for players with six or more years of major league service was $25 million in 1987 and $39 million in 1988. The shortfall for players with three to five years of service, he said, was $13 million in 1987 and $25.5 million in 1988.
The arbitrator will hold additional hearings beginning late next month to determine damages arising from the 1989 and 1990 seasons.
O'Connor said he thought the entire collusion matter could be wrapped up before the end of the year. He said the clubs were prepared to put the damage amount into an escrow account.
The arbitrators, Fehr said, will have the final say on ''how many dollars go to which players.''

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
U.S. Becomes TV Studio For World

BYLINE: By George Vecsey

 BODY:
People keep saying the United States is into a recession, and the dollar is down, and we can't manufacture automobiles anymore.
But the United States must have some economic clout because the biggest sports events in the world keep being assigned to Uncle Sam, or Uncle Sixth Avenue, which is more to the point.
The latest example of American buying power is the International Olympic Committee's assigning the 1996 Summer Games to Atlanta, an American city in the state of Georgia, not to be confused with the Soviet republic of Georgia. American cities are in; other world cities are not so in. 
The 1996 Summer Games will be the seventh set of Olympic Games to be held in the United States. No other nation will have held more than four.
The United States will also be host to the 1992 America's Cup in San Diego and the 1994 World Cup of soccer, coming to a city near you. Both decisions are examples of how Prime Time Television has overpowered the First World, the Communist World and the Third World.
All three major television networks are within a short walk (except that the heavy hitters take stretch limousines) of each other near the street New Yorkers call Sixth Avenue and some misguided city official once renamed the Avenue of the Americas.
The three networks pay top dollar for the biggest sports events, $401 million for the 1992 Summer Games in Barcelona and clearly, despite budget cuts in news operations, heading for the moon. And then, of course, there is cable money.
The influence of television is not to be minimized. This Olympic decision is remindful of the old Peter Arno cartoon of a blonde unwrapping her new pearl necklace, and her sugar daddy leaning forward and saying something like, ''And now, Miss Evans, if I could ask just one small favor.''
In this case, the one small favor is Carl Lewis and Ben Johnson going off the blocks at, oh, roughly, 10 P.M. Eastern time, not too late for consumers in New York, and after drive time in Los Angeles.
Atlanta has many advantages, including modern airports, hotel rooms, telephone lines and arenas, plus roads convenient to everybody except Pascual Perez. The former Braves pitcher once tried to drive to the ball park and, unless I have my facts confused, ended up being the subject of a song by the Kingston Trio called ''The Man Who Never Returned.''
One drawback in Atlanta is that every street is named Peachtree. I know an Ethiopian sports official who lives in Paris who once tried to visit the Atlanta organizing committee and blew half his budget trying to get by cab to Peachtree Street, Drive, Place, whatever.
Atlanta has the extremely important asset of being a city with something to prove. It has gone from being razed by William Tecumseh Sherman to being recognized as the home of Coca-Cola, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King and Ted Turner. It has gone from being a sleepy, muggy hill town to being yet another sleek American city, the capital of the New South, albeit still muggy.
The city also has a huge supply of churchgoing, club-member citizens who will volunteer time and expertise to make 1996 Games work. It is also very positive that one of the major cities with black leadership will show America's complex face to the world. From a domestic point of view, the choice of Atlanta is very nice, but on another level it is too bad that television money and modern American technology and good will can so completely engulf the world's sporting events.
Yachting being basically about rich people who congregate in luxurious harbors, it should have been no surprise that the 1992 America's Cup, and its estimated $1 billion windfall, was given to San Diego and not Alma-Ata or Kampala.
It was considerably more chilling when Colombia had to turn back the 1986 World Cup because it could not afford it, and Brazil could not take it over, so the cup event went to Mexican television interests. Now the 1994 World Cup has been handed over to a country that does not have a major league.
As sports events demand modern facilities, fewer nations can expect to be host. Athens was the so-called traditional favorite for the 100th anniversary of the modern Games, but tradition is slightly less important than telephone lines and security.
Atlanta will be a gracious host, but there is a danger of the Games' becoming too much a celebration of being American.
Even though perched on the edge of the United States, Toronto would have provided a somewhat different world view than Atlanta. And through its proximity to Asia, Melbourne would have been a reaffirmation of the I in I.O.C.
Perhaps Melbourne suffered from having been the host in 1956. It surely suffered from being too far away from the most important time zone of all, the time zone of Sixth Avenue.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Jubilant Atlanta Basking in Its Olympic Feat

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Sept. 18

 BODY:
This city, which exudes a gleeful optimism and exhibits a propensity for unabashed self-promotion, proved yet again today that it was the little city that could when it came from nowhere to be designated as the host city for the 1996 Summer Olympics.
More than 2,000 people gathered in the predawn darkness on the plaza of the downtown Underground Atlanta tourist and retail complex to watch the vote by the International Olympic Committee in Tokyo on huge closed-circuit television screens. The party was arranged by the three-and-a-half-year-old Atlanta Organizing Committee, which had conducted the city's $7 million effort to attract the Games.
They chanted ''We want the Games'' as the broadcast from Tokyo built toward the final decision. With the announcement, the plaza reverberated with cheers, flashed with fireworks and rocked to the music of marching bands. By then the crowd was exuberantly shouting, ''We won the Games''. 
 
New Stadium Is Planned
With the city's designation secured, the effort to put on the Games now begins. That effort will require the investment of an estimated $1.2 billion to build the necessary facilities, which will include a new stadium and dormitories for the athletes, according to Robert M. Brennan, the spokesman for the local organizing committee. It is estimated by local officials that the Games will generate more than $3.4 billion in spending in the city over their 16 days.
''It's fabulous,'' Bud Lawlor, a banker clutching his briefcase and his eyes beginning to water with a hint of tears of joy, said as the vote was announced this morning at about 8 o'clock Eastern time.
''It's a dream come true,'' cheered Judy Baker, ''and this is going to put us on the map.''
''Now everybody will know that Atlanta is a great city,'' said Ropeka Gunn, an 18-year-old Georgia Tech freshman.
There was a brash, ''I-knew-it'' tone of vindication in the words of many who gathered in the plaza. The selection, some said, was just icing on the cake after the city's success two years ago in attracting the 1992 Democratic National Convention and its more recent success in being selected as the site of the 1994 Super Bowl, which will be played in a domed stadium now under construction.
At the very least it has all helped reinforce the city's claim to being an international city and its sense of itself as the progressive and bustling center of the American South, a region in which economic growth and racial harmony go hand-in-hand.
But others conceded that there was nothing short of miraculous in the city's attracting the Summer Games of the XXVI Olympiad when it seemed that the odds were against Atlanta.
 
A Winner on First Attempt
For one thing, it had been Atlanta's first attempt to attract the Games and traditionally no city had been awarded the Games on its first attempt. And it was the centennial of the modern Olympic Games, which were held in 1896 in Athens, which was among the six cities that were finalists and had built its campaign on the logic and sentimental value of being the host for the 1996 Games.
Most attributed the city's success to the ''one to one, personal salesmanship'' approach devised by William P. Payne, the head of the Atlanta Organizing Committee. In the last two years, 71 of the 91 members of the I.O.C. who would vote on the host city had visited the city and had been wined, dined and escorted by a host of local volunteers, political figures and business people. Likewise, delegations of Atlantans have traveled regularly to meetings of the international committee and other gatherings of international sports groups to promote the city.
The city also had Andrew Young, its former mayor, a civil rights figure and former United Nations Ambassador who is well known and respected throughout the world. Young was featured in much of the city's literature aimed at committee members. The facts that Atlanta was the birthplace of Dr. Martin Luther King and the center of the civil rights movement were also promoted.
''Andy Young was our not-so-secret weapon,'' said Lew Whiting, an Atlantan who competed in the pentathlon in the 1972 Olympics and was a former official of the United States Olympic Committee. ''He just had so much respect in the international community and he knew so many of the diplomats.'' Brennan said that the city in its proposals stressed its advantages in the areas of public transportation, its international airport, extensive highway system and facilities as a convention city with more than 88,000 hotel rooms in the downtown and outlying areas.
The city proposal called for establishing nine locations for 19 of the sports within a three-mile area of downtown Atlanta. Suburban locations would be used for tennis, archery, canoeing and equestrian events while yachting events would be held in Savannah, 240 miles east, and rafting events would be held on the Ocoee River in Tennessee, 125 miles to the north. $587 Million Fund Needed An estimated $587 million in operating funds will be required for the Games as well as $418 million in new construction that includes $145 million for a 85,000-seat downtown stadium adjoining the Fulton County Stadium, where the Braves and the Falcons now play, and $59 million for an Olympic village to be situated on the campus of Georgia Tech. After the Games, the new Olympic stadium will be used by the Braves, while the domed stadium already under construction will be the home of the Falcons. Current projections indicate that more than 84,000 full-time jobs will be created.
''This has really pulled Atlanta's iron out of the fire economically,'' said Jeffrey A. Rosensweig, a professor of international finance at Emory University in Atlanta. ''Employment was dropping and there was nothing on the horizon to keep the economy growing at the pace it had grown during the 1980's.''

An article yesterday about the choice of Atlanta for the 1996 Olympic Games misstated the date of the Democratic National Convention there. It was 1988.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN: Electoral Powder Keg;
In Messages of Dissatisfaction by Voters, Politicians Sense Danger of an Explosion

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Voters sent an unmistakable message of dissatisfaction to their political leaders Tuesday in two quite different states, Massachusetts and Oklahoma, as a widespread mood of discontent with government and politics began to boil over at the ballot box.
In primaries for governor in both states, voters rejected established politicians and turned to candidates who had never held elective office and had campaigned against ''professional politicians'' and the statehouse gang.
These campaigns tapped feelings of frustration that politicians have been watching for months in their polling and their travels around the country.
''It's like walking on gunpowder out there,'' R. Marc Nuttle, executive director of the National Republican Congressional Committee, said this week after a trip to important Congressional districts. ''You can feel the crackling under your feet. You can smell it in the air.'' 
 
Incumbents Ousted
In Massachusetts, where Democrats in general and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in particular are reviled for letting the Massachusetts Miracle slide into a fiscal morass, voters searched down the ballot for incumbents and old-line Democrats to vote against.
''There was a tidal wave coming and we happened to be standing on the beach when it hit,'' the Massachusetts Attorney General, James Shannon, said after losing his bid for renomination for no apparent reason other than that he was in office. He was one of several well-known incumbents ousted from state or local contests.
For the Democratic nomination for governor the voters rejected Francis X. Bellotti, the former Attorney General and a longtime figure in Democratic politics, in favor of Dr. John R. Silber, the president of Boston University, who contends that government is causing more problems than it is solving. In the Republican race, they turned down the minority leader of the State House of Representatives, Steven Pierce, in favor of William Weld, a former United States attorney, who in the closing days of the campaign ran television advertising emphasizing his prosecution of corruption in Boston's City Hall.
 
Oklahomans Limit Tenure
In Oklahoma, the voters were angry over two big tax increases and a state government deadlocked between a Republican governor and a Democratic legislature, and they vented their frustration by imposing a 12-year limit on the tenure of legislators, the first state ever to do so, but quite probably not the last. California and Colorado have similiar measures on their ballots this November.
''They stay in there so long and they get too much politics and too much graft goes on,'' said Wanda Bayless of Tulsa, explaining why she and her husband voted for the term limit. ''We backed it so we wouldn't have career politicians as opposed to politicians who want to serve their country and have something else to go on to.''
Tuesday's voting was the loudest statement by voters this year of the sort of disillusionment expressed by Mrs. Bayless, but it was not the first. Just the week before, voters here in Washington, battered by the scandal of a mayor caught using drugs, rejected two prominent office holders, one from the city council and the other from the House of Representatives, and instead nominated to be their next mayor a woman lawyer who campaigned by waving a shovel and promising to ''clean house'' at City Hall.
On the same day in neighboring Montgomery County, Md., which is like much of suburban America, the county executive was rejected at the polls in favor of a candidate who promised to block growth and tax real estate developers.
With just seven weeks until the elections and virtually all the primaries out of the way now, politicians are preoccupied with how and whether voters would express their anger in general elections.
But there are differences between general and primary elections. Voters have sometimes used primaries to send messages stronger than they would want to live with for a full four years.
In Massachusetts, for example, there were some independents who said that they voted for Dr. Silber on Tuesday to shake up the Democrats and that they would vote for Mr. Weld in November.
 
Complicating Factors
There are also limits to the options voters have for expressing their dissatisfaction in general elections. In many places there is little competition for the Congressional seats that are up for re-election, in both House and Senate races. Also, the crisis in the Persian Gulf has clouded an already complicated situation, making it harder for challengers to get press attention and leaving some voters torn between frustration with the status quo and a traditional tendency to not want to rock the boat in a time of foreign crisis.
But politicians recognize the developing mood nevertheless and are adjusting. Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio, who is chairman of the Democratic Governor's Conference, said recently that his party's only hope for recapturing the White House was to nominate ''an outsider'' who could run against Washington's role in the savings and loan scandal, tax increases and the Federal budget deficit.
President Bush has so far succeeded in staying above the angry mood. ''He keeps confronting people who once would have played great villians on 'Mission Impossible,' '' said Andy Kohut the former president of the Gallup organzation who now runs his own polling concern. ''He had Noriega as a villian. He took a firm stand. Then he began to dip in the polls in July and up came Mr. Hussein, a very able replacement for Manuel Noriega.''
Mr. Kohut also noted that Mr. Bush will become increasingly vulnerable as the economy deteriorates.
While a resistance to taxes, or at least to wasteful spending of taxes, is a common thread in the voter discontent, the antagonism seems to have far less to do with ideology, or even policies, than with a more visceral frustration over the status quo.
''I am against the political machine in Massachusetts,'' said Dawn M. Dudash, a 38-year-old resident of Cape Cod. ''Silber may bring some change; not necessarily good change, but at least some change. There wasn't any viable alternative.''
 
Resentment of Privileges
Politicians are resented as a class apart, with privileges not enjoyed by the people who elected them. Bill Wynor, 37, a window cleaner at the Oklahoma State Capitol, said: ''A good example of what people are mad about in Oklahoma is that most senators and representatives have two secretaries. One does all the work and the other just bubbles. She just sits out front and looks good. These guys have simply gotten too fat in office.''
In some states, Republicans can be in as much trouble as Democrats are in Massachussets. Gov. Henry Bellmon in Oklahoma and William P. Clements Jr. in Texas, both Republicns, are extremely unpopular and probably would have been defeated had they not stepped aside. In Maine, which is suffering through the same New England recession as Massachusetts, Gov. John R. McKernan Jr. is facing a stiff challenge in November.
Robert Squier, a consultant to Dr. Silber, said it was wrong to describe the national mood as simply anti-incumbent. He said it is much more a search by voters for politicians who identify with citizens instead of with special interests, and are ready to make changes. It is far easier for candidates who are not part of the system to convince voters they will do that. The losers in the Democratic races for governor in both Massachusetts and Oklahoma were well-known political figures and were represented by the same consultant, Raymond Strother. Mr. Strother, sensing what was coming, tried to position both Mr. Bellotti in Massachusetts and Representative Wes Watkins in Oklahoma as candidates who understood the voters' frustration.
But given the longstanding ties of both candidates to the establishment, voters rejected them in favor of newcomers: Dr. Silber, whose outspoken comments seemed like gaffes to insiders and refreshing candor to many voters, and David Walters, an Oklahoma real estate man who tied his campaign to the limit on legislative terms.
The Oklahoma Republican primary was won by Bill Price, a former U.S. Attorney who made his reputation prosecuting corruption among county officials.

HEADLINE: New York Census Missed 254,534 Dwellings

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
New York City officials said yesterday that they had found 254,534 housing units that were not counted by the Census Bureau. They said their finding bolstered their claim that almost one million New Yorkers were not counted.
In a formal challenge to the Federal agency's 1990 population count, the officials, relying on records of city agencies, aerial photographs and information from utility companies, said the Census Bureau had missed five or more residences on nearly 12,000 of the more than 28,000 residential blocks in the city.
''The Census Bureau has sabotaged the accuracy of New York City's population count,'' Mayor David N. Dinkins said in announcing the findings of the city's analysis yesterday. ''If the paltry results of the Bureau's poor work are not challenged, New Yorkers will lose representation in Congress as well as hundreds of millions of dollars in Federal aid over the next decade.'' 
 
Loss of 38,000 People
New York City began work on its challenge after the Census Bureau released a preliminary estimate that put the city's population at 7,033,179. That meant New York had lost 38,000 people during the 1980's, a decade in which the city experienced its greatest economic boom since World War II and, city officials and outside experts believed, had grown by about a million people.
City officials provided examples yesterday of what they considered typical errors. One was a building that belongs to the city housing authority that it said the Census Bureau missed altogether.
But the difficulties of counting and checking the count of a city as complex as New York were apparent even as officials were putting their case forward. At one location on the list of blocks that the city said were undercounted - an apartment building in Sunnyside, Queens - the superintendent and some residents said yesterday that Census Bureau enumerators had repeatedly visited the building and interviewed tenants. [Page B2.] City officials said they were worried that the Census Bureau, which must provide President Bush with final population figures by Dec. 31, would not have enough time to check all the blocks the city officials cited and count all the people they believe were missed.
Dierdre Blackwood, a spokeswoman for the Census Bureau, said the agency had set a target date of Oct. 9 for reviewing challenges. But she added, ''Obviously, if we have serious challenges, we will continue to recanvass.''
''We're going to review all document challenges and recanvass where it's necessary,'' she said. ''We have some enumerators on standby.''
On Monday, the Census Bureau had received responses from slightly more than 7,000 of the nearly 40,000 localities across the country it had counted this year. About 1,700 had accepted the bureau's population estimates, Ms. Blackwood said, while 5,400 had filed challenges. The localities have different filing deadlines, the last of which is Sept. 24.
Los Angeles, Philadelphia, Chicago and other cities either have filed or are expected to file challenges to Census Bureau population estimates. Bureau officials have repeatedly said that they expect the estimates to rise as a result.
In an appearance before a Congressional subcommittee last week, the director of the Census Bureau, Barbara Everitt Bryant, said the agency was ready to recheck dwellings in 500,000 census blocks. Other officials said the bureau had set aside money to recheck up to 2.1 million housing units.
The Census Bureau did not provide a breakdown of its population estimate by borough or by census block, city officials said, but it did tell the city how many residences it found on each block.
 
Analysis of Real-Estate Maps
The city based its challenge on a Planning Department analysis of records from the Departments of Buildings, Finance and Housing, the Housing Authority, Consolidated Edison and the New York Telephone Company as well as on real-estate maps and aerial photographs.
That analysis determined that 254,534 housing units had been missed, ranging from 80,039 in Queens to 12,451 on Staten Island.
The Census Bureau's preliminary figures showed 2,933,053 housing units in New York City. City planners now say there are 3,187,587.
Many of the missing units cited by the city are in two bands, one that stretches across northern Manhattan and the South Bronx and another across the southern part of Brooklyn and Queens. Both are areas where substantial numbers of immigrants and members of minorities live.
The city has long contended that the Census Bureau has difficulty counting urban neighborhoods accurately, especially those in which many residents do not speak English, move frequently or fear the Government because they are undocumented aliens or illegally doubled up in public housing.
 
Exact Addresses Unknown
City officials also said that in some instances the city had found fewer residences on a block than the Census Bureau had. In one instance, they said, the bureau listed 185 housing units in Central Park, perhaps underscoring the difficulties of counting and checking counts of the city's population.
For the most part, city officials noted, they had no way of knowing the exact addresses of missing residences, since they did not know the addresses of the residences that the bureau had counted, only the number of housing units in a block.
Moreover, city officials acknowledged that 40,000 to 50,000 of the units that the city had said were missed might be vacant.
Even so, given the citywide occupancy rate of approximately 2.5 people a unit in a recent city housing survey, 200,000 uncounted units would result in about 500,000 uncounted residents.
City officials say they believe more residents were missed in housing units that the Census Bureau did count. They also said the agency's finding of more than 150,000 vacant dwellings in city was too high, leading to others being missed.
Hundreds of the blocks included in yesterday's challenge were also challenged by the city in a pre-census review in January, a circumstance Mr. Dinkins noted in a letter to Sheila Grimm, the bureau's regional director in New York.
 
Homeless Shelters Missed
In the letter, Mr. Dinkins also said city records showed that 29,329 persons in prisons, college dormitories, homeless shelters and other institutions had been missed.
Yesterday's challenge constituted the latest chapter in the contentious relationship between the Census Bureau and the city.
In 1980, the Bureau put the city's population at 7,071,639, though the agency acknowledged that it might not have counted as many as 450,000 residents. New York challenged the count but lost.
Two years ago, the city, joined by several other cities and states and civic and civil rights groups, filed another lawsuit against the Commerce Department, the Census Bureau's parent, seeking to force the bureau to conduct an additional population survey after the 1990 national headcount that could be used to compensate for another undercount.
In July 1989, on the eve of the trial, the Commerce Department, agreed that it would conduct a post-count survey and publish guidelines setting forth how it would decide whether to use the survey to adjust its count. But in December, the department released preliminary guidelines that were immediately attacked by the city as ''outrageous.'' Among other things, they allowed the department to take into account whether an adjustment would cause ''political disruption.''
Still, a lawyer representing the city in the case indicated in an interview this week that the post-count survey was ''the only safety net'' the bureau had.
''I do not think they are up to the job of catching the undercount in any systematic way,'' said the lawyer, Robert S. Rifkind.

HEADLINE: Rinfret, Out of Money, Threatens To Abandon Race for Governor

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
Pierre A. Rinfret lost a campaign manager and a finance chairman today and disclosed that his campaign for governor of New York State was broke. He threatened to end the campaign unless Republican leaders started supporting him financially and politically.
In an unusual move in an erratic campaign, Mr. Rinfret told the leaders that he had no money for campaigning and that he was ''probably going to have to shut down our operations on Friday.''
At the same time, his manager, Assemblyman John J. Faso of Kinderhook, left the campaign, saying he disagreed with the strategy of threatening Republican leaders. 
 
Promises Statement Tomorrow
William E. Simon, the former Secretary of the Treasury and the campaign's finance chairman, also quit, saying he would not raise money for Mr. Rinfret, an economist who was virtually unknown in state politics before his nomination. ''I told him I'm not a fund-raiser, that's it,'' Mr. Simon said in a telephone interview. ''I wish him well.''
He said that starting next week, he would be in the Far East until after the election. He spent most of the summer on his yacht in Europe.
The candidate and his aides did not answer telephone calls today, but a person close to Mr. Rinfret expressed doubt that he would actually quit the campaign. The associate acknowledged that Mr. Rinfret's threat has ''shaken up a lot of people.'' He said that the candidate would be unavailable to reporters, but not to politicians, until tomorrow, when he would issue a statement. Mr. Rinfret's name will be on the ballot in any event.
The developments came two days after the release of a Marist Institute poll of 821 voters. Only 14.5 percent said they would vote for Mr. Rinfret, the lowest rating any politician could recall for a major party candidate. The margin of error was plus or minus four percentage points.
 
Senate Control Threatened
Mr. Rinfret's poor showing so far and the latest developments in his stumbling campaign raised the possibility of an electoral disaster that could cost the Republicans the State Senate, which they now control by a 32-to-26 margin with three seats vacant. It could also cost the party the second line on future ballots and any chance of controlling the Legislature for 10 years.
Republican leaders, who have been distancing themselves from what they consider an electoral debacle, said they were shocked and unable to contact Mr. Rinfret. State Senator Guy J. Velella, the Bronx Republican leader and chairman of the State Senate Republican Campaign Committee, speculated that Mr. Rinfret was ''trying to scare people.'' Mr. Velella had refused a Rinfret request for Senate Republican campaign funds.
Mr. Rinfret said in a television interview on Sunday that he had raised $1.25 million. In his last financial report, in mid-July, he reported raising $869,632, including $540,000 of his own money, with $709,225 unspent at that time. The next report is due on Oct. 5.
 
Conservatives Seek to Capitalize
Seeking to capitalize on the Republican troubles, Michael Long, the Conservative Party state chairman, called on Republicans to unite behind the Conservative gubernatorial candidate, Herbert London.
Democrats are making their strongest effort in years to win the State Senate. Gaining a majority in that chamber, coupled with their control of the governorhip and the Assembly, would allow them to completely dominate the redrawing of Congressional and legislative district lines. They would have a golden opportunity if there was any sizable drop in the Republican statewide vote because of dissatisfaction with Mr. Rinfret.
''If people stay home, you are about to see the biggest blowout in history,'' Mr. Long said. His Republican counterpart, J. Patrick Barrett, who has not been active in the Rinfret campaign, did not return telephone calls.
Mr. Long said a shift of voters from Mr. Rinfret to Mr. London might cost the Republicans the second line on the ballot for the next four years. But he added that that would be ''temporary'' compared with a loss of the State Senate to Democrats, who would then control the reapportionment process that decides district lines for the next 10 years.
If the Republican gubernatorial candidate ran third behind Mr. London, the 28-year-old Conservative Party would become the state's second-ranking party, behind the Democrats, and share with them the naming of members of boards of elections from the state level on down to neighborhood election districts. It would be the first time since the founding of the Republican Party in the Civil War era that the Democratic-Republican monopoly in the state was broken.
 
Breaking With Inner Circle
Mr. Rinfret has broken with several members of his initial inner circle, including State Senator Roy M. Goodman, the Manhattan Republican leader who recruited him to be the gubernatorial candidate, and Larry Kudlow, a Bear Stearns partner, a vice chairman of the Republican state committee and an early Rinfret adviser.
Mr. Goodman said he had not been asked to be a Rinfret adviser.
The businessman who recommended Mr. Rinfret as a possible candidate to Senator Goodman, Lawrence C. Leeds Jr., said last night that he knew nothing of the day's events. ''I think Pierre has a lot of good attributes in terms of being able to run this state,'' Mr. Leeds said. ''Hopefully, as the public gets to know him a little better, he can get a lot of votes.''
Vice President Dan Quayle was the main attraction at a Rinfret fund-raiser on Tuesday at the Sky Club, but the event netted at most $15,000, Mr. Faso said. He said he was leaving by mutual agreement because he disagreed with ''the direction of the campaign.'' Mr. Faso has been criticized by Republican leaders for what several said was his unswerving loyalty to the candidate even when he was criticizing fellow Republicans like Jack F. Kemp, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
Mr. Rinfret did not appear at two Quayle ''photo opportunities'' before and after the fund-raiser. He also canceled campaign events over the weekend, angering Republican leaders.
One, Comptroller Peter T. King of Nassau County, publicly echoed what many Republicans have said privately. ''Rank-and-file Republicans are going to start looking to Herb London as a rational alternative to Mario Cuomo,'' he said.

HEADLINE: GUATEMALA IS TOLD TO SOLVE SLAYING

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has told President Vinicio Cerezo of Guatemala that it will cut military aid if the recent killing of an American innkeeper is not fully investigated and the suspects are not prosecuted, State Department officials say.
The body of the innkeeper, Michael DeVine, 49 years old, originally a resident of Belleville, Ill., who lived in Guatemala for almost 20 years, was found on June 9 on the side of a road, his head partly severed and his hands tied behind his back. Since then, a private investigator employed by his widow, Carole, has uncovered evidence that points to the involvement of a local Guatemalan Army unit based in the northeastern town of Flores.
While no motive for the crime has been firmly established, a senior Senate aide who is monitoring the case said the seeming involvement of an army intelligence unit suggested a linkage to drugs or other contraband. 
The Senate aide, who spoke on condition that he not be identified, said that there was no indication Mr. DeVine was involved in drugs himself, but that he might have accidentally come across evidence of army involvement in the growing of poppies for heroin production.
 
Washington Cuts Aid
The DeVine case comes when relations between the Bush Administration and the Cerezo Government are strained. The Administration recalled Ambassador Thomas F. Stroock for a week in March, protesting rising human rights abuses and Mr. Cerezo's inability or unwillingness to assert civilian control over the Guatemalan Army.
Between 1989 and 1990, Washington cut economic aid to Guatemala from $141.3 million to $113.4 million and military aid from from $7 million to $3.3 million. The State Department this month placed Guatemala on its list of major drug-trafficking countries because of its growing poppy crop.
Ambassador Stroock warned Mr. Cerezo in at least two meetings in the last four weeks that the Administration would cancel much if not all of the remaining military aid next year unless the DeVine case was resolved, State Department officials said.
Mr. Cerezo, in a letter to Mr. Stroock dated Sept. 6, pledged that the national police and Attorney General's office would investigate the killing.
''People linked to the security forces could be responsible for the death,'' Mr. Cerezo acknowledged. ''It is our aim to pursue every investigation to determine such responsibility, and if that's the case, find those responsible for the act and apply the sanctions the law establishes.''
 
Unkept Commitments Noted
The State Department was gratified that Mr. Cerezo stated his commitment to solving the DeVine case, but United States officials privately expressed skepticism that the Guatemalan Government and army would prosecute army officers. They noted that Guatemalan officers are rarely punished for human rights abuses.
''We've been disappointed before on unkept commitments,'' a State Department official said, ''but we're willing to give the Government the benefit of the doubt for a few weeks.'' The official said there were a number of suspects in the case, whom the Government had pledged to question.
Mr. DeVine, who adopted two Mayan Indian children with his wife, was a popular member of the American community in Guatemala. He held an interest in a restaurant in the resort town of Antigua and owned a ranch in the jungle province of Peten that he converted into a inn that offered tourists horseback riding, fishing and hiking. ''He was a clean-cut kind of guy,'' said the Senate aide monitoring the case.
According to evidence compiled by a private investigator and confirmed by the United States Embassy, the white Toyota pickup truck used by Mr. DeVine's assailants is currently assigned to the Guatemalan Army base in Flores. The truck, which the army used to accompany local gasoline trucks to protect them from guerrilla attack, has since been repainted red.
 
Public Protests Avoided
While the Administration has strongly pressed the DeVine case privately with Mr. Cerezo and top Defense Ministry officers, officials said the State Department was moving cautiously in public. They said the Administration feared that public protests could make the case an issue in the current presidential election campaign, one that could be used by the ruling Christian Democrats to prove their nationalism.
Mr. Cerezo is ineligible to run for re-election this November, but his hand-picked candidate, former Foreign Minister Alfonso Cabrera Hidalgo, is the Christian Democratic standard-bearer. Mr. Cabrera, who has been repeatedly linked to drug traffickers by Western diplomats, has used the private helicopter of a reputed narcotics smuggler on campaign trips.
While the Bush Administration has not taken a public position on the election, United States officials have made it known that they do not want Mr. Cabrera to win.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Bush Seems to Toughen His Approach to War

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he was ''prepared to take additional steps'' if diplomacy failed to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis peacefully.
Mr. Bush, who made his comments at a political luncheon here, was explicit for the first time in saying that there were actions he was prepared to take against Iraq beyond diplomacy and economic sanctions.
He seemed to be toughening his language in a measured way, inching ever closer to open discussion of the possibility of war. But the White House tried to knock down speculation that this was a calculated move. 
 
Implicit Threat of War
The threat of military action against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has been implicit in the President's words and actions since he first sent American troops to Saudi Arabia on Aug. 7, five days after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
Mr. Bush has pointedly refused to rule out the possibility of war in his public statements, and his speech to Congress last week left little doubt that he was prepared to take military action if economic sanctions fail. But the White House has tied its talk of ''options'' to the idea of expanding the current sanctions.
Today Mr. Bush repeated the United Nations' demands that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait, restore the previous Government to power and free all the hostages it is holding in Iraq and Kuwait. Then he added: ''If Iraq does not meet these nonnegotiable conditions, then its isolation will not end. We are, as I have said before, prepared to take additional steps if sanctions and the quest for a political resolution do not work.''
Mr. Bush inserted the phrase ''as I have said before'' after an advance text of his remarks circulated among reporters and White House aides were besieged by questions about the phrasing.
 
Vagueness in Helsinki
Even before he spoke, the aides tried to soften the impact of his words, saying they were a ''nuance'' and not a change in policy, because the Administration has been prepared for the possibility of war for weeks. Speaking on condition of anonymity, the aides also said Mr. Bush did not mean for his speech to toughen the tone of the oratory directed at Mr. Hussein.
Before Mr. Bush met in Helsinki with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union on Sept. 9, the White House said he would ''review options'' if the current sanctions against Iraq failed in their purpose of strangling Iraq's economy. But White House officials said they were referring primarily to additional economic measures.
In Helsinki, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev issued a joint statement saying that if ''current steps'' failed to drive Iraq from Kuwait, ''we are prepared to consider additional ones consistent with the U.N. Charter.'' Administration officials, including Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, said that left open the possibility of military action, but the wording was kept deliberately vague because Mr. Gorbachev refused to agree to a more explicit endorsement of military force.
In his speech to Congress last week, Mr. Bush went a step further. ''Sanctions will take time to have their full intended effect,'' he said. ''We will continue to review all options with our allies, but let it be clear: we will not let this aggression stand.''
In his speech today, Mr. Bush reiterated his commitment to pursuing a diplomatic solution to the gulf crisis. And he repeated his support for humanitarian shipments of food and medicine to Iraq and Kuwait to aid ''innocent children, mothers, the sick and the elderly.''
 
'Strict Supervision'
But he said this must be done under ''strict supervision.'' In Denver on Tuesday, at another political event, Mr. Bush said, ''We cannot allow Saddam Hussein to divert needed humanitarian aid in order to sustain his army of occupation.''
During his two-day swing through California to aid Senator Pete Wilson in his gubernatorial campaign, Mr. Bush has drawn an increasingly direct political connection between the gulf crisis and the election campaigns around the country.
Mr. Bush said the American forces in the gulf were ''striving to defend'' American freedoms. ''One of these freedoms is the right to vote, to choose our form of government,'' he said. ''Fellow Republicans, I can't think of anything that would better honor these heroes than to exercise that privilege. As we do we'll stand up for America. We'll show Saddam Hussein what this great nation is all about.''

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Iraqi Tankers' Loading Oil in Gulf May Signal Iranian Help in Breaking Embargo

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Three Iraqi tankers have recently docked and taken on oil at an Iraqi pipeline terminal in the Persian Gulf, American officials said today, a move that may signal new efforts by President Saddam Hussein to export oil and to enlist Iran into breaking the global trade embargo against his Government.
The development comes as the Director of Central Intelligence, William H. Webster, said that Mr. Hussein has managed to smuggle up to three million barrels of oil out of his country, either by truck or by ship, since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.
 
No Sizable Leak Seen
Mr. Webster, in an appearance in Manhattan on Tuesday evening, said the smuggled oil totals only 2 or 3 percent of Iraq's potential production during that period and does not represent a significant leak in the United Nations embargo.
Before the economic sanctions against Iraq were imposed by the United Nations, Iraq and Kuwait were authorized by OPEC cartel agreements to ship a total of 4.6 million barrels of oil daily, but production for export has virtually ceased since the trade embargo began on Aug. 6. 
 
Fear Iran Transshipment
The movement of the Iraqi tankers has raised concerns among Government analysts that the oil they take on is destined for Iran, where it could be moved onto Iranian tankers for sale on the world market.
United States intelligence officials say they have recently detected a new push by Mr. Hussein to win Iran's help in breaking the embargo, said the officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
They said that Iran recently had discussed with Iraqi officials the possibility of linking the two nations' pipeline networks, a project the Central Intelligence Agency believes could be completed in about a month. Such a link could move up to 500,000 barrels of Iraqi oil into the Iranian system each day, C.I.A. analysts are said to believe.
Iraq and Iran also have discussed an arrangement under which Iran would sell Iraq's oil on the world market in exchange for a share of the profits, one Administration official said today.
 
Unloading at Kharg
Officials say that the three oil-laden Iraqi tankers now anchored in the Persian Gulf could easily sail for Iran's main oil terminal, at nearby Kharg Island, where they would unload their oil for export through Iran's tanker facilities there.
Those concerns are heightened by the fact that all four Iraqi tankers now off the Fao peninsula arrived there by a circuitous route, hugging the Iranian coast and avoiding international waters where they might be stopped and inspected by foreign warships.
The United Nations resolution that authorizes military action to enforce the embargo, passed on Aug. 25, does not specify whether that authorization is limited to international waters, but instead ''invites'' member states to cooperate to insure compliance.
A State Department official said tonight that the United States would not enter another nation's waters to enforce the embargo without first asking permission. It is not known whether Washington did so in the case of the Iraqi tankers.
The route apparently was approved in advance by Iran. It worked for most of the tankers, but the last of the four, called Al Fao, was stopped by an American warship and inspected before it reached Iranian waters, a senior Pentagon official said today. The inspection found no contraband and the tanker was allowed to proceed.
 
A Matter of Sanctuary
That official and other Government experts said today that the coast-hugging gambit raises questions of whether Iran intends to help Iraq slip the naval blockade by giving its tankers sanctuary while they shuttle between Iraqi pipeline terminals and Iran's Kharg Island terminal.
The tankers all anchored off Iraq's southern coast in the last three weeks. They are the first to load Iraqi crude oil since the invasion and the blockade that followed it. Al Fao tied up in the same area this week, but has yet to take on oil, United States officials said.
On Tuesday, after an address to a private group in New York, Mr. Webster said that C.I.A. experts believe that the embargo has stopped 97 to 98 percent of the oil that left Iraq before the invasion. Iraq had been exporting 3.14 million barrels of oil daily.
 
Most Going to Jordan
Mr. Webster said the vast majority of the oil that has escaped the embargo has gone to Jordan in exchange for forgiveness of Jordanian debts to Iraq. Other Government officials said today that Jordan is receiving up to 45,000 barrels of oil a day from Iraq, all by truck - the same amount it received before the embargo.
Jordan has told the United States that none of the oil is being re-exported, one official said today.
By accepting the oil, Jordan is technically violating the United Nations trade ban, which orders member states to bar the import ''of all commodities and products originating in Iraq.''
The rest of the oil that is known to have escaped the embargo was shipped to Yemen shortly after the invasion and is sitting in the Iraqi tankers anchored off the Fao peninsula, officials said.
 
U.S. Sharing Intelligence
In a related matter, Mr. Webster said Tuesday that American intelligence agencies are distributing some of their reporting on the Kuwait crisis to allies around the world, but that they were not exchanging intelligence with the Soviet Union.
He said the United States ''would be very happy if they'd share some things about their weapons and equipment'' sold to Iraq's military, but that the Soviets appeared unwilling to provide that sort of data.
Today, Vladimir Kryuchkov, head of the Soviet intelligence service, the K.G.B., told The Associated Press in an interview that his agency would welcome an exchange of intelligence on Iraq.
The C.I.A.'s spokesman, Mark Mansfield, said today that the agency does not comment on intelligence relationships with other nations.
Mr. Webster has often said that the United States would not deal directly with the K.G.B. until the Soviet Union is proven to have abandoned its support of terrorism and instituted democratic reforms.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Turks, on West's Side, Regain Voice

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Although the Persian Gulf crisis is adding to this country's already considerable burdens, it has also handed Turks an unexpected gift of reborn confidence. Turkey's troubles are plain enough. It stands to lose billions of dollars a year in trade and investment because of the embargo against Iraq, and prices in the last few weeks have skyrocketed for basics like gasoline and bread. From senior officials to store clerks, Turks say they dread being dragged into an unwanted war in neighboring Arab lands that once were part of the Ottoman Empire.
There is, some of them point out, an old saying here born of painful experience: ''Don't get mixed up in Arabs' business.'' 
Yet the country's leadership, exuding self-assurance, argues that its tough, unhesitating stand against Iraq and alongside the West must reap long-term benefits. However the crisis may end, officials insist, the United States and Europe will have to recognize Turkey as a powerful voice in the region.
 
'Turkey Will Be Present'
''If there are profound changes in the Middle East map, Turkey will be present at the discussions,'' said Kamran Inan, a Cabinet minister. ''Naturally, this cannot be done behind our back.''
Ercan Vuralhan, a former Defense Minister and a member of Parliament from the ruling Motherland Party, added, ''Without Turkey, you cannot establish a successful Western position in the Middle East.''
Some right-wing Turks go so far as to demand that they win back Iraq's northern provinces of Kirkuk and Mosul, rich in oil, which they regard as having been unfairly lost in the reparceling of former Ottoman lands in the 1920's. This, however, is not a position that anyone in the center-right Government has taken publicly, and opposition leaders on the left warn against dreams of territorial expansion.
More modestly, Turkey wants to reap immediate economic benefits from its anti-Iraq line. President Turgut Ozal, the chief architect of Turkish policy and the only politician here with real power, is expected to bring along a shopping list when he goes to Washington next week to meet President Bush.
Even more than financial help to offset embargo-related losses, the Turks want Washington to increase its quotas for their textile imports.
 
More Military Assistance
Turkey also wants more than the $500 million a year it now gets from the United States in military assistance, to help modernize an army that is hobbled by outmoded equipment. According to Mr. Vuralhan, this may include a specific request that Washington modify its requirement that for every $10 in military aid that goes to Turkey, archrival Greece gets $7.
The Turks regard the formula as unfair capitulation to the Greek lobby, given the fact that Turkey's population of 57 million is about six times that of Greece and its armed forces of 800,000 is the largest in North Atlantic Treaty Organization except for the United States.
Now, Turks like to think they may be able to apply pressure of their own, something that was close to unimaginable until Iraq invaded Kuwait last month.
As recently as the beginning of August, many here were convinced that they had been exiled to the margins of the world's strategic map through a logic that to them seemed irrefutable:
The sudden end of the cold war meant NATO's decline as a military force, and with it Turkey's importance as the alliance's southern bulwark. By extension, the argument ran, Turkey would lose its trump card in its fierce campaign for eventual membership in the European Community - a mission already difficult enough for a large, poor, Muslim nation that lies almost entirely in Asia.
 
Neutrality Quickly Abandoned
But President Saddam Hussein of Iraq changed those perceptions in a single day by invading Kuwait. It reminded everyone, including the United States and Europe, that Turkey remained a pivotal component of Western strategy. Mr. Ozal, who much to his opponents' dismay has turned the largely ceremonial Turkish presidency into a powerful position, reinforced the new image by abandoning this country's traditional neutrality in Middle Eastern disputes and retaliating swiftly against Iraq.
Most significantly, in the opinion of Western diplomats, Turkey moved in the first days of the crisis to shut twin pipelines across its southern territory that had carried more than half of Iraq's oil exports. Mr. Ozal has since been as ardent a preacher as any for the need to maintain sanctions.
The Turks have also let the United States keep 14 F-111 bombers at the Incirlik air base near the southern city of Adana, and may also allow 24 F-16 fighters to stay on after a long-planned military exercise is completed.
Officials say Turkish forces have been beefed up considerably along the border with Iraq to nearly 100,000 men, pinning down a comparable force said to have been amassed on the Iraqi side.
 
No Troops to Gulf
Thus far, Turkey has sent no troops or ships to the Persian Gulf. But on Sept. 5 Mr. Ozal increased his powers on this score as well when Parliament, completely in his ruling party's control, handed over to the Government what normally is the legislature's prerogative to send troops abroad and to let foreign soldiers be stationed here.
Opinion polls strongly suggest that Turks want no part of a shooting war, and so Turkish soldiers presumably would be shipped overseas only as a last resort. Still, most newspapers and virtually all opposition politicians are skittish about the steps already taken.
Even among strongly anti-Hussein officials in the Government, there is a wide streak of skepticism that the crisis will suddenly melt overseas hostility to Turkey or Western Europe's reluctance to let the Turks join its economic union. In the end, they suspect, all they may reap for their troubles is one more report attacking their human-rights policies.
''When this thing is over, we will be put in our place,'' a senior official said.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
AMMAN ASKS FUNDS TO HELP IN CRISIS

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The Jordanian Government made a strong public plea for international financial aid today, warning that unless it is compensated for enforcing the international embargo against Iraq, the nation's economy may collapse.
Private economists and foreign diplomats, noting that more than half the nation's exports had been sold to Iraq and Kuwait, said the Government's warning appeared to be valid.
Foreign diplomats also said they feared mass unemployment and food shortages if the downward economic spiral caused by the gulf crisis was not stopped, though the Jordanians themselves did not issue such dire warnings. 
Still, the Finance Ministry did say that, with hundreds of thousands of unemployed Jordanian workers pouring back into the country from Iraq and Kuwait, the nation's unemployment rate, which already stands at 15 percent, may rise to 35 percent or higher.
 
'Keep Our Options Open'
As to the concern that Jordan's support for Iraq may discourage other countries from offering assistance, Finance Minister Basel Jardeneh contended at a news conference that ''Jordan certainly is not a part of this conflict - it has nothing to do with the invasion of Kuwait.''
Information Minister Ibrahim Izziddin said: ''We decided the best thing was to keep our options open to all parts of the conflict. If there is going to be a peaceful settlement, someone should be able to talk to Iraq.''
Although the United Nations sanctions committee and several individual countries have said they agreed there was a need to provide compensatory aid, Jordanian officials say they do not know when the money will be received or how much it may be.
West Germany and Japan have together offered several billion dollars in aid to the countries most affected by the crisis, but the offers are imprecise.
Japan, for example, said last week that it was ''considering'' giving $2 billion to Jordan, Egypt and Turkey, but Jordanian officials say they don't know how much of that would be intended for this country.
Saudi Arabia and other gulf nations that have offered large sums in aid to the United States and other countries in the crisis have conspicuously declined to offer anything to Jordan. The gulf countries are openly angry at Jordan's support for Iraq.
But while Jordanian officials say they are grateful for the pledges of aid, the offers have not been received with unequivocal enthusiasm.
The Finance Ministry has told that United Nations that if the gulf crisis continues for a year, the problem will cost $2 billion, which is equivalent to two-thirds of the nation's gross national product.
Jordan's economic relationship with Iraq and Kuwait has been ''very intimate, very deep, very close,'' Mr. Jardeneh said. ''The economy is facing very strong dislocation - I mean, people who are producing mainly for Iraq won't find it easy to find new markets.
A Finance Ministry report showed, as examples, that the virtual closure of the port of Aqaba would cost Jordan $250 million in lost port charges and overland transportation fees over a year.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
U.S. Officials Satisfied With Soviets' Gulf Role

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Ten days after the summit meeting in Helsinki, Bush Administration officials say they are satisfied with Soviet cooperation in isolating Iraq.
Senior Administration officials said that whatever differences emerged in Helsinki between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev over the use of military force to resolve the crisis have been overshadowed by the diplomatic coordination that has emerged since the meeting.
They noted with particular enthusiasm the recent warming in Moscow's relationships with Israel and Saudi Arabia, and Soviet support of United Nations Security Council efforts to expand the blockade on Iraq to include restrictions on air traffic.
''We've been exceptionally pleased with the Soviet role,'' said a senior State Department official, who insisted on not being identified. ''Without the current Soviet position, the whole color of the gulf problem would be totally different.'' 
 
Soviet Visit to Teheran
The official said the Helsinki meeting was crucial in demonstrating to Iraq that the two countries were working in concert for the removal of Iraqi military forces from Kuwait. The meeting was also useful, he said, because ''the two guys could condition each other for the future, for what they would do next.''
Officials said they were not concerned by a visit by a Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, Aleksandr M. Belonogov, to Teheran this week to discuss the gulf crisis with Iranian leaders. Although detailed information was not available on his trip, the officials expressed confidence that his visit would not undermine efforts to isolate Iraq.
''There are no signs that the Soviets are doing anything other than urging the Iranians to comply with the sanctions,'' said another senior State Department official. He and others in the Administration said the Soviet Union was in a better position than the United States to ''steady Iran'' in support of the embargo.
American officials applauded Mr. Gorbachev's meeting last weekend in Moscow with two Israeli officials, Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai and Science and Energy Minister Yuval Neeman, as a step toward eventual Soviet diplomatic recognition of Israel.
 
Saudi-Soviet Ties Applauded
Though Mr. Gorbachev told the ministers that he would recognize Israel only after it dropped its opposition to an international conference on the Middle East, American officials suggested that Moscow would not allow its long-held demand for such a meeting to hinder its efforts to expand its diplomatic role in the Middle East.
They also noted with approval the visit to Moscow by the Israeli Housing Minister, Ariel Sharon, for several days last week to discuss resettlement of Soviet Jews to Israel.
United States officials pointed to the restoration of relations between the Soviet Union and Saudi Arabia earlier this week as another positive diplomatic development.
Administration officials have not yet begun to characterize the Soviets as allies. Indeed, they expressed some disappointment that Moscow had done no more than contribute two small warships to the international gulf force -vessels that are being deployed only in defense of Soviet shipping and citizens. They also said they wished the Soviets would withdraw from Iraq the 150 military specialists still stationed there.
 
Military Role Criticized
But even on those points, Administration officials said they understood how difficult it was for the Soviets to alter overnight an alliance with Iraq built up over more than two decades.
''Throughout this process, they've had to be brought along,'' said a senior State Department official. ''They're really making major adjustments in relationships. We have to respect that.''
Some observers outside the Administration have expressed less appreciation of the Soviet role in the gulf.
Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, a leading Democratic member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said Soviet reluctance to do more militarily to isolate Iraq ''is a disappointment,'' adding: ''The Soviets clearly have a reluctance about the use of military force. That could be a problem down the road.''
Michael Mandelbaum, director of East-West studies at the Council on Foreign Relations, said the Soviet Union had not done much since the summit meeting besides restore relations with Saudi Arabia.
''The most important contribution the Soviets have made,'' he said, ''is to have made it possible to end the cold war, which means that for the first time in 40 years we can conduct military operations in the Middle East without worrying about triggering World War III.''

HEADLINE: Puerto Rico Journal;
A Drive To Make Spanish No. 1 Voice

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R.

 BODY:
Some legislators in this United States commonwealth of 3.6 million people are seeking to demote the English language and enshrine Spanish as the official tongue of Puerto Rico.
A bill now being considered by the island's House of Representatives would repeal a 1902 law that gave Spanish and English equal status. Backers of the measure say they want to do away with an anachronistic law, a vestige of the days after Spain lost the Spanish-American War in 1898 and ceded Puerto Rico to the United States.
''We want to reconcile the law with the linguistic and cultural reality of our people,'' said Representative Hector Lopez Galarza, a former professor of Spanish and Hispanic studies, who sponsored the bill. 
Opponents say the bill is unnecessary and contend that the issue was intended to embarrass those who favor statehood for the island.
A vote in the House and Senate may come as early as next month, and, if the bill is approved, Mr. Lopez Galarza said, he plans to go further and push for an amendment to Puerto Rico's constitution that would make Spanish the only official language. Such an amendment would be more durable than a mere law, he explained, especially at a time when Puerto Rico's very status as a commonwealth is in question.
The bill, which mandates that government business be conducted in Spanish, is largely symbolic, as are most of the ''English only'' laws in effect in 16 states. Proponents say they are willing to install a sizable loophole allowing transactions and documentation to continue to be in English when necessary.
And regardless of what the current law says, Spanish is clearly the primary language of Puerto Rico. Instruction in Puerto Rico's 1,700 public schools is already given in Spanish, for example, with English as a mandatory course.
Similar legislation to restore the ascendancy of Spanish has languished in the past, and many here say its reappearance is a political maneuver in the larger fight over Puerto Rico's status, long the dominant issue on the island.
The United States Congress is now looking at bills that would enable Puerto Rico to vote on its future status: whether it would be the 51st state, an independent nation or a United States commonwealth, as it is now.
Some of Mr. Lopez Galarza's opponents contend that his Popular Democratic Party, which favors commonwealth status, is bringing up the Spanish language bill as a way of embarrassing the pro-statehood New Progressive Party. These critics say the statehood forces would find it much harder to convince Congress that Puerto Rico wants to be the 51st state if the island's own legislature has just voted to repudiate English.
The language bill's chances are uncertain. In addition to the New Progressive Party, its opponents include the largest teachers' organization and some business groups, which deem it unnecessary. The Popular Democratic Party, which dominates both houses of the legislature, is itself divided.
The language debate has stirred deep-felt emotions here about cultural identity and nationalism, which sometimes conflict with residents' sense of practical reality. Many Puerto Ricans say they love Spanish, but they need English.
''From a professional point of view I'm against the bill because English is the language of business,'' said Tomas Sanabria, 32 years old, whose job with Puerto Rico's quasi-public Industrial Development Company consists of luring United States companies to the island.
With the United States accounting for most of the Island's commerce and tourism, hundreds of high-paying jobs are available only to bilingual applicants, many Puerto Ricans say.
The economic need to learn English galls some.
''You go to the states and you're forced to speak English; they come here and you have to speak English to them,'' said Carmelo A. Paris, a 26-year-old from San Juan, who said he was unemployed. ''Spanish should be the official language. It's tradition.''
But nearly a century of political and economic association with the United States has heavily influenced Puerto Rico's speech.
Even one of the bill's staunchest supporters, Representative Juan Lopez Hernandez, caught himself speaking about ''el floor'' of the House during the bill's hearings last week. ''Hemiciclo!'' a colleague whispered, correcting him, to the smiles of the audience.
