HEADLINE: Racial Harm Is Found in School 'Tracking'

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Sept. 19

 BODY:
Black and Hispanic students are falling behind in math and science partly because they are more likely than other students to be put into classes for those with lower abilities, according to a Rand Corporation study released yesterday.
Furthermore, students in those classes tend to have less-qualified teachers and lower-quality equipment and curriculum materials, the nationwide study concluded. It cited the ''nearly universal practice'' of schools' placing their least-qualified teachers in classes of students with the least ability and best-qualified teachers in classes of brighter students.
While this ''tracking'' is supposed to sort students based only on academic ability, the Rand researchers said ethnic background too often played a role, even at the primary school level.
For example, at elementary schools where minority students make up most or all of the population, 28 percent of the curriculum consisted of low-ability math and science courses, the report said. At schools with 90 percent to 100 percent non-minority students, only 7 percent of the classes were on the slow track.
The study of 1,200 public and private schools nationwide was financed by the National Science Foundation.
The Rand Corporation, of Santa Monica, Calif., specializes in research and analysis on national security and domestic welfare issues.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 CAMPAIGN;
STUNNING PRIMARY IN MASSACHUSETTS

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The people of Massachusetts launched a political revolt Tuesday, giving smashing victories to Dr. John R. Silber as the Democratic candidate for governor and William F. Weld as the Republican contender.
The result sets up a November election that is too wildly unpredictable to forecast, citizens and political experts here said today, because outrage remains the public mood, and the candidates do not fit the normal political labels. Dr. Silber, in fact, the acerbic president of Boston University, is widely seen as a Republican running as a Democrat, and Mr. Weld, a patrician former United States Attorney, is often viewed as a moderate Republican.
''This wasn't an election, it was a revolution,'' said Cathy Walsh, a bank teller in Boston. Ms. Walsh, a lifelong Democrat, said she had voted for Dr. Silber ''because he tells the truth and is not afraid to take action.'' But she said she may vote for Mr. Weld in November ''because I really want to send a message to the politicians. Things are so bad, let's fire everybody and start over again.'' 
 
Virtual Clean Sweep
Indeed, Tuesday's primary election resulted in a virtual clean sweep for candidates who ran against incumbents or established politicians. Not only did Dr. Silber defeat Francis X. Bellotti, a former state Attorney General, and Mr. Weld beat Steven Pierce, the minority leader in the state House of Representatives, but the incumbent Democratic Attorney General, James Shannon, was defeated, as was the Democratic Speaker of the House, George Keverian. Mr. Keverian was running for state Treasurer.
The turnout of 1.41 million was a record for a primary election in Massachusetts, surpassing the previous high of 1.40 million set in 1982 when Michael S. Dukakis defeated the incumbent governor, Edward J. King, in a bitterly fought Democratic primary.
Dr. Silber and Mr. Weld defied public opinion polls with their victories. Dr. Silber had been behind Mr. Bellotti, 54 to 31 percent as recently as last Thursday, according to the Boston Globe. Mr. Weld had been down by more than 20 percentage points on Labor Day to his adversary, Mr. Pierce.
But in Tuesday's primary, with 98 percent of the ballots counted, Dr. Silber won 53 to 44 percent, picking up 545,447 votes to 446,265 for Mr. Bellotti. Mr. Weld defeated Mr. Pierce 60 to 40 percent, winning 26l,150 votes to 173,146 votes.
 
Year for Outsiders
The most important explanation for both men's triumphs was that they were perceived as the outsiders in a year of discontent over the biggest tax hike in Massachusetts' history and an economy that has fallen into recession.
In a talk today to a unity meeting of Democrats at the Boston Sheraton Hotel, Dr. Silber said: ''I'm the one who understood what was going on. I listened more carefully. I understood the outrage.''
Dr. Silber is not easy to label politically. He is conservative on some issues, favoring tough budget cuts, but liberal on others, opposing the death penalty and backing programs for child nutrition and early childhood schooling.
Polling experts said they believed the opinion polls had been misleading because a large group of voters did not want to tell pollsters how they really felt, perhaps because Dr. Silber had been criticized in the press and by Mr. Bellotti for remarks about the elderly, blacks and women that were construed as insensitive.
While some political analysts had laughed at Dr. Silber's comments as political suicide, the remarks nevertheless seem to have struck a chord with many voters.
Frank Tamanini, a 34 year-old Boston firefighter, said he liked Dr. Silber's toughness. ''He told it the way it is,'' he said. ''This city is all screwed up with drugs and crime.''
Dan Hart, Dr. Silber's director of operations, said that based on exit polls, Dr. Silber had run most strongly among independent white male voters older than 35, winning them by a two-to-one ratio.
Mr. Hart said the candidate fared worst among blacks and female Democrats, losing among women by about 54 to 47 percent.
Dr. Silber's weakness among women and blacks, two important voter blocks for Democrats, could hurt him in the November election.
But Mr. Weld faces a large numerical problem of his own. Republicans make up only about 13.4 percent of registered voters in Massachusetts, compared with 42.9 percent for Democrats and 43.8 percent for independents.
Mr. Weld is a strong supporter of abortion rights, while the other Republican candidate, Mr. Pierce, is a strong opponent of them. It was widely believed here today that Mr. Weld's abortion stand helped him in a state that is generally supportive of abortion rights.
 
Role of Tax Petition
One key to the November election is how voters now gauge an petition sponsored by the Citizens for Limited Taxation that would roll back state taxes and fees to their 1988 levels, forcing the next governor to cut $2 billion next year out of Massachusetts' $13 billion budget. Mr. Weld has backed the petition, which polls show winning a popular majority. Dr. Silber has called it too drastic.
Nevertheless, Dr. Silber's aides say he will try to convince voters that a vote for him will serve the same purpose as the petition, bringing fiscal responsibility to state government, without the drastic consequences of the ballot measure. But if the public remains in its anti-government mood, Mr. Weld's support for the tax-cutting petition could benefit him.
Whatever the outcome in November, many residents expressed jubilation.
Carol Obernesser, a pharmaceutical representative who lives in suburban Hingham, said: ''I think it's great. It shows that the people of Massachusetts are fed up and that this election will mean change.''

Bellotti, who had opposed him in the primary. Elsewhere in the city, William F. Weld, right, the Republican candidate, greeted commuters. (Photographs by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: The Second-Best Way to Save Gas

 BODY:
There's a potent prescription that at a single stroke would slash America's dependence on foreign oil, trim the trade deficit, roll back smog and avert global warming. It's to mandate that auto manufacturers produce more fuel-efficient cars. The Senate is considering a bill by Senator Richard Bryan of Nevada to raise the fuel efficiency of new cars 20 percent by 1995 and 40 percent by the year 2001. That's not the best way of improving fuel efficiency, but it's a lot better than doing nothing. 
The most efficient way of making the national auto fleet guzzle less fuel would be to slap a stiff tax on gasoline. Fuel efficiency standards mandated by Congress are in effect a hidden tax that bites by raising the price of cars. The standards are less effective than a gas tax would be because they hit only new-car owners. Owners of old cars will hang on to their gas guzzlers longer, as the efficient cars will cost more. And even new owners, if tempted to drive more, may use nearly as much fuel as before.
A gas tax would impinge on everyone equally; in addition, each cent per gallon would raise $1 billion in revenue. But half of Washington refuses to raise new taxes, and the other half lacks the courage to explain to voters why a gas tax is necessary. In this Sahara of leadership, the Bryan bill is a beckoning oasis.
Under a law passed after the 1973 oil crisis, the average fuel economy of new cars has nearly doubled, from 14 miles per gallon to 27. Each mile-per-gallon increase saves 420,000 barrels of oil a day. The Reagan Administration opposed these standards on ideological grounds, and in 1986 the Task Force on Regulatory Relief, under its chairman, Vice President Bush, proposed abolishing them altogether. Yet without the standards, the United States would be even more dangerously dependent on foreign oil than it already is.
Further gains in efficiency are certainly possible as existing technologies spread to all new models. The Bryan bill won't be cheap; manufacturers will bear heavy retooling costs to meet this and other legislated requirements. And the feasible gains may not be as great as Senator Bryan avers. But the auto manufacturers' contention that his standards will make all cars Pinto-sized is hard to swallow whole. Detroit cries wolf so reflexively when asked for cleaner, safer or more efficient cars that its credibility runs short.
Senator Bryan may also be overly optimistic in saying his standards can be met without forcing manufacturers to offer smaller and lighter-weight cars. Reducing weight is such an obvious route to fuel efficiency that the average car is almost certain to get smaller. Smaller cars, besides their other less convenient features, are also less crush-proof in accidents. But a rise in traffic deaths need not be inevitable if the lighter cars embody improved safety features.
The Bryan bill isn't the best way to make cars fuel-efficient. But it deserves the vote of every senator who dares not demand a higher tax on gasoline.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Magic Numbers in Government

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
New York politicians are at war over a number - 5,000 new police officers for New York City. Each politician offers powerful arguments for or against the 5,000. But all are engaged in the venerable and honorable game of setting the ''magic number.'' 
The game is the same, whether the issue is the police, budget deficits, arms control cuts or minimum wage levels. And the fact is, you can't run a government without pulling numbers out of the air, within bounds of political reason. Take the following typical examples: Today, legislators and White House officials are battling over how much to reduce the budget deficit. Some argue that a $50 billion slice would be too high, sending the economy into recession. Others insist that $30 billion is too low, and would leave interest rates too high. Neither possesses anything resembling ''proof.'' The goal for both is to set the tempo of cuts. Last year, President Bush vetoed a bill that would have raised the minimum wage to $4.55 an hour from $3.35. He and Congress then settled at $4.25. Did that 30 cents spell the difference between survival and ruin for businesses and workers? Not a chance. Each side was simply making the good fight for the benefit of its own constituents. In 1985, President Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev agreed to cut nuclear arms by 50 percent. Where did they get that number? Not from any study of what each would need to maintain deterrence. It was small enough for each side to keep thousands of nuclear weapons, and big enough to sound consequential and dramatic.
All of which sheds some light on the police matter in New York City. Politicians, like Gov. Mario Cuomo, who want to get out front on the issue of crime, rally behind putting 5,000 new police officers on the streets, and fast. Their rivals, like Mayor David Dinkins, who don't want to move so far so quickly, dismiss the proposal as a ''magic number.''
City Hall says the champions of the 5,000 haven't made their case, and that the only rationale for the number is that it happens to represent the difference between the present force and its all-time high of 31,000 in 1971. Mayor Dinkins says he needs time to study the matter.
Well, he can study from now to next month or the end of his term and still won't be able to produce an analysis that proves 3,000 would be more cost-effective than 10,000 or 5,000. At some point, he's going to have to make a decision and pick his own magic number. That's the only proven way to focus on the size of the bill and who will pay it, and the only practical way to start the process of putting more officers on the pavements of New York.
LESLIE H. GELB

HEADLINE: Why H.U.D. Ran From Grace

BYLINE: By Alfred A. DelliBovi; Alfred A. DelliBovi is Under Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Of all the reports produced in the last decade, one stands alone in its potential to make the Government more effective and efficient.
That is the President's Private Sector Survey on Cost Control, commonly known as the Grace commission report of 1983. Its chairman, Peter Grace, and his panel pointed the way for the Federal Government to reach twin objectives: save money and deliver better service to people who need government's help.
At many Federal agencies in the Reagan Administration, such as the Department of Transportation, the Grace commission report was taken seriously. At the Urban Mass Transportation Administration, where I served as administrator, the report's recommendations were crucial in efforts to transform the agency from a weak, ineffective player to a strong, achievement-oriented agency that defined transit's leading edge. 
Unfortunately, the same was not true at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, where failure to deal with problems identified by the Grace commission report created the fertile field in which scandals have grown.
At the U.M.T.A., weaknesses identified in the Grace commission report were tackled head on. The agency consolidated regional offices to save the costs of both personnel and office space. It installed a computerized and highly efficient grants management process to monitor and control ongoing mass transportation projects valued at more than $33.2 billion. It implemented new processes to correct inefficient grant disbursement procedures. As an agency of the Department of Transportation, the U.M.T.A. also participated in the consolidation of department-wide safety-related functions.
The story at H.U.D. was far different, and helps explain why mismanagement and weakness in virtually every area identified by the Grace commission eventually exploded into the H.U.D. scandals. I will mention just two examples.
The Grace commission reported to H.U.D. on Aug. 31, 1983, that many of the department's property disposition staff were unqualified and untrained. This staff was responsible for overseeing huge amounts of money and real estate agents who sold H.U.D.-owned properties and collected fees. These agents were supposed to turn over the proceeds of the sales to H.U.D.
But the recommendations fell on deaf ears at H.U.D. As a result, a Maryland real estate agent named Marilyn Harrell walked away with about $5 million in taxpayer money she should have turned over to H.U.D.
The Grace commission also reported in 1983 that a lack of procedural documentation in multi-family management was preventing managers from evaluating breakdowns and resolving problems. The commission also cited H.U.D.'s failure to force program participants to comply with rules and regulations.
In short, recommendations were ignored. As a result, developers and their consultants prostituted H.U.D.'s moderate rehabilitation program for tremendous personal gain.
In examples too numerous to mention - from cash management and debt collection, to H.U.D.'s giant, complex organization, to the incredible lack of modern accounting and financial management systems, to an almost total breakdown in management planning and evaluation, to the absence of managerial accountability - the Grace commission had H.U.D. pretty well pegged.
The real tragedy is that when the commission made its report, H.U.D. wasn't listening. Another failure. Nothing was done to implement the commission's recommendations, and many of America's top business leaders who volunteered their time on the commission were disenchanted.
As the report passes its seventh anniversary, my message to the public servants who prepared it is, Don't be discouraged. Aggressive efforts are now under way to restore strength and credibility to H.U.D. and its programs.
The Grace commission report can't just die or fade away. Under the guiding hand of real management professionals who are now being put in place at H.U.D., it lives to fight another day.

HEADLINE: 7 Hours of Talks, No Budget Accord

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Congressional leaders and Bush Administration officials met for seven hours today in an effort to break the impasse on a deficit-cutting package and to avoid broad automatic spending cuts that will take effect on Oct. 1 if no agreement is reached.
The small group of negotiators, who are meeting in private and without staff, refused to comment on their deliberations other than to say they had scheduled another session for Thursday. Even as they huddled, senior lawmakers in both parties began maneuvering to put together their own budget packages.
Privately, some Republicans are signaling their interest in removing President Bush's plan to reduce the capital gains tax, a main dispute in the talks. 
Without a compromise by Oct. 1, the start of the 1991 fiscal year, Congress will have to approve some sort of stopgap spending legislation to pay for the Government's operations. And to block the automatic spending cuts, the legislation would have to roll back the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law. It sets a deficit limit of $64 billion for the fiscal year 1991, well below the level contemplated in any of the budget packages now under consideration.
 
Moderates Fear a Backfire
The President has said he will veto any temporary spending bill and allow the automatic cuts to begin. Although that strategy is intended to put pressure on negotiators to reach an agreement, some moderate Republicans on Capitol Hill are privately beginning to express concerns that it could backfire.
''We seem to need some event to push the parties together,'' said Representative Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, the senior Republican on the House Budget Committee. ''We have to declare a last-minute, some kind of drop-dead date.''
Automatic spending cuts have been imposed three times before, at the start of the fiscal years 1986, 1988 and 1990. But the 1988 order was rescinded before the cuts ever took effect, and in the two other instances the cuts were relatively small and of short duration.
This year, cuts initially totaling $85.4 billion would be required. The reductions would be split equally between military programs and a variety of domestic programs. Under guidelines sent out by the Office of Management and Budget, hundreds of thousands of Federal workers, including meat and poultry inspectors and air traffic controllers, will be ordered to take furloughs beginning Oct. 1.
 
Democratic Plan Pushed
Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the House budget panel, said the best hope may lie in the last budget offer Democrats made to Republicans during 10 days of discussions by a larger negotiating group at Andrews Air Force Base in nearby Maryland. Democrats proposed scrapping most of their demands for new domestic spending and suggested that Republicans drop their demands for any revenue-losing measures, including the cut in the capital gains tax.
Mr. Panetta said that if the current negotiations failed to produce an agreement, Democrats would prepare a budget that closely tracks their previous offer. They are sure that some of the more moderate Republicans who have been involved in the budget negotiations, including Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the senior Republican on the Senate Budget Commitee, would be willing to sever the capital gains tax cut from the budget package if they could be guaranteed a separate vote on the tax cut.
But Democrats would require that such a measure include an offsetting tax increase for the wealthy.
Neither Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate minority leader, nor Senator Domenici has given any public indication that they would accept such a proposition. When he was asked about it, Mr. Domenici said through a spokesman that he does not favor that approach.
 
Revenue-Raising Measures
In their 10 days of bargaining at Andrews, the budget negotiators tentatively agreed to some $59 billion in revenue-raising measures over five years, including increased excise taxes on beer, wine and alcohol, a new luxury tax on expensive cars, boats, jewels and furs, and tighter tax rules for American subsidiaries of foreign-owned companies.
They also narrowed differences on the amount of money to be cut from programs like Medicare, Medicaid and farm subsidies and from military spending. But they could not settle on any new system for enforcing the spending cuts and found themselves at loggerheads over the capital gains issue.
Republicans maintain that the captial gains tax is the one element in the deficit package that promises to stimulate the economy, while Democrats contend that the cut amounts to a giveway for the rich. They insist that the revenue loss and the direct benefit that the gains cut would give to the wealthy be offset with increases in taxes for upper-income Americans, but Republicans have opposed any increase in income tax rates.
Even if the capital gains tax cut were to be dropped from Republican proposals, Democrats have said tax increases for the wealthy would still be needed to offset the impact of the increased excise taxes and an anticipated energy tax on lower- and middle-income Americans.

HEADLINE: Now Atlanta Gets Down to Brass Tacks

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS; Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Sept. 19

 BODY:
With the designation of Atlanta as the site of the 1996 Summer Olympics, the boosterism and promotion of the Atlanta Organizing Committee, which led the effort to land the Games, will now give way to the quasipublic Metropolitan Atlanta Olympic Games Authority, which will be the operating authority to raise funds and oversee construction for the Games.
The authority, created by the State Legislature in 1989, will oversee the raising of about $1.2 billion. Of that sum, $418 million will go for the construction of new facilities; nearly $600 million for operating funds and $157 million as a ''surplus.
Andrew Young, the city's former mayor and the chairman of the organizing committee said in a telephone interview from Tokyo that much of what has to be done is ''pretty simple'' since the city entered the effort to attract the Games equipped with the necessary infrastructure. 
 
'Clean, Pleasant' Urban Area
''One of the things that always surprised visitors from the International Olympics Committee,'' said Robert M. Brennan, spokesman for the organizing committee ''was that there was even a city like ours here in the South, a clean, pleasant progressive urban area. That became part of our thrust, that we had something to offer as an undiscovered part of the world.''
Still, the Atlanta metropolitan area with its population of 2.6 million will have to build a number of facilities to meet the needs of the Games. With the creation of the authority by the state and with its ability to issue tax-exempt bonds, Atlanta has welded a public sector and private sector partnership for the Games. This approach contrasts sharply with the approach of Los Angeles to the 1984 Summer Games. Then a private group was given the authority to operate the Games on the condition that it not use tax revenues at all.
Whether the Atlanta group will have to use its bonding authority was unclear. Private businesses as well as public officials and the heads of area educational facilities were well represented in the Atlanta effort, said Wayne Gantt, an economist in Atlanta. 85,000-Seat Stadium Planned The major facilities that the organizing committee proposes to build include a 85,000-seat stadium for track and field, pool facilities for swimming, diving and water polo competitions, an Olympic village to house the athletes, a velodrome for the cycling events and indoor facilities for shooting and archery events.
Among the city's existing or soon-to-be completed facilities are the 71,000-seat Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium, the home of the baseball Braves and the football Falcons; a $210 million domed stadium on which construction began last year that will be the site of the 1994 Super Bowl and the home of the Falcons; the Omni indoor coliseum, where the Atlanta Hawks of the National Basketball Association play, and the Georgia World Congress Center convention center. To these will be added the new Olympic Stadium, which will later become the Braves' new home.
Most of the existing and planned facilities are contained in a three-square mile downtown area where the organizing committee plans to hold as many as 19 of the most popular events of the Games.
 
Stadium Cost at $145 Million
The price tag on the proposed Olympic Stadium has been put at $145 million by the Atlanta committee. The stadium is to be built next to the Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium and will be site of the opening and closing ceremonies of the Games as well as the track and field events, soccer and show-jumping finals. The Olympic baseball com-petition will be held in the existing stadium.
In addition to the new stadium the Games authority will finance the construction of the Olympic Village dormitories on the downtown campus of Georgia Tech. The estimated $59 million dormitories are envisioned as twin towers flanking a major downtown artery and connected by an enclosed pedestrian bridge. Committee officials have said that after the Games the buildings, with their 15,500 units, will be given to the university as student housing.
The domed stadium now under construction will have 72,000 seats and will be divided into two 36,000-seat arenas for basketball and gymnastics competitions.
Adjacent to the domed stadium is the World Congress Center, a two-building complex of flexible space that will be configured as small arenas for sports such as badminton, fencing, judo, table tennis and wrestling.
Also connected to this complex is the Omni, the 17,000-seat coliseum that will be used for the volleyball tournament.
 
Georgia Tech to Be Used
Additional downtown facilities will include the Georgia Tech Coliseum, which will house boxing competitions, and the existing Atlanta Civic Center, where weight-ifting events will be held. There are also plans for a 15,000- seat natatorium for swimming and diving events, which will be built by extending and reshaping facilities on the Georgia Tech campus.
A new water polo stadium is to be built at the Atlanta University complex, the home of the city's historically black colleges, Morehouse, Spellman, Clark and Morris Brown. Stadiums there will also be expanded to accommodate the Olympic field hockey events.
Just north of city and outside of the downtown ring is Blackburn Park, the city's tennis center and home of the Atlanta Lawn Tennis Association. The association has 55,000 members and is believed to be the largest active tennis association in the country. The center has 31 courts, which the organizing committee said could be enlarged and equipped with more seating to accommodate the tennis events.
East of the city at Stone Mountain Park, the authority is scheduled to build an open-air velodrome for the cycling events. The Olympic Park at the 3,200-acre state park will be outfitted as well for pentathlon, rowing, shooting, equestrian, archery and canoeing events.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Andrew Young, Atlanta's former Mayor and head of organizing committee. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: New Discount Frontier: Home

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE

 BODY:
THEY live for Loehmann's; a hangtag quickens their pulse. This fall, New York's more ferocious bargain hunters have a new frontier: the home.
Juicers by Philippe Starck, tea kettles by Michael Graves and sheets by Mario Buatta are turning up in new places, at discounts that can be substantial. Those who are less name-conscious can also find good buys on silk comforters for cold winter nights and towels to last a college-age child for at least the next four years. 
In general, go south and don't stop: it is in Lower Manhattan where a bargain hunter can have fun.
Head first toward the Battery and the sparkling new Century 21 at 22 Cortlandt Street. For 30 years, it was a no-frills store on Cortlandt Street frequented by the chic and the not-so-chic, united in their dedication to the fashion bargain. No longer. Last month, Century 21 opened a three-story, 100,000-square-foot store down the block, and there has been an apparent feeding frenzy ever since, as if every day is three days before Christmas. Mobbed or not, though, service tends to be surprisingly swift.
The street level glistens with marble, mirror and mahogany; if you squint, it looks vaguely like Macy's Herald Square. Housewares are on the lower level, a bright, well-organized place to shop.
The management is not saying what is behind the upgrading of Century 21 at a time of retailing troubles and a sluggish local economy. But the timing seems right for off-price decorator totems. Some price cuts are deep, but just as often, the mere suggestion of a bargain - perhaps 15 percent off - seems enough to inspire the shopper.
One recent lunch hour, Deborah Leitner, a 34-year-old paralegal in Manhattan, was standing in the nerve center of the floor - the linen section - clutching a set of blue sheets made by Wamsutta and black-and-white cotton place mats. ''I like the quality, their reasonable prices,'' she said. ''Unlike a lot of discount stores which sell a lot of junk - seconds and irregulars - these are first quality.''
On that day, sheets introduced as recently as this spring were already discounted. There was Mario Buatta's flower-strewn Marissa pattern for Revman, which has a dark forest-green border. A twin flat sheet was selling for $13.97; its list price is $18-$19, according to the manufacturer.
Liberty of London's Prince Edward pattern, featuring a ruby red and deep blue paisley design, was also on the shelves. A twin flat sheet was marked $19.97, down from $22, according to Martex, the manufacturer.
Marimekko's vinyl place mats with red, blue and white stripes or a yellow pear on a pink ground, were two for $1; this spring they were $3 each. Also available were towels, pillows, comforters, blankets, shower curtains, window shades and blinds, a selection as dazzling as it was deep.
When Michael Graves, the architect, designed his whistling tea kettle with the little red bird for Alessi in 1985, it quickly became a status symbol at $145. At Century 21, the kettle is $119, but the status police need not know. Philippe Starck's futuristic juicer with a spidery body and long, tapered legs, for Alessi, sells for $64.97 here; its list price is $75.
In adjacent cabinets, there are crystal by Baccarat, Lalique and Orrefors, and china by Lenox. Nearby are luggage by Perry Ellis and Yves St. Laurent, Black & Decker Dustbusters and Sanyo rice cookers. The only thing missing is furniture. Although Grand Street is the traditional heartland of linens in Manhattan, Conway on Broad Street in the Financial District is worth a visit. Of all the city's Conway stores, this may be the nicest. The lower level is devoted to pillows and towels, which came in a full spectrum of colors from white to peach to bottle green. Bath towels ranged from $5.99 to $7.99. Matching hand and face towels were also available.
Syms on Trinity Place sells primarily clothes, but the 1 percent of the store devoted to the home can be interesting. Recently, on the fourth floor, there were dozens of white cotton hand towels for $1 each. There are also plenty of stylish odds and ends - the random piece of luggage, the occasional comforter.
The corner of Church and Warren Streets, with its various odd-lot stores, can be a treasure trove, depending on the day. Towels by Andree Putman were among the spoils recently at Weber's Job Lot; but there were also 25 sponges, each a slightly different thickness, for a scant 99 cents.
Across the street at Job Lot Trading Corporation, 49 cents bought a package of three sponges shaped like chickens, fish and bears. The American country look was there, too, in antiqued painted wood mirrors and picture frames. A five-by-eight-inch mirror, framed in either blue, gray, white or celadon, was $2.98.
Chinatown has accessories for the home that go far beyond chopsticks. On the second floor at Pearl River Emporium on Canal Street, a 70-by-88-inch pure silk comforter, deep red with red flowers on a red background, sells for $155. A hot pink style, 70 by 90 inches, was $195.
A parakeet might find happiness in Pearl River's bamboo birdcages: single tier ($9.50), double ($13.50) or triple ($17.50). A shaving brush with a natural wood handle, the sort you might see in a Ralph Lauren still life, is $1.25; and sandalwood, jasmine and rose soaps are three for $1.
On the third floor are dishes. A shallow seven-inch enameled tin bowl, in white with a red rose in the center, sells for $1.95. White china dishes, each hand-painted with a different species of fish, sell for $2.95.
At Kam Man on Canal Street, the specialty is food, but downstairs, there are also traditional glazed ceramic garden seats. A hexagonal seat - deep blue on the top, with mustard-colored sides depicted leaping stags - is $42.50. A clay casserole in a wire basket (the metal conducts the heat) sells for $9.50. Straw trivets in natural, dark green and pink are 79 cents.
The south side of 14th Street, between Seventh Avenue and Broadway, has dozens of stores selling clothing and home furnishings. Guards perch on ladders in front of them, on the lookout for thefts; wind-up toys scurry along the pavement, and then there are the bargains.
Grand Discount House sported a cotton bath towel ($2.99) depicting the faces of the New Kids on the Block. For another sensibility, Paterson Silks was selling beige linen, a fabric that decorators often use for upholstery and slipcovers, for $14.95 a yard. The salesman was quick to point out the list price of $22.

HEADLINE: Parent & Child

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE KUTNER

 BODY:
THE Iraqi invasion of Kuwait has affected many families in ways other than having to pay more for gasoline. Psychologists and psychiatrists are beginning to see changes in children's play and artwork, which are usually good reflections of their unspoken hopes and fears. Most children first show their concerns through changes in their behavior. Their words come later.
Dr. Barry Garfinkel, the chief of child and adolescent psychiatry at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis, and many of his colleagues are beginning to see not only children who have parents, older siblings and other relatives in the military, but also the children of reservists who may be called to active duty. 
''Even mild-mannered children are becoming more aggressive in their play,'' Dr. Garfinkel said. ''It's a way for them to get a handle on their angry feelings.''
One psychologist described how a 9-year-old girl drew a picture of her father, who is in the medical corps of the Naval Reserve, standing alone on the deck of a ship and firing a gun. It was her way of bringing her fears, both legitimate and unrealistic, out in the open. Her father might soon be away, alone and in danger.
''Children's imaginations can run wild with this situation, especially if they have a parent involved,'' Dr. Garfinkel said. ''The children I've talked to are imagining that their parents are in situations worthy of Indiana Jones. They talk about booby traps and terribly complex predicaments.''
Although most American preschoolers will pay little attention to what is happening in the Middle East, those who have parents or other close relatives involved in the military action may distort events in ways that fit their limited knowledge of the world. They may envision Saudi Arabia as only a few blocks or a few miles away, and imagine war spreading to their neighborhood. They may be especially frightened if they are being raised by a single parent who is in the military or if the parents are married and the mother is in the reserves or on active duty.
''You can expect young children to ask questions that adults would never ask,'' said Dr. Gerald P. Koocher, the chief psychologist at Children's Hospital in Boston. ''If their father's overseas they'll want to know: 'Will my dad come home to visit this weekend? Can we go see him?' ''
Children sometimes ascribe mystical powers to their thoughts and wishes. Because of this, young children may feel an inordinate amount of responsibility for their family's health and safety.
For example, a psychologist who studies how children respond to the threat of nuclear war recalled a 9-year-old boy who cried himself to sleep at night.
''He was afraid that he and his family were going to be killed by an atomic bomb, but he didn't want to talk about it for fear that talking might make it happen,'' said the psychologist, Dr. Milton Schwebel, a professor emeritus in the graduate school of applied and professional psychology at Rutgers University in New Jersey.
Dr. Antoinette Saunders, a clinical psychologist and the director of the Capable Kid Center, a child guidance clinic in Evanston, Ill., said: ''Children below the age of 11 may become clingy and may not want to leave home. They may become more moody or withdrawn.''
They may also withdraw because they are overwhelmed by their fears about what is happening. Just as their limited knowledge of geography will make some children worry that their homes may soon be bombed, their views of the day-to-day life of a soldier may be very distorted.
''Imagination is much worse than reality for children,'' Dr. Garfinkel said. ''The children I've seen are already talking about poison gas and chemical warfare, but they're not thinking about the heat and the boredom.''
 
'Will Daddy Be Coming Home?'
PARENTS can do several things to help their children handle their concerns about events in Iraq and Saudi Arabia:
Encourage your children to talk about their fears.
The simplest way to do that is to start the conversations yourself. ''If you don't talk about these issues, you may be giving your children the message that they're not allowed to talk about them,'' said Dr. Milton Schwebel, a professor emeritus in the graduate school of applied and professional psychology at Rutgers University.
Children may not ask the questions that are bothering them the most: Are they safe? Will they be abandoned or separated from their family? Are they powerless? It is important to answer those questions even if they are never asked.
Use analogies and measures that a child can understand.
With young children, use terms from their everyday lives in discussions of geography or the subtleties of world economics and international politics. The idea that a relative in the military is 7,000 miles away may make more sense to children if you describe it as 10 times the distance to their grandmother's house.
''Ask your child what she might do if a child next door took something of hers,'' said Dr. Gerald P. Koocher, the chief psychologist at Children's Hospital in Boston. That will allow you to discuss how there can be different solutions to a problem. While a 30 percent increase in the price of gasoline will not mean anything to young children, they may understand it better if you say that filling the tank on the family car has increased by the price of 10 candy bars.
Remember that the primary concern of younger children is being separated from their parents.
If their father has been shipped overseas, for example, it is important to reassure them repeatedly that he will be coming home.
''They need to know that even though Daddy is going away, we'll write letters to him and he'll return,'' Dr. Schwebel said. He also strongly recommended that parents join a support group of families who have someone in the Persian Gulf.
If one parent is away, expect your children to withdraw for a while.
There is nothing unusual about this. It is simply their way of coming to terms with what is happening. The next stage is what many parents find confusing.
''Two or three months later, that withdrawal can turn to indifference and emotional numbing,'' said Dr. Barry Garfinkel, the chief of child and adolescent psychiatry at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis. ''Children may react very negatively when the missing parent's name is brought up.'' That anger is usually more in response to their feelings of abandonment than to anything specific in the parent. Again, it is important to encourage the children to talk about their feelings, even if those feelings make them feel uncomfortable.
When the parent comes back home, do not expect everything to return to normal immediately.
Even those children who have been very excited about their parent's return may suddenly act as if the returning parent was not important. ''The children may need some time to discharge the pent-up anger they've felt, so that they can respond with less ambivalence,'' Dr. Garfinkel said.

HEADLINE: Archdiocese Orders Play to Vacate Church

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN

 BODY:
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has demanded that an Off Off Broadway theater company in Manhattan terminate performances of a play being presented in a former parochial school the company leases from the archdiocese. The archdiocese says the play has language that is against the church's principles and is being performed in violation of terms in the lease between the church and the theater.
The RAPP Theater Company, which is part of the RAPP Arts Center, at 220 East Fourth Street on the Lower East Side, says the archdiocese's action amounts to censorship and has vowed to fight the church's action, even though the group agreed in its lease not to present such work.
''We will not buckle under the pressure,'' said R. Jeffrey Cohen, the founder and artistic director of both the company and the center, who added that the company had been threatened with eviction if it continued to perform the play. ''My attorneys are looking into it and they are convinced that the church's position is unconstitutional as well as being unconscionable.'' 
 
A Monologue of Diatribe
The play, ''The Cardinal Detoxes,'' by Thomas M. Disch, is a 35-minute monologue about an archbishop who has been placed in a church-run detoxification center because he has killed a pregnant woman in an automobile accident while driving under the influence of alcohol. In the play, he delivers a diatribe against church policies on abortion, women's rights, homosexuality and other issues.
The play was first presented in the spring, when the company received no complaints from the church. It resumed performances in August and is presented on Friday and Saturday nights at 11:30, after the company's current production of ''As You Like It - Fresh,'' in which the Shakespeare play is moved to the Lower East Side and deals with racial and economic issues in New York City.
Mr. Cohen said that on Monday the center received a letter from the lawyers for the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Holy Redeemer, the agent for the archdiocese, which is the landlord, demanding that the theater company ''immediately terminate the performance'' of the play because it violates the center's lease.
 
A Matter of Principles
Joseph Zwilling, the director of communications for the archdiocese, said yesterday that the archdiocese's action in no way amounted to censorship. ''One of the clauses of the lease states that the tenant acknowledges that the land is owned by the Roman Catholic Church and is subject to the religious, moral and ethical principles and directives of the archdiocese, and that any activity permitted on the premises offensive to those principles would be detrimental to the landlord's reputation as a Roman Catholic church,'' Mr. Zwilling said.
Such activity, he said, included obscene language, pornography, nudity and anything else the church deemed objectionable. ''This was agreed to by the tenant after extensive discussions,'' Mr. Zwilling said. ''We went over this very carefully. They said they would abide by these principles.''
''They are renting space from a church, and because we are a church we have certain standards by which we must run our institutions - and that includes the institutions that are rented out to other people,'' Mr. Zwilling added.
 
The Lease Language Stands
Mr. Cohen said that in 1986, when the lease was signed, he and his lawyers tried to negotiate different language but were told that the clause was standard in church leases and would not be excised. He said he received verbal assurances from the priest who was the pastor of the church at the time - but is no longer there - that the clause would never be enforced.
''It was either sign or abandon the project entirely,'' Mr. Cohen said. ''And my attorney suggested to me that if anything happened it would become a constitutional issue because you cannot legislate in a lease against freedom of expression.''
The RAPP Arts Center is an experimental group that presents avant-garde theater, music, dance and film. Among those it has presented are the performance artist Karen Finley and the Moscow Puppet Theater. It also subleases space in the building to painters, visual artists, other theater and dance companies and social-service organizations.
Mr. Cohen said he had not decided whether to defy the church's order and present the play at his group's theater this weekend. ''We will not discontinue the performances,'' he said. ''The question is whether to do the play on this property or in another space near this property.''
 
A Concern for Others
One reason he is considering performing the play elsewhere, Mr. Cohen said, is his concern about the other tenants in the building. ''We have to be very careful about the way we might jeopardize their tenancy in pursuing a constitutional issue,'' he said.
Mr. Disch, the playwright, who is the drama critic of The Nation and a science-fiction writer, said he was not surprised at the archdiocese's action.
''I wrote the play because I grew up Catholic,'' he said. ''I've been a passionate and devout ex-Catholic since my teen-age years. The church has always been at the forefront of any national effort to censor and tone down the arts.''
Mr. Cohen said that as far as he knew, no church representative had seen the play. ''I challenge the church to find anything within the text of the play which is profane and which is against church policy,'' he said.
''It's all about their discomfort with having experimental artists in one of their buildings,'' Mr. Cohen added. ''Which they should have thought of before they leased it to us.''
But Mr. Zwilling said the archdiocese had seen a copy of the script. ''We also have their newspaper advertisement,'' he said, ''which describes the play as 'Tom Disch's powerful indictment of the Catholic Church.' ''

HEADLINE: Big Shift In Phone Regulation

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The Federal Communications Commission today gave the nation's eight big providers of local telephone service greater freedom to raise or lower the prices they charge long-distance carriers for completing interstate calls. The move signals a fundamental shift in the economic philosophy of American regulation.
The charges account for about half the cost of placing a long-distance call. But the F.C.C. declined to estimate the effect of today's decision on long-distance carriers, and ultimately on consumers, because the charges will now depend more closely on the productivity of the local telephone companies. 
Some telephone user groups criticized the move, while the local phone companies praised it.
 
Consumer Group's Reaction
Gene Kimmelman, telecommunications expert at the Consumer Federation of America, said the productivity incentives might not encourage adequate investment in the telephone network. And he said the price caps mandated by the new system, which effectively require a company to lower the price of one service if it raises the price of another, could allow prices to rise faster than under the old system, which was based wholly on what is known as ''rate of return'' regulation.
But Frank Gumper, the managing director of regulatory policy at the Nynex Corporation, which is the parent of the New York Telephone Company, said consumers would benefit because Nynex would be able to operate more efficiently and pass on the savings. 8 Companies Involved The price caps apply only to the GTE Corporation and the seven regional Bell companies, including Nynex, created by the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company on Jan. 1, 1984. Together, these eight companies own 85 percent of the nation's local telephone lines. The F.C.C. decided that each of the roughly 1,300 smaller companies that own the other 15 percent could choose annually whether to switch to price-cap regulation or stay with rate of return.
The new regulatory system will take effect on Jan. 1 and will last at least four years. The commission ordered that the price caps increase each year by less than the local phone companies had expected but more than A.T.& T. and consumer groups had sought. The commission will impose price ceilings for three broad categories of services that the local phone companies provide in conveying calls from businesses and homes to the nearest long-distance switching centers.
Within the three categories the local phone companies will be able to raise or lower their charges to long-distance companies for specific services by 5 percent without seeking regulatory approvals, provided that a weighted average of the prices in each category does not exceed the price ceiling.
Today's move reflects the current economic thinking that regulators should not dictate specific pricing and investment decisions to monopolistic industries, but should instead create rules that force companies to behave as efficiently as they would in a competitive market. Local telephone service, unlike long-distance service, is a natural monopoly because it is not feasible for another company to string telephone wires to every home and business - although a few small companies have laid high-capacity private lines from large corporations to long-distance switching centers in large cities like New York.
Alfred C. Sikes, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said in an interview after the decision that his goal was to create a regulatory environment in which built-in incentives prompted companies to set voluntarily the lowest feasible prices for consumers, and to develop the most efficient telephone network possible.
''I don't believe that career Government people, or for that matter career non-Government people, can find out what the true cost of a service should be,'' he said.
Six Congressmen have sent letters in the last several days to the commission, criticizing the price-cap plan. The House Subcommittee on Telecommunications and Finance plans a hearing by the end of the year on whether price caps help consumers.
The F.C.C. today also lowered the maximum allowed rate of return on interstate access charges to 11.25 percent, from 12 percent, for the small local phone companies, with excess profits refunded to consumers. Each of the eight companies on price-cap regulation, previously limited to a 12 percent return, will now be allowed a 13.25 percent return if it chooses price caps that go up slowly over the next four years, or 12.25 percent if it chooses price caps that climb more quickly. Profits above these levels are to be split equally between the consumer and the company, up to an additional 4 percent rate of return, above which all extra profits are to be refunded to consumers.
 
The Struggle for Profits
It is unclear whether the local phone companies will be able to earn these higher rates of return. Both rates of increase in the price caps are roughly comparable or slightly less than the rates of increase that have actually occurred in interstate access charges in recent years. A.T.&T. has been on a price-cap plan since July 1 of last year.
The five commissioners of the F.C.C. voted unanimously to adopt the price-cap regulation and lower the maximum rate of return.
The intent of price-cap regulation is to encourage phone companies to introduce risky new services and improve old ones, because the new system allows them to keep some of the resulting profits.
The exact amount by which the price ceilings will rise had been a subject of bitter dispute in the industry. On one side were the local telephone companies, who favored allowing price caps to increase nearly as quickly as producer prices in the economy.
On the other side was a coalition of A.T.& T., the MCI Communications Corporation, consumer groups and large corporate users of telephone services, who all favored a slower rate of increases in price caps. The coalition contended that the rate of increase suggested when the commission staff publicly outlined its price-cap plan earlier this year would result in an extra $5 billion in charges by the local phone companies to long-distance carriers over the next four years, charges that long-distance callers would eventually pay.
 
Calculating the Savings
The commission staff included two new, slower rates of increase and a different method of calculating part of the price caps in the plan adopted today. The two changes will save consumers between $1.8 billion and $2.75 billion over the next four years, or roughly half what A.T.&T. and its allies sought.
A.T.&T. said in a statement today, ''Although the order is very complex and we're still evaluating it, based on our current understanding, the commission has moved substantially from its earlier, flawed proposal.''
Also in dispute is whether the local telephone companies might seek to cut costs and increase profits by reducing their annual investments in new equipment and by reducing the quality of service. The commission said it would require companies to submit quarterly reports on quality.
But Herbert E. Marx, the counsel of the Independent Data Communications Manufacturers Association, a Washington trade group, called this measure inadequate and said that reduced quality ''is an inherent flaw in price-cap regulation.''

HEADLINE: Macy Plans To Buy Back 'Junk Bonds'

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
R. H. Macy & Company, the giant retailer, is planning to purchase a large chunk of its ''junk bonds'' to cut its $600 million in annual interest payments. The company has some $4.7 billion in long-term debt, and another $1 billion in short-term borrowings that fluctuate seasonally.
To finance the buyback, Macy is looking at several options, including selling up to 20 percent of the company, selling non-operating real estate assets and borrowing from its bank lenders. $1.6 Billion in 'Junk Bonds' 
Reports of the buyback began to circulate yesterday, but they failed to increase the price of Macy's bonds, which have declined in value as United States retail sales have slumped and the economy has weakened. The company's 14.5 percent debentures, due in 2001, were bid at 42 cents on the dollar yesterday, unchanged from the day before.
Macy has about $1.6 billion in face value of high-yield, high-risk junk bonds that were issued to help finance a 1986 leveraged buyout to take the company private.
Myron E. Ullman, Macy's executive vice president, offered no timetable for the buyback, nor would he specify the amount of bonds to be purchased. He said, however, that the company would ''move quickly.''
Macy has three main options for financing the buyback. The only one that does not require the approval of its bank lenders is selling an ownership position and using the proceeds to buy debt. Mr. Ullman said that Macy's agreements with its senior lenders allowed it to use up to $300 million of equity funds for debt purchases without bank approval.
This summer, Macy sold a 1 percent stake to a real estate developer. The $15 million in proceeds were used to retire about $50 million face value of subordinated debt.
With bank approval, the company could sell some non-operating assets. These assets include an office building in Los Angeles and equity in shopping centers in Brooklyn and in San Jose, Calif.
The final option would be for Macy to obtain new borrowings from its existing lenders. The last two options ''require the banks' participation and approval, which is neither forthcoming nor certain,'' Mr. Ullman said. But he anticipated that ''some combination'' of the three options would be followed.
The company's two lead banks are Manufacturers Hanover and Bankers Trust New York, which recently lent money for a similar bond-buyback program at RJR Nabisco, but only after lengthy negotiations and the payment of high fees to the banks. Equity in Macy is currently held by the General Electric Company, which owns 20.2 percent; the LoewsCorporation, 12.1 percent; the Mutual Shares Corporation, 12.1 percent, and the real estate developer Alfred Taubman, 4.1 percent.
Mr. Ullman also said he was uncertain whether Macy would meet an earlier forecast of earning an operating profit of about $650 million for the six months ending next Jan. 31. Mr. Ullman said that the estimate could no longer be considered ''in the bag'' because of the sluggish economy and slow retail sales.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Cools Hope Of Rate Cut

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, said today that while the Persian Gulf confrontation had ''introduced new and substantial risks'' to the economy, there was still no clear evidence of actual or imminent recession that would force a cut in interest rates now.
''We have not tilted down,'' Mr. Greenspan declared, at the same time expressing concern that the nation's basic inflation rate has, in fact, crept higher amid ever-slackening economic activity.
He spoke shortly after publication of yet another dose of poor news: a drop last month in housing starts and building permits and a Federal Reserve survey showing economic activity ''expanding more slowly or declining'' in most of its 12 districts throughout the country.
 
Budget Action Awaited
For some time Mr. Greenspan has said that once the Bush Administration and Congress reach agreement on a long-term plan to cut the Government's budget deficit, he would play his part by cutting rates. He indicated today that he still held that position, and seemed unwilling to move before such a deal was reached. 
Economists generally interpreted Mr. Greenspan's remarks before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress to mean that conditions do not yet require the central bank to relax its tight grip on monetary policy.
In the credit markets, traders reacted by selling short-term notes and buying long-term bonds, taking Mr. Greenspan's remarks as a sign that the Fed was more concerned with fighting inflation than with a recession. [Page D16.] Tough Medicine Considered Mr. Greenspan rejected almost summarily suggestions that the economy was so fragile it could not stand the fiscal medicine now being considered, which involves cutting spending and raising taxes enough to trim the deficit by $50 billion next year and a total of $500 billion by the middle of the decade.
He strongly implied that the interest-rate cuts that would come after such a fiscal stance was adopted, especially the cuts in long-term rates, would more than offset any budget-related drag.
In an effort to quantify the implications of this summer's jump in oil prices, Mr. Greenspan estimated that a $10 increase in the price of a barrel of oil would add one and a half to two percentage points to the inflation rate over the next year while knocking roughly one percentage point off the rate of growth in gross national product.
Prices rose 5.6 percent in the 12 months ended last month, and G.N.P. is thought by many to be growing in the current quarter at an annual rate of about 1 percent.
''Hard data on the output of goods and services in the period since the invasion of Kuwait are limited and it is difficult to distinguish the effects of higher oil prices from developments that would have occurred anyway,'' Mr. Greenspan said. ''Clearly, growth is, at best, sluggish. Nonetheless, judging from both hard data and more anecdotal reports, we are not, at least as yet, witnessing a cumulative unwinding of economic activity.''
 
Defining Recession
When asked to elaborate, Mr. Greenspan took pains to distinguish between the conventional definition of recession, two straight quarters of contraction in G.N.P., and what he suggested was a more useful description, a period in which business activity not only slumped but dropped significantly enough so that the downturn feeds on itself. A severe loss of jobs, for instance, leads to mortgage defaults, which in turn hurt banks.
Unlike the conventionally defined recession, Mr. Greenspan said, the self-perpetuating type always becomes so clear that it ''never gets revised'' away by after-the-fact refinement of the data. The most recent example of this unmistakable kind of recession occurred in 1967, he said.
 
Auto Sales Cited
As for current conditions, Mr. Greenspan said some comfort could be taken from the fact that sales of new motor vehicles ''have softened only moderately'' in light of the Persian Gulf situation and that retail sales of other items remained about the same in August as in the preceding few months.
He acknowledged that surveys showed a steep drop in consumer confidence but said this might be ''largely a reflexive response to bad news rather than an objective assessment of the outlook.''
''The prospects for weakness cascading throughout the economy do not as yet appear compelling, in part because of the tight rein that businesses have been keeping on inventories,'' Mr. Greenspan added.
 
No Odds Given
Mr. Greenspan said at one point today that it was ''too soon to indicate'' whether the odds of recession, without specifying what kind, were greater or less than 50-50.
One way to guarantee recession, Mr. Greenspan said, would be to let inflation rise substantially, a development that would be speeded if oil-price increases were allowed to become embedded in wage rates.
Mr. Greenspan was not asked by committee members why the rate on Federal funds, which the central bank controls, tumbled earlier this week. After the session, however, a Federal Reserve spokesman, Joseph R. Coyne, attributed the drop solely to ''technical'' factors, which he would not describe.

HEADLINE: Savings Bailout Chief Asks for $100 Billion

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
The head of the Federal bailout of the savings and loan industry asked Congress today for $100 billion to $110 billion for the new fiscal year, which begins next month, to continue the rescue program.
Appearing before the House Ways and Means Committee, L. William Seidman, chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, said the agency would need at least $50 billion to cover the future costs of the rescue it is overseeing. That figure is generally in line with the Bush Administration's revisions in May to its estimates of the overall bailout bill.
Mr. Seidman said the amount, which is used to make up losses at insolvent institutions so that insured depositors can be fully reimbursed, could be greater if the economy and real estate markets around the nation continue to decline. 
 
Need for Working Capital
He said an additional $50 billion to $60 billion would be needed for working capital, which is intended to be used to pay temporarily for assets acquired by the Government and for advances to certain institutions under control of Resolution Trust.
Working capital has generally not been considered part of the overall cost of the bailout, because it is expected to be recouped eventually, largely through the Government's sales of assets. Resolution Trust's portfolio of real estate, securities, outstanding loans and other assets inherited from collapsed institutions has swelled to more than $165 billion.
Resolution Trust's sales of assets suffered a setback this week when the agency announced that it had canceled a $300 million worldwide auction of some of the largest properties because, it said, the company running the auction, Auction Company of America, had failed to spend $2 million on a pre-auction publicity. The company, however, said it had spent nearly $2 million, and accused Resolution Trust of bungling.
 
Support for the Request
The request for new money was endorsed by both Charles A. Bowsher, who as Comptroller General heads the General Accounting Office, and Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, both of whom also appeared before the Ways and Means Committee.
They said said that a failure to continue rapidly rescuing institutions could substantially increase the ultimate cost of the bailout. The Bush Administration has estimated that the effort will at most cost $130 billion, excluding interest, over the next 30 years, while other estimates, including interest, have put the total as high as $500 billion.
When Congress and the Bush Administration established the Resolution Trust Corporation in the bailout legislation signed last year, $50 billion was appropriated to cover the cost of the rescue effort. That money is expected to be gone within the next few months, having been spent on resolving the financial problems at more than 350 institutions.
 
Effort to Save Fragile S.& L.'s
Mr. Seidman told the committee that he and T. Timothy Ryan Jr., director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, had begun exploring the possibility of permitting many fragile savings and loans to survive in an effort to keep the cost of the bailout down.
''There are at least some institutions that might be handled at a more efficient cost if they were managed and supervised more closely rather than closed,'' said Mr. Seidman, who also heads the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. But he quickly added that no decision had been reached on how Resolution Trust would treat such institutions over the next few months.
He said that if additional funds were available, then he would favor exercising certain cost-cutting options in the contracts of nearly 100 transactions that transferred institutions in late 1988 to private entrepreneurs. A study released Tuesday showed that the Government could save $2 billion to $3 billion if it spent $22 billion to buy back high-yielding notes and poor assets that have been guaranteed.
Mr. Seidman also acknowledged that a year into the savings and loan rescue, the regulatory agencies supervising the effort were only beginning to approach the proper level of staffing. But there are still some areas where the agencies are looking to increase their staffs. Resolution Trust alone expects over the coming months to double its staff of lawyers to 2,000, he said.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Sees Growth for U.S. in 1991

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19

 BODY:
Despite oil price increases stemming from the Middle East crisis, the United States will avoid a recession next year and experience even faster growth than in 1990, the International Monetary Fund said today.
The global lending agency, in its first assessment of the impact of oil price rises since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2, concluded that the United States will not exprience the growth contractions of the rest of the world, but that most other countries will also avoid an actual economic decline.
The upbeat analysis of the I.M.F. staff is in line with projections of Bush Administration economists, but counters forecasts of many private economists who, citing rising inflation, a fall-off in real estate values and weak consumption, see a decline ahead for the United States.
 
Recession Is Expected
In its Blue Chip Economic Indicators letter for September, a compilation of opinion of 50 prominent economists, the I.M.F. noted that the ''majority of the panel now expects recession to start this year or next.'' 
The I.M.F. projections appeared today in its World Economic Outlook, a publication prepared for the joint annual meeting here next week of the I.M.F. and its sister lending agency, the World Bank.
While higher oil prices will cause somewhat weaker economic growth and higher inflation than would have otherwise been the case, the impact will be ''much less'' than in the 1970's, the last time oil prices surged dramatically, said Jacob A. Frenkel, the I.M.F.'s director of research.
Oil prices have about doubled since July to around $35 a barrel. In the mid-1970's, prices quadrupled.
 
Lower Oil Prices
I.M.F. economists said they based their forecasts on the ''plausible'' scenario that oil prices will average $26 a barrel for the remainder of 1990 before dropping to $21 a barrel by the fourth quarter of 1991. The $21 figure is a reference price set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries before the Iraqi invasion.
The projections assume that most of the four million barrels a day in production missing from Iraq and Kuwait will be gradually offset by increased supplies, as currently promised, from Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.
''If you had increased production of the order of four million barrels a day by these countries,'' said Ernesto Hernandez-Cato, a senior adviser in the I.M.F.'s research department, ''the crude demand/supply situation would be restored to an approximate balance that would not be inconsistent with the price in the range of $21 to $25 a day.''
 
Sluggish Growth
The reasons cited for the improving prospects in the United States are the diminishing impact of oil price increases, lower interest rates expected to arrest the declines in housing and consumer durable purchases, and a depreciating dollar, which should help performance of American exports next year.
But American growth is likely to be sluggish, with the economy growing by only 1.7 percent next year, compared with 1.3 this year.
Although the economic growth rates of Germany and Japan are seen falling next year, their actual rates will still be substantially ahead of the United States. The I.M.F. sees growth tapering off in Germany from 3.9 percent to 3.3 percent and in Japan from 5.1 percent to 3.7 percent.
The unification of East Germany with West Germany is expected to result in a ''temporary fall in output and employment,'' the I.M.F. report said. At the same time, Germany will become an even bigger importer, especially of investment goods, to restructure the East German economy.
For the short term, the I.M.F. said, there is likely to be ''upward pressure'' on prices, interest rates and the value of the Deutsche mark. But ''over time, the short-run aggregate demand effects of unification would gradually be offset by the increase in productive capacity,'' causing interest rate and price pressures to subside, the report added.
